HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed in Hectic Day Of 'Tug of War' Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed against other major currencies in choppy, hectic trading yesterday.
Zlatko Glamuzina, chief currency dealer at the New York office of Banco di Sicilia, likened yesterday's currency trading to ''a tug of war'' between bullish and bearish investors. 
''The bulls would like to see the dollar go up and they say it has reached its bottom,'' he said. ''But the bears are trying to pull it lower and seem to be winning the battle over all.''
 
Gorbachev Rumors Unfounded
Currency traders said the dollar was bolstered by unfounded rumors that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union had resigned. The dollar was also bolstered by reports of intervention by some central banks to push down the value of the surging West Germany mark.
Putting a damper on the dollar, however, was speculation that the Federal Reserve was easing interest rates.
In New York, the dollar finished at 144.05 yen, up from 143.97 yen late Tuesday. The pound brought $1.60 in New York, down from $1.6085 late Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.7280 West German marks, down from 1.7322; 1.5645 Swiss francs, down from 1.5732; 5.9070 French francs, down from 5.9185; 1,289.00 Italian lire, up from 1,284.75, and 1.1597 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1625.

HEADLINE: Schembechler Will Retire as Michigan Coach

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 13

 BODY:
After more than two decades as one of America's most successful college football coaches, Glenn Edward (Bo) Schembechler of Michigan announced today that he would leave his job following the Jan. 1 Rose Bowl game against Southern Cal.
Schembechler will be succeeded by Gary Moeller, his top assistant for many years. Schembechler said he was also considering resigning as athletic director, a position he has had for two years.
''The toughest thing I've ever had to do is to give up my football team,'' Schem-bechler said as his voice cracked and his eyes grew misty at a news conference in Crisler Arena. ''But I'm doing it. I'm a very happy man. If I shed a tear, it's not because I'm sad.'' 
Schembechler, whose 234 victories are the most among active coaches in Division I-A and the fifth-highest total in football history, said that his health was fine but that he wanted to take things more cautiously after he had one major heart attack, one near heart attack and two bypass operations. The most recent surgery was two years ago.
 
'I'll Probably Miss It'
''I don't want to run my luck too far,'' Schembechler said. ''I don't know how I'll react next fall when football season comes along. I'll probably miss it, but that's the way it goes.''
Although the 60-year-old Schembechler has hinted frequently in recent years that he didn't want to grow old on the sidelines, his announcement jolted the fans and the sports community of the Great Lakes State, where Schembechler has been the transcendant sports personality since arriving from Miami of Ohio for the 1969 season.
''I can't imagine football Saturdays without Bo Schembechler,'' said Alissa Feldgus, a senior economics major from Philadelphia. ''Bo is Michigan football.''
Word of Schembechler's decision began to circulate around campus Monday night after Schembechler spoke to students in a sociology seminar. When a student asked Schembechler about the new coaches' offices in the new football building, Schembechler said he wouldn't be using the office.
''Bo is to Michigan what macaroni is to cheese,'' said Adam Schrager, a senior from Evanston, Ill. ''He means more to the state than any particular individual and it's obvious from walking through campus that his leaving has had a tremendous impact at a time when students should be studying for finals.''
 
Another Effect
Schembechler's announcement also created the possibility of a major side effect: that if the Wolverines beat Southern Cal in the Rose Bowl, they could be chosen as national champions for the first time in his career.
There is no tournament to determine a national champion. The two most widely acknowledged polls are conducted by the news agencies, The Associated Press poll of sportswriters and sportscasters and United Press International's poll of coaches. The outspoken and sometimes bombastic Schembechler has friends and foes in both groups but is highly regarded in his profession.
Currently, both polls show Michigan ranked third, behind No. 1 Colorado and No. 2 Miami. If Colorado loses to No. 4 Notre Dame in the Orange Bowl and if Miami loses to No. 7 Alabama in the Sugar Bowl, Michigan could move up with a Rose Bowl victory.
''I've never dwelled on records,'' Schembechler said. ''I've never worried if I've won the national championship, or if I'm the worst bowl coach in America.''
In 21 seasons at Michigan, Schembechler has a record of 194-47-5. Including his six years at Miami, his record is 234-64-8. His highest finish in the polls was in 1985, when his team was second by both A.P. and U.P.I.
 
Looking Over a Shoulder
Schembechler said he was reluctant to remain as athletic director because ''I'd want to go to practice and I shouldn't do that. I don't want to be looking over Gary Moeller's shoulder.'' Schembechler said he enjoyed the athletic-director role ''as long as I could coach football.''
''He keeps telling me, 'You don't want me around, you don't want me around, you don't want me around,' '' Moeller said.
Schembechler said he might take a larger role with the Detroit Tigers. He is currently on the board of directors. He has said, in the past, that he might want to be a football commentator.
''I love all sports,'' Schembechler said. ''I love to be around sports. A lot of people have talked to me about a lot of things. I have to work. There is a great misconception that I am so narrow, that football is everything in my life.''
Asked how he would like to be remembered, Schembechler said of himself: ''He's a decent guy. He's honest. He worked hard and he knew a little football.''

CORRECTION-DATE: December 28, 1989, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in SportsMonday this week about Bo Schembechler's final game as Michigan's football coach misstated the date of his first heart attack. It was 20 years ago this week, on Dec. 31, 1969.

HEADLINE: U.S. Plans to Ground Air Fleet That Can Direct Nuclear War

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
The Pentagon plans to halt the round-the-clock flights of an airborne command post that for three decades has been a grim symbol of America's preparation to wage nuclear war even if the President and other political leaders were killed in a surprise attack, Pentagon officials said today.
The plan, part of a Defense Department effort to adjust its forces in a changing world, reflects the improved relations between the United States and Soviet Union and the belief that the threat of a surprise nuclear attack is diminishing.
Since 1961 the Air Force has continuously kept aloft, on a rotating basis, a fleet of planes collectively referred to as ''Looking Glass.'' Instead, Pentagon documents propose that the planes be shifted ''to continuous ground alert with specified number of sorties per week.'' 
A Defense Department official said the Pentagon recommendation needs the approval of President Bush. While some recent recommendations have prompted appeals within the Pentagon, one official said the decision on ''Looking Glass'' so far has not drawn strong objections.
The plan to curtail the flights would save about $20 million in the fiscal year 1991 and is part of a broad reconsideration by Pentagon officials of military planning and spending.
 
Some Cuts Are Accepted
As part of those deliberations, Pentagon officials said the Joint Chiefs of Staff have told Defense Secretary Dick Cheney that they are willing to accept the sizable cuts that Mr. Cheney plans for military spending over the next four years. But the Chiefs say any further reductions would undermine American security.
Until recently, the Bush Administration had projected a modest increase in military spending over those years, after accounting for inflation. The difference between the budgets that the Administration had originally planned for and the budgets now under consideration in the Pentagon, from 1992 through 1994, is $180 billion.
Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, has told Mr. Cheney that such a reduction can be made over the next several years as long as the Pentagon thereafter holds the line on military spending, a Pentagon official said. The Chiefs had argued that the United States needs to plan for small increases in military spending, after accounting for inflation, in the mid-1990's to maintain weapons modernization and personnel programs.
''Our position is it will go too far if you don't turn it around,'' said Gen. Alfred M. Gray, the Marine Corps Commandant, referring to the downturn in military spending. By the mid-1990's, he said, ''we have to see it go the other way.''
The Chiefs' warning comes after recommendations from former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara and other former Pentagon officials that spending cuts be far more than those under review by Mr. Cheney. At a Congressional hearing this week, Mr. McNamara recommended reducing by half the current level of Pentagon spending, which is about $295 billion, over the next decade.
Proposals for cuts of the magnitude suggested by Mr. McNamara and the growing clamor for reductions in Pentagon spending on Capitol Hill have alarmed military officials, who say that such sweeping cuts would undermine the United States' ability to maintain new strategic nuclear forces and project conventional power around the world.
The military services, one officer said, have been told to identify $180 billion in cuts and are ''reluctantly going about doing that.''
 
'High Price' of a Superpower
''If you go beyond that, we are not going to be able to maintain the edge we need for the next 10 years,'' he said. ''There is a pretty high price tag associated with being a superpower.''
The initial suggestion to cut back the ''Looking Glass'' flights was first made by the Strategic Air Command.
Each flight is commanded by a general from the Strategic Air Command, based in Omaha, who would assume control of nuclear forces in the event the country's top leaders were killed in a nuclear war.
The decision on the airborne command planes, which was made known today, came as Pentagon officials disclosed an array of cuts made in response to the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law and President Bush's decision to trim his military spending request for the fiscal year 1991, which begins Oct. 1, 1990.
Pete Williams, a Pentagon spokesman, said Army and Air Force uniformed personnel would be cut by about 25,000 this fiscal year as a result of the budget-balancing law.
 
An Important First Step
The troop cuts will save about $900 million in spending in the fiscal year 1990. Even though the United States has about 2.1 million uniformed military personnel, the troop cuts are important because they represent the first step toward a smaller military.
In addition to troop cuts, the Pentagon is planning a broad range of reductions to trim its 1991 spending request. President Bush decided last week on a budget request for 1991 of about $295 billion in spending authority.
To stay within the bounds of the Bush request, the Pentagon is planning to cut its spending request for the anti-missile defense plan, one official said.
Instead of seeking $5.3 billion in 1991 for the anti-missile program, the Pentagon is now focusing on a spending request of about $4.4 billion. Congress approved $3.6 billion in spending on the anti-missile shield for 1990.
But Mr. Cheney remains committed to the Air Force's program to build the B-2 bomber. Air Force Secretary Donald Rice said last week that the Pentagon was considering stretching out the purchase of the costly new bombers to ease budgetary pressures. But Mr. Cheney has decided to proceed with earlier plans to purchase five additional B-2 bombers in 1991.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
East German Asks Help of U.S. In Keeping His Country Separate

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST BERLIN, Dec. 14

 BODY:
The new leader of the East German Communist Party asked for help today from the United States to keep his country from being absorbed by its powerful West German neighbor.
''I have never been in America in my life,'' the 41-year-old leader, Gregor Gysi, said, ''but I think it is a country that should not give up its responsibility for Europe.'' He spoke in an interview in German in his office at the clearly dispirited party headquarters.
''If the continued independence of the German Democratic Republic is in the interests of stability in Europe, then you should think about whether you want to leave help for the G.D.R. up to a single neighbor country, and thereby create dependency, or whether it wouldn't be better to share the responsibility, to prevent the re-emergence of Greater Germany,'' he said. Then referring to the possibility of unification, he added: ''But if so, then it should happen quickly - and simply.'' 
 
A Practicing Lawyer
Unlike his predecessors, Mr. Gysi (his last name is pronounced GEE-see, with a hard G) has not automatically become the most powerful man in his country. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d came this week but saw the Prime Minister, Hans Modrow, not Mr. Gysi, and the party chief said he did not yet have an appointment to see the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, when he comes to Dresden to see Mr. Modrow next Tuesday.
Until this week Mr. Gysi was not a politician but a practicing lawyer whose clients included members of non-Communist opposition groups here. He said that he had no inkling before a week ago that he might become leader of the party, and that he had had only four to six hours a night of sleep since then.
''I admit I am slowly becoming exhausted,'' he said in his second-floor office today, looking it, and wearing the same gray flannel suit he's been in all week. ''But I have to get this important extraordinary party congress behind me.''
 
A New Name Is Coming
The 2,750 delegates to that congress who named him as chairman last Saturday - abolishing the title of General Secretary held by his two disgraced predecessors, Egon Krenz and Erich Honecker - will meet again this weekend to pick a new name for the party, for 43 years known as the Socialist Unity Party of Germany.
Mr. Gysi was unassuming, articulate and willing to show a sense of humor about himself in the interview, just as he has been in public appearances bebe''Well, it's an awful responsibility in an awfully difficult time,'' he said smiling and sighing at the same time. ''Socially I'm worse off - I had quite definite possibilities as a lawyer that I've had to give up. But as it very quickly became evident that, really, nobody wanted the job, when they suddenly agreed to nominate me, I gave up my feeble attempts to fight it off.''
He said that he accepted the nomination by the 25-member working committee that took over after Mr. Krenz and his Central Committee resigned en masse Dec. 3, ''because I didn't want to be accused by history of not making the contribution I could have made to save this country.''
 
He Was 'Far Removed'
His biggest qualification, he admitted, was that ''I was not only not close to, I was quite far removed from the leadership.''
''I never dreamed of being party chairman before last Wednesday or Thursday - not even in nightmares,'' he laughed. A regular party congress in the spring will decide whether he stays on after that, he said.
Dream or nightmare, Mr. Gysi has his work cut out for him, to try to make a discredited party that held a monopoly on power in this country until only a month ago into one that can win a respectable share of the vote in a free election expected to be held next May 6. Asked what share of the vote he expected the party would win, Mr. Gysi said, ''Any figure I gave you would be simply plucked out of the air.'' Diplomats and rank-and-file leaders here say the 1.7-million-member party would be lucky to get 15 to 20 percent of a free vote.
Mr. Gysi could not be more different from the austere Saxon Stalinism of Walter Ulbricht or the defensive sanctimony of Erich Honecker if he tried. Mr. Honecker's grandiose offices have been sealed up, and Mr. Gysi said he drives a Lada, a compact Russian Fiat, instead of riding in a chauffeur-driven Volvo. And he may be the first Communist Party leader to admit publicly that there are things he doesn't like about Communism.
 
Dislikes and Admirations
''What I don't like about it is its tendency to be exclusionary, its tendency to pronounce eternal truths, its tendency to administration, to bureaucracy,'' he said. ''What I admire is the Communist ideal, the steadfastness of principle, the consistency in time of revolution.''
He also showed no reluctance to discuss details of his personal life like his Jewish ancestry.
But his main concern, he made clear, is to get his party to rebuild and redefine itself in time to save the country.
''There is no alternative in this country, neither structurally nor organizationally, in political effectiveness or experience or knowledge,'' he said.
He said that the newly emerging democratic parties, many of whose leaders are also lawyers whom he knows, should have the same opportunities as his own but do not have its potential. ''We extend our hand to them, we are trying to agree on compromises to insure continued democratic development in the G.D.R.,'' he said, ''and I hope we will all try to fend off the attacks of the right, especially from the radical right.''
 
Opposes Talk of Reunification
''Much will depend on whether we succeed in making a convincing case that the given situation, with two German states, is in the interests of stability in Europe,'' he said. ''I am dead set against this talk about reunification. I am for a process that will certainly lead to a unification of Europe some day, and in this framework of European unity the Germans will have their place, but I am utterly against a special German solution before such a process of European unification is completed,'' he said.
If that happened, he said, East Germany would become ''the poorhouse of the Federal Republic.'' Absorption of East Germany into what he called ''Grossdeutschland'' -Greater Germany - would create a dangerous economic imbalance in Western Europe, he maintained, and would be seen as a victory for the right wing.
''Then a nationalistic frenzy would break out here,'' he said. ''If one border falls, all the others, from Bessarabia to Tyrol, are endangered. Peace in Europe has existed since the Second World War really only because nobody really altered the borders or put them in serious question,'' he said. After premature reunification, he said, Poland's borders would be endangered by conservative demands for recovery of lost German territories to the east.
 
'A Left Alternative'
''The result would be that America, Britain, France and the Soviet Union would be forced to make a terrible choice, as at Munich, between giving in piecemeal or remaining firm,'' Mr. Gysi said. ''I feel that Germans in this century have lost the right to create the risk of instability and war, and precisely this risk would arise.'
But, he said finally, he did not want his country to fade away because ''I want there to be a left alternative to the Federal Republic of Germany.''
For though Mr. Gysi would look right at home in Wall Street or Federal court, he is a believing Communist, one who recognizes Marx and Lenin as inalienable parts of the party's heritage and grew up with them from childhood. His father, Klaus Gysi, is a 77-year-old former minister of culture and publisher who fought in the French resistance in World War II.
''My father and my mother were persecuted by the Nazi regime as antifascists, so I was raised in a very definite anti-fascist sense, with an orientation to the party, which led to my joining as a candidate member at 18 and a full member at 19, in 1967,'' Mr. Gysi said, explaining why he had become a Communist. ''And I grew up under the influence of the utopian ideal of a classless society, though I realize that it's not on the immediate agenda.''
 
Refers to Soviet Changes
Nor does Mr. Gysi need to be told that he wouldn't be where he is without a lot of help from the changes President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has brought to the Soviet Union.
''I am firmly convinced that they are the basis for the changes in other socialist countries, because without changes in the Soviet Union there wouldn't have been any in the G.D.R., and if there had been, they would not have succeeded, as the example of Czechoslovakia 1968 shows.''
''A whole dimension of people are coming to the surface whom we never heard of before,'' he observed, and it could have been a reference to himself a month ago.
The empty party headquarters has lost all its old leaders, many of whom are now in jail or under investigation for corruption, and their staffs left with them. Mr. Gysi and his colleagues carry their own briefcases and, sometimes, answer their own telephones. ''One of my conditions here is I do not want leading functionaries of the party to hold office for life,'' he said. That damaged us colossally and we shouldn't allow it again.''
 
No Wholesale Dismissals
But he said there would be no wholesale dismissals. ''I can't announce a new humanism and then treat the apparat inhumanely - that's wrong.''
Asked if he considered himself Jewish, Mr. Gysi said: ''I can't say that I am. I have a Jewish grandmother, my father's mother, and my mother had a Jewish grandfather. So figure it out, since I'm not prepared to calculate the proportions according to the Nuremberg race laws,'' the Nazi rules defining racial ''purity.''
''My mother also had a Russian grandmother,'' he went on, ''and the rest of my family were in the classic sense Germans.''
Gysi, he said, is a German-Swiss name. ''There's a lot of influences there that will work out for better or worse - time will tell, but so far I've found it's for the good, it always made me open-minded. And these ancestors also led me to take an interest in the life of the Jewish community, but I'm not a believer, I'm not a practicing Jew or a member of the community, but I have always supported it.''

LENGTH: 1812 words

HEADLINE: NORTHEAST BANKS FACE HEAVY LOSSES ON PROBLEM LOANS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Troubled real estate loans are causing heavy losses for bankers in the Northeast.
With office vacancy rates reaching 25 to 30 percent in places like central New Jersey and Stamford, Conn., and with many condominium developments only half filled after two years on the market, a growing number of developers are having difficulty paying off loans. Many bankers concede that they may never collect the full value of loans to developers.
Among the 10 states whose banks show the highest increase in bad real estate loans, all but two are in the Northeast, with New York, New Jersey and Connecticut all on the list. Banks in those 10 states had increases of at least 55 percent in their delinquent real estate loans from the end of 1988 to mid-1989, according to a report by Sheshunoff Information Services Inc. of Austin, Tex. The report was based on bank reports to the Government. 
 
No Texas-Size Crisis Seen
But despite the problems, analysts do not expect a crisis of the magnitude that led to the failure of many banks and savings and loan associations in energy-producing states. The Northeast is not as devastated as Texas was in the mid-1980's, and banks in the region have a bigger financial cushion than many of the savings and loans that collapsed in Texas.
The difficulties with real estate loans are not confined to the Northeast, where banks are the primary lenders for commercial real estate. Banks in Arizona and Florida are among others with major problems. The real estate troubles of some banks in the energy states, though, are beginning to recede.
 
'Unprecedented' Boom
''The United States enjoyed an unprecedented building boom during the 1980's, with overbuilding and an oversupply of office space, shopping centers, hotels - just about everything, all over the country,'' said David Shulman, director of real estate research at Salomon Brothers. ''Texas was not an anomaly, it was a precursor.''
Where there is trouble the cause is most often overzealous lending by institutions seeking new markets as opportunities to lend to businesses have dwindled and foreign lending has often proved to be a money loser, analysts say. The eagerness to lend has resulted in too many new buildings flooding the market in many areas.
But the problem in the Northeast has also been caused by a weakening in the regional economy, resulting in part from a slowing in growth of military spending, a shrinking of computer firms in the Boston area and cuts by Wall Street firms after the stock market crash in October 1987.
As banks in the Northeast try to stem growing losses by cutting back on new lending, the region's economic woes are increasing. Economists studying the Northeast predict modest rises in unemployment and more delinquencies on loans of all kinds. $50 Billion in Reserves Still, analysts do not think losses from the $19.7 billion in delinquent real estate loans nationally, about a third of which are held by Northeastern banks, are high enough to touch off a round of collapses comparable to what the savings and loan industry has experienced. Banks around the country have more than $200 billion of shareholder capital and about $50 billion of reserves for loan losses.
Nor do banks have the extensive ties to real estate interests that existed among savings institutions, many of which were owned and operated by developers. Because banks are not allowed to act as developers and own real estate, except to dispose of foreclosed properties, there is less room for the fraudulent lending practices that were so costly to savings and loans, analysts say.
Still, the problem has become a heavy drain for banks, particularly those in the Northeast. The Bank of New England recently said it expected a large loss in the fourth quarter because of problems in real estate lending. And the Bank of Boston said its third-quarter loss of $125 million was mostly a result of a $370 million increase in its reserve for loan losses, mostly for real estate.
 
Rising Share of Bad Loans
The Bank of Boston said its delinquent real estate loans had risen by $185 million, to $1.1 billion, or about 13 percent of all its real estate loans. Nationally, bad real estate loans amount to just under 3 percent of all real estate loans held by banks.
Both Bank of New England and Bank of Boston, the two largest banking companies in New England, were recently required by Government regulators to sign agreements to improve their procedures for limiting their risk on real estate loans.
Savings banks in the Northeast have also been hit hard by losses on real estate loans, said Don J. Fauth, an analyst at the First Albany Corporation, a securities firm. He cited the Government takeover last week of City Federal Savings Bank, the largest savings institution in New Jersey, and said several other savings banks in the region would not survive in their present form. He noted that after the savings banks raised more capital earlier in the decade by issuing stock to investors, they tried to increase profits by turning to more risky lending on construction projects rather than their traditional home mortgage lending business.
Among the nation's largest banks, Citibank has also reported a big rise in bad real estate loans in recent quarters and expects more.
Insurance companies are also big lenders on commercial real estate, but generally their loans come only after a project is completed and is at least half occupied. While their profits may be affected by increased vacancies and smaller-than-expected rental-income increases, analysts say they are not experiencing the kind of loan losses that banks are.
L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which oversees the health of the nation's banks, predicted last week that real estate losses would increase further in the current quarter. Certain Northeastern areas ''have some of the highest commercial vacancy rates in the country,'' he noted.
 
Worries About the Future
What other regions do not share with the energy-producing states, at least so far, is a drop in employment sharp enough to lead to a big rise in defaults on home mortgages. But recent declines in home prices and slower sales of homes in the Northeast and other areas are making bankers worry about bigger problems in the future. In the New York City area, for example, prices have fallen 5.1 percent in the last year, compared with a 14.4 percent gain in the two years ending in 1988.
When a period of rapid increases in home prices, like ones that occurred in the Northeast, is followed by steep drops, mortgage defaults can be devastating to bankers because the value of the abandoned home can be less than the amount due on the defaulted mortgage.
''We have not seen unusual losses on single-family mortgages so far, but if the markets continue to worsen, you have to worry,'' said Donald F. McCormick, chairman of the Howard Savings Bank in Livingston, N.J.
But for now, problems with loans for commercial property account for almost all of the banking industry's real estate problems. Loans for construction of residential and commercial properties, and other loans for commercial properties, totaled $382.3 billion at the end of September, accounting for nearly 19 percent of all loans and leases held by banks, up from about 6 percent in 1982.
Although bankers began cutting back on new lending and tightening loan standards as much as two years ago, they have been overwhelmed by the market's deterioration.
 
It Looked Good at the Time
In Garden City, L.I., for example, executives at Howard Savings thought they were being prudent and cautious when they provided half of a $100 million loan to finance a development of 300 high-priced condominiums. The bank verified that buyers had made commitments to acquire about two-thirds of the units. What the bank did not foresee was that many buyers are now threatening to walk away from their commitments and trying to recover their deposits, which averaged about $50,000.
Today, fewer than two-thirds of the units in the complex have been sold, and prospects for that project and others are so bleak that Howard Savings earlier this week increased its reserve for losses on real estate loans by $70 million, resulting in a loss for the year of about $45 million.
Indeed, banks are learning that real estate problems can develop without the kind of full-fledged recession that Texas suffered.
With about 185 million square feet of new office space due for completion within two years, Mr. Shulman of Salomon Brothers does not expect enough gains in office employment to bring down the vacancy rate from its current 19 percent. And increased weakness in the national economy would cause higher vacancy rates across the country.
In New England, bankers acknowledge that much of the problem is of their own making.
''This market suffers from an oversupply of new buildings, not a lack of demand,'' said Gary D. Smith, head of real estate lending at the Fleet/Norstar Corporation, a Providence, R.I., banking company that has fared better than many competitors in real estate lending.
The growth in real estate lending, and the special risks it poses, have prompted the F.D.I.C. to start a special study of the industry and of conditions around the country. Bankers, for their part, are adopting tougher loan standards, like requiring more lease commitments for new projects, higher cash contributions by developers and guarantees by developers that last for the life of the loan, not just to the end of construction.
In retrospect, banking data for real estate lending should have suggested that a problem was in the works, said Alex Sheshunoff, president of the consulting firm that issued the report. ''The basic fuel for speculative excess is credit,'' he said, adding that ''rapid loan growth is the best leading indicator of future bank problems.''
 
Real Estate Loans Up 75%
He said that from 1984 through 1988, real estate loans, including home mortgages, grew by 75 percent, to $636 billion, not counting $40 billion of home equity loans extended to homeowners as second mortgages. That growth rate was far greater than the 40 percent growth in loans to individuals, to $258 billion; the 17 percent rise in business loans, to $497 billion, or the 9 percent decline in agriculture loans, to $45.3 billion.
In the last year, the growth has remained rapid, despite warnings from regulators starting two years ago.
Indeed, profits from real estate lending can still be attractive, and will keep many bankers in the business. Lowell Bryan, a director at McKinsey & Company, a consulting firm, estimated that fees and interest on banks' commercial real estate lending now total $11 billion, or more than 40 percent of average annual profits of the banking industry in the last few years.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1707 words

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Kirkland Wins Acclaim for Success Abroad, but Faces Criticism at Home

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Television viewers could hardly have expected to see Lech Walesa when they tuned in the sitcom ''Roseanne'' and the Miami-Notre Dame football game Thanksgiving week. But there was Poland's Solidarity leader, an A.F.L.-C.I.O. button in the lapel of his conservative brown suit, promoting the labor federation in a 30-second spot that appeared in tens of millions of American living rooms.
The Nobel Peace Prize winner said, his Polish words translated in a subtitle: ''Please continue your support for us in Poland and support unions in the United States. Say union, yes!''
The $600,000 advertising campaign illustrates American labor's happy marriage with Poland's trade union movement and a clever attempt to use the world's most visible worker-hero to lift the flagging ratings and wounded spirit of America's unions. 
The effort is the brainchild of Lane Kirkland, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations. After a decade of quiet toiling for Solidarity, pushing early for sanctions against Poland and lobbying hard on Capitol Hill when the sanctions were eased, he is now seeing the fruits of his labor.
 
An Avowed Anti-Communist
Mr. Kirkland, a self-professed veteran of the cold war who says he has learned ''nothing new'' about foreign policy since Pearl Harbor, says the changes in Poland prove the wisdom of the federation's policy of never dealing with unions affiliated with Communist regimes.
His critics called him rigid and unrealistic. Now it is his time to crow.
''I certainly think that what's happening in Poland is a vindication of our central belief in free and democratic trade unionism and our shunning of any contacts with unions created by state power,'' said the 67-year-old labor leader, a former merchant seaman who unabashedly takes credit for helping to force concessions from the Communists. ''Solidarity was there and we kept it going.''
The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s support for Solidarity is a story of how union bureaucrats became secret agents: large sums of money smuggled in by visitors, coded messages published in the personals columns of Poland's community newspapers, printing presses and electronics equipment from Radio Shack illegally shipped by truck and minivan. The federation pumped $5 million into Solidarity in the 1980's, opened an office for the Polish union in Brussels, publicized its plight and stood fast even when pundits said the movement was dead.
 
Acclaim From Union Leaders
These deeds have won acclaim from union members, but have done little to ease organized labor's problems at home. After Mr. Kirkland, a well-connected Washington fixture, assumed the presidency of the federation in 1979, he was expected to breathe new life into the labor movement. He has solidified labor unity in the past decade and has even won a few victories in Congress.
Last month he unanimously won a sixth term as president of the federation, a post that pays $175,000 a year and makes him the preeminent spokesman for the 14.1 million union members in the United States.
But critics say Mr. Kirkland, a former speechwriter for Adlai E. Stevenson's Presidential campaigns, has failed to stir the passions of the nation's working class or to improve the image of big labor in America. And he has been unable to devise ways to compensate for the shrinkage in America's manufacturing base, the foundation of the labor movement, or to stem a 10-year slide in the percentage of the American work force that is unionized.
Union polls have shown that the majority of the nation's union members do not even know who Mr. Kirkland is, and he could easily star in popular culture's highest tribute to anonymity, the American Express commercial.
 
Labor's Unchanged Image
''He's shored up the federation but has not been as effective in reaching outside and changing the image of labor to the public,'' said Charles Heckscher, an expert in labor relations at Harvard Business School. ''Organized labor is the least-admired institution in America, and in such an environment you need someone who can break out of the boundaries of the job and the established ways of thinking.''
The contrast between the political standing of American workers and the image of their Polish brothers was illustrated at the federation's biennial convention last month, when President Bush was profuse in his praise for Solidarity's victories and insisted that he and Mr. Walesa appear on the podium together.
A few days later Mr. Bush vetoed legislation that would have created a Congressional commission to investigate and propose solutions to the eight-month-old Eastern Airlines strike. The veto was a personal defeat for Mr. Kirkland, who had taken a visible role in the strike - even appearing on a picket line at Washington's National Airport.
Mr. Kirkland, the son of a South Carolina cotton buyer and descendant of a Confederate senator, sees himself as the worker's emissary to the world. His federation's offices in important capitals function as mini-embassies. and he has served on the boards of elite foreign policy research centers. Since the mid-1970's he has fought for a greater voice for labor in the making of foreign policy, calling international issues ''far too important to be left in the hands of a tight, incestuous breed of economists and diplomats.''
 
Help From Foreign Unions
The federation is increasingly turning to foreign labor leaders to help their American counterparts. It routinely solicits foreign trade unions to put pressure on foreign-owned companies operating on American soil that curb free trade union practices, invites labor leaders from around the world to address federation meetings and recently escorted delegations of foreign workers on visits to the striking Pittston coal mine workers.
Mr. Kirkland's international activism has prompted some union officials to grumble that he prefers the brave new world of Eastern Europe's factories to the fallow fields of American unionism. But he bristles at such suggestions, pointing to the federation's long history abroad.
''We don't go out shopping for clients and customers,'' he said. ''Workers around the world - white-collar, blue-collar, artistic and otherwise - they come to us because of our history and because of the work this organization has done over the years and despite what our detractors and critics may say about us at home.''
Nevertheless, the unions' rank and file joke that should there ever be another Democrat in the White House, Mr. Kirkland would rather be Secretary of State than Secretary of Labor.
 
At Home in Capital's Salons
Indeed, Mr. Kirkland looks more like a Cabinet member or a corporate lawyer than a grass-roots organizer. He is a man who seems more comfortable in Washington's salons than on a picket line. his friends include the painter Robert Rauschenberg, former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan. Two weeks ago Mr. Kirkland made his first trip to Poland as part of the President's Cabinet-level delegation, accompanying Secretary of Labor Elizabeth Dole in visits to to a tractor plant, a housing project and a training center.
Cozying up to the powerful has exposed Mr. Kirkland to criticism that he is too close to the Establishment, but he could not run his foreign programs without Federal funds. Of the $27 million dispersed by the federation's little-known institutes abroad in more than 80 countries last year, only $600,000 comes from union dues.
Two Government sources, the Agency for International Development, which helps economies in the developing world, and the National Endowment for Democoracy, a congressionally financed foundation that seeks to sell the principles of democracy abroad, provide the rest.
The federation spends much of its foreign funds on anti-Communist causes that have tended to coincide with White House policies, and some of the its foreign policy positions have divided the union leadership.
In 1983, for example, the presidents of 22 of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. unions criticized the federation's support for what they called right-wing anti-Communist labor unions in El Salvador. Mr. Kirkland came under fire for appearing to support former President Jose Napoleon Duarte's regime and for participating in a Commission on Central America headed by Mr. Kissinger.
 
Unflinching Support for Israel
On Israel, Mr. Kirkland remains unflinching in his support, influenced in part by his wife, Irena, a Czech-born survivor of Auschwitz.
William W. Winpisinger, who recently retired as president of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, recalls an acrimonious meeting in 1982 on a resolution on Israel's invasion of Lebanon. Mr. Kirkland refused to brook any criticism of Israel. ''In exasperation I said, 'Can't we at least condemn the killing?' and Lane jumped all over me and said, 'Israel is catching enough hell around the world, and one of their best friends isn't going to turn on them now.' ''
For now, the federation is working with fledgling labor groups in Hungary, Bulgaria and Lithuania, and it recently lobbied, unsuccessfully, to send a delegation to the Soviet Union to meet with striking Siberian coal miners about establishing the first free trade union on Soviet soil since the 1917 Revolution.
But Mr. Kirkland is being pushed to move even faster in opening alliances with workers in Eastern bloc countries, even if they are members of official unions.
''Lane - and I really mean this -is an outstanding leader, extremely intelligent with a good view of the future,'' says Douglas Fraser, former president of the United Automobile Workers who argued for a more lenient policy toward the Soviet bloc. ''But oftentimes he looks at foreign policy with blinders on.''
Indeed, Mr. Kirkland seems to find it hard to abandon the beliefs of his youth or his guardedness toward glasnost. ''Changes have come and I welcome them and I'm prepared to respond and test them further,'' he said. ''But my views were colored by the experiences of my generation, and my approach toward the Soviets hasn't changed. Glasnost is just beginning to reach the workplace.''

PUB-DATE: December 15, 1989

SECTION: Section A; Page 42, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 602 words

HEADLINE: Betting on What in China?

 BODY:
Two big bets: President Bush gambles that China's embattled hard-liners will reward his sudden support with a big diplomatic payoff that will prove he's a savvy realist. Deng Xiaoping, who has his own brand of realism, bets that the visit of senior U.S. envoys to China reinforces his domestic and international position at minimal cost.
It's the Deng wager that is paying off. Nothing he can be expected to offer Mr. Bush is likely to efface the shame of America rushing to give official blessing to an oppressive regime that kills its own people in the streets. 
Mr. Bush wants Beijing to halt missile sales to the Middle East, restrain its Khmer Rouge allies in Cambodia and play a positive diplomatic role in its own region. Those are all worthy goals. Yet for their sake, the Administration has soft-pedaled America's most important objective: China's return to political and economic reform.
It would be dangerous to isolate a nation of one billion people, the President contends. Yes, and that's all the more reason not to isolate Washington from those Chinese who identify with reform.
Mr. Deng makes his goal plain. He demands the right to impose his idea of order on China without foreign criticism. He learned long ago that Washington practices a double standard, winking at abusive practices in China while fulminating against similar abuses elsewhere in the Communist world.
A few years back, Mr. Deng dismissed the arguments of Communists worried about possible negative Western reaction to a crackdown on student democracy demonstrators. ''We put Wei Jingsheng behind bars, didn't we?'' he recalled. ''Did that damage China's reputation?'' Wei Jingsheng, a leader of China's Democracy Wall movement 10 years ago, has been held under harsh conditions ever since. Mr. Deng subsequently pushed his liberals aside and promoted hard-liners. This spring he sent the army to clear student demonstrators from Tiananmen Square. Hundreds of idealistic young Chinese were mowed down by submachine guns.
By sending Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, and Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger to toast the butchers of Beijing, Mr. Bush vindicates Mr. Deng's contempt for Americans' principle and patience. The visit, and the two emissaries' failure to criticize Chinese repression, can only undermine the surviving reform forces in China, forces that a farsighted U.S. policy would try to sustain.
The point is not just of timing, or how soon is too soon to let bygones be bygones. Mr. Deng's new leadership now controls the army, the party, the Government and the security apparatus and has become steadily more repressive. Thousands of intellectuals have been arrested. Free movement of citizens has been severely restricted and Maoist ideological indoctrination reimposed. Private enterprise is now severely curbed.
Yet the Deng regime is elderly, isolated from much of the country and compelled to paper over serious policy disagreements. After 10 years of economic reform, millions of Chinese have a personal stake in renewed economic growth and ties with the outside world. Army leaders don't want to be cut off from advanced technologies.
Thus the reformers around the former party leader Zhao Ziyang have not been decisively crushed. They may yet return to power - an outcome Americans would surely welcome. Even if Beijing now rewards Mr. Bush with the concessions he seeks, the U.S. will have paid dearly. In the end, Mr. Bush failed to grasp the most hard-headed point of all: Beijing's present rulers need his approval far more than he needs their strategic help.

SECTION: Section A; Page 43, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 736 words

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
How Much Is a Baby Worth?

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
This was going to be a column devoted to criticizing the drug legalizers. Then I read a new study about crack babies.
Suddenly, the case for drug legalization seemed to be coming from a different world. It seemed to be a spiritually weary world where money counts more than the lives and brains of children, a world so weighed down by ennui that surrender to an agreed national disaster seemed far more sensible than struggling with it. 
Not many Americans live in this world. But among those who do are a number of important people - journalists, academics, some economists and now one Federal judge. They get a lot of attention because of who they are rather than the merit of their case.
They say it is a case so dazzling and new that opponents of legalization cannot open their minds to it lest they be blinded. In truth, it has been examined over and over and found to be based on wish fulfillment, callousness and fantasy.
The economic fantasy: If narcotics were legalized the profit would go out of the business. Right away it would wither and we would save all that money on police and jails.
That thought must be highly amusing to the drug kings. They will simply produce cheaper and stronger narcotics than the law would allow for a market swelled year after year by all those new customers introduced to drugs through legalization.
The social fantasy: The black and Hispanic communities, already losing one young generation after another to drugs, are so stupid and self-destructive that they would submissively accept the theory that their problem was too expensive to trouble with.
Allied to that is the root-cause fantasy: Nothing can be done until root economic and social problems are eliminated. Using that logic we would still have legalized segregation in the United States.
And now we have the brand-new Sweet Butter fantasy. Federal Judge Robert Sweet tells us that if Americans can learn not to use butter, why, they can learn to cut down on cocaine.
That's nice, Judge. You just go ahead and order your toast dry. But afterward you might want to call Senator Lloyd Bentsen for a copy of his study on crack babies, some of whom may never be coordinated enough to butter their toast at all.
The Texas Democrat wants his Finance Committee to examine the financial impact of crack babies, children of women addicted to cocaine in its crack form.
The groundwork study for the committee says about 375,000 crack babies were born in this country last year alone. Some mature normally but most others have problems like malformations and learning disabilities.
In the first five years of life, they do not speak or understand language as well as other babies.
And they die, a lot of them just die. The incidence of sudden infant death is 10 times larger for drug babies than just babies.
Speaking of money, Judge, $2.5 billion was spent last year just for intensive care for crack infants.
Happily, many of these children survive and can be prepared for school. But Florida estimates that because of continuing learning problems it costs $40,000 to get one drug baby ready for kindergarten - about what it costs to send a kid through college.
Nationally the cost will be about $15 billion a year to prepare all the drug babies for kindergarten. Then, of course, special learning programs for every grade would cost between $6 billion and $12 billion a year more.
Some crack babies may enter high school. But about 40 percent will leave, and those who do drop out will need special care forever - medical, employment help or welfare, for instance.
So, Judge, let's suppose there is legalization. Let's even grant that maybe we would save on jail costs. After all, what would be the point in jailing drug kings for long terms just because they can sell the stuff cheaper and better than the Government can?
But stretching our imaginations, Judge, what happens if all the crack addicts are simply not terribly moved by the stirring butter message? Isn't it at least possible that they might buy more crack from the nice clean Government store than they did when they were hassled by the cops and had to get it in filthy, dangerous hallways?
Never mind money. If we can afford the savings and loan bailout we can afford the drug war. The only worthwhile question is, would legalization mean fewer pregnant crack addicts, fewer babies with damaged brains?
Do you really think so?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: OP-ED

HEADLINE: In Albany and Trenton, Worries Over Economic Outlook;
Advisers to Cuomo Expected to Suggest Delay in Next Tax Cut

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Offering Gov. Mario M. Cuomo the kind of advice that he seems to be hoping for, the Governor's committee of economic advisers will recommend that the next phase of the state's income tax cut be delayed, committee members said today.
Over the last several months, the Governor has frequently suggested delaying the tax cut to help solve the state's budget problems but has never explicitly endorsed the idea.
The report by his Council on Fiscal and Economic Priorities, which has not yet been made public, makes it even more likely that the Governor will propose a delay in the tax cut when he presents his budget next month.
 
'A Rather Sober Picture'
The report, which is expected to be released Friday, indicates that the state's financial condition is far gloomier than the Cuomo administration has acknowledged. And even with a delay in the income tax cut, the report suggests that additional tax increases will be needed to close the budget gap. 
''It paints a rather sober picture,'' one committee member said. ''There's a significant deficit looming.'' All the committee members interviewed spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Mr. Cuomo has often used committees like his economic advisory council to float unpopular measures and then gauge the public reaction to them. He has also used such prominent committees to try to win over potential opponents to his cause.
Some Cuomo administration officials were involved in the discussions that resulted in the report. But there were signficant disagreements among the members of the committee - who include some of the top business leaders in the state - about what the report should recommend.
Because of those disagreements, the report's discussion of the income tax cut is couched in vague terms and not officially labeled a recommendation. But several people familiar with the report said it represented deferring the tax cut as the most reasonable response to the state's fiscal problems.
''If you read through the bureaucratese, you would come out thinking the tax cut should be deferred,'' one committee member said.
 
Potential Budget Gap
Members of the panel said the report predicts that the state is facing a potential budget gap of at least $1.5 billion for the coming fiscal year, which starts April 1.
The last official forecast that the Cuomo administration made for the next fiscal year put the budget gap at $500 million. Since that forecast was made in February, administration officials have admitted that the gap is greater, but they have refused to say by how much.
Delaying the next phase of the income tax cut, which would lower the state's top tax rate to 7 percent from 7.5 percent, would save the state roughly $400 million next year.
To supplement this, an array of possible tax increases are listed in the report. They include an increase in the gasoline tax and a broadening of the sales tax to include additional goods and services.
 
Prepared by Subcommittee
The report was drafted by a 16-member subcommittee of the Council on Fiscal and Economic Priorities. The co-chairmen of the subcommittee are Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, and James D. Robinson 3d, chairman of American Express.
The chairman of the full council is the president of New York University, John Brademas.
In the past, the Governor has relied heavily on the recommendations of his economic advisory committee, whose members include the heads of several of the state's major corporations. Just a few days after the committee recommended in 1986 that the state cut its personal income tax rates, for example, Governor Cuomo proposed a tax cut that mirrored the recommendation.
Today, the Governor's budget director, Dall W. Forsythe, who has been privy to most drafts of the report, insisted that he did not know what the committee would recommend.
''When we get them, we'll take their recommendations very seriously,'' Mr. Forsythe said. ''It's an important group.''
 
Fraught With Controversy
The disagreement among the committee members over their report indicates how fraught with controversy next year's budget negotiations are likely to be. The state's largest business lobbying group, the Business Council, has said it will oppose a deferral of the income tax cut, but many other groups, including labor unions and advocates for the poor, have come out in favor of a delay.
The report augurs more bad news for New York City, which is suffering from severe fiscal problems of its own. If the state's fiscal situation is as dire as the report suggests, the city is unlikely to receive any increased aid from the state. One of the report's strongest recommendations is that state spending be stringently curtailed next year.
''The picture is not good,'' said one official familiar with the report. ''The city is going to have to live within its own budget. And the same medicine would not be a bad thing for the state.''

HEADLINE: In Albany and Trenton, Worries Over Economic Outlook;
New Jersey Economy Grew Much Slower Than Nation's in '89

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
After six years of sustained growth, New Jersey's economy slowed so sharply this year that the state stands a greater risk than the nation of sliding into a recession next year, a panel of economic advisers to the Governor warned today.
The panel, the Economic Policy Council, predicted an economic growth rate of only about 2 percent next year and said any increase in state spending greater than that might require new taxes.
''This is one of many indications that there might be difficult times ahead,'' said Jon Shure, the spokesman for Governor- elect James J. Florio, who will be submitting his first budget to the Legislature in February at about the time the council expects the worst effects of the economic slump to become apparent.
 
'A Normal Business Cycle'
Gov. Thomas H. Kean's administration was sanguine. Calling the economic downturn ''a normal business cycle,'' Mr. Kean's press secretary, Carl R. Golden, said:
''The Governor has been saying since the summer that our tax revenues are down. However, we're weathering this better than they are in Massachusetts and New York, where they are predicting large budget deficits. We're still looking for a budget surplus.'' 
The health of the economy has become a major concern for Mr. Florio, who said during the campaign that he saw no need to raise taxes. Instead, he promised to improve state services chiefly by a reordering of priorities and more efficient management.
In recent days Mr. Florio has said he is concerned about the weakening tax collections and the effect they will have on paying for the state's current $12.1 billion budget and his first state budget.
Dr. Joseph J. Seneca, professor of economics at Rutgers University and chairman of of the Economic Policy Council, said that 1989 was a year of fundamental change in the New Jersey economy.
 
'Slower Than the Nation'
''After years of consistently outperforming the national economy, we grew much slower than the nation this year in virtually every major area,'' he said.
Manufacturing continues its long decline in the state despite some improvement nationally attributed to increased exports; unemployment rates are rising; retail sales are down, especially for durable goods like automobiles; housing starts are dropping and could hit bottom during 1990, and consumer confidence is low, the report released today by the three-member council said.
In addition employment in service industries, which Dr. Seneca described as ''the engine that has driven the New Jersey economy'' and offset manufacturing losses in the past, decreased sharply this year.
Dr. William C. Freund, chief economist emeritus of the New York Stock Exchange and a council member for 22 years, said a recession, if it appeared, should not be deep or long-lasting.
 
Early Recovery Expected
''The good news is we are not facing a collapse or a disaster,'' he said. ''We should hit bottom before the middle of next year and begin to recover after that.''
He said the New Jersey economy was ''particularly vulnerable to a decline because it has performed so well.''
''In effect, we are paying the price for the success of the past decade,'' he said.
He also said the economic slowdown in New Jersey was being reflected throughout the Northeast.
Dr. Freund said he expected the Federal Reserve Board to lower interest rates next year in response to a slowing national economy. He said this could prompt increased consumer spending and improve the housing market. There were 42,000 housing starts in New Jersey in 1988 and 36,000 this year, and about 33,000 are anticipated in 1990.
 
A Spending Correction Seen
Retail sales, which averaged an 8.7 percent increase over the last six years and grew by 10.2 percent in 1988 alone, will grow by only 2.4 percent this year, the council projected. For many years, increases in retail sales outpaced increases in personal income, and the council said consumers might at last be restoring some balance between their incomes and expenditures.
Since 1985 total manufacturing in the United States has increased by 2.1 percent, while New Jersey has seen a 6.5 percent decline.
The chemical industry, the state's largest with 120,000 workers, grew by 0.5 percent during that period ,while thatin the country as a whole grew by 5.2 percent. The council said further research was needed to explain the reasons for the state's poor performance and to devise strategies to improve the picture.
 
Personal Income Is Strong
The one still strong economic indicator in the report was the growth of personal income, which increased about 8 percent this year, compared with 9 percent last year. A tight labor market helped lift salaries, and consumer caution led to more investment and less spending. As a result, income from interest and dividends also grew.
However, as unemployment rates increase, the growth in personal income will inevitably decline, the council report said.
Dr. David F. Bradford, professor of economics and public affairs at Princeton University and the third council member, said he was concerned over evidence suggesting that the state's poorest residents did not benefit very much from the recent strong economy. He said they would probably be the first the feel the effects of the economic slowdown.

HEADLINE: Labor Leader Sets Demands For New Pact in Early Talks

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
Amid warnings of impending New York City deficits, a senior city union leader yesterday staked out an unusually early position in upcoming labor negotiations and called for moderate wage increases equal to the rate of inflation at the least.
In addition, the leader, Barry Feinstein, president of local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said his union was prepared to support random drug tests of its members if the city set up a rehabilitation program and protected workers' privacy.
The announcement appeared aimed at seizing the initiative from business leaders who have begun calling for wage deferrals, givebacks and increased workloads for city workers. By coming before Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins takes office, Mr. Feinstein also seemed to be seeking to steal a beat from other union leaders. 
''We want to stop some of the off-the-wall comments by those who are not in government, attempting to shape what unions should or shouldn't be doing in this round of bargaining,'' Mr. Feinstein said. ''If such calls were taken seriously the city work force would be bereft of wages and benefits.''
 
Seeking Annuity Fund
Even so, Mr. Feinstein, who was a principal Dinkins supporter during the campaign, presented a bargaining position that was moderate compared to positions taken at the outset of ne gotiations in previous years, and that seemed to reflect Mr. Feinstein's own bleak fiscal analysis.
He called for an across-the-board 5 percent increase over two years to keep up, he said, with projected infla tion, and additional increases for some workers - especially hospital technicians, whose salaries lagged behind those of wages won by workers in non-city hospitals - and the establishment of an annuity fund to augment pensions for members of the union.
In a statement, Mr. Dinkins, who has not yet announced the appointment of a labor negotiator, said that labor agreements must be negotiated ''with strict attention to the city's fiscal environment,'' and ''in good faith and candor at the bargaining table.''
Paul Dickstein, the city's budget director, called Mr. Feinstein's statement ''moderate'' and reflected the fact that ''Barry does understand the city's fiscal condition well.''
But Mr. Dickstein noted that the city's financial plan for next year projects a $395 million deficit, assuming labor settlements that cost an additional 1.5 percent a year. He said that the 5 percent increases sought by the union would cost $385 million more the first year, and $770 million in the second year of the contract.
 
Warning of Fiscal Limits
Negotiations of new contracts for the more than 200,000 city workers is a major challenge facing Mr. Dinkins in his first year of office. Contracts for Mr. Feinstein's 10,000 city workers, and for police officers, firefighters and sanitation workers expire next June 30. Contracts for teachers and most other city workers expire on Sept. 30.
Earlier this month, Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, warned Mr. Dinkins that he should plan a no-growth city budget. He proposed the deferral of all wage increases, or the payment of small increases, offset by reductions in the city work force.
Mr. Feinstein announced his bargaining position only days after Mr. Dinkins, in a speech to a business group, adopting the gloomy tone used by Mr. Rohatyn, warned that fiscal problems were setting limits on what government can afford to do.
Concerns over these issues, Mr. Feinstein said, led him to accelerate his schedule for beginning negotiations. He said he would be calling the new administration on Jan. 2, to set a date for the first bargaining session.
Other union leaders said this reflected Mr. Feinstein's desire to make the first settlement with the city, setting a pattern that would be followed by other unions, and enhancing his reputation as one of the city's most sophisticated and experienced labor leaders.
Leaders of major non-uniformed municipal unions worked together to elect Mr. Dinkins, but since Election Day, have been less cooperative in developing approaches to the new administration. Until the mid-80's the unions conducted joint negotiations with the city.
Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State County and Municipal Employees, which represents 140,000 workers, said he was surprised by Mr. Feinstein's announcement, especially since they were both suing the city over a new drug-testing policy.
''Barry speaks for Barry only, he does not speak for Stanley Hill or other union leaders,'' Mr. Hill said. ''For the past year and a half we were a team, working to get David elected. I am trying to figure out what is happening.''

HEADLINE: Dinkins Appointee Sees No New Tax Incentives

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, who is to be deputy mayor for finance and economic development in the administration of David N. Dinkins, said yesterday that she did not foresee New York City providing any new tax incentives to help retain businesses in the near future.
In a briefing and an interview in which she made her first comments about her new job, Ms. Hernandez-Pinero also said she did not envision the Dinkins administration offering special concessions to keep companies in Manhattan when alternative sites were available in the other four boroughs.
''It's highly unlikely that we would offer additional incentives to keep someone in Manhattan,'' said Ms. Hernandez-Pinero, who was formerly Mr. Dinkins's deputy Manhattan Borough President and has been the city's Commissioner of Financial Services for nearly two years. 
''I think we would try every effort to persuade them that there are a lot of other advantages to relocating to the other boroughs,'' she said in the interview. ''And I'm sort of buoyed by our success with Chase and a lot of development in Brooklyn and Long Island City.''
 
'We Don't Have the Money'
She was referring to the decision of the Chase Manhattan Bank last year to relocate 5,000 computer operations workers to the planned Metrotech development in downtown Brooklyn instead of New Jersey, after the Koch administration and the state offered a special $235 million package of tax incentives, energy discounts and security arrangements.
''I'm not certain that the package of incentives that we currently can offer cannot be improved in terms of how they're leveraged in specific situations,'' Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said at a briefing in the Manhattan borough president's office, one of a series that has been scheduled for reporters with the Mayor-elect's new appointees.
''But I don't see adding dollars,'' she said. ''I don't see adding new programs or new incentives. Quite frankly, we just don't have the money.''
Later, in the interview, she stressed that such matters would be handled case by case, and that there would be room for negotiation. ''David doesn't take absolutist positions,'' she said.
A spokesman for the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Richard Riley, said the business group would have ''no substantive comment'' on Ms. Hernandez-Pinero's remarks. ''But as always, we'll be happy to work with her on specific issues,'' he said.
