HEADLINE: Andrei Sakharov, 68, Nuclear Inventor and Mainspring of the Soviet Conscience

BYLINE: By RAYMOND H. ANDERSON

 BODY:
Andrei Dmitriyevich Sakharov was one of those rare figures who appear at turning points in history, a man whose courage in fighting for intellectual and political freedom impressed much of the world but put him in long and dangerous conflict with his own country.
Dr. Sakharov, a nuclear physicist who was haunted by the weapons he had helped create, left the prestige and orderly life of his top-secret research laboratory for the dangerous spotlight of a struggle against oppression, censorship, and threats to civilization from war and society's destruction of the environment.
In an earlier age, he might have been a Socrates or a Roger Bacon, challenging the established order in a search for truth or secrets of the universe.
In the Soviet age, he was to be known as a dissident.
For years after he turned his back on the Soviet establishment, Dr. Sakharov was criticized, threatened, insulted, ostracized and then, in January 1980, exiled to the remote and closed Volga city of Gorky. 
 
Call From Gorbachev
Seven years later, when he was ailing in body and seemingly broken in spirit, he received a telephone call from Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader bent on modernizing the Soviet Union. Mr. Gorbachev told the physicist he could return to Moscow and take his place in a changing society.
It was an appropriate decision, considering that Dr. Sakharov's program for social, political and economic justice had become a key part of Mr. Gorbachev's campaign of glasnost and perestroika.
While he was in nuclear weapons research, Dr. Sakharov was virtually unknown outside the small circles of scientific and political leaders. In 1968, he emerged dramatically in the human rights struggle and became the movement's inspiration and standard-bearer.
After his return from the Gorky exile, Dr. Sakharov was widely referred to as the conscience of Soviet society, a man who had held true to his dream and principles when others capitulated.
He was allowed for the first time to travel abroad. This year, he even got a seat in the new Congress of People's Deputies, a legislative body for rebuilding the nation. With usual bluntness, he gave his views from the podium and won cheers from young, liberal deputies and jeers from the older conservatives.
 
Patriotic Scientist
In earlier years, in his nuclear weapons research, Dr. Sakharov collaborated with Igor Y. Tamm in a priority project after World War II to develop a fission bomb. The weapon was detonated in 1949 to the terror of the West. Dr. Sakharov then went on to play a principal role in the breakthrough to the even more deadly hydrogen weapons.
The physicist looked upon his work then as a patriotic endeavor, necessary to help his homeland build a deterrent shield against the growing nuclear arsenal of the United States.
In recognition of his achievements, the Soviet Academy of Sciences elected him a full member in 1953, when he was only 32 years old. His status brought esteem, a fabulous income for a Soviet citizen, a car and driver always at call, a large apartment in the city and a luxurious cottage in the countryside.
Dr. Sakharov was also honored with many of the high awards that the Soviet state bestows upon its distinguished citizens, including the Stalin Prize, the Order of Lenin and the unusual distinction of being a three-time Hero of Socialist Labor.
He gave it all up and for years alienated his own children, Dmitri, Tatyana and Lyubov when he rebelled against both the nuclear peril and the Kremlin's politics.
Dr. Sakharov's first known step to dissent began in 1957 over the issue of radioactive hazards posed by nuclear test explosions in the atmosphere.
 
Treated as an Eccentric
In later years, he was to denounce social injustice, political arrests, censorship, distortions in the economy, weaknesses in science and education, alcoholism, poor health care and low salaries that kept most people on the edge of poverty.
At first, the Kremlin leaders listened to Dr. Sakharov's concerns with attention and a degree of respect. Later, they began to treat him as an eccentric but invaluable scientist whose whims had to be indulged. Even when he infuriated the leaders with stinging public criticism in 1968, they refrained from open reply for four years, hoping to persuade him to return to the nuclear laboratory.
Vexed by his sharpening defiance and criticism of Soviet policy, including the December 1979 invasion of Afghanistan, and worried by his many contacts with Westerners, the Soviet security police seized Dr. Sakharov on a Moscow street on Jan. 22, 1980, stripped him of rights, awards and privileges and flew him to Gorky.
That Volga city is a top-secret center of military industry, off limits to foreigners. There, he lived in an isolated apartment, mostly without a telephone and under constant security police surveillance, harassment and threats. He was confined to Gorky for seven years.
Support for the scientist in his lonely struggle came mainly from abroad. It took the form of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1975, high tribute from world leaders, scholars and scientists, and the emergence of a virtual Sakharov cult at Western universities.
 
No Word for Two Years
As time passed in his exile, apprehension abroad about Dr. Sakharov began to fade. But it flared again in 1984, when the physicist went on a hunger strike to support his wife's demand that she be allowed to go abroad for heart and eye treatment.
Dr. Sakharov disappeared in May that year, and no word was received from or about him for two years.
The outside world seemed bewildered about what to do on behalf of Dr. Sakharov and his wife, Yelena G. Bonner. In July 1984, for example, the European Parliament voted to send a delegation to the Soviet Union to try to visit him. But it turned down a proposal that a seat in its hall be left permanently empty in tribute to him.
As early as 1958, Dr. Sakharov attracted attention outside the Soviet Union when he and a colleague, Yakov B. Zeldovich, published an article in the Communist Party newspaper Pravda criticizing a plan by Nikita S. Khrushchev, the impulsive party chief, to compel high school graduates to work for a year in factories or elsewhere before being allowed to go on to universities or technical institutes.
The two scientists insisted that such an interruption would be particularly harmful to students gifted in the sciences. What such students needed, they insisted, was accelerated study. Many of Dr. Sakharov's proposals for emphasis on the scientific method and new mathematics were adopted by the Soviet educational system, although he got no credit.
 
Shortcut to Forefront
In 1963, he was embroiled in a controversy over the harm caused to Soviet science by Lysenkoism, the primitiveteaching of Trofim D. Lysenko, the agronomist who maintained that acquired characteristics could be transmitted to the next generation.
This doctrine was, in the party's view, a shortcut that could take the Soviet Union and its peoples into the world's forefront, producing a new Soviet man and wondrous farm crops and animals. Dr. Sakharov supported classical geneticists, irritating Mr. Khrushchev but helping to break the hold of Lysenkoism on Soviet biological science.
Perhaps the turning point for Dr. Sakharov came in 1966, when he and other intellectuals began to worry about a move to revive Stalin as an authority figure. Their apprehension was aroused by the trial and imprisonment of two writers, Andrei D. Sinyavsky and Yuli M. Daniel, on charges of slandering the Soviet Union through publication abroad of satirical and critical manuscripts under pseudonyms.
In October 1964, Mr. Khrushchev was deposed, and his successors, Leonid I. Brezhnev, Aleksei N. Kosygin and Nikolai V. Podgorny, were edging toward rehabilitation of Stalin.
 
Heeded the Warning
Dr. Sakharov and 24 other prominent figures, including Maya Plisetskaya, the ballerina, and Konstantin Paustovsky, the writer, sent a letter to Mr. Brezhnev, the party leader, warning that ''the people would never understand or accept'' restoration of Stalin to a place of honor.
The party heeded the warning, deciding on a more gradual approach to ease the stigma and shame evoked by Stalin's name.
In 1968, a wave of dissident protests, repression and trials caused severe tension in the Soviet Union. A bitter conflict with China was taking on menacing form. Czechoslovakia was stirring against remnants of Stalinism and was moving fast along the road of liberalism toward ''Socialism with a human face.''
In 1968, the Soviet nuclear-weapons program lost Dr. Sakharov.
The high point of his fight against repression came in the summer, when tensions were high in Moscow as the Soviet army and its allies prepared to invade Czechoslovakia.
 
Look at the Perils
In a 10,000-word typewritten essay circulating clandestinely hand to hand in the intellectual community, ''Progress, Coexistence and Intellectual Freedom,'' Dr. Sakharov took a long-range look at the perils confronting the world - ''war, hunger, environmental pollution, stultifying mass culture and demagogic myths.''
The only hope for the future of civilization, Dr. Sakharov wrote, was cooperation between the Soviet Union and the United States and an ultimate convergence of their opposing systems.
''Profound thoughts arise only in debate, with a possibility of counterargument, only when there is a possibility of expressing not only correct ideas but also dubious ideas,'' he wrote. ''The philosophers of ancient Greece understood this, and it is unlikely that anyone would challenge this today. But, after 50 years of full control over the minds of the entire country, our leadership seems to be afraid of even a hint at such debate.''
The essay called for a thorough investigation into the damaging effects of Stalin's decades of dictatorial rule and demanded that ''neo-Stalinists'' be ousted from positions of influence.
 
'The Only Guarantee'
''Intellectual freedom is the only guarantee of a scientific-democratic approach to politics, economic development and culture,'' he declared.
These were daring words in a Communist society under the tight control of the party and the security police.
A Moscow dissident relayed one of a handful of copies of the essay to a foreign correspondent, and The New York Times published an article about it on July 11, 1968, and printed the full translated text 11 days later, after arrangements had been made to get the manuscript to New York. The essay was broadcast back to the Soviet Union repeatedly by the Voice of America and other Western shortwave stations.
The impact was profound and long-lasting. Around the world, people expressed amazement that such honest expressions of conscience could come from a person born and reared in the totalitarian Soviet system.
Soviet officials attempted to get Dr. Sakharov to sign an article already prepared for Izvestia, saying the essay in by The New York Times was a fraud. He refused. Dr. Sakharov was stripped of his top-secret security clearance. When he left the party headquarters and drove back to his laboratory, the guards refused to open the gate for him.
Dr. Sakharov was transferred to the Lebedev Physics Institute but remained a member of the Academy of Sciences. He was penalized by a salary cut, but he still received five times the salary of an ordinary worker. He was allowed to keep his academy-assigned apartment and country cottage, and he was eligible until his exile to Gorky to summon a car and driver from the Academy of Sciences' motor pool -sometimes, he once said, to drive him to dissident gatherings.
 
Liberal Intellectuals
Andrei D. Sakharov was born on May 21, 1921, into a Moscow family of cultured and liberal intellectuals. This, he said, was a determining factor in shaping his world outlook. His father, Dmitri, was a physics professor and author of a number of well-known texts. His grandfather, repelled by a wave of hangings in the 1905 revolution, attracted attention throughout Russia by a campaign to eliminate the death penalty.
''From childhood, I lived in an atmosphere of decency, mutual help and tact, a liking for work and respect for the mastery of one's profession,'' Dr. Sakharov wrote.
He studied physics at Moscow University, where he was quickly recognized as a brilliant student. He had just completed his third year when, on June 22, 1941, the Germans invaded the Soviet Union.
In a rare exemption during wartime, he was allowed to stay in the university to complete his studies in 1942. For the remainder of the war, Dr. Sakharov worked as an engineer in a military plant and he won recognition for improvements in quality control.
 
Peaceful Use of Atom
In 1945, the war over, he began graduate studies, and in 1948 received a candidate's degree, roughly equivalent to a Western doctorate. He then vanished for a decade, going off to the top-secret nuclear-weapons project in remote Turkmenistan. While there, he also worked on peaceful uses of nuclear energy. As a scientist, Dr. Sakharov was not required to join the Communist Party.
The nuclear project was under the control of Lavrentii P. Beria, head of the security police until 1953, when he was arrested and executed. Prisoners did most of the atomic project labor.
''Every day I saw the huge material, intellectual and nervous resources of thousands of people being poured into the creation of a means of total destruction, something capable of annihilating all human civilization,'' Dr. Sakharov wrote in the introduction to ''Sakharov Speaks,'' published in New York by Alfred A. Knopf in 1974. ''I noticed that the control levers were in the hands of people who, though talented in their own way, were cynical.''
 
'Impotence and Fright'
He made a vain effort in the late 1950's to persuade Mr. Khrushchev to cancel a series of atmospheric tests and tried later to stop what he termed ''the senseless detonation of an enormous hydrogen bomb,'' whose fallout, he warned, would be certain to cause a ''colossal'' number of radiation victims. The bomb was detonated anyway.
''The feeling of impotence and fright that seized me on that day has remained in my memory ever since,'' he wrote.
In 1963, the United States and the Soviet Union signed a treaty banning nuclear explosions in space, the atmosphere and under water. Dr. Sakharov's forebodings about mankind were eased by that treaty. And he was gratified that he had played a key role in persuading Moscow to accept the curbs.
In March 1970, the nuclear physicist, by now a world-noted dissident, was joined by Valentin Turchin, a mathematican who later emigrated to the United States, and Roy Medvedev, a Marxist historian and unrelenting critic of Stalinism, in addressing a troubled letter to the Kremlin leadership, analyzing failures throughout the Soviet system, including ''economic breakdown and stagnation.''
The critique was devastating. The three pointed to crippling policy errors and red tape in the economy, technological backwardness, defects in planning and accounting, widespread alcoholism, censorship, imprisonment of writers, plundering of forests, ruin of farmland and pollution of water resources.
 
Easing of Secrecy
''The cause of all this trouble,'' the letter said, was not the Soviet Communist system as such, but rather ''cruel distortions in the system caused by the antidemocratic traditions and norms of public life'' that appeared during Stalin's dictatorship and persisted after his death.
They proposed an urgent program of democratization, a gradual easing of obsessive secrecy, amnesty for political prisoners, elimination of nationality designations in passports, reforms in industry, education and the press, and gradual introduction at all levels of multiple candidates for party and government posts.
The proposals, which focused on the worst sore points of Soviet society, met only cold silence from Soviet officialdom.
Persisting in the struggle and turning more and more to foreign public opinion for support, Dr. Sakharov and two others, Andrei Tverdokhlebov and Valery Chalidze, who later went to the United States, announced on Nov. 4, 1970, the formation of a Committee for Human Rights, seeking to implement in the Soviet Union the terms of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
After the death of his first wife, Klavdiya, in the late 1960's, Dr. Sakharov married Yelena G. Bonner in 1971. She was a physician whom he met at a dissident rally. He left his large Academy of Sciences apartment and moved into her modest two-room quarters, which they shared with her mother.
 
Nobel Prize
Over the years, Miss Bonner gave him support in his lonely battle, and she was to become the focus of wrath and charges that she had incited Dr. Sakharov to commit dissident deeds.
In 1975, at a time when he was under growing threats and pressure, the Norwegian Parliament's Nobel Committee said Dr. Sakharov ''has fought not only against the abuse of power and violations of human dignity in all its forms, but has with equal vigor fought for the ideal of a state founded on the principle of justice for all.''
Stung by the Nobel Committee's gesture, Moscow branded Dr. Sakharov ''a judas'' and ''laboratory rat of the West.'' He was denied a visa to go to Norway for the award. His wife, in Italy for eye care, went to Oslo and read his speech, in which he again stressed the urgency of intellectual freedom.
In January 1977, a day after the inauguration of President Jimmy Carter, Dr. Sakharov sent him a letter citing human-rights violations and oppression in the Soviet Union. He received a reply through the American Embassy, but there was no further correspondence between the two as human rights were overshadowed by other issues in Washington.
 
Afghanistan Invasion
In the letter, Dr. Sakharov said a bomb blast in a Moscow subway car, which killed several people, was similar in purpose to the Hitler-inspired Reichstag fire in 1933, which enabled the Nazis to consolidate their rule, and the Stalin-instigated murder of Sergei Kirov in Leningrad in 1934, which opened the door to a wave of purge trials.
In December 1979, when the Soviet leaders were trying to stifle the dissident movement as the Moscow Olympics approached, they complicated their own uneasy situation by sending troops into Afghanistan. Dr. Sakharov alarmed the Kremlin by denouncing the military intervention and urging the world to retaliate through a boycott of the Olympics.
The response was swift. Security officers of the K.G.B. stopped an Academy of Sciences car taking Dr. Sakharov to a seminar, removed him and delivered him to a deputy prosecutor, who informed him that he had been stripped of his state honors and would be sent to Gorky, 250 miles east of Moscow. His wife was given two hours to pack and accompany him to the airport.
In Gorky, Dr. Sakharov was kept isolated from the world. His mail was intercepted, and most of his visitors were turned away by secret police agents. In 1984, after he went on a hunger strike, all visitors were barred.
Dr. Sakharov's attempts to call friends and supporters from public telephones were thwarted by the security police. Yet he managed to transmit a manuscript, which he titled ''A Time of Anxiety,'' to The New York Times. In it he told of a grim life in exile and reiterated his many criticisms of the soviet system.
 
'What Kind of Country?'
Five months after being sent into exile, when he learned that a dissident friend, Viktor Nekipelov, had been sentenced to a labor camp for anti-Soviet activities, Dr. Sakharov asked, in a stinging statement passed to Westerners in Moscow by his wife, ''What kind of country is this, cruel and without a soul, that destroys its best citizens and cynically breaks its own laws and international agreements?''
After Mr. Gorbachev intervened in December 1986 to permit him return to Moscow, Dr. Sakharov became an ally of the Soviet leader, speaking out in support of the program for democratization. But he warned often against letting any Soviet leader acquire too much power.

HEADLINE: Diner's Journal

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER

 BODY:

Upscale Brasserie New York could surely use some authentic French brasseries, those bright, bustling, drop-in restaurants that serve traditional fare at economical prices. La Cite, the dazzling new rococo extravaganza on West 51st Street, is a bit highfalutin to be called a brasserie. A better term might be brassaurant, Manhattan style, where prices can escalate fast. 
The grand, multi-level setting has two main dining arenas and a more intimate grill room. Art Deco molding, wonderfully garish period chandeliers, ornate columns, mirrors and a hustling staff in snappy black jackets make for an exuberant scene. A jeroboam of Champagne is wheeled around the dining room like a float at the Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade, and a sneak preview of the choucroute garnie is displayed in a large silver voiture.
It is too bad the choucroute ($23.50) did not live up to its stellar billing. Instead of a juicy melange of juniper-laced sauerkraut, sausages, pork and potatoes, this tasted as if it had been assembled at the last minute, therefore lacking integrated flavors. Cassoulet ($21.50) was unevenly cooked, with dry pork and moist preserved duck. The best dish was grilled sirloin, well aged and tender, with an excellent bearnaise sauce and french fries that unfortunately had absorbed too much oil ($29.50). The unusual salade Nicoise - a mound of rare-grilled tuna slices bedded on green beans, red potatoes, tomatoes, mixed greens, olives and laces of fried shallots, all in a good vinaigrette ($26.50) -would make a fine light meal.
La Cite, 120 West 51st Street (956-7100), serves lunch and dinner from noon to midnight daily. The grill room serves from noon to 2 A.M. All major credit cards are accepted.
 
Late Supper at '21'
The ''21'' Club, in an attempt to bolster late-night dining, is offering a special supper menu from 10:30 P.M. to midnight in the downstairs dining room. Among dishes on the late menu, served Monday to Saturday, are Caesar salad ($11), black bean soup ($7.50), fried clams with spicy tartar sauce ($12.50), fettuccine with grilled radicchio, walnuts and Parmesan ($22), and venison chili with toasted tortillas ($25). A pre-theater menu ($37.50 prix fixe) is served from 5:30 to 6:30 P.M. Monday to Saturday. Reservations: 582-7200.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

 
 
The Economy
Troubled real estate loans are causing heavy losses for bankers in the Northeast. With office vacancy rates reaching 25 to 30 percent in places like central New Jersey and Stamford, Conn., and with many condominium developments still only half filled after two years on the market, a growing number of developers are having trouble paying off their loans. Bankers concede that they may never collect the full value of their loans to developers. Among the 10 states whose banks show the highest increase in troubled real estate loans, all but two are in the Northeast. [Page A1.] 
Business inventories climbed to their highest level in two months in October. Some analysts said that while the backlog had not reached a dangerous level, it was a growing concern. [D1.]
The Justice Department is investigating whether several airlines, including American, Delta, Pan Am and Northwest, illegally fixed prices in a round of fare increases in September. [D4.]
 
 
 
Companies
Shearson Lehman Hutton and American Express announced a plan to raise badly needed cash by issuing stock and debt and selling assets. The plan succeeded in preventing a downgrading of Shearson's debt. In late October, Moody's Investors Service said it was reviewing Shearson's debt. A lower debt rating would have increased Shearson's cost of borrowing. [D1.]
A company that advances money to retail suppliers will cut off funds to companies selling goods to Campeau. A spokeswoman for Heller Financial said the company acted because of the news that Campeau might seek bankruptcy protection for its two American department store divisions. [D1.]
Xerox sued Apple Computer, accusing it of unlawfully using Xerox copyrights in its Macintosh and Lisa computers. Xerox is seeking more than $150 million in royalties and damages. [D1.]
T. Boone Pickens will eliminate Mesa Limited Partnership's common distribution. The company has been battered by a depressed market for natural gas. [D5.]
Groups led by Robert M. Bass and Safeway Stores have raised their stakes in Vons, the California supermarket chain. [D5.]
 
 
 
Markets
The stock market closed moderately lower after recouping more than half of its deepest decline. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 7.46, at 2,753.63, after being down as much 18 points at midday. [D6.]
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher, pushed by renewed selling in the high-yield ''junk bond'' market and a larger than expected increase in weekly unemployment claims. [D13.]
Prices for near-term deliveries of hogs surged more than a penny a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as frigid weather in the Midwest reduced slaughter rates. [D14.]
The dollar finished mixed in dull trading on world currency markets. Gold prices slipped overseas but appeared to stabilize in trading in the U.S. [D14.]
 
International
The S.E.C. and its French counterpart signed a sweeping agreement, agreeing to cooperate in each other's investigations of insider trading, misrepresentation, manipulation and fraud in securities offerings and purchases. [D4.]
 
 
 
Today's Columns
Institutions with large ''junk bond'' portfolios are turning their holdings into readily marketable securities with investment-grade ratings. Market Place. [D1.]
Most economists still contend that there will be no recession in 1990. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [D2.]
McCaffrey & McCall named William J. Vieser its president. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [D9.]

HEADLINE: Inventories Up by 0.4%; Sales Off 0.7%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
Business inventories climbed to their highest level in two months in October. Some analysts said that while the backlog had not reached a dangerous level, it was a growing concern.
The Commerce Department said today that inventories climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in October, to a seasonally adjusted $793.9 billion, after remaining flat in September. The September report was revised from a two-tenths of 1 percent increase reported initially, and followed August's gain of four-tenths of 1 percent. 
 
Sales Ratio Up
Business sales in October dropped seven-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $519.2 billion, after falling a revised seven-tenths of 1 percent in September. September sales were originally reported to have fallen three-tenths of 1 percent, after rising 3 percent in August.
The October business activity produced a slight increase, to 1.53, in the ratio of sales, meaning it would take 1.53 months to exhaust inventories at the October pace. The ratio was 1.51 in September and 1.50 in August.
''We have not reached the point where we need to call out the Marines, but there are some warning signals,'' said Robert G. Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
But Michael P. Niemira, an economist at the Mitsubishi Bank in New York, said that while businesses should be cautious, their inventory control systems should be able to adjust before problems became too serious.
If inventories were to pile up excessively, it could mean cutbacks in production and a loss of jobs, perhaps leading to a recession. However, neither Mr. Dederick nor Mr. Niemira found the ratio to be at a dangerous level.
Mr. Niemira suggested that the ratio reflected the end of the slow-growth cycle and predicted that ''things will begin to look better in 1990.''
 
Auto Inventories Fall
The Commerce Department reported that retail automobile inventories fell 3.7 percent in October, but Mr. Niemira said that represented some problems with the Government's seasonal adjustment factor, because car sales have plummeted since the end of September.
Inventories at the manufacturing level, which represent about 45 percent of the total, rose three-tenths of 1 percent. Manufacturing sales, on the other hand, dropped six-tenths of 1 percent.
Inventories of wholesalers jumped 1.7 percent, while their sales were off one-tenth of 1 percent. Over all, inventories were 4.1 percent above those of a year ago, while sales increased 6.9 percent over October 1988.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Making 'Junk Bonds' Respectable

BYLINE: By ANISE C. WALLACE

 BODY:
With more potential sellers in the ''junk bond'' market than buyers, some institutions with large junk portfolios are using a version of financial magic to turn their holdings into marketable securities with investment-grade ratings.
Thomas Spiegel, who resigned as chairman of the Columbia Savings and Loan Association earlier this week, partly because of its huge exposure to junk bonds, is working with bankers at the First Boston Corporation to explore setting up a new company - owned at least in part by Columbia - to repackage the savings association's $3.8 billion of junk bonds for new investors, subject to regulatory approval.
 
Obligations Collateralized
Adapting techniques used in collateralized mortgage obligations, they are issuing collateralized bond obligations, which typically are broken into three tranches, or units, with the lowest risk in the top tranche.
These transactions, while extremely complicated, follow acceptable accounting and investment guidelines, and the diversity of the portfolios is said to more than offset the risk of default for large investors. Not surprisingly, the collateralized obligation is attracting considerable interest from a variety of issuers. Since November 1988, when the first collateralized obligation was offered, almost a dozen companies have repackaged $2 billion of their junk bonds as new high-rated bonds and sold them in private transactions to institutional investors in the United States and Europe, according to the Standard & Poor's Corporation. 
The first tranche, usually about three-quarters of the issue, is senior to the others. The so-called class A investors receive their interest payments before any other creditors, and the yield is typically about two percentage points higher than other A-rated bonds. For instance, a recent $300 million collateralized obligation offered by Duff & Phelps, an investment firm in Chicago, included a senior tranche of $240 million with a 10.05 yield, according to Timothy P. Norman, a vice president of the firm.
Investors in the second and third tranches - known as class B and C holders - receive a much higher interest rate, but their securities have a lower rating. In the Duff & Phelps issue, the $45 million class B tranche yields 13.25 percent and the class C tranche is a zero-coupon bond yielding 15.29 percent. The yield on these units is much higher than the class A tranche because of the risk that a higher-than-expected default rate will wipe out these investors' expected interest payments - but this tranche also has a greater opportunity for appreciation.
The capital structure of the collateralized obligation also includes a group of equity holders. In many cases, the issuing companies put their own capital into the equity and third tranche. In exchange, they will receive whatever interest is left over when all of the bondholders have received their principal and interest. Their goals are to realize cash flow from the sale of the top tranches and to profit from the unusually wide yield spread between the average interest rate of the underlying bonds and the interest rate on the new bonds.
Buyers of the new collateralized obligation bonds are showing faith in the rating agencies, believing that their requirements are strict enough to protect them. And despite the fact that the buyers will not buy junk bonds directly, they seem to be buying the argument that a portfolio of diversified junk bonds is worth the risk.
The suddenly popular strategy has also been used by the First Executive Corporation, another West Coast financial institution that like Columbia invested heavily in junk bonds.
In the last year First Executive, an insurer, transferred more than $700 million of its estimated $6 billion junk bond portfolio to six companies affiliated with it. In exchange, the company received newly issued high-rated bonds issued by the six affiliates. So far, First Executive has not resold the high-grade bonds to new investors. But Mark Schoder, an insurance analyst at Conning & Company in Hartford, said company officials had told him that the transaction was performed largely to make the sale of their junk bond holdings easier.
The move, which was approved by California's insurance regulatory authorities, also allowed First Executive to reduce by $10 million a year the amount it must set aside as reserves against investment losses.
To be sure, the number of savings institutions and insurance companies that have junk bond portfolios large enough to meet the requirements for a collateralized obligation is probably quite small, investment bankers say. Nevertheless, some bankers expect the number of these collateralized obligations to double next year.
An important key to the success of the collateralized obligations is the rating that the agencies like S.& P. and Moody's Investors Service assign the newly issued bonds. Junk bond holders set up an affiliated company that buys a diversified pool of low-rated junk bonds either directly from the original owner or in some cases on the open market.
If the holdings meet S.& P.'s strict requirements concerning diversification, credit ratings and default risk, the new bonds are given an investment grade rating, at least A, because the rating officers determine that the huge amount of interest generated by a diversified portfolio of junk bonds should cover the new bonds' interest payments, even if as much as 35 percent of the junk bonds in some portfolios default, said Kurt Sampson, an S.& P. rating officer.
Based on the agency's studies of previous default patterns, the interest generated from a $200 million portfolio of diversified junk bonds, for example, should provide as much as 140 percent of the collateral necessary to finance $200 million of the new debt, he added.
With an investment-grade rating, the issuers then can sell their new collateralized obligation bonds to buyers like insurance companies and foreign financial institutions. ''This can make a market for institutions with high-yield bonds who want to sell them,'' Mr. Sampson said. However, these new bonds do not have an active secondary market. As a result, the underwriters say, the valuation of the junk bonds used as collateral in the portfolio - a source of sharp controversy in this thinly traded market - is less important because it is unlikely the underlying junk bonds will have to be sold.
''As long as the bonds are performing, that's what you look to to service the debt,'' Mr. Sampson said.
For example, issuers currently are using bonds yielding on average 14 percent to finance the interest payments on securities yielding 10 percent and for a smaller group of securities yielding 13 percent. ''I'd do that all day if I could,'' Mr. Schoder of Conning said.
Obviously, the chief risk for the collateralized obligation equity holders as well as the bondholders is the potential for default by the highly leveraged companies in the junk bond portfolio used as collateral. But if the issuer is astute enough to select bonds of companies that do not default, there will be residual interest left over.
Issuers are finding that Wall Street brokers and money managers are scrambling to help them package these bonds because in an otherwise slow year they have found that collateralized obligations are extremely profitable. Typically, bankers charge an underwriting fee of about 2 percent of the issue, and the investment managers charge an annual investment management fee of about one-half of 1 percent of the portfolio.
 
A Popular Way to Repackage 'Junk'
 
Using a suddenly popular financing technique, ''junk bond'' holders are able to issue new high-grade bonds backed by their low-rated debt. The collateralized bond obligations, as they are known, are privately sold to financial institutions. Following are some of the largest, in millions of dollars.
 
Duff & Phelps C.B.O. Partners ... $300
W.S.G.P. International Diversified Funding ... 250
Chancellor Capital Holdings ... 200
Equitable Captial Diversified Holdings ... 200
Long Run Bond ... 180
Premier Financial ... 104
 
Source: Corporate Financing Week and Underwriters

CORRECTION-DATE: December 22, 1989, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
The Market Place column in Business Day on Dec. 15 about a method for turning ''junk bonds'' into investment-grade securities misstated the status of a regulatory review of the First Executive Corporation's attempt to repackage some bonds. The California Department of Insurance is conducting an examination of the transaction and has not yet reached a decision on it. A related article appears on page D6.

HEADLINE: New Toyota Target: The Midwest

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FORT SCOTT, Kan.

 BODY:
The Toyota Motor Corporation thought particularly long and hard before opening a dealership last year in this isolated and economically depressed southeastern Kansas town of 9,000 people. For one thing, communities like this and indeed the Midwest as a whole are the last bastion of the Big Three domestic auto makers, far less penetrated than other regions by Toyota and other Japanese manufacturers.
But that is beginning to change. Because of their new manufacturing plants in the United States, the Japanese companies can finally begin to produce enough cars to expand beyond their strongholds on the East and West Coasts and in the Sun Belt.
As a result, Toyota is paying more attention to the Midwest to help produce the sales growth that might help it pass the Chrysler Corporation in the 1990's as the country's third-largest automotive concern, after General Motors and Ford Motor. Chrysler has 10.4 percent of the United States car market this year. Toyota, with 7.1 percent of the market, now stands fifth in the United States, behind Honda of America, which has 7.8 percent. 
As part of its strategy, Toyota, Japan's largest auto maker, is opening dealerships in small communities like Fort Scott. The Nissan Motor Company is also focusing on the nation's midsection, although not as explicitly. And while other Japanese auto makers say they are not specifically aiming at this area, analysts agree that all will probably increase their presence.
At a time when the auto industry as a whole is reporting large sales declines in the United States, mostly because of the weakness of the Big Three, Toyota's sales have been rising and the company has been gaining market share. Far from slowing Toyota, the industry downturn is actually providing opportunities to expand in areas where its vehicles have not been as readily found.
Until recently, the availability of Japanese cars in the United States was restrained by agreements between the auto makers and the Japanese Government that limited exports. Because demand for Japanese products could not be met on the coasts and in the Sun Belt, there was no point in venturing too aggressively into the Midwest. (Japanese exports of trucks are not restrained, but most models remain subject to a 25 percent tariff, making them more costly.) Now, the Japanese car makers can expand in the Midwest because of the growing availability of vehicles produced at their United States assembly plants - in Toyota's case, at a Lexington, Ky., plant and at a Fremont, Calif., plant, where Toyota operates a joint venture with G.M.
Besides increasing availability, producing vehicles in this country also offers a way of reducing any bias against imports. ''Our salesmen tell customers who are reluctant about imports that Toyota cars are being made in the U.S.A.,'' said Joseph Bosco of Mauro Toyota in Kenosha, Wis., which opened last summer. ''We feel it's been a positive.''
 
A Different Market
Midwesterners buy a lower percentage of imported cars than people in other parts of the country. A survey by J. D. Power & Associates found that imported cars accounted for just 22.6 percent of all vehicle registrations in the Midwest in 1988, compared with 51.6 percent in the West, 36.8 percent in the Northeast and 35.3 percent in the South.
Some people attribute the weaker sales of foreign cars in the Midwest to a prejudice against imports, as well as to less availability.
But David Shepherd, whose family has been selling domestic cars and trucks in Fort Scott since 1952, noticed in recent years that ''a few people had started driving to Kansas City to buy Hondas and Toyotas.''
Fort Scott, started as an Army garrison meant to protect Indian tribes from the encroachment of settlers, was established in 1842. While Kansas City and Wichita grew, Fort Scott became increasingly removed from the beaten path. The economy of the area, which relies on tourism, farming and some light industry, has remained below the national average.
 
Sales Pass Expectations
Since Mr. Shepherd opened Shepherd Toyota - the first and only import car franchise in Fort Scott - in August 1988, sales have climbed to about 180 cars and trucks a year, well in excess of the company's initial sales projection of 75. Only about 500 new cars and trucks are registered annually in Fort Scott and surrounding Bourbon County.
Mr. Shepherd said that while resistance to import brands was waning it was still present. ''At my Rotary Club meetings I can sit across from a guy at lunch and say, 'Look, Virgil, people want a good Japanese product and Toyota is the best.' And he'll say, 'Well, I'll never drive one of those blankety-blank things.' ''
As Toyota plans over the next five years to increase its sales in the United States to 1.5 million cars and trucks annually from slightly less than a million now, new Toyota dealerships have opened or are opening in places like Bellevue, Neb.; Spirit Lake, Iowa; Dickinson, N.D.; Monroe, Mich., and Danville, Ill.
''When I was a district manager for Chrysler I used to work these areas of the Midwest,'' said Robert McCurry, now executive vice president for Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. ''It's 50 miles between towns, and most people won't drive that far to buy cars and get them serviced. That's why we've got to be in more places like Fort Scott.''
Toyota has 1,130 dealers in the nation and plans to add 200 in five years, a third in the Midwest. Nissan, which has about the same number of dealers, has a different strategy: It will not open dealerships in small towns that can sell only a couple of hundred cars a year, said Robert J. Thomas, a Nissan vice president.
''Our plan is to get more sales out of the points we have, and that we can do by adjusting advertising budgets, setting higher objectives and then helping the dealers attain them,'' Mr. Thomas said. Basically, he said, this means providing more cars and trucks to dealers who have not been able to get enough in the past, which Nissan will be able to do because of increased production capacity at its Smyrna, Tenn., plant.
All told, ''we forecast that the Japanese auto makers will add about 1,400 new dealerships in the Midwest by 1992,'' said Chris Cedergren, an automotive analyst for J. D. Power & Associates. ''About 5,000 applications have been made. The dealers are really dying to get these franchises.''
 
Dealership Long Sought
Toyota has taken care to forge a strong relationship with its dealers. Mr. Shepherd, who also sells most G.M., Ford and Chrysler lines at two large showrooms, had been writing to Toyota and other Japanese auto makers requesting a franchise, without success, since the late 1970's. ''One rainy evening in November 1986 a Toyota manager in charge of dealer placements just walked into our showroom without warning,'' he said. ''Then I didn't hear from them again for six months.''
During that period, Mr. Shepherd later learned, Toyota conducted an extensive study of the auto market in his region of southeast Kansas. Because Toyota thinks that profitable dealerships are more effective in selling vehicles, it wanted to be sure there were enough potential customers, taking into account other Toyota dealerships, like one in Joplin, Mo., an hour's drive to the southeast. The auto maker was also concerned about the relatively low average household income in the area - $12,500.
The day his Toyota dealership opened, Mr. Shepherd was surprised to receive a plant with a congratulatory note from Yukiyasu Togo, president of Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. It was the first gift he had ever received from an auto executive.
Mr. Shepherd's wife, Sharon, noted that spouses of Toyota executives were included and introduced at a dealers' meeting, something she had never seen at meetings with Big Three sales executives.
The sales staff of Shepherd Toyota discovered that the first shoppers were more sophisticated than those visiting his domestic franchises, Mr. Shepherd said, and seemed to know a great deal about Toyota products.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
No Consensus About Recession

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
IS the economy on the verge of a recession?
There are many straws in the wind, and even some flying rooftops, that suggest that a recession may have already started.
Housing starts are off, and prices of existing houses are slipping. Car and truck sales are down sharply, and the auto companies, stuck with high inventories, are scheduling layoffs and plant shutdowns well into January. Most leading indicators are declining, including the average workweek in manufacturing, unfilled orders for manufactured goods, and contracts and orders for new plants and equipment. Profits have been receding. 
But most economists still contend that there will be no recession in 1990. The Bush Administration's economists predict that the economy, after adjustment for inflation, will grow by 2.6 percent in 1990. Private business economists are more cautious, but with few exceptions also predict that the economy will avoid a real recession next year. The consensus forecast of the 50 economists surveyed by Blue Chip Economic Indicators is for real growth in 1990 of 1.7 percent. With such slow growth, the private forecasters see the unemployment rate edging up to 5.6 percent, from 5.3 percent this year.
Why, despite the many signs that the economy is weakening, do a large majority of economists foresee no recession? The main reason is that they expect the Federal Reserve to continue easing monetary policy. ''There's little doubt that interest rates will decline substantially in the first half of 1990,'' said Eric Heinemann of Heinemann Economics and Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company. ''Alan Greenspan has no wish to become the scapegoat for a severe economic contraction.''
The monetary authorities have already been supplying more reserves to the banking system, and Stephen H. Axilrod, a former economic adviser to the Fed who is now vice chairman of Nikko Securities, said he thinks the Fed will continue to ease money markets, ''but at a cautious pace.''
''Suppose the Fed were to stay tight,'' Mr. Axilrod said. ''That would almost assuredly precipitate an economic downturn.'' The sharp rise in unemployment would then worsen the electoral prospects of Republicans in midterm Congessional elections and make it virtually impossible to cut the Federal budget deficit, lest the slump and joblessness be made worse.
But if the Fed eases quickly and sharply, he said, that will almost certainly avoid a downturn in 1990, at the cost of higher inflation than the Fed, and possibly even the country, would like. The upshot is likely to be that the Fed and the nation will get both a little more inflation and a little more unemployment than anybody wants. What might brighten this outlook? One hope is that the trade deficit will improve enough to give the economy an extra lift. In the third quarter, the trade deficit shrank by $9.4 billion, to $22.69 billion. But virtually the entire improvement resulted from a weaker dollar, which raised the dollar value of American corporations' foreign earnings.
The danger of too steep a fall in the dollar is that it would prevent the Fed from feeding monetary reserves to the economy fast enough, lest the falling dollar cut off foreign investment here. As things stand, Richard B. Hooey, David W. Rolley and Helen Hotchkiss, economists at Drexel Burnham Lambert, see the fundamentals on the dollar turning negative. But they suggest that dollar rallies could emerge from capital flight to the United States ''if events in Eastern Europe are disappointing.''
Is there a chance that eased tensions in Eastern Europe and improved prospects of arms control arrangements might brighten the economic outlook? The reductions in military expenditures would reduce the United States budget deficit enough to permit a greater relaxation of monetary policy, bringing down interest rates and spurring investment, without intensifying inflationary pressures, the optimists say. The drop in the deficit would increase net national savings and trim American dependence on foreign capital inflow.
That is a hopeful long-term prospect, but it looks premature to expect such an outcome in 1990. In the context of sluggish economic growth, rising unemployment and recessionary dangers, sharp cuts in military outlays would probably be resisted by both the Administration and Congress. Neither the White House nor the Pentagon has developed long-range plans for reducing military expenditures, but improved prospects for peace and economic stability could improve the psychological climate for business and the markets in 1990.

HEADLINE: GATT Critiques U.S. Policy

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Dec. 14

 BODY:
In its first examination of overall United States trade policy, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world body that oversees trade, said today that its 96 member nations saw the United States as one of the countries most open to imports. But it added that they were troubled by persistent protection for certain parts of the American economy and a trend toward unilateral retaliation in trade disputes. 
Trade ministers agreed last December to begin detailed country-by-country examinations, to give a lift to the four-year round of negotiations to liberalize trade. The United States, the world's biggest importer, volunteered to be among the first three candidates, along with Australia and Morocco.
The report praised the United States for a ''low'' level of trade barriers ''over a broad range of products.'' But it also noted that ''certain sectors of the U.S. economy, such as sugar, dairy and other agricultural products, textiles, clothing, steel, machine tools, automobiles and semi-conductors, enjoy relatively high levels of protection'' and that the number of protected sectors has ''increased over the years.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Gain on 'Junk' Sales

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday, pushed by renewed selling in the high-yield ''junk bond'' market and a larger-than-expected increase in weekly unemployment claims.
Traders said most of the price move, which amounted to as much as three-eighths of a point for some securities, occurred very early in the session. The prices barely budged after the initial flurry.
''All of the action took place between 8 and 9 this morning,'' a government bond trader said. ''Since 9, we have traded in a one-basis-point range.'' 
Many of those early orders came from London, the traders said.
Reports of deepening problems at the Campeau Corporation led some market participants to speculate that a certain ''flight to quality'' aspect was behind the run-up in Treasury issues yesterday.
 
Worries Over 3 Companies
Kingman Penniman, a senior vice president and high-yield specialist at McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei, said concerns in London about upcoming debt payments by three troubled high-yield issuers prompted the rise in Treasury prices.
''Southland Corporation, Western Union and Interco all have interest payments that are due on Friday,'' he said. ''Concern about these companies may have prompted a flight to quality.''
Reports that the Toronto-based Campeau may seek protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code pushed prices of the bonds of Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation down by as much as 2 points each. But even before yesterday's decline, the securities were trading at prices that were normally associated with companies that have filed for bankruptcy protection.
Federated's 16 percent bonds due in 2000 were trading yesterday at 16 cents to 20 cents on the dollar, Mr. Penniman said. Allied's 11.5 percent bonds due in 1997 were offered at about 14 cents on the dollar.
 
Broader Market Stable
For the most part, concern about the troubled credits had little effect on the broader high-yield market.
''Over all, the market was rather stable, in light of the heightened concern about the interest payments,'' Mr. Penniman said. By late yesterday, the prices of most high-yield issues had dipped by a quarter to a half a point.
Aside from concerns about the high-yield issues, Treasury securities also benefited from a rise of 86,000 in initial unemployment claims for the week that ended on Dec. 2.
The claims data, coupled with weak 10-day car sales figures reported by the eight domestic manufacturers on Wednesday, as well as other recent economic reports, ''says that there is a pretty good slowdown going on, and that there is a chance that there may be negative growth for a couple of quarters,'' said Edward J. Sawitz, the president of the Discount Corporation of New York, a primary dealer in Government securities.
''The improvement in prices says to me that the market, after having a number of shifts in psychology in the last few weeks, has swung back to the view that the economy really is slowing down and that the Fed is going to ease policy.'' 2019 Bonds Rise By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds due in 2019 were offered at a price of 103 6/32, up 3/8 of a point, to yield 7.84 percent, its lowest yield level in a month.
Among note issues, the 7 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered at a price of 100 1/4, up 6/32, to yield 7.68 percent. The 7 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 2/32, up 5/ 32, to yield 7.71 percent.
Meanwhile, the rates on one-year Treasury bills sold at auction yesterday fell to their lowest levels in a year and a half.
The bills were sold at an average rate of 7.14 percent, down from 7.17 percent at the last auction on Nov. 16 and the lowest level since the auction of June 30, 1988.
Interest rates in the secondary Treasury bill market also eased.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.61 percent, down by 6 basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bill rates fell by 5 basis points, to a late-offered rate of 7.38 percent.
 
Secondary Prices Up
The traders in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and for tax-exempt municipal bonds said that prices generally moved higher yesterday.
Corporate traders said prices of most issues rose by a quarter of a point or so. Municipal issues improved by a quarter to half a point in brisk trading, the dealers said.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported that two of the three measures of the nation's money supply fell during the week that ended on Dec. 4. The third and broadest measure, M-3, rose by $4.3 billion.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed as Gold Slips Abroad but Is Stable in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed yesterday in dull trading on world currency markets.
Gold prices slipped overseas but appeared to stabilize in the United States. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $408.30 an ounce, up 20 cents from late Wednesday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $408.30 an ounce, up 30 cents.
Traders said the market was extremely quiet. ''Everybody is on the sidelines,'' said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.
Dealers and investors had been awaiting the release today of United States economic data, including merchandise trade figures for October and producer prices and industrial production data for November.
Dealers have been expecting October's trade deficit to register somewhere between $9 billion and $10 billion. But the Canadian Government's report yesterday showed the nation's first monthly trade deficit in 13 years was cause for some speculation that the American deficit may have benefited.
''A lot of people track the two against each other since Canada is our largest trading partner,'' Mr. Flanagan said.
Others suggested Canada's weak showing might reflect a slowdown in the United States economy. Mr. Chandler said that since Canada's major exports to the United States are autos and auto parts, a decline in United States auto sales might have contributed to Canada's shortfall.
In New York, the dollar finished at 144.15 yen yesterday, up from 144.05 yen late Wednesday. It cost $1.6010 to buy 1, more expensive than Wednesday's $1.6000.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday, included: 1.7344 West German marks, up from 1.7280; 1.5630 Swiss francs, down from 1.5645; 5.9285 French francs, up from 5.9070; 1.1598 Canadian dollars, unchanged, and 1,292.25 Italian lire, up from 1,289.00.

LENGTH: 1105 words

HEADLINE: President Rejects Plan to Ground Nuclear Airborne Command Post

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
President Bush today rejected a recommendation by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to halt the round-the-clock flights of an airborne command post that could be used to wage a nuclear war, Administration officials said.
Mr. Cheney had endorsed a proposal by the Air Force's Strategic Air Command that the planes be kept on the ground some of the time because of the military's belief that there is a reduced risk of a surprise Soviet nuclear attack.
The Defense Department's recommendation was to have been formally transmitted to the White House today as part of Mr. Cheney's budget request for the fiscal year 1991. But after the White House learned of it in The New York Times this morning, the President rejected it, Administration officials said. 
 
Objection to Its 'Symbolism'
Brent Scowcroft, Mr. Bush's national security adviser, called Mr. Cheney this morning to veto the proposal, objecting to its ''symbolism,'' Administration officials said.
White House officials did not explain why Mr. Bush differed with the judgment of civilian and military officials in the Pentagon that continuous flights were no longer necessary.
But the White House apparently felt that ending the round-the-clock flights might create a public perception that the United States was moving too fast to cut military capabilities.
 
An Assertion of Authority
The President's rapid move to preserve the flights, and his use of Mr. Scowcroft to deliver the message to Secretary Cheney, appeared to represent an assertion of White House authority over Pentagon planning and reinforced Mr. Scowcroft's power as a Presidential adviser.
It is not unknown for the White House to reverse planning recommendations by the Defense Department; earlier this year, for example, it rejected Mr. Cheney's recommendation to kill the Midgetman missile. But the disclosures about the airborne command post made Mr. Bush's decision something of a public rebuke for his Defense Secretary and for the Air Force.
After the telephone conversation with Mr. Scowcroft, Mr. Cheney, talking to reporters, said of the command-post plan, ''I do not propose to go forward with it.'' He made no mention of the White House objection or of his earlier decision to support the Air Force proposal.
 
Unlikeliness of Surprise Attack
Bruce G. Blair, an expert on nuclear command systems at the Brookings Institution, a Washington research center, said the Strategic Air Command ''does not consider surprise attack to be a plausible threat in peacetime, not only because of the improvement in superpower relations but also because the Soviet threat to command aircraft on ground alert has been diminishing since Moscow withdrew missile-firing submarines from our coasts a couple of years ago.''
He also said the Strategic Air Command does not like the continuous flights because they place a great demand on the command's generals, who take turns manning the flights about once a week.
The planes, a military version of the Boeing 707, have been kept aloft on a rotating basis since 1961. Each flight is commanded by a general from the Strategic Air Command, based in Omaha, who would assume control of nuclear forces if nation's top leaders were killed in a nuclear war.
The President's decision was disclosed as the Pentagon submitted its proposed budget for 1991 to the White House. That budget would provide the Defense Department with about $295 billion in spending authority, a cut of about 3 percent in purchasing power compared with the budget for the current fiscal year, after accounting for inflation.
 
Scramble to Cut Programs
Department officials have been scrambling to cut military programs to make them fit within the proposed 1991 budget.
Pentagon officials said Thursday that the department would ask for $4.4 billion in spending for the ''Star Wars'' program to develop an anti-missile shield. That is about $1 billion less than the Pentagon had initially planned to ask for the 1991 budget. But it is still $800 million more than Congress approved for the Pentagon's program in the current fiscal year.
In other proposed cuts, the Pentagon plans to end production of the M-1 tank, the Air Force's Maverick anti-tank missile and the Navy's Harpoon anti-ship missile, Defense Department officials said. In addition, the officials have been developing plans to retire two of the Navy's four battleships.
Defending his budget proposal, which has not been officially disclosed, Mr. Cheney lashed out today at Congressional critics who have complained that spending cuts are being made without a strategy.
''Hogwash - it's simply not true,'' the Defense Secretary said in a speech here to the Princeton Model Congress, a gathering of high school students.
 
Increased Warning Time Cited
Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Senate Armed Services Committee, has questioned whether the Pentagon's budget plans have adequately taken account of new intelligence estimates about the increased warning time of a Soviet attack. American intelligence experts have concluded that the United States would have one to three months before a full-scale Soviet attack on Europe, instead of the 14 days' warning time that have been assumed by Pentagon planners.
''Sam's a good friend of mine, but I was puzzled,'' Mr. Cheney said in reply to a student's question after his speech. ''He hasn't seen the plan. We are, in fact, taking into account in our long-range planning the changes that are under way in Eastern Europe. Senator Nunn is just wrong.''
Mr. Cheney also complained about members of Congress who have said military resources should be diverted to civilian needs now that Soviet military programs are being cut back. Jim Sasser, a Tennessee Democrat who heads the Senate Budget Committee, stressed the benefits of such a ''peace dividend'' in a hearing this week.
Mr. Cheney said, ''It is irresponsible, it seems to me, for members of Congress to suggest that there is some kind of peace dividend to be cashed in, to buy all the goodies everybody on Capitol Hill can think about buying.''
Military spending cannot be cut ''willy-nilly on the basis of a few members of Congress who have always had projects they wanted to fund,'' the Defense Secretary continued, adding, ''They never supported a strong national defense, and now they are prepared to find ways to cut money out of the defense budget and go spend it on domestic programs.''
Mr. Cheney also said it was ''far too soon'' to conclude that the economic and political changes brought about by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union were irreversible.

HEADLINE: Government That Exiled Him Hurries to Mourn Sakharov

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 15

 BODY:
The Soviet Government, which once exiled Andrei D. Sakharov for being a human rights champion, today embraced him in death. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev mourned the national loss of ''a man of conviction and sincerity.''
The Government moved swiftly to seek a state funeral and marshal Politburo tributes for the tart-tongued humanist who died on Thursday night, only hours after delivering another denunciation of the Communist monopoly of the nation.
But the Sakharov family was reported working on other plans for the burial of the 68-year-old Nobel laureate and deputy to the new national legislature who collapsed from a heart attack and died alone in his study.
The sudden news swept this hard-pressed nation with much of the political and emotional power that Dr. Sakharov wielded in two decades of singular criticism of the Kremlin. 
Many Soviet citizens felt that with this death, President Gorbachev had lost a badly needed, greatly respected moral goad. And Dr. Sakharov's nation had lost another embattled individualist who demonstrated the virtue of resisting the regime at personal risk in the service of others' freedom.
''As long as he was alive, we all felt safe,'' said a woman who stood mourning on the street below his apartment, her face wet with tears and snow.
''Uzhasna,'' she muttered in Russian: terrible.
No less lamentable than the death of the physically frail, spiritually relentless man were the political ironies that ensued before the eyes of Muscovites: guards of the K.G.B., who once kept Dr. Sakharov at bay in his apartment, cleared a path to his front door this afternoon so a quickly assembled Government funeral commission could express sad-faced grief to his widow, Yelena G. Bonner.
Tass, the Government press agency, which once denounced Dr. Sakharov as a traitor deserving his six years of internal exile in Gorky, issued warm posthumous descriptions of him as a civil rights battler and even offered videotapes of his final days for sale to foreign correspondents at $1,500.
Dr. Sakharov's death was the opening story on the evening television news program, ''Vremya.'' The account focused briefly on the moment of silence observed in the Congress rather than on a detailed biography of Dr. Sakharov and his long history of resisting the Kremlin. Izvestia, the Government newspaper, had no mention in its evening edition.
''Zglyad,'' the alternative Friday television program of current events, now the most popular in the nation, devoted considerable time and sympathy to Dr. Sakharov in the recollective style reminiscent of American television's treatment of the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Most poignant was a moment when Dr. Sakharov's widow paused in mid-interview as it dawned on her what she was discussing.
''My God,'' she said, her eyes welling with tears. ''My God.'''
 
'A Terrible Mistake'
''They did all they could to kill him,'' lamented Boris Fayants, one of the many ordinary Soviet citizens who seemed clearly to feel that Soviet political life, with its fresh seeds of hope born when President Gorbachev ended Dr. Sakharov's exile, had been drastically altered by the death.
''For us, it was wonderful to see him elected to the Congress, but for him it was a terrible mistake,'' Mr. Fayants, a mathematician, said, grasping at his own heart.
Mr. Gorbachev said, ''This is a big loss,'' choosing to comment not from the Congress rostrum but in a corridor outside in a brief interview with reporters. ''This was not some sort of a political intriguer, but a person who had his own ideas, his own convictions, which he expressed openly and directly.''
The death of Dr. Sakharov, a physicist who evolved from designing the Soviet hydrogen bomb to leading the nation's antiwar movement, deprives the Soviet leader of a badly needed force for credibility.
 
Gorbachev Gained Credit
Mr. Gorbachev was obviously peeved at times to see Dr. Sakharov arise regularly from his sixth-row congressional seat to deliver sharp-toned blasts at Gorbachev programs. But the President seemed far more mindful of the fact that he gained credit for having invited such political change and goading in the first place.
It was credit from the outside world more than the members of the Communist majority in Congress. After Dr. Sakharov's death, they all had to stand for a moment of silence in his memory this morning.
Sakharov associates complained that the funeral commission included prominent party officials who did nothing to help him a decade ago when the Government ostracized him for refusing to cease his criticism of the Soviet combat role in Afghanistan, and he was exiled to Gorky.
The body of the slender, stoop-shouldered physicist was discovered by his wife. He had returned to their eighth-foor apartment near the center of the city after another long day of congressional debate and caucusing with the opposition group he helped to found.
 
Green Sackcloth
Needing to work further on a congressional speech on the economic crisis, Dr. Sakharov had gone down to his study, a separate apartment on the seventh floor.
''He was in his undershirt, probably getting undressed, and he fell to the floor with a heart attack,'' said a friend, the poet Vladimir Kornilov.
Dr. Sakharov's body, wrapped in a green sackcloth and strapped to a stretcher, was carried down to a waiting ambulance at 1:30 this afternoon. Wet, thick snow fell on the city. ''There is no one in the Congress to take up his leadership,'' said Igor Belkov, a passer-by watching the scene. ''He was the real leader in the real perestroika.''
In Congress, Dr. Sakharov's admirers had the same thought. Anatoly A. Sobchak, normally a steely eyed analyst of things politic, was teary-eyed in conceding the enormous loss of Dr. Sakharov.
 
'One on One'
''This was a man whose uncompromising fight in the period of stagnation - one on one against the whole Government apparatus, beaten down, betrayed - was maintained with all his strength so that this day, today, would come,'' he said.
Funeral plans had not been announced by tonight. The Government's offer to hold a large-scale ceremony at the Academy of Sciences reportedly was rejected by the family in favor of a less officious memorial on Monday at a sport arena more accessible to the public. Miss Bonner reportedly preferred that burial be in her family plot at Vostryakovskoye Cemetery at the southwestern edge of the city. President Gorbachev gave no clear answer as to whether he will be at the funeral.
 
Opposition Loses Leader
Dr. Sakharov died in the midst of a campaign to demonstrate to the nation the value of opposition voices in the one-party legislature. The stilling of his own special voice now makes this point most dramatically, but raises questions of how the nebulous early opposition caucus he helped found, the Interregional Group, will carry on without him.
Both the opposition and Mr. Gorbachev seemed to benefit from Dr. Sakharov's treks to the rostrum. The last public exchange of the two men on Tuesday was typical. Legislators groaned as Dr. Sakharov came up to speak. Mr. Gorbachev had been busy brushing aside other speakers, but not Andrei Dmitrivich.
In one sentence, squinting and craggy-voiced, Dr. Sakharov ripped into the Government's failure to move toward its promises on land reform. In the next, he turned toward Mr. Gorbachev wielding a sheaf of telegrams like a fiery sword, speaking for citizens demanding that Congress repeal the Communist Party's power monopoly.
''That's all,'' Mr. Gorbachev snapped, growing short with the man he freed from exile. Dr. Sakharov retreated from the uncertain new legislature for the last time looking unsurprised and unsatisfied, as if he harbored every intent of complaining another day.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
Bush and Mitterrand Meet Today on Europe's Role

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Reflecting France's traditional distrust of NATO, President Francois Mitterrand is expected to emphasize the European Community's claim to a predominant role in reshaping Europe when he meets President Bush on the Caribbean island of St. Martin on Saturday.
French officials said that Mr. Mitterrand views a continued United States presence in Europe as a useful counterweight to a reunified Germany, but that he does not believe that Western Europe should speak principally through the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
NATO Foreign Ministers meeting in Brussels this week endorsed a United States proposal that the 16-nation alliance assume a more active political role in preparing for what Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has called ''the new Europe and the new Atlanticism.''
In a major policy statement in Berlin last Tuesday that served as a backdrop for debate at the NATO meeting, Mr. Baker also called on the United States and the European Community to establish new institutional and consultative links in face of turbulent change in Eastern Europe. 
 
Independent Nuclear Force
While France is a member of NATO, it does not take part in the alliance's joint military command and has traditionally insisted on the independence of its nuclear forces. It has also long viewed NATO as something of an instrument of United States policy.
Le Monde today quoted the French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, as saying it was premature to create ''a new architecture'' for Europe as suggested by Mr. Baker. He also expressed distrust of NATO's tendency ''to take care of everything in every area,'' the paper said.
''Europe within the alliance, but also Europe as an independent and responsible entity should reaffirm its political and security roles on the East-West scene,'' Mr. Dumas was quoted as remarking after the NATO session in Brussels.
Although President Mitterrand is expected to echo France's concerns when he meets Mr. Bush on Saturday, he is also well placed to speak for Western Europe as a whole since, over the six months ending Dec. 31, he has held the rotating post of President of the 12-nation European Community.
 
An Impromptu Meeting
In this capacity, he called an impromptu summit meeting of community leaders in Paris on Nov. 18 to organize a regional response to events in Eastern Europe. He also presided over a regular twice-a-year summit meeting in Strasbourg last week, where community leaders spelled out the conditions under which German reunification would be acceptable.
Further, after the Soviet-American summit meeting off Malta this month, Mr. Mitterrand traveled to Kiev for talks with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. His meeting with Mr. Bush, scheduled a month ago, also fits into his strategy of insuring that the European Community is not forgotten in the new Soviet-American dialogue.
French and American officials said Mr. Mitterrand and Mr. Bush were in broad agreement on many aspects of the Eastern European challenge, above all on the need for German reunification to take place gradually in the context of existing East-West accords and recognized borders.
''I can only observe that, regarding the issue of German reunification, Mr. Baker spoke in terms very close, if not identical, to the view expressed in Strasbourg last Saturday,'' Hubert Vedrine, Mr. Mitterrand's spokesman, said. This week, NATO also endorsed the conditions laid down by the community.
 
Strengthening Relationship
French and American officials said that, having known each other since the early 1980's, the two Presidents have a good personal relationship, and that it has been strengthened by frequent meetings and telephone conversations since Mr. Bush became President.
''It's clear that Bush and Mitterrand prize their ability to talk to each other about their views and concerns,'' an American official said, ''and this has not always been the case with French and American Presidents.''
Yet with Britain dragging its feet on European integration and West Germany increasingly distracted by events in East Germany, political experts here said Mr. Mitterrand now believes France has the primary responsibility for keeping the community on the fast track toward economic union.
The French leader has made no secret of his view that a strong European Community offers the best opportunity of insuring that West Germany - or a united Germany - remain committed to the values of an integrated Europe. France has even suggested informally that the community assume a security role.
