HEADLINE: Baker Says Gorbachev's Economic Plan Lacks Basic Changes

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d expressed some disappointment today with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's new five-year plan for the Soviet economy, saying it failed to include the kind of structural changes that would begin to re-orient the Soviet Union to a more productive free-market system.
The Secretary of State chose his words carefully when discussing Mr. Gorbachev's latest economic blueprint, outlined in Moscow on Wednesday, but he left no doubt that the Bush Administration viewed it as a somewhat shortsighted, watered-down program that would only worsen Soviet economic troubles by retaining control of production and distribution in the hands of central planners.
Mr. Baker gave his assessment at a news conference after a two-day NATO foreign ministers' meeting. In their final communique, the 16 NATO ministers gave a general endorsement to many of Mr. Baker's recent suggestions for transforming the alliance into more of a political body that could help manage change in Europe as the Soviet threat diminishes. 
The ministers also reached agreement on an approach to the ''Open Skies'' negotiations, which will begin with the Warsaw Pact in Ottawa in February. In a speech on May 12, President Bush proposed that NATO pursue an Open Skies arrangement with the Eastern bloc, which would allow reconnaissance flights over each other's military installations.
 
Doubts About Gorbachev
Mr. Gorbachev's latest economic moves were also discussed among the 16 NATO ministers. Several officials said the seeming inadequacy of Mr. Gorbachev's proposals, combined with the appearance that he has lost control over the process of change he initiated in Eastern Europe, had set off another of the periodic waves of pessimism in the West about his prospects. The mood was graphically captured on the cover of this week's British-based The Economist magazine, which showed Mr. Gorbachev standing alone atop Lenin's tomb. Beneath him was the headline, ''Yesterday's Man?''
Speaking of the discussions among the NATO ministers, a senior State Department official said: ''While everyone is very pleased and excited about the reform process in Eastern Europe, and they obviously recognize the role that Gorbachev has played in at least permitting that process to proceed, one should go into 1990 with one's eyes opened about the difficulties the Soviet Union still faces and the fact that their leadership has, in the view of many NATO members, not come to grips with some of the key economic decisions they must make.''
Just over a week after President Bush offered Mr. Gorbachev a package of economic incentives and technical advice to help Moscow establish a system of real prices, a convertible currency and access to international financial institutions, Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov presented to the Congress of Deputies in Moscow the leadership's blueprint for the next five-year plan, the standard Soviet framework for economic planning. The plan retained most of the traditional limits on privately owned businesses and property, and took virtually no steps toward phasing out subsidies, establishing market-base real prices or a convertible currency.
Ask for his reaction to the plan, Mr. Baker, reading from notes, said: ''I don't think it is particularly useful for us to be overly critical, but speaking as a former Secretary of the Treasury, I think that what has happened is that political concerns have tended to dominate economic considerations. Now, that happens from time to time, not just to closed economies but free-market economies as well, because you can only reform to the extent that you have the political support necessary to accomplish reform.
 
Emphasis on Short Term Seen
''What appears to me has happened,'' Mr. Baker added, ''is that there is going to be a short-term reliance on the planned economcy to produce goods to the possible detriment of the long-term needs to move toward an increasing free market economy.''
On his first trip to Moscow in May, Mr. Baker urged Mr. Gorbachev to make the hard choices now - both because they were economically correct and because the Soviet leader could still blame his predecessors for the inflation and unemployment that would necessarily accompany such radical steps.
In their final communique, the NATO ministers echoed Mr. Bush's four-point, step-by-step framework for German unification and endorsed, in very general terms, the ideas outlined by Mr. Baker in his Berlin speech on Tuesday calling for a ''new architecture'' for the new era in Europe. No specific measures, however, were adopted by NATO to translate that architecture into any new concrete structures.
The mood among European diplomats at the NATO conference seemed to be that it is satisfying to know that the United States plans to continue playing a role in Europe - which will both help counterbalance any unified Germany and maintain a general balance of power with the East - but that given the pace of change now taking place today on the Continent, trying to carry out any ''new architecture'' now would be like trying to build a house in the middle of an earthquake.
Nevertheless, drawing from Mr. Baker's speech, the final communique declared that NATO ''will increasingly be called upon to carry out its political function.''
 
New Ideas on 'Open Skies'
As for the NATO ministers' agreement on how to approach the ''Open Skies'' negotiations, it contained several interesting elements.
For instance, each NATO and Warsaw Pact country will be assigned a quarterly ''quota'' of overflights they will have to allow over their territory, depending on their geographical size. The country conducting an observation flight could use only ''unarmed, fixed-wing civilian or miitary aircraft'' that would also have enough room to carry an ''observer'' from the country being overflown, NATO proposed.
The aircraft making the reconnaissance flight could carry a variety of cameras and sensors, with the exception of ''devices used for the collection and recording of signals intelligence.'' That is, equipment that could intercept phone calls or radio messages.
The observer monitors from the host country who would go along on each flight ''would insure that the aircraft is operated in accordance with the flight plan and would monitor operation of the sensors,'' NATO said.

LENGTH: 1163 words

HEADLINE: Scarlett and Rhett Take Atlanta Again

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Just as it did 50 years ago, this city gave a brazen and bosomy hug this week to the 50th anniversary of the premiere of ''Gone With the Wind,'' a weeklong promotional frenzy that included a costume ball, a parade, tours of antebellum homes, star-gazing and memorabilia-hawking.
The chief sponsor was none other than Atlanta's own enfant terrible of the entertainment business, Ted Turner, whose company, Turner Entertainment Company, owns the rights to the film classic.
Wearing a cream-colored frock coat and slacks, his fingers curled around a stiletto-thin cigar, Mr. Turner addressed the more than 1,500 period-costumed guests Thursday night at a re-enactment of the 1939 ball that accompanied the premiere. He said that if he were an alien from another planet the film would be his textbook and primer in understanding human behavior. 
''Not what happened in Tiananmen Square or the dropping of the Iron Curtain, but 'Gone With the Wind,' '' Mr. Turner said.
 
The Stuff of Scholarship
If popularity is the standard, Mr. Turner's hyperbolic paean seemed justified. The movie has earned the equivalent of $800 million in inflation-adjusted dollars and Margaret Mitchell's book has sold over 25 million copies in 27 languages.
Discussion of the film's impact on the public is long past the romance and chivalry; it has entered the realm of scholarly debates on historiography and sociology.
It is perhaps the depiction of the South before and after the Civil War and its perpetuating and burnishing of the mythic genteel, aristocratic plantation South that accounts for much of the movie's endurance, said Charles Wilson, a professor of history at the University of Mississippi and co-editor of the Encyclopedia of Southern Culture.
But ''Gone With the Wind'' has proved over time to be a wonderfully adaptive film, Professor Wilson said, which not only can glorify a part of the Old South but can also symbolize the New South in the indomitability, toughness and adaptability of Scarlett O'Hara.
Amid all the discussion, he said, it is clear that the book and the 1939 film premiere here put Atlanta on the map culturally.
 
Atlanta as South's Capital
''There has long been an argument about whether there was a cultural capital of the South, and this book and, to a greater extent, the film as much as anything validated Atlanta's claim to that title nationally and more importantly, regionally,'' Mr. Wilson said. ''Virginia had been viewed as the dominant state since colonial times, but ''Gone with the Wind,' coming in the midst of a Southern literary renaissance, shifted the center of the story of the lost cause to Georgia and Atlanta.''
While the recreation of the 1939 parade today drew only a few hundred spectators, the scene at the Fabulous Fox Theater where the ''re-premiere'' was held duplicated the 1939 scene, complete with spotlights raking the sky, limousines and mock columns flanking the marquee.
Atlanta has a reputation for promoting itself at the drop of a hat, and Mr. Turner's celebration triggered a reflexive self-indulgence.
From beginning to end, everybody seemed ready to join the party, including 10 of the surviving actors in the film who returned here for a reunion.
They included Butterfly McQueen (Prissy), Ann Rutherford (Careen O'Hara), Evelyn Keyes (Suellen O'Hara), Fred Crane (Brent Tarleton) and Rand Brooks (Charles Hamilton, Scarlett's first husband). Five others played children in the film.
 
Where They Were Then
It was a time for trivia questions and trading of memorabilia for the thousands of devoted fans who came to Atlanta. ''I was born the same week the film opened,'' said Bill Quigley of New Rochelle, N.Y., as the performers reminisced on a stage at Rich's department store. ''I've seen the film 24 times and read the book five times, and I just had to be here.''
Masako Nomura recalled first reading the book and seeing the film 20 years ago while she was a university student in Tokyo. ''I was fascinated by Scarlett's personality,'' Mrs. Nomura said. ''She's a strong personality and my ideal. She's not like women were in my country.''
Fans were given rare insights into the filming to add to the trove of trivia it has already generated. Cammie King Conlon, who portrayed the doomed Bonnie Blue Butler, Scarlett and Rhett Butler's child, told listeners that a 35-year-old man had been her double in the scene in which she fell from her pony.
And Greg Geiss, as the newborn Bonnie Blue Butler, when he was barely seven months old, said he was paid $95 for the role and still has the contract.
 
'We All Had Ancestors . . .'
The antebellum ball in the Georgia International Convention and Trade Center in College Park, at $100 a ticket, was not quite the exclusive affair that the Junior League-sponsored ball here was in 1939, but it was no less a party.
For Colquitt Carter, who was president of the Junior League in 1939, the festivities brought back the excitement of 1939.
''It was so personal to everyone because we all had ancestors who had lived through that time,'' she said.
Six Southern governors attended the 1939 premiere and ball, recalled Louise Allen, the wife of former Mayor Ivan Allen of Atlanta, and ''suddenly it was the greatest thing that had happened to Atlanta up to that time.''
 
'It Is an Affront to Us'
Not everyone was happy. Atlanta's black population stayed away from the 1939 festivities, partly because of anger at the film's stereotypical depiction of blacks.
But the choir of Atlanta's Ebenezer Baptist Church, in slave garb, sang at that ball. Edgar Goff, the grandnephew of Hattie McDaniel, who won an Academy Award for best supporting actress for her role of Mammy, said his great-aunt and other black actors could not find adequate hotel accommodations in 1939 Atlanta and did not attend the premiere.
There were many blacks at this celebration, but the acceptance was not universal. The current Ebenezer choir declined Mr. Turner's invitation to recreate the 1939 performance, said Rev. Joseph Roberts Jr., pastor of the church.
''It's a great old classic,'' he said, ''but it is an affront to us, and I just felt that with what has happened in the civil rights movement and especially what has emanated from this church under Martin Luther King Jr., people have a different status now.''
 
Atlanta in the 20th Century
Perhaps as an indication of the film's adaptability to a new South, Mayor Andrew Young, who is black, made a videotaped welcome to the ball and celebration that depicted the city's progress and growth as the work of the ''spiritual heirs of Scarlett and Rhett and those of Mammy, Prissy and freedmen.''
That was fine with Mr. Goff, a retired Los Angeles architect who said the film was as much about his great-aunt -''the archmother and global mammy'' - as about Scarlett O'Hara.
''Hattie couldn't be here back then,'' he said, ''but I thought someone from the family ought to be here this time.''

HEADLINE: Books of the Times;
Slaves' Historian Changes His Mind

BYLINE: By Herbert Mitgang

 BODY:

Without Consent or Contract
The Rise and Fall of American Slavery
By Robert William Fogel
539 pages. W. W. Norton. $22.50.
It isn't often that a historian reverses himself, but that, in effect, is what Robert William Fogel has done in ''Without Consent or Contract: The Rise and Fall of American Slavery.'' His new book is a much more humane work than his cold-blooded and controversial ''Time on the Cross: The Economics of American Slavery,'' which he wrote 15 years ago with Stanley L. Engerman, a fellow cliometrician. 
Cliometricians (after Clio, the muse of history) are scientifically oriented historians who maintain that statistical analysis, based upon various records rather than human testimony, can take the guesswork out of the past. By contrast, traditional historians appreciate any kind of new evidence but consider modern techniques as merely tools; they believe that statistics alone cannot rebuild the complex house of history.
Mr. Fogel, director of the Center for Population Economics at the University of Chicago, doesn't quite give up the ideas he advanced in ''Time on the Cross'' but instead takes a moral stand against slavery for the first time. In ''Time on the Cross,'' he strongly disputed previous works in the field, like ''The Peculiar Institution: Slavery in the Antebellum South'' by Kenneth M. Stampp (Knopf, 1956). Mr. Fogel left the impression that, judged by his extrapolation from plantation and other old records, slavery wasn't all that bad.
''Time on the Cross'' maintained that the slave system in the South yielded a higher rate of economic growth; that slave plantations were more efficient than free farms; that food, clothing, shelter and health care were far better than traditional historians had imagined; that the average income of a prime field hand in the South was 15 percent greater than the income he would have earned as a free agricultural worker in the North, and even that slaves weren't really whipped too often because punishment would have cut down their productivity. This view largely overlooked the auction of men and women like chattels, the breakup of families, the fundamental human desire to be free and the cruel punishment -what Lincoln, in his Second Inaugural Address, called ''every drop of blood drawn with the lash.''
Now, in the aptly titled ''Without Consent or Contract,'' Mr. Fogel admits that he originally did not emphasize the horrors and human cost of slavery. At first, he notes: ''I had not thought very deeply about the substance of the moral issues because they seemed so obvious. The brutalities of the slave trade, slave breeding, and the extremely hard conditions of labor spoke for themselves.''
In ''Without Consent or Contract,'' Mr. Fogel says his beliefs about slavery have been continually changing for more than a quarter of a century. He constructs what he calls a modern indictment of slavery that rests on four counts, all of which seem perfectly obvious ideas that were advanced by the abolitionists a century and a half ago. Nevertheless, Mr. Fogel leaves no doubt that, personally, he is opposed to the idea of slavery.
He writes: ''The first, and overarching, count in the new indictment is that slavery permitted one group of people to exercise unrestrained personal domination over another group of people.'' His second count, which he also calls new, is that slavery meant ''denial of economic opportunity.'' The third count is ''denial of citizenship,'' and the fourth count he calls ''denial of cultural self-identification.''
Taking a larger view, Mr. Fogel concludes that the Civil War achieved more than just inflated wealth for Northern capitalists and partial freedom for blacks. Giving the war a meaning for the present time, he writes: ''It preserved and reinforced conditions favorable to a continued struggle for the democratic rights of the lower classes, black and white alike, and for the improvement of their economic condition, not only in America but everywhere else in the world.''
''Without Consent or Contract'' amounts to a partial mea culpa. For this Mr. Fogel's book deserves attention because it adds to the debate about the nature of slavery instead of fueling it anew. But he has not conceded that cliometric conclusions can be as speculative as any economic interpretation of men and events. In rather elusive language that does not help his cause, he continues to justify some of his previous notions. What the cliometricians fail to recognize is that there is no heartbeat inside a computer.

HEADLINE: Mr. Baker's First Draft for Europe

 BODY:
If the Bush Administration doesn't think hard and convincingly now about America's place in the Europe emerging from the current earthquakes, Washington will lose the constructive role it has played for two generations.
Recognizing the need, Secretary of State Baker has now taken a useful and welcome first step. In West Berlin on Tuesday he sketched out ''a new architecture'' built on the ''old foundations'' of NATO, the European Community and the European Security Conference. 
Mr. Baker correctly gave pride of place to NATO, which serves as a cornerstone of Western security and as America's main bridge to Europe. As the Soviet withdrawal from Eastern Europe continues, Washington will face growing doubts about the alliance.
Americans will wonder why a large-scale U.S. troop presence is still needed. Europeans will ask whether NATO is simply a cold war relic. As such sentiments swell, Washington will have to do much more than simply reduce its 300,000 troops. It will have to redefine NATO's role.
Mr. Baker started doing just that in Berlin. He mentioned expanding alliance capabilities to monitor arms control pacts. That's constructive, and the idea could easily be broadened to include cooperative verification arrangements with the Warsaw Pact. He spoke of enhanced consultations on regional conflicts. That suggestion never got anywhere before, but it's worth talking about again. He also spoke vaguely but suggestively about turning the alliance into more of a political organization to improve links to the East.
The secretary also addressed trans-Atlantic economic ties. Recognizing that economic frictions may abrade these connections, he called for new forms of consultation between the U.S. and the European Community. For as Western Europe moves toward economic integration, it is also creating openings to Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. Mr. Baker reminded the Community to find a place for the U.S. as well.
But the emerging Europe is more than military blocs and economic markets. It is becoming whole. Mr. Baker understands that. He joined his allies in welcoming Moscow's call for a summit meeting next year of the 35-member Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe.
This group's mandate already covers the appropriate all-European agenda. The elements include peaceful resolution of disputes, protection of human and minority rights, guarantees of existing borders and freer flows of people and goods.
Secretary Baker does not pretend that his blueprint is more than a draft. But he skillfully blends old and new. Europeans welcome the effort, and the beginning of the most important alliance conversation in 40 years. The new architecture has a new architect.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Letter: On Medicare;
Catastrophic Care Is a Community Task

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''The Limits of Medicare'' (editorial, Nov. 27) once again asserts that ''the families paying the surtax [for Medicare catastrophe insurance] rebelled . . . they resented subsidizing insurance for the poor and paying for benefits that many already received from former employers.'' Though stated as fact, that assertion is only theory. It is one of the many possible explanations for resentment. 
Some of us, not yet Medicare beneficiaries, opposed the financing mechanism, believing that while a social insurance program such as Medicare should involve transfers to assist low-income persons, these transfers or subsidies should be paid for by affluent individuals of all ages. We believe in principles of community and in acts of sharing. Our definition of ''community'' is broader than that utilized in the Medicare catastrophic legislation; we think of Americans regardless of age as members of the American community; the law defined community in terms of age (only the old would be subject to the surtax). The unwillingness of the general population to share in the costs of the catastrophic program represented an implicit redefinition of the term ''community'' that many Americans of all ages found a troubling development.
The young charge the elderly, who presumably were unwilling to pay for the poor, with being selfish. It could as easily be asserted that it is the young who are selfish: Have they supported legislation requiring that they help pay for the costs of catastrophic care of the less affluent (including young disabled)?
Congress has not seen fit to enact a tax that would ask all of us, of all ages, to finance universal health care. Surely the prospects for legislation that addresses financing issues in more comprehensive fashion are not enhanced by ascribing base motives to those who advocated restructuring catastrophic insurance because they believe its flawed financing provisions set an undesirable and dangerous precedent.
 
RASHI FEIN
 Boston, Nov. 27, 1989
 
The writer is professor of medical economics, Harvard Medical School.

HEADLINE: Administration Supports Family Planning

 BODY:
To the Editor:
To paraphrase my fellow Missourian Mark Twain, assertions of the demise of United States support for family planning in developing countries are highly exaggerated and without foundation. Many opinion leaders, including you, have concluded that because the Bush Administration opposes abortion and coercive sterilization, it opposes family planning (''Abortion and the Real George Bush,'' editorial, Oct. 23; ''How to Embarrass Americans,'' A. M. Rosenthal column, Oct. 24). The Bush Administration is strongly committed to family planning assistance to developing countries. The United States is the world's leading source of such aid, providing more than 40 percent of donor funds for international population programs. 
Since 1981, the United States has obligated $2.3 billion for population activities through the Agency for International Development. In 1989 alone, A.I.D. allocated $250 million for voluntary family planning in 95 developing countries, including 45 in sub-Saharan Africa.
Nor does the bulk of this go to natural methods. Consider the following:
* A.I.D. is the source of 75 percent of donor-provided contraceptives for the developing world. Since 1968 this has included 4.5 billion condoms, 630 million cycles of oral contraceptives and 37.5 million intrauterine devices. Two-thirds of the condoms, three-fourths of the IUD's and nearly half the oral contraceptives have been provided since 1981.
* A.I.D. has trained some 150,000 family planning service providers in 120 countries - two-thirds of them since 1981.
* A.I.D.'s research program has revolutionized our understanding of population dynamics, with 139 demographic surveys in 65 countries. We are the world's largest supporter of such research in the developing world.
* In 1988 alone, more than 30 million couples received family planning services through programs supported by A.I.D.
The 28 countries with the largest A.I.D. population programs have seen a 26 percent decline in the average number of children per woman, from 6.1 in the 1960's to 4.5 today.
When Indonesia expanded family planning in 1974, women were averaging more than 5 children each; by 1987 the rate had plunged to 3.3.
In Mexico, fertility dropped from 6.3 children per woman in 1973 to 3.8 in 1986. The drop reflects changes in Mexico's population policy and a national family planning program begun in the early 1970's.
This Administration opposes abortion and coercion as methods of family planning. But to leap from that to a conclusion that we no longer support family planning is a canard, pure and simple.
 
MARK L. EDELMAN
Acting Administrator, Agency for International Development
 Washington, Nov. 27, 1989

HEADLINE: School Districts' Battle On Tuition Goes to Court

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIDGEFIELD PARK, N.J., Dec. 15

 BODY:
A neighboring borough that sends its students to this Bergen County community's high school has refused to pay its tuition bill since the beginning of the school year. As a result, the Ridgefield Park Board of Education contends it may have to borrow money to meet its payroll next week.
School officials in the borough, Little Ferry, which sends 202 students to the 546-student high school, say a partial audit several years ago raised suspicions that Ridgefield Park has overcharged them by hundreds of thousands of dollars in recent years.
But the Ridgefield Park Board of Education, which says tuition has not been inflated, sued this week in Superior Court in Hackensack to collect the $558,943 in monthly tuition charges it says Little Ferry owes, $186,314 in tuition charges that come due this month and $130,000 in underpayments for two previous school years. 
Ridgefield Park has also taken the unusual step of asking the court to freeze Little Ferry school board assets unless the total amount, $875,258, is paid within 24 hours of a court order. A hearing is scheduled for Monday before Judge Arthur J. Lesemann of Superior Court.
 
Case Said to Be 'Rare'
The situation is highly unusual, said Dr. Seymour Weiss, director of the State Department of Education's Bureau of Controversies and Disputes.
''I'm not familiar with any other circumstance where a district in New Jersey has refused to pay tuition because officials believed the tuition calculations were improper,'' Dr. Weiss said.
And while it is not unusual for school districts to sue each other or municipalities, he said, suing for delinquent tuition payments with the threat of seizing another district's assets is ''rare.''
The suit contends that Ridgefield Park has been put into ''an extremely precarious financial situation.''
''If this court does not order Little Ferry to immediately make back tuition payments, the Ridgefield Park Board of Education will not be able to meet its employee payroll on Dec. 22,'' the brief said.
But the Ridgefield Park School Superintendent, Charles Juris, said the district would take out a loan if necessary. ''We're not going to allow that to happen,'' he said.
 
Up to $8,244 for a Student
Among the 591 school districts in New Jersey, 151 send students to other towns, said a spokesman for the Department of Education, Ron Shapella.
Little Ferry, a borough of 1.5 square miles and 9,900 people, has sent its high school students to this neighboring 1.92-square mile village of 12,000 people, since 1953. In the mid-1960's the towns agreed that a new high school was needed, Mr. Juris said. Opened in 1968, the two-story brown-brick structure sprawls next to the New Jersey Turnpike down a steep hill from modest two-story houses.
This school year, tuition for Little Ferry students will amount to an estimated $1.6 million, up to $8,244 a student from $6,000 last year, said the Little Ferry School Superintendent, Stacy Holmes.
Underpayments or overpayments occur because of the difference between anticipated costs per pupil made at the beginning of the school year and the actual cost at the end. The actual costs are verified by the State Department of Education.
In court papers, Little Ferry contended it was overcharged $203,000 in 1985 and $285,000 in 1986 and said Ridgefield Park ''improperly and illegally included teachers' salaries which exceeded those actually expended.''
Ridgefield Park says it is owed $130,000 for that period.
 
Awaiting Results
In November 1987 Little Ferry filed the first of two petitions to the Education Commissioner, Dr. Saul Cooperman, requesting it be allowed to audit Ridgefield Park's records dating to 1974. The first was rejected on technical grounds. The second drew a response from Dr. Weiss of the Department of Education that the law does not allow one district to audit another. A district could, however, ask for an audit by the department's Division of Compliance and then appeal that audit to the Commissioner, he said.
Mr. Juris of Ridgefield Park said an audit by the division ''corroborated our figures,'' but Mr. Holmes said the Department of Education had refused to share it with Little Ferry.
On Nov. 1 Ridgefield Park filed a petition with the Commissioner, and on Nov. 16 an administrative law judge, Ward Young, ordered Little Ferry to make its fall tuition payments and some past underpayments. Dr. Cooperman must now decide whether to adopt the decision.
Mr. Holmes said any move to end the relationship with Ridgefield Park must be approved by the Commissioner and would involve a costly legal process. Mr. Juris said the loss of 40 percent of the student body would have an adverse economic impact on the quality of education.

HEADLINE: SoHo Gift to Wall St.: A 3 1/2-Ton Bronze Bull

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Wall Street awoke to a gigantic bull on its doorstep yesterday - a 3 1/2-ton 16-foot-long bronze sculpture by an artist from SoHo who deposited it outside the New York Stock Exchange and declared it a Yuletide symbol of the ''strength and power of the American people.''
Hundreds of people walked around, gawked at, admired and stroked the long-horned whip-tailed bull, the image of a surging market in the lore of high finance.
But the symbolism was apparently lost on the Police Department, which said the work had no permit and was obstructing traffic at the busy intersection of Wall and Broad Streets, and even on the stock exchange, which hired a trucking company and had the humongous thing carted away. 
By day's end, the Dow Jones industrial average was down 14.08 points. And while analysts spoke of obscure economic forces, the clerks and sidewalk cognoscenti on the nation's street of dreams were bemoaning the unceremonious removal of Arturo Di Modica's ''Charging Bull.''
 
Inspired by Crash
''We're very disappointed,'' said John Levinson, an analyst with Goldman Sachs, who arrived with a colleague, Judy Comeau, too late to see the sculpture. ''It's a tragedy that artists aren't allowed to express themselves in the spirit of Christmas and friendship.''
Mr. Di Modica, who was born in Sicily, created the black-patina bull of bronze and stainless steel in his studio at 54 Crosby Street over the last two years in response to the market crash in 1987. ''He wanted to encourage everybody to realize America's power,'' said Kim Stippa, his assistant.
The Library of Congress said the earliest known reference to bulls and bears as market symbols was in a 1714 book, ''Country Lasses'' by C. Johnson. ''You deal in bears and bulls,'' the author wrote.
On Thursday night, Mr. Di Modica and some friends loaded the bull on a flatbed truck, drove to the deserted financial district and set down the work on the yellow center line of Broad Street, outside the exchange, facing Wall Street.
Daylight brought crowds, and hundreds stopped to admire and analyze the bull, which was charging under the branches of a 60-foot Christmas tree, also set in the middle of Broad Street. Mr. Di Modica handed out copies of ''The Bull,'' a paean-in-a-flier to his work.
 
The Law Steps In
But even as the bulls and bears went to work, security officials at the exchange were calling the police. ''In effect, they told us there was a very large statue of a bull there, and it wasn't there yesterday, and to the best of their knowledge shouldn't be there,'' said Officer Joseph Gallagher, a police spokesman.
The police said that it was a traffic obstruction and that Mr. Di Modica had no permit. ''He had a negative reaction in the past and decided not to apply for a permit,'' Ms. Stippa said.
As the police were considering how to remove the bull, the exchange hired a company from Queens to truck away what a spokeswoman for the exchange, Sharon Gamsin, called ''The Beastie.''
''We were concerned about safety, security, public access,'' she said. ''That's a very busy thoroughfare.'' As for the bull's effect on prices, she added, ''I'd be delighted to give you the names of several market analysts who make their living doing such things.''

HEADLINE: Frederick Nolting Jr., U.S. Envoy To Saigon in 60's, Is Dead at 78

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Frederick E. Nolting Jr., who was United States Ambassador to South Vietnam from 1961 to 1963, died on Thursday at the University of Virginia Medical Center in Charlottesville, Va., a spokesman for the center said.
Mr. Nolting was 78 years old and lived on an estate near Charlottesville in Albemarle County, Virginia.
The spokesman, Jeffrey N. Ware, said he was admitted to the hospital Nov. 13 suffering from heart problems and died of cardio-pulmonary arrest as a result of an aneurism, or swelling, of his aortic artery. 
President Kennedy named Mr. Nolting, a veteran diplomat, as Ambassador to Saigon during the administration of Ngo Dinh Diem.
After taking up his duties, Mr. Nolting voiced the view that military efforts against the Vietnamese Communist forces were more important than political reforms. #1962 Speech Criticized In a 1962 speech in Saigon, he said, ''What a marvelous transformation would take place in this country if all those who criticize their government would decide to work with it and for it.''
The Asia expert Stanley Karnow, in his 1983 book ''Vietnam: A History,'' contended that the statement was ''an astonishing display of naivete'' and that Mr. Nolting had carried out a policy of appeasing Mr. Diem.
Mr. Nolting's tour as Ambassador ended in August 1963. In a statement when he left Saigon he praised what he called the progress made in South Vietnam in agriculture, education, health and commerce and ''in the inculcation of democratic principles.''
But critics have contended that Mr. Diem's authoritarianism undercut support for his Government and therefore hampered efforts against the Communist forces.
 
Born in Richmond
Mr. Nolting was succeeded as Ambassador by Henry Cabot Lodge. Mr. Diem was overthrown and slain in a coup mounted by South Vietnamese generals in 1963.
Frederick Ernest Nolting Jr. was born on Aug. 24, 1911, in Richmond to Fredrick Ernest Nolting Sr. and Mary Buford Nolting. He grew up in Richmond and earned a B.A. degree in History in 1933 from the University of Virginia, in Charlottesville, where he went on to earn a master's degree and a doctorate in philosophy. He earned a second master's degree in philosophy from Harvard.
After being a member of a Richmond investment concern and a Navy officer in World War II, Mr. Nolting joined the State Department in 1946 and went on to be special assistant to Secretary of State John Foster Dulles for mutual security affairs.
Before he became Ambassador in Saigon, his other diplomatic assignments included serving as deputy chief of the United State mission to the North Atlantic Treaty Organiztion and to the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.
 
Retired From Service in 1964
He retired from the Foreign Service in 1964 with the rank of Career Minister, was for some years an executive of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, based in Paris and New York, and went on to hold teaching and administrative posts at the University of Virginia. He retired there in 1982.
Mr. Nolting was the author of a 1988 book ''From Trust to Tragedy'' and a former board chairman of the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Foundation.
He is survived by his wife, the former Olivia Lindsay Crumpler, whom he married in 1940; four daughters, Molly Nolting Bruner and Jane Nolting Meniktos, both of Charlottesville, Grace Lindsay Nolting of Columbia, Va., and Frances Nolting Temple of Geneva, N.Y., and seven grandchildren.
A memorial service is to be held at 11 A.M. on Monday at Saint Paul's Church in Ivy, Va., near Charlottesville.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

 
 
The Economy
The U.S. trade deficit widened sharply in October, to $10.2 billion, and imports jumped to a record, the Commerce Department reported. Many analysts saw the figures as a setback, although some contended that they did not mean consumers were continuing to spend freely, which would help to insure the continuation of a seven-year business expansion. [Page 35.] 
Industrial production rose a lackluster 0.1 percent in November despite rebounding from a major strike and the devastating California earthquake, the Federal Reserve said. [37.] Producer prices fell 0.1 percent last month. The Labor Department put the annual inflation rate of 4.6 percent for the first 11 months of 1989. [37]
The Bush Administration is studying a plan to create a new type of long-term savings account. The interest would be wholly exempt from taxes, and depositors would be allowed access to their money before they retire. [35.]
 
 
 
Companies
G.M. will buy half of Saab-Scania's car-making operations. The move enlarges G.M.'s European presence and plugs a hole in the company's product line. Saab has been looking for a partner. [35.]
Chrysler broadened the scope of its rebates and low-interest financing programs. Rebates will be offered for the first time on the company's highly successful mini-vans. [35.]
Bank of New England's problems in real estate lending are far more severe than previously estimated, the company said, and will result in a substantial loss for the year. [35.]
Manhattan Lawyer magazine will cease publication as a weekly next week, and reappear as a monthly in the spring, its president said. [36.]
Executives of some big newspaper companies predicted that 1990 would be another tough year for advertising sales, but most said a recession was unlikely. [36.]
Gillette will cut 750 jobs, sell some European units and reorganize its U.S. operations. [37.]
Eastman Kodak said its fourth-quarter earnings would be reduced by $273 million, or 85 cents a share, by write-offs of assets and payments to employees who are losing their jobs. [37.]
 
 
 
Markets
Stocks closed moderately lower after falling more sharply earlier in the ''triple witching'' day. [38.] Wall Street awoke yesterday to find a 3 1/2-ton bronze bull on its doorstep. Irritated Big Board officials hired a trucking company to cart away the sculpture, a Soho artist's tribute to the power of America. [31.]
Prices of Treasury securities were largely unchanged after strong opening gains were erased later in the session. [38.]
Gold prices rose sharply, with futures settling $5.50 to $5.60 higher on the Comex, as traders reacted to Panama's latest declaration of hostility against the U.S. Energy prices also surged amid fears that shipments through Central America could be disrupted. [43.] The dollar finished mostly lower in light trading.. [43.]
 
International
Comecon is rapidly disintegrating, many Eastern European officials and economists say. The Soviet bloc's trade organization will soon become an empty shell, some say; others suggest that it could survive, but as a wholly different organization. [35.]
China will devalue its currency by 21.2 percent against the dollar, effective today. It is the first devaluation since 1986. [39.]

When investing for retirement, it is vital to accumulate a portfolio that will outpace inflation, because many retirees can expect a 20- or 25-year retirement. Your Money. [36.]
A ''Roto Rooter'' for clogged arteries was patented by a Stanford cardiologist and his father, a physicist at Johns Hopkins. It could provide an alternative to current techniques. Patents. [36.]

HEADLINE: Bank of New England Says It Will Post Large 1989 Loss

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Bank of New England Corportion announced yesterday that its problems in real estate lending were far more severe than previously estimated and would result in a substantial loss for the year.
The Boston-based banking company, the second largest in New England and the 18th largest in the nation, also said it was considering a merger and the sale of assets. In addition, the company said it might rescind a 34-cents-a-share stock dividend to be paid in early January, which it had announced just a few weeks ago. 
After earning nearly $122 million in the first nine months of the year, Bank of New England could lose more than $500 million in the fourth quarter and more than $350 million for the year, analysts estimated.
The loss will result from a large increase in the company's reserve for loan losses, which it said yesterday would rise to more than $1 billion, from $354 million at the end of September. Earnings will also be weakened by a rise in delinquent loans to about $1.6 billion, from $900 million at the end of September.
Investors and analysts were well aware that Bank of New England was one of many banks facing big losses from its real estate lending in the slowing New England economy. In late November, when the company said it expected to announce a large loss for the fourth quarter, investors concluded that the problems were not so large as those disclosed today because the company also declared its stock dividend.
In active trading on the New York Stock Exchange that was more than 10 times the normal volume, the company's stock fell $3.375, to $9, a 27 percent decline on the day, with more than 4.6 million shares traded. In 1987, before the problems began to emerge, Bank of New England stock traded above $30 and the company was highly recommended by many analysts.
''People are not sure this is the bottom of the bank's credit problems,'' said Virginia Adair, an analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert. ''If there is a recession in 1990, as we expect, credit problems would continue to rise.''
The possible rescinding of the stock dividend was especially bothersome to investors, analysts said. ''When management says the problems are serious enough that they are reconsidering a dividend they declared just a few weeks ago, it raises a lot of questions,'' Ms. Adair said.
The bank said yesterday that a special committee of directors had hired Lazard Freres & Company, the investment banking firm, to study possible mergers or additional sales of assets. It also said that Hugh M. Taylor, executive vice president, had been named head of the real estate group, replacing James M. Sweeney, executive vice president, who was assigned other duties.
In October, the Bank of New England announced plans to sell 53 branches and cut about 800 jobs. In addition to the $20 million to $30 million gain it expects from the branch sales, it recently sold part of its leasing business to the Bank of Tokyo for $110 million and is trying to sell other leasing businesses for $20 million to $30 million.
Analysts said other assets that the banking company might readily sell include its credit card loan portfolio, which totaled $628 million at the end of 1988, and some of its banking holdings. Among its more attractive bank holdings are the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company of Hartford.

HEADLINE: Savings Incentive Studied

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
The Bush Administration is studying a plan that would create a new type of long-term savings account in which interest would be wholly exempted from taxes and depositors would be allowed access to their money before retirement, Administration officials said today.
The purpose of the account, which would require that the money be kept on deposit for a number of years, is to raise the chronically low rate of personal savings in this country. Economists have warned for years that this low rate has been undermining business vitality and future economic growth.
The Administration officials said that the so-called family savings plan was under intense study by the White House and the Treasury, and represented an effort to fulfill a campaign promise by President Bush. Although family savings plan is a working name, the proposal under study would not necessarily apply only to married people with children, the officials said. 
 
No Agreement on Details
The timing of the plan might be advantageous to the White House, since it could permit the Administration to take the lead in the savings debate. Lawmakers said today that the plan would become part of the sharp debate begun this fall between Republicans who want to cut capital gains taxes and Democrats who want to expand the availability of individual retirement accounts.
Government officials cautioned that no details of the proposed account had been agreed upon. But they confirmed a report published Friday in The Wall Street Journal that Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady presented such a proposal on Tuesday to the White House Economic Policy Council.
Under the Brady plan, any interest earned on deposits kept in the account for a 10-year period would be exempt from taxes, both as it builds up and when the funds are withdrawn. The plan initially outlined by the Treasury Secretary would permit savers to contribute up to $5,000 a year to such an account, and provide for penalties on early withdrawal.
 
'A Very Firm Consensus'
One Government official said, however, that the structure of the account could change, with the deposit limit being lowered to $4,000 and early-withdrawal penalties varying according to a sliding scale.
''It is no secret that some kind of savings plan has been bandied about in the Administration for some time and there has been this working group studying the issue,'' said one White House official. ''The only real thing that was done on Tuesday was a very firm consensus that we should do something. However, the council wants to see some very realistic proposals that would be true incentives for individual savings, not gimmicks.''
Indeed, the details are still so sketchy, one official said, that it was not entirely certain what kinds of institutions would be able to offer these accounts. He surmised, however, that all commercial banks, savings banks, savings and loan associations and credit unions, all of which carry Federal insurance on deposits up to $100,000, would be able to offer them.
The new savings approach is different from current tax-favored accounts, such as the individual retirement account and 401(k) plans, in several ways. Most significantly, the I.R.A. and 401(k) plans merely defer payment of taxes until retirement, while the new account would exempt all interest from any tax.
 
Withdrawl Penalty Likely
Also unlike the I.R.A., which is set up by an individual, and a 401(k), which is employer-sponsored, the new account is not geared toward retirement. It is intended to run only for a fixed period of time, say 10 years. It is also meant to serve such non-retirement needs as education expenses.
However, like the I.R.A. it is expected that the Adminstration would require a penalty for early withdrawal.
Some members of Congress have opposed the type of savings plan offered by the Administration, arguing that only the wealthier middle class and upper class could afford to commit such sums for 10-year periods. But economists argue that these taxpayers are the only real sector of the economy that can generate a large new increase in savings.
Moreover, the plan is also likely to encounter opposition from those who argue that it will be costly for the Treasury. But Government officials said today that this savings plan would give up far less revenue than some of the proposed I.R.A. plans in Congress.
 
A Skeptical View
Some lawmakers and Government officials took a skeptical view of the proposed account, arguing primarily that it did not adequately encourage individuals to generate new savings. They predicted that depositors might instead simply shift money from other accounts into these tax-favored accounts.
''I think the spotlight on savings is welcome, but I am not sure that this provides enough of an incentive,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who is a member of the House Banking Committee. ''The benefits are so long term and so far away, and Americans seem to be obsessed with short-term payoffs.''
This fall the Adminstration tried unsuccessfully to push a cut in the capital gains tax through Congress, while the Democrats tried in vain to pass a counter measure that would expand the availability of individual retirement accounts. Neither passed in a legislative standoff.
Though the low savings rate, which has averaged 4 percent of after-tax income over the last four years, has not held center stage as a national issue the way the budget deficit has, many economists say it is an even more pernicious problem. That, they say, is mainly because the rate of savings at the Government, corporate and personal levels in the United States is at nearly an all-time low and is significantly behind that of most of the nation's major trading partners. The personal savings rate in Japan, for instance, has averaged 15.5 over the last four years.
 
The Importance of Savings
Personal savings, which comprise deposits at banks, investments in mutual funds, stocks and bonds, as well as equity ownership in homes, is central to the nation's economic health because businesses essentially borrow the savings to invest in new plant and equipment.
When savings are scarce, the scramble to borrow becomes more intense, which tends to push up interest rates, meaning some corporations cannot invest in modernized plants. That in turn reduces their productivity and profitability, and can result in lower wages for workers.
It also means that businesses may look overseas for new investment capital, possibly selling key assets to foreign investors.

LENGTH: 922 words

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Widest in 10 Months

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit widened sharply in October to the highest level in 10 months and imports soared to a record level, the Commerce Department reported today.
The $10.2 billion deficit was higher than expected, and many analysts regarded the report as a setback despite some heartening elements, particularly a rise in exports despite a strike at the Boeing Company, one of the nation's largest exporters.
The $2 billion jump in imports startled some analysts, and some contended that it did not mean that consumers were continuing to spend freely, which would help to insure the continuation of the nation's seven-year business expansion.
''To import the goods is one thing,'' said Stuart G. Hoffman, senior economist at the Pittsburgh National Bank. ''To sell them profitably is another.'' 
 
Little Growth Expected
Most recent indicators have indicated that the economy is markedly slowing. and many analysts now expect little, if any, growth in the quarter that ends Dec. 31. The Labor Department reported today that producer prices fell by one-tenth of 1 percent in November, the third decline in five months. And the Federal Reserve said industrial production rose by a lackluster one-tenth of 1 percent last month. [Page 37.] Earlier this week, the Government reported that retail sales had been virtually unchanged in recent months and that business inventories had begun to swell.
In addition to raising fresh questions about the durability of the trend toward lower trade deficits, the report released today raised the prospect of more trade friction with Japan. The deficit with Japan jumped to $4.9 billion, from $4.1 billion in September, and accounted for 48 percent of the October deficit. Imports of Japanese cars accounted for nearly half of the rise.
 
Oil Bill at $4.4 Billion
The nation's bill for imported oil, reflecting both increased volumes and higher prices, climbed to $4.4 billion, or 43 percent of the overall deficit.
Under Secretary of Commerce Michael R. Darby called the rise in imports ''disappointing'' but stressed that trade data are subject to wide monthly fluctuations. Indeed, the department today raised its deficit total for September to $8.5 billion, from the $7.9 billion initially reported, mainly because of weaker exports.
Yet exports did better than expected in October, particularly since the Boeing strike had idled the company for most of the month. A Boeing spokesman said that the strike's effects had not yet been fully calculated, but that Boeing delivered only four 747-400's costing $125 million each to foreign buyers in October, compared with nine in September.
Walter K. Joelson, chief economist for the General Electric Company, another large exporter, said its export business continued to be ''very strong'' even as the country's manufacturing sector slumped over all. He predicted a further improvement of some $20 billion in the trade deficit in 1990, compared with a reduction of about $10 billion this year and $34 billion in 1988.
The October export total was $31 billion, $329 million higher than the revised level for September.
 
Pressure on Federal Reserve
Even though the October report is not as current as other recent data covering November, economists generally saw it as putting more pressure on the Federal Reserve to relax its monetary policy.
Milton W. Hudson, an economist at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, expressed the hope that the central bank would soon cut interest rates to avoid what he said could be a situation of ''weakness begetting weakness'' in the economy and the financial markets.
There have been signs that goods ordered during the summer are piling up unsold and that soft real estate prices are causing consumers to feel less wealthy, he added. At the same time, however, there was widespread agreement that strength in European economies, especially in West Germany, would be likely to cushion a downturn in this country.
 
Exports of Capital Goods Down
Today's trade report showed that the biggest gains in exports for October were a $700 million advance in the ''other merchandise'' category and a $300 million rise in vehicles, parts and engines. Exports of capital goods fell, however, by $900 million.
In imports, the main changes were a $1.4 billion increase in industrial supplies and materials and a $300 million increase in foods, feeds and beverages.
While October is a month for bringing Christmas goods into the country, the $10.2 billion deficit figure - the biggest since December 1988 - was adjusted to make allowance for this seasonal pattern. On an unadjusted basis, the deficit climbed to $11.5 billion, from $8.6 billion in September, revised from $8 billion, the report showed.
 
Disappearance of Fluke
By country, the most significant changes - apart from the jump in the American deficit with Japan - were the rapid disappearance of what seems to have been a fluke September surplus with Western Europe and a worsening of the deficit with Hong Kong, South Korea and Singapore. The deficit with Taiwan remained practically unchanged.
The October deficit with Western Europe totaled $460 million, following a $1.2 billion surplus the month before, and the year-to-date deficit now totals $1.1 billion.
With Canada, the nation's biggest trading partner, the deficit climbed to $843 million, from $610 million in September.
On a three-month moving average, the deficit for October is $9.6 billion, up from $9 billion in September and $8.8 billion in August.

HEADLINE: G.M. to Buy Half of Saab Car Unit

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 15

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation surprised the auto industry today by announcing it would buy half of Saab-Scania A.B.'s troubled car-making operations. The move enlarges G.M.'s European presence and plugs a hole in the company's product line, which needs models that can compete with imports like BMW and Mercedes-Benz.
G.M. attributes Saab's trouble primarily to its small size and figures it can bring economies of scale to the Swedish company, benefiting both partners. G.M. will pay $500 million for 50 percent of a new company, Saab Automobile A.B., that comprises Saab's auto making assets.
Saab has been looking for a partner for several months as its sales and profits have dwindled, and even some company insiders were betting on Fiat S.p.A. Volvo A.B. and the Ford Motor Company also made offers for Saab, but it rejected those three, reportedly because it was unwilling to give up a controlling interest. 
Instead Saab approached G.M., which only six weeks ago lost out to Ford in a bid for Jaguar P.L.C.
Saab-Scania will keep its profitable truck making, aircraft and military operations. The joint venture requires approval by the Swedish and United States Governments, and is expected to be completed by mid-January, G.M. officials said.
In addition to its equity investment, G.M. is committing $100 million to the company for use as operating capital to cover salaries, materials and equipment purchases for Saab, a G.M. spokesman said. Saab's sagging car business lost $188 million in the first eight months of this year.
The cars built by the new company will be sold under the Saab name through Saab's independent dealer network both in the United States and abroad, an attempt to preserve the prestige and customer base that Saab has built up, analysts say.
''It's less expensive for a car company to buy a luxury division than it is to make one from scratch, mainly because of the high costs of setting up distributors,'' said Scott Merlis, an auto industry analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company.
 
Advantages for G.M. Debated
Analysts said the financial advantages of the deal were less compelling than the improved position it provided for G.M. in Europe.
''G.M. will lose money on this in the first year, but the numbers are small enough that it's not critical,'' said Harvey Heinbach, an analyst with Merrill Lynch.
But some analysts questioned the wisdom of the deal.
''I don't see what G.M. has gained,'' said Maryann N. Keller, an analyst with Furman, Selz, Mager, Dietz & Birney. ''The Opel product line in Europe is already very strong, with models that aren't all that different from the cars that Saab sells.''
Unlike Jaguar, which can bring out new models in a year or two with the help of Ford's investment, ''Saab has nothing in the pipeline,'' Ms. Keller said. Manufacturing costs in Sweden are among the highest in Europe, she noted.
''G.M. will probably make Saab profitable in a year or two if the currency situation is favorable, if component costs are saved and if costs at Saab's plants are cut,'' Mr. Merlis said.
 
Saab's View
''Our problem has been that our volume is too small,'' said Kai Hammerich, an executive vice president with Saab-Scania in Sweden. The company's market share in Europe is less than 1 percent. G.M. already has an 11.4 percent share through its Opel and Vauxhall subsidiaries.
''With a strong partner, we can get the resources to expand our business,'' Mr. Hammerich said, adding that Saab expected to increase production and broaden its product line.
The deal does provide G.M. with an option to make cars at Saab's three plants. In North America G.M. has too much car-making capacity, but in Europe, the only place it has earned profits on car-making operations this year, G.M. believes it could use more.
 
Saab's Potential Output
G.M. officials estimate that the three Saab plants - two in Sweden, one in Finland - could turn out between 180,000 and 200,000 cars a year - about as much as a single American plant. But the Saab factories have been running at half to three-quarters capacity since the mid-1980's, because of slumping sales.
With the company's future uncertain, Saab's sales in the United States have fallen 16 percent so far this year from a year earlier.
G.M. also plans to acquire a large stake in Saab's automotive electronics business, which will be spun off into a separate company, Saab-Scania Automotive Electronics A.B. Saab will retain majority ownership of the electronics business, which is of interest to G.M. primarily because it makes a new direct ignition device that improves cold starting and prolongs spark-plug life.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
Retirement Plan To Beat Inflation

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
WITH life expectancies increasing, many people who stop working at age 65 can expect a 20- or 25-year retirement. That makes it vital to accumulate an investment portfolio that will provide returns that outpace inflation. And those who accept a lump-sum pension distribution and roll it over into an individual retirement account will need to manage it with long-term needs in mind.
That is because, even if inflation rates remain low, the cost of living in the later years of retirement will considerably exceed that of the earlier years, and few pensions are adjusted for inflation. 
''Ten thousand dollars in Treasuries today won't buy $10,000 worth of goods 10 years from now,'' because of inflation and taxes, said Gerald Morlitz, director of Arthur Andersen & Company's personal financial planning group in New York, who conducted a seminar this week for executives on planning to retire. ''I think you are making a big, big mistake if you have everything invested in fixed income.''
If inflation remains a moderate 4.5 percent, it would take $1,553 to buy goods in 10 years that cost $1,000 today; in 20 years, it would take $2,412. At the inflation rate of the last decade, 6.46 percent, it would take $1,870 in 10 years and $3,497 in 20 years.
Many people prefer to avoid risks, choosing ''safe'' investments that will let them sleep at night, Mr. Morlitz said, but they are focusing on market risk while overlooking business risk (affecting a particular holding where one has a big stake such as the A. H. Robins-Dalkon Shield case), interest rate risk and purchasing power risk.
Diversification is a key to managing these risks, he said. That means diversifying assets and changing one's investment styles over time. Many executives have accumulated blocks of their employer's stock but have been so immersed in their work that they have not taken time to redirect their assets into a diversified portfolio.
Even geography is part of diversification. ''If you own a block of I.B.M. stock, don't buy a rental property in Westchester County,'' Mr. Morlitz said. ''If I.B.M. moves south, think what will happen to Westchester real estate.''
A retired person might have time to manage a rental property, however, and therefore might wish to buy one elsewhere, or might want to diversify the stockholdings and buy the rental property close to home.
Mr. Morlitz advised people nearing retirement to pay off their debts because in retirement they may not have enough cash flow to cover those debts. The exceptions to the debt-free rule, he said, are home mortgages and debt incurred to buy an income-producing asset like a rental property.
When it comes to securities portfolios, ''we're proponents of professional management,'' he said, because it takes ability, as well as time and willingness to do well in the market. ''How are you going to go out and compete with people who are immersed in the market day to day and make their living by it?'' he asked. ''It's a pipe dream.''
For portfolios of $500,000 or $1 million or more, Mr. Morlitz recommended that investors select a well-regarded firm that manages individual accounts, like Neuberger Berman, Lazard Freres, Sanford Bernstein or Morgan Guaranty. For smaller accounts he recommended no-load or low-load mutual funds, like those in the Fidelity and Vanguard groups. Arthur Andersen, an accounting and consulting firm, does not manage investments.
One favorite investment for retirement is a tax-deferred annuity sold by insurance companies, and here Mr. Morlitz advised that the company be carefully chosen. Some insurance companies have invested heavily in ''junk bonds'' and could suffer large losses, affecting their ability to pay out on annuities. Others, like Northwestern Mutual, Massachusetts Mutual and New England Mutual Life, have lower-risk portfolios, he added.
 
Help in Retirement Planning
T. Rowe Price Associates Inc., the Baltimore-based investment management firm, is offering a free retirement planning kit to help people figure out how much money they will need for retirement and how to reach their goals. The kit can be ordered by calling 1-800-638-5660.
The kit has a 16-page, letter-sized workbook developed with Coopers & Lybrand that explains how to calculate income and expected retirement needs, allowing for various rates of return on investment and inflation. It guides people through the process step by step. Steven E. Norwitz, vice president of Price, estimates that it will take people who have well-organized records an hour to work through the booklet.

HEADLINE: Top Newspaper Executives Predict Tough Year for Ads

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
Top executives of some of the nation's largest newspaper companies predicted this week that 1990 would be another tough year for advertising sales, but most said they thought a recession was unlikely.
In what has become an annual ritual, the company representatives went before dozens of media analysts during Paine Webber's ''Conference on the Outlook for the Media'' to describe the last year and project the year to come.
While each company had a somewhat different assessment of its prospects, the cumulative message was characterized by several of the analysts as positive but cautious. ''They were mildly optimistic,'' said J. Kendrick Noble Jr., a media analyst for Paine Webber Inc. who organized the conference. ''But they were mildly optimistic last year and the year before, and it got worse, so this year they're even more tempered.'' 
 
Shift of Emphasis
Several analysts also described a widespread, if subtle, shift of emphasis among the newspaper executives.
After several years of belt-tightening, many companies can no longer depend on reducing costs to maintain the double-digit annual increases in profitablity that were routine in the early and mid-1980's.
While virtually every company mentioned a determination to control costs, there was new emphasis on increasing circulation in order to raise advertising rates.
And with competition fierce for advertising dollars, there was a new emphasis on finding inventive ways to increase advertising volume. These methods include everything from more aggressive volume discounting to creating new publications and offering promotions that give ''added value'' - the buzz words of the week - to newspaper advertising.
 
Tribune Company's Plan
The Tribune Company, whose holdings include The Chicago Tribune and The Daily News in New York, devoted much of its presentation to the importance of its impending negotiations with The News's 10 unions.
James Hoge, publisher of The News, told the analysts that The News would probably show a loss for the year and said that he was determined to win the power to hire, supervise, assign work and determine overtime. With union concessions, he said, plans to build a color printing operation would proceed, but he declined to estimate what that would cost in buyouts and other expenses.
The New York Times Company emphasized its circulation growth during the last year, in which daily sales went above 1.1 million for the first time. A slide presentation described the company's new highly automated printing and distribution plant in Edison, N.J., which is expected to begin operation next year.
 
Decline in Ad Linage Expected
Walter E. Mattson, president of the company, said The Times would continue to struggle with a soft local economy and that he expected the paper to experience a 7 percent decline in advertising linage in 1989.
Mr. Mattson said 1990 would probably be another difficult year for The Times, with a further but smaller loss in advertising linage. He said he expected the trend to reverse in 1991.
Knight-Ridder Inc. gave special attention to the start-up of its joint operating arrangement with the Gannett Company in Detroit. On Nov. 27, after nearly four years of seeking Government approval, the companies were allowed to merge the production, advertising and distribution operations of their respective papers, The Detroit Free Press and The Detroit News.
James K. Batten, the company's chairman, said The Free Press was expected to show its first profit in 12 years in 1990, though he declined to say what that profit would likely be.
The Detroit papers have raised circulation and advertising rates.
Gannett said 1990 would mark the first full year of profitability for U.S.A. Today, and it added that it would also be the first year the national daily pays all its own expenses. Some expenses were previously carried by other Gannett papers.

HEADLINE: Output Rose A Slim 0.1% Last Month

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Industrial production rose by a lackluster one-tenth of 1 percent in November despite rebounding from a major strike and the devastating California earthquake, the Federal Reserve Board said today.
Many economists said the weak gain, accompanied by moderating inflation, suggests that the Fed should permit another easing of short-term interest rates to stimulate the economy.
''Manufacturing production continues to slow,'' said John Silvia, an economist with Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. ''It's not collapsing, but it is slowing. And I think the Fed is sensing that it has some type of leeway to ease.'' 
In today's report, the Fed attributed the slim gain, the first in three months, to a recovery from the Boeing Company strike, which ended in late November, and from the lingering effects on the computer and related industries of the San Francisco Bay-area earthquake in October, when output had slumped six-tenths of 1 percent.
''Excluding the impact of these events, the total index would have been little changed in both October and November.'' the Fed reported.
The manufacturing sector has been among the hardest hit by the Fed's tight-money policies as the central bank tries to contain inflation by slowing the economy without tipping it into a recession.
 
Producer Prices Drop
But in the latest report on inflation, the Commerce Department said today that producer prices dipped one-tenth of 1 percent in November, the third decline in five months.
Industrial output had not risen since a gain of four-tenths of 1 percent last August and that followed a drop of one-tenth of 1 percent in July. It was down three-tenths of 1 percent in September.
Output at manufacturing plants making both durable and nondurable goods rose two-tenths of 1 percent in November after falling eight-tenths of 1 percent in October and four-tenths of 1 percent in September.
Production of durable goods -items expected to last more than three years - rose five-tenths of 1 percent last month after falling 1.8 percent in October and seven-tenths of 1 percent in September. Nondurable manufacturing fell two-tenths of 1 percent after rising five-tenths of 1 percent in October and one-tenth of 1 percent in September.
 
Operating Rate Dips
In another report reflecting sluggishness, the Fed said the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities edged down one-tenth of one percentage point, to 82.7 percent, in November, reaching its lowest rate since April 1988.
''That's one of the reasons you're seeing producer prices falling,'' said Donald Ratajczak, economic forecasting director at Georgia State University. ''When you have excess capacity, that's when you see price concessions.''
The closer the nation's industry gets to full operating capacity, the greater difficulty it has in producing enough to meet demand, leading to shortages and subsequent price increases. Analysts generally consider an operating rate of 85 percent or above as an indication of inflationary pressures.
Factory use had dipped in October to 82.8 percent, from 83.4 percent in September. The rate posted 10-year highs of 84.3 percent last December and January.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Down By 0.1% in November

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
A sharp drop in the cost of gasoline helped to push producer prices lower in November, the Government said today.
The annual rate of inflation, as measured by the Labor Department, was 4.6 percent for the first 11 months of the year, up from 4 percent for all of 1988 but much lower than had been feared earlier this year.
The Producer Price Index dipped one-tenth of a percent last month after rising four-tenths of a percent in October and jumping nine-tenths of a percent in September. The index declined five-tenths of a percent in July and four-tenths in August. 
From June through November, the index averages out to an annual inflation rate of about 1 percent in contrast to a 9 percent-plus rate for the first five months of the year.
''If ever there was an example of inflation coming in like a lion and going out like a lamb, it was this year,'' said David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a Government securities dealer in New York. ''That has to be good news for everyone, particularly the consumer.''
Energy prices declined 3.3 percent last month, their sharpest drop since August. A 7.7 percent plunge in gasoline prices more than compensated for a one-tenth of a percent rise in natural gas costs and a seven-tenths increase in heating oil prices.
Analysts credit the taming of inflation to the tight-money policy that the Fed pursued through the spring. As evidence, they cited a separate report by the Federal Reserve on industrial production in November.
The operating rate at the nation's factories, mines and utilities eased a tenth of a percentage point, to 82.7 percent, well below the 10-year high of 84.3 percent at the start of the year, the central bank said.
 
Fed Reversed Course
Since summer, the Fed has reversed course on monetary policy, hoping to avoid a recession by permitting interest rates to fall. Lower American rates could help the deficit by depressing the value of the dollar, stimulating exports and discouraging imports. The latest round of economic reports may encourage the Fed to lower rates further, although some economists do not expect a drop until after the first of the year.
The producer price report showed food costs rising a substantial eight-tenths of a percent in November, after a 1.4 percent jump in October, the biggest in 22 months. Food prices generally declined from April through September.
Pork prices jumped 7.1 percent after rising 9.5 percent in October. Prices for turkeys and eggs also rose and dairy prices were up 3.3 percent, the fifth consecutive increase exceeding 1 percent.
The increases were partly offset by a 15.1 percent drop in vegetable costs, which had risen 18.9 percent a month earlier, and a 6.5 percent decline in fresh fruit prices. Prices for fish, chicken, coffee and rice also fell.
The price of goods excluding the volatile food and energy categories -a measure many analysts consider a better gauge of underlying inflationary pressures in the economy - rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent last month after rising one-tenth in October.
Before adjusting for normal seasonal variations, the Producer Price Index stood at 114.8 in October. This meant that a hypothetical basket of goods cost $114.80 last month, compared with $109.80 a year earlier and $100 in 1982, when the index's base was set at 100.
The inflation news was also favorable for earlier stages in the production process. The price of goods in the intermediate stages of production fell a tenth of 1 percent in November, compared with no change a month earlier. Prices of crude goods rose four-tenths of 1 percent after holding steady in October. Excluding food and energy, crude goods prices dropped 2.3 percent.
