HEADLINE: Dow Drops 14.08 on 'Witching' Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks closed moderately lower yesterday, after recovering from earlier sharp losses, as investors reacted to the ''triple witching hour,'' the quarterly time when stock options, stock-index futures and stock-index options all expire.
Monte Gordon, research director of the Dreyfus Corporation, said, ''You're likely to get substantial volatility on triple witching day.'' The market was further roiled yesterday by reports that Panama considered itself at war with the United States, which set off heavy computer-directed selling programs, and by rumors of a new insider trading scandal.
Mr. Gordon also cited the October trade deficit of $10.2 billion, which was far higher than expected. But he said the figures Washington reported for producer prices, industrial production and capacity were in line with expectations. 
Mr. Gordon called it disappointing that there was no news to suggest that the Federal Reserve would vere from present policy. As a result, lower interest rates seem unlikely before the end of the year, he said.
 
Dow Up 8.11 for Week
The Dow Jones industrial average, which was down almost 45 points around midday, closed off 14.08, to 2,739.55, For the week, it gained 8.11 points. Yesterday, the Dow transportation average slumped 14.93, to 1,170.70, and the utility average rose 1.32, to 235.98, its sixth straight high.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.52, to 193.45, with 924 issues down and 619 ahead, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 0.79, to 350.14. Volume rose to 240.4 million shares, from 178.7 million shares Thursday.
Elaine M. Garzarelli, executive vice president of Shearson Lehman Hutton, said, ''We're stuck in a trading range for the next year of 2,500 on the downside and 3,100 on the upside.''
Traders said some takeover stocks were depressed by a column in The Daily News by Liz Smith, who said that there were rumors at a party, which she did not attend, that a new inside trading indictment would ''shake Wall Street again to its foundations.''
 
'The Arbs Got Nervous'
''The arbs got nervous and started selling,'' a trader at one major firm said. ''The rumor went around that Coniston was involved.'' Coniston Partners said it knew of no investigation, but UAL, in which it owns a major stake, fell to as low as 156 1/4 before rallying to 160 1/4, down 3 for the day.
One Wall Street trader said that arbitragers had been so battered this year that many overreacted, selling big blocks of Hilton Hotels, Georgia Gulf, USX, MGM/UA, Aristech Chemical and Lin Broadcasting, all stocks involved in deals that have already been announced.
Leading the Big Board's most-active list, Bank of New England fell 3 3/8, to 9, on a volume of 4.6 million shares, after it said it expected a big loss because of the real estate slump in New England. Bank of Boston fell 1 5/8, to 17 1/8, possibly in sympathy.
General Motors, which announced it would take a 50 percent stake in Saab-Scania, the troubled Swedish auto maker, fell a point, to 42 1/2, on 2.4 million shares.
I.B.M. fell during the day to as low as 94, close to its low point near 92 1/2 in 1983, but closed at 95, off only 1/8 point.
DiGiorgio gained 1 3/4, to 27 3/4, after the food company said it had resumed talks on a $32-a-share takeover bid.
Prices fell on the American Stock Exchange and in over-the-counter trading. The Amex market-value index declined 1.32, to 375.50, and the Nasdaq composite index was down 3.64, to 443.84.
In the over-the-counter market, Apple Computer fell 1 1/8, to 33 3/4, on 4.6 million shares after Thursday's copyright infringement suit by Xerox. Apple also told analysts yesterday that it would not meet its growth targets for the October-December period.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Lower in Light Day, Hurt by Economic Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mostly lower yesterday in trading that remained thin despite the release of important economic data.
The Government's latest reports on the economy proved bearish for the dollar. The Commerce Department said the trade deficit widened to $10.2 billion in October, greater than the $9 billion traders had expected. A large deficit makes a case for a lower dollar, which helps improve the trade gap by making imports more expensive and exports cheaper.
Separately, the Labor Department said producer prices slipped one-tenth of 1 percent in November, bucking predictions that called for a one-tenth of 1 percent gain.
After the figures were released, ''the dollar came off fairly substantially,'' said Bob Morrissey, senior trader at the Bank of Boston's New York office.
The dollar fell below the important 1.7210 level against the West German mark, leading traders to believe the currency is gathering momentum to move lower.
In New York the dollar closed at 144.15 yen, unchanged from late Thursday. And one pound cost $1.6030, more expensive than Thursday's $1.6010.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.7190 West German marks, down from 1.7344; 1.5480 Swiss francs, down from 1.5630; 5.8785 French francs, down from 5.9285; 1,283.50 Italian lire, down from 1,292.50, and 1.1608 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1598.

LENGTH: 1160 words

HEADLINE: Raising Money Tops Colleges' Agenda for 90's

BYLINE: By LEE A. DANIELS

 BODY:
Colleges and universities, facing many of the same competitive pressures as big corporations, are trying to raise huge amounts of money to prepare for the 1990's, a decade that many educators think will bring expensive and potentially disruptive changes to their institutions.
Prestigious private schools like the University of Pennsylvania are aiming for a billion dollars or more. The major state universities, long used to being supported largely by public money, are increasingly matching the major private institutions in their fund-raising ambitions. And less well-known colleges and universities, like Ball State University in Muncie, Ind., which says it needs $40 million in outside donations over the next five years, have joined the now-crowded field. 
All these schools differ in many respects. But, says Hanna Holborn Gray, president of the University of Chicago, they share concerns about things like continuing to be able to attract and give financial aid to students, attract and pay new faculty and meet the increasing expense of buying equipment and supporting faculty members doing advanced research.
''Our entire society now must make do with more limited resources,'' Dr. Gray said. ''For higher education, that means sharpened competition for students, faculty and dollars at all levels.''
That has made getting private dollars ''absolutely essential to the quality of management in higher education,'' says George A. Brakeley 3d, former chairman of the American Association of Fund Raising Counsel.
The reason, Mr. Brakeley and others knowledgeable about higher education declare, is rooted in the growing pressure the changed American economy has put on these institutions to cut costs, streamline management, raise new capital and produce a better ''product'' - that is, improve their educational quality.
Among the growing pressures on colleges and universities are these:
* Rising costs for salaries and benefits of faculty and staff (the average salary for a full professor at a four-year college is $50,420 for the 1988-89 school year, according to the American Association of University Professors), for building upkeep and for services and financial aid to students.
* Growing public concern over tuition increases, as evidenced by a current Justice Department investigation of some colleges' tuition-setting practices.
* The extraordinary diversity, in terms of race, ethnicity and age, of undergraduates, and the costs of serving these more diverse students, some of whom need significant remedial help.
* New developments in scholarship, such as the increasing collaboration of faculty in different disciplines in combined research projects, which not only tend to be far more expensive but have disrupted many traditional practices.
 
The 'Typical' Student Changes
Higher education has undergone tremendous change during the 1980's. For the first time, more than half of the nation's undergraduates, now 11 million strong, entered college as adults, not teen-agers. Also, numerous studies show that increasing numbers of undergraduates are taking longer to gain their degrees and attend more than one college.
In addition, a recent study predicted that, barring a two-thirds increase in the number of new Ph.D.'s, colleges and universities will face a big shortage of faculty members in the early 1990's.
In response, the larger public and private universities are more aggressively hunting for private money. The University of Miami in Florida and Ohio State University are each among the handful now trying to raise more than $400 million.
Even the University of Pennsylvania's gigantic effort will not break new ground. It is the fourth institution, after Boston University, New York University and Stanford University, whose campaigns got under way in the mid-1980's, to try to raise $1 billion. Cornell University will probably launch a billion-dollar campaign next year.
 
Harvard Reaches High
And Harvard University will likely up the ante in 1991 by mounting a campaign to raise $2 billion, according to sources at the school.
To be sure, the major private universities as a group remain the most proficient fund-raisers, according to a study in the recent issue of Currents, the magazine of the American Association of Fund Raising Counsel.
But John A. Dunn, Jr., vice president of planning at Tufts University in Medford, Mass., one of the study's authors, notes that now 6 of the 20 most successful fund-raisers are public institutions, among them the University of Minnesota, the University of Illinois and the University of Wisconsin at Madison.
Over all, Mr. Dunn says, public universities account for 20 of the top 50 institutions in total gifts.
And, as with Ball State, institutions which have previously done relatively little fund-raising have joined in the hunt. For example, the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, Va., is trying to raise $65 million in its first major effort.
Giving to higher education fell last year for the first time since 1976 even as total gifts to philanthropy increased. Experts attributed the decline, to just under $8.2 billion from $8.5 billion the previous year, to the impact of the Tax Reform Act of 1986, which affected big donors by tightening some rules on deductions for charitable giving. Fund-raisers expect donations to rebound next year.
School officials hope the rund-raisers are right. ''We've raised our tuition by 6 percent, but that's our limit,'' says John E. Worthen, Ball State's president. ''We're loath to go higher, because then we'd be pricing ourselves out of range of the students we think we can attract.''
 
Finding Their Niche
Dr. Worthen said the campaign's other compelling cause was to secure a ''niche'' as a teaching university.
''We're a mid-sized university,'' he said. ''Our people do research, but they do less of it, so we can't compete with an Indiana or an Illinois. But we can be excellent in teaching undergraduate and graduate students.''
Officials at major institutions talk about their niche as well. But their eyes are set on the very top of higher education's pecking order.
Sheldon Hackney, Pennsylvania's president, speaks of his university being part of ''a new set of leadership institutions'' among the major research universities - those which, having planned properly, will emerge from the coming decade rich and strong.
 
The View From New York
This vision - and ambition - is one shared by John Brademas, president of New York University, and Edward T. Foote 2d, president of the University of Miami.
''We don't have any small plans here,'' said Dr. Foote.''We're striking to become one of the greatest research universities in the world.''
Mr. Brademas said the ''restructuring'' he envisions will not be ''a matter of some institutions there now declining in quality. It's the question of who can rise to that level of excellence in these difficult times.''

HEADLINE: Left or Right? Brazilians Will Decide Today

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Brazilian voters will choose on Sunday between two presidential candidates offering radically different paths for Latin America's most populous nation: socialist or free market.
The three most recent polls show the two candidates in a technical tie.
After tumbling steadily in polls in the last 10 days, Fernando Collor de Mello, the center-right candidate, is believed to have benefited from a strong performance in a nationally televised debate on Thursday night.
Today, however, the leftist and union candidate, Luis Inacio da Silva, predicted confidently that he would win by three to four percentage points. 
In interviews at their campaign headquarters, the candidates displayed sharply differing styles and sharply differing visions for solving the country's pressing problems: mass poverty, 1,700 percent annual inflation and a $110 billion foreign debt, the largest in the developing world.
Interviewed in Brasilia, the 40-year-old Mr. Collor argued energetically in favor of privatizing state companies, encouraging foreign investment and injecting competition into Brazil's monopolistic brand of capitalism. ''We have a corrupted, degenerate capitalism,'' Mr. Collor said. ''We have to reduce the participation of the state in the economy.''
In foreign affairs, Mr. Collor advocated closer trade links with the United States, Japan and Europe. He said he hoped that by the year 2000 Brazil would join the ranks of the superpowers.
 
New Approach to Debt
On the debt, he advocated allowing each Brazilian debtor company to negotiate directly with creditor banks -a violation of most loan contracts. Brazil has not made service payments on the debt since July.
From May until last week, Mr. Collor led in opinion polls. But in recent days, Mr. da Silva severely damaged his rival's standing by painting him as the establishment candidate.
The son of a wealthy family, Mr. Collor had a privileged upbringing in Rio and Brasilia, where he became a national karate champion. In 1979, at the age of 29, he was appointed by Brazil's military Government to be Mayor of Maceio, the capital of Alagoas State. While a member of a succession of parties that supported the military government, he became a congressmen and then Governor of Alagoas.
Unwilling to be labeled a rightist, Mr. Collor declined to make campaign alliances after Brazil's first elimination round of voting on Nov. 15. Campaigning alone, but with heavy financial support from businessmen, he crisscrossed the interior of Brazil, conducting as many as 10 rallies a day in small cities.
In sharp contrast to Mr. Collor, Mr. da Silva grew up in the interior of Brazil's impoverished northeast, ended his time in school at the primary level, and fled to Sao Paulo in the back of a truck when a drought threatened to kill his family.
 
Jailed by the Military
In Sao Paulo, he rose to the top of the trade union movement, frequently crossing verbal swords with Brazil's military. In 1979 he formed the Workers' Party and the next year the military jailed him for a month for leading an ''illegal'' strike. In 1986, he was elected congressman for his party, a coalition of trade unionists, Socialists and Marxists.
In last month's vote he was the furthest to the left of the top six vote-getters. Since then, he has moderated some of his stands to win endorsements from more moderate leftists.
In an interview last week, the stocky 44-year-old called for ending all debt payments until a political solution is found, for giving workers seats on the boards of state enterprises, and for distributing unused land from large estates to landless peasants.
Asked if his candidacy was out of step with recent developments toward private enterprise systems in Eastern Europe, he replied with a phrase that has won cheers on the campaign circuit: ''We are going to knock down our own Berlin wall - a wall of hunger, prostitution, illiteracy and poor health.''

HEADLINE: U.N. Asks Hong Kong to Delay Deportations

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Dec. 16

 BODY:
United Nations refugee officials are asking Hong Kong not to forcibly return any more boat people to Vietnam until an international meeting next month tries to come up with a new approach to the problem.
But United Nations officials reject claims that the British colony's forced repatriation of 51 boat people on Tuesday violated international law regarding refugees.
''The 51 who were sent back were determined by the Hong Kong authorities as well as us to be non-refugees,'' said Raymond Hall, a spokesman for the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. ''There was no question of a violation of refugee law in that case.'' 
The meeting in Geneva on Jan. 18 and 19 is to be attended by representatives of more than 25 nations, including the United States, Vietnam, Britain and Southeast Asian countries. They make up a panel named at an international conference here in June to seek a new strategy to resolve the problem of the boat people.
The committee has been deadlocked since its establishment, largely because of United States opposition to forced returns. Britain, which says the forced repatriations have been temporarily suspended, insists that the colony has no choice but to carry them out.
At the June conference it was unanimously agreed that the Vietnamese should be screened and that those determined to be economic migrants and not legitimate political refugees should return to Vietnam. Those at the meeting agreed that refugees should be persuaded to return ''voluntarily.'' But participants could only agree to a vaguely worded proposition that ''alternative'' solutions should be found if voluntary repatriation did not work ''after a reasonable period of time.'' Amnesty International and other human rights groups have protested that the deportations should end because screening is not done fairly. United Nations officials share some complaints about the speed of the procedure and the quality of language interpretation for the Vietnamese.
But they say Hong Kong officials have been improving the screening process. ''We have safeguards in Hong Kong which don't necessarily exist in other countries,'' said Dennis McNamara, deputy director of refugee law and doctrine at the High Commissioner's office.
Under an agreement with the British colony, the High Commissioner's office has played a large role in screening the boat people.
The United Nations criteria are based on a 1951 refugee convention that defines a refugee as anyone outside his or her country who has ''a well-founded fear of persecution'' on political, ethnic, religious or other grounds.
 
Cases Subject to Review
The United Nations has about 20 lawyers stationed in Hong Kong monitoring the screening and intends soon to increase the number to 35. Under an agreement with the British colony, the High Commissioner's office may review the cases of all Vietnamese determined by Hong Kong to be non-refugees.
Whenever United Nations officials believe a determination is mistaken, they have the right to change that person's status to that of a refugee. Hong Kong is allowing those determined to be refugees to remain on its territory until they are resettled by a country of permanent asylum. About 8,000 of the nearly 57,000 boat people in Hong Kong have been screened so far, according to the High Commissioner's office. Eight hundred forty-one were granted refugee status by Hong Kong officials, and another 65 by United Nations refugee officials.
Although the repatriations have been suspended by Britain, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has defended the practice and said it will continue.
British officials have accused the United States of hypocrisy on the issue. In November, after a meeting with President Bush, Mrs. Thatcher pointed to the United States policy of intercepting boats filled with Haitian asylum-seekers and forcing them back to Haiti.

HEADLINE: Greek Communists Face Revolts in the Ranks

BYLINE: By PAUL ANASTASI, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATHENS, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Like many Communist parties that have relied heavily on the support of Eastern European governments, Greece's Communist Party is battling for survival.
''All members are called upon to struggle toward the development of a new type of party,'' a Communist statement said after a Central Committee meeting last week to discuss the crisis in its ranks. ''It has been determined that the party's influence is waning among the poorer classes.''
The Communist Party has averaged 12 percent of the vote, or about 750,000 voters, in recent elections. Now, in an attempt to stem an erosion of public support, Communist leaders have resorted to several moves, including the formation of a more moderate left-wing umbrella party that has secured Communists a place in government for the first time. 
Other senior party officials have defected to the rival Socialist and conservative parties, while a large number of hard-liners have broken off and threaten to form a separate Communist party.
Founded in 1918 soon after the Bolshevik Revolution, the Greek Communist Party went so far as to denounce the defense of Greek soil against the Nazi invasion, reversing its stand only when the Soviet-German alliance collapsed.
At the end of World War II, it tried to seize power by force. After a four-year civil war, the Communists were defeated, largely as a result of British and then American military and economic aid. Outlawed in 1947, the party was not legalized again until 1974.
The party never deviated in its loyalty to Moscow, opposing Greece's membership in NATO and the basing of American troops on Greek soil, and supporting the Soviet interventions in Hungary in 1956, in Czechoslovakia in 1968 and in Afghanistan in 1979.
But Mikhail S. Gorbachev's liberalization programs caught the Greek Communists by surprise. Not until 1987 did the party leader, Harilaos Florakis, declare his support for perestroika. And as international Communism foundered, he soon joined more moderate leftist parties to form the Coalition of the Left and Progress, which won 13.1 percent of the vote in the inconclusive elections in June and 10.8 percent in the November voting.
In an unprecedented move earlier this year, and as evidence of further moderation, the leftist coalition joined the conservative New Democracy Party in a three-month interim Government. At present, the Communists are part of an all-party Government.
But such ideological concessions have brought a revolt from the hard-liners. Fifteen members of the party's Central Committee have either resigned or been dismissed. Some have expressed disillusionment with Communism because of developments in Eastern Europe. Others have protested that the leadership has abandoned its ideological purity.
 
Yeltsin Is Avoided
This has so debilitated the party leadership that when Boris N. Yeltsin, a leader of Soviet political forces that think perestroika is proceeding too slowly, visited Athens two weeks ago, Mr. Florakis was the only Greek party leader to decline a meeting. His concern was to avoid further reaction from hard-liners.
Other Greek Communist leaders have joined rival parties. Markos Vafiades, the leader of the rebel Communist government set up during the civil war, joined the Socialists after denouncing his former comrades as K.G.B. agents and secret members of the Soviet Communist Party. Mikis Theodorakis, the renowned composer, left the Communists two months ago and joined the conservative party.
Mr. Florakis supports changing the party's name and turning the present left-wing alliance into a permanent party structure.
A West European diplomat here who specializes in Communist affairs said: ''The Greek Communist Party had always been an affiliate of the Eastern bloc. With the parent company discredited and in disarray, it would not be surprising if the subsidiary branch in Greece closed down or changed its business altogether.''

HEADLINE: San Francisco Crane Collapse Was No Fluke

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
When a construction crane fell more than 16 stories into the heart of San Francisco's financial district last month, killing five people, it was one of the worst such accidents on record. But it was no fluke.
Scores of people, nearly all of them construction workers, die in less spectacular crane accidents every year, and hundreds more are injured in inherently dangerous work made even more perilous because it is all but unregulated.
In all states, people need licenses or other forms of certification to be architects, building inspectors, surveyors, plumbers, electricians and truck drivers. 
But except for New York State, New York City and a few other states and municipalities, no license is needed to run machines that are vastly more powerful than automobiles.
''Any idiot can get out there and operate a crane,'' said Joseph A. Kinney, executive director of the National Safe Workplace Institute in Chicago.
 
Few Inspections of Construction
The Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration, like most state safety agencies, has regulations for cranes, and some are stringent and precise. But like most of the state agencies, OSHA says it lacks the money and personnel to investigate construction sites for hazards before accidents happen. It investigates afterward.
In addition, few authorities require contractors to keep someone at their building sites who is responsible for overall safety, including the health of workers. The condition of the San Francisco operator, Lonnie Boggess, who died in the collapse, has come into question because of reports that he drank and was suicidal.
And few states or cities - New York City is the principal exception - require contractors to give advance notice of crane maneuvers, like the process of raising a tower crane that was a factor in the collapse in San Francisco.
There are no reliable records of construction accidents, much less of those involving cranes, but construction vies with agriculture, mining and heavy manufacturing as the nation's most hazardous business, the Labor Department says.
 
Injury Rate Is Highest
And in a survey of eight major business sectors in the economy, including mining and manufacturing, the Labor Department found that the injury rate at companies with fewer than 500 workers - the vast majority of companies - is highest in construction.
Crane operators are the elite workers on a construction job; tower crane operators, masters of machines that can be as complex as a small airplane, are the elite of the elite. In California, unionized operators earn $22.22 to $27.45 an hour, plus another $10.47 in benefits - more than any other construction workers - so they can often count on annual wages exceeding $50,000.
The machines they operate include slender, one-legged tower cranes, like the one in San Francisco, and long-nosed behemoths that crawl over the ground hoisting and delivering their loads with the might of hundreds of men.
In the hands of inexperienced operators, ''cranes are very, very dangerous, and they can cause a lot of havoc,'' said David V. MacCollum, a construction safety consultant in Sierra Vista, Ariz., who formerly ran safety programs for the Army Corps of Engineers and is a former president of the American Society of Safety Engineers.
With their big iron hooks and their loads, cranes can slam workers, he said. The cranes can also tip over and crush workers, drop them to their deaths when lifting them or electrocute them when crane booms run into high-voltage power lines - the most common cause of crane-related deaths.
Mr. MacCollum was an expert witness in a case against a crane company in Seattle that was involved in an accident there four years ago, which he said appeared similar in its mechanical aspects to the one in San Francisco.
Scott Dearing, an experienced tower crane operator, then 30 years old, plunged 324 feet in his crane's cab. As in San Francisco last month, the crane was being ''jumped,'' a delicate and time-consuming procedure used to move up the top of a tower crane as floors are added to a building.
 
Fault Is Called Widespread
In the Seattle case, workers on the crane removed too many bolts at a critical moment. The remaining bolts broke, and the cab and the big horizontal boom tipped over. The boom struck the pavement first, apparently breaking Mr. Dearing's fall. Remarkably, he survived with minor injuries but suffered stress and is unable to work, he said in a lawsuit.
Mr. Dearing won a $465,000 settlement from the company that operated the crane. ''My accident happened because the company that held the franchise did not adequately supervise or train their employees,'' he said.
''But others were at fault here too -the unions, the state and the Federal Government - not just the crane contractor,'' he said. Not once did Washington State's job safety authorities or Federal inspectors examine the crane, he went on, adding: ''They just examined my reports. What kind of safety inspectors are these?''
In the 1988 and 1989 fiscal years, OSHA dispatched investigators to 73 sites where 75 fatalities resulted from violations of OSHA's safety standards for cranes. The agency's penalties, an object of criticism by labor unions and safety experts, were as low as $320 and rarely more than $3,000.
New York City and New York State have written the toughest safety restraints in the nation, but only after the deaths of pedestrians in Manhattan.
 
Accident Kills Pedestrian
Seven years ago, a crane dislodged chunks of a rooftop at Madison Avenue and 53d Street. They fell 44 stories, killing Warren F. Levenberg, an executive on the sidewalk below. And four years ago, a crane crushed the legs of Brigitte Gurney, another pedestrian, in an accident at Third Avenue and 63d Street. On Oct. 3, a crane tipped over in Midtown, just missing midafternoon crowds and the Russian Tea Room.
John V. Moran, an official of the Laborers' National Health and Safety Fund, which is financed by labor and business, said New York State ranked sixth, after South Carolina, Maryland, Massachusetts, Arizona and New Jersey, among 36 states he surveyed for the fatality rate of construction workers over five years.
Besides requiring certification for crane operators and contractors to supply safety managers on construction sites, New York City requires that builders put netting around their projects to trap falling debris. ''And we inspect all building sites twice a week,'' the city building commissioner, Charles M. Smith Jr., said. ''They check 85 items.''
California is likely to give new consideration to adopting restraints on crane operation for the same reason New York did: because someone outside the construction crew - Kathleen Tay Holden, a school bus driver - was killed. ''Cranes don't get attention when they fall on workers,'' said an official of the state OSHA.
Even the building industry in California acknowledges that some additional regulation may be desirable, because it would bring into line some builders who take excessive risks. ''Our industry is so competitive that there are those who will cut corners,'' said Richard B. Munn, executive vice president of the Associated General Contractors of California in Sacramento. ''It would be my guess that there will be a real push for crane operation licensing as a result of this.''

HEADLINE: Hawaii to Screen for Potential Child Abusers

BYLINE: By CAROL LAWSON

 BODY:
In an ambitious effort to combat child abuse, Hawaii has begun the nation's first effort to screen all parents for danger signs.
By 1992, the state aims to evaluate every new parent so that those most likely to abuse their children are identified. Those considered most prone to commit abuse are offered five years of counseling and home visits intended to help troubled families cope with economic and psychological problems.
Experts say that although there are other prevention programs around the country an effort with the scope of Hawaii's has never been tried before in the United States. Studies have shown that intensive early intervention in the home can sharply reduce the incidence of child abuse. 
''Hawaii has a strong, exciting program,'' said Heather B. Weiss, director of the Harvard Family Research Project. She said the program, Healthy Start, ''has the potential not only to prevent abuse, but also to promote family development.''
 
Increase in Reported Abuse
Nationwide, there were 2.2 million reported cases of child abuse in 1987, the most recent year for which figures are available, according to the American Association for Protecting Children, a divison of the American Humane Association.
Hawaii's program, now in its first year of statewide operation, screens about 60 percent of new parents and offers weekly home visits to the 20 percent who are judged to be at risk. Officials said that only about 5 percent of the parents approached had declined to take part. About 75 percent of the parents served by the program are mothers on welfare.
Healthy Start officials said they had heard concern from outside the state that the program's widespread screening could be viewed as an invasion of privacy. But Hawaii state officials said that care is taken to avoid labeling families as potential abusers and to offer help without threats.
 
'There Is No Coercion'
''I don't see this as an invasion of privacy,'' said Betsy Uohara Pratt of the Hawaii Family Stress Center, which supervises the training of counselors in the program. ''We are providing help to families that need it before something goes wrong. Our services are voluntary. There is no coercion.''
Healthy Start begins with the screening of new parents in the hospital shortly after the birth of their child to assess marital status, income, housing, history of substance abuse, family support network and desire for a child.
Ms. Pratt said Healthy Start screeners can often glean danger signs from hospital charts, which, for example, can show that a parent lacks a telephone or a permanent address. Such danger signs lead to follow-up interviews with the parents.
Interviewers try to determine if parents were abused as children if the parents seem to lack self-esteem, if they have difficulty getting along with children and other adults, or if they are hostile or impatient with babies or have been violent toward children in the past.
Parents thought to be prone to commit abuse are offered the services of Healthy Start home visitors, following the family with visits and telephone calls in the years that children are at the highest risk of serious abuse - up to 5 years of age. The visits are weekly for at least six months and then gradually become less frequent. The visitors help teach parents how to deal with their children and also, in an effort to stabilize the family, to help low-income parents make use of social services in the community.
The program is expected to cost about $6 million annually.
While the results of Healthy Start will not be known for several years, the program has already run into one unexpected problem. ''We are finding more severely high-risk families than we expected because of the spread of drug abuse,'' said Gail F. Breakey, director of the Hawaii Family Stress Center in Honolulu, which conducted the three-year pilot program upon which Healthy Start is based.

HEADLINE: Plantation Owners Sell History to Preserve It

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Along the back roads of Louisiana's plantation country, among white-columned mansions and gardens perfumed with sweet olive trees, marketers are busily trying to sell history.
The owners of the graceful houses built more than a century ago, trying to preserve some of the nation's major architectural treasures, have thought up dozens of ways to attract paid visitors, from house tours to bed and breakfast inns to re-enactments of Civil War battles.
But this year the plantation country is roiled by unusual worries. A dozen or more of the great houses are for sale, in large part because of the high cost of mortgages and maintenance. In some cases there is dissension among the descendants of earlier owners. 
 
'Demolition by Neglect'
''Our biggest problem,'' said Donna Fricker, a state historian, ''is demolition by neglect. The climate here is cruel to people and to buildings. Some of these houses may be in the hands of 12 heirs who can't agree on anything and the houses are just falling down.''
What the houses mean to the history-conscious region is more than the price they would bring on the market.
''These are our chateaus of the Loire Valley, our castles on the Rhine,'' said Eugene Cizek, an architecture professor at Tulane University. ''The same kinds of people created them.''
''The design of these houses is as fine as you'll see anywhere in the nation,'' he said. ''On the eve of the Civil War there was more money in the Lower Mississippi Valley per capita than any other place in the New World.''
Keith Marshall, owner of Madewood Plantation House in Napoleonville, said what is going on now is ''almost a replay of the post-Civil War period,'' when economic problems threatened to bring down many of the 400 plantation houses that had survived the Union troops.
 
Decreasing by One a Year
Since then, 300 houses have vanished like the culture that spawned them, victims of demolition, fire or neglect. The houses are now vanishing at the rate of one a year.
''Around the time of the 1984 World's Fair, people thought these houses were great investments,'' Mr. Marshall said. ''Everybody thought they were going to make millions - that the South shall rise again.''
But the hopes of the homeowners were shattered, along with the hopes of the whole region, by the economic downturn in the oil industry.
In most of the best-kept houses, visitors are diligently sought. Oak Alley, on the Mississippi River in Vacherie, built a Christmas bonfire on Dec. 9 and gave a party for 200 people at $50 a ticket.
The bonfire was just one event among many fund-raising efforts for Oak Alley that include house tours, a restaurant, a bed and breakfast operation and, this year, a re-creation of a Civil War battle.
Oak Alley is owned by seven cousins who inherited the house from their great aunt, Josephine Stewart. One of them, Zeb Mayhew, lives in the overseer's cottage and supervises Oak Alley's commercial endeavors. It is satisfying work, he says, but a losing battle in the face the harsh economies to pay high maintenance costs.
But four of the cousins, who live in the Northeast, prefer to sell; Mr. Mayhew does not fault them. ''So much money and effort have already been put into the place by family members,'' he said. ''You can't keep going to the family well.''
And so the house has been on the market for two years. Its price: $4.8 million.
Mrs. Fricker, the historian, believes that the home is a treasure worth preserving. ''I hate to sound magnolia-mouthed,'' she said, ''but Oak Alley represents the pinnacle of 'Gone With the Wind' plantation architecture.''
At Madewood, the price of preservation is vigilance and a range of commercial activities, Mr. Marshall said.
Madewood has rented rooms for several years, ever since an electric bill arrived that was ''$450 larger than the largest bill we'd ever had,'' he said.
''I was in a state of shock,'' he said. Then came a call from three couples asking for overnight accommodations. $150 per Couple per Room ''Without skipping a beat, I said yes,'' Mr. Marshall recalls of the somewhat arbitrary method he chose for setting a price. ''I divided $450 by the three couples and said the price would be $150 per couple for the room dinner and breakfast.''
Without overnight guests, he said, ''We'd have to pay the bills out of our paychecks.'' Mr. Marshall is owner of an art supply business; his wife, Millie Ball, is a reporter for The Times-Picayune.
Mr. Marshall and Ms. Ball entertained 150 people for an early Christmas dinner Dec. 9 at $50 per guest, an event to promote the house as well as to finance a scholarship program for young artists.
On occasion, plantation house owners must take on onerous tasks to promote the past. Mr. Marshall said that one day when a television crew arrived, he dragged his wife ''kicking and screaming into a hoop skirt.''
''She stayed red as a beet all day long,'' he said. ''They wanted us to wave from the balcony. Finally I had to take her hand from behind and lift it for the camera.''

HEADLINE: Motorcyclists Lose in Battle With the Tortoise

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Three desert motorcycle races have been denied Federal operating permits. The denials marked a victory for environmentalists trying to save the desert tortoise.
Ed Hastey, state director for the Federal Bureau of Land Management, said on Monday that the permits for the annual Barstow-to-Las Vegas motorcycle race, the Johnson Valley-to-Parker, Ariz., race and the Parker 400 would be denied indefinitely.
The tortoise was added to the nation's endangered species list as an emergency measure on Aug. 4. Its status will be reviewed next April. The Barstow-to-Las Vegas race, the most popular among off-road enthusiasts, has been fought in court over the years by the Sierra Club, the Wilderness Society and other groups that say it damaged the environment. 
 
Put on Hold in 1975
The race, first run in 1967 with thousands taking part, was put on hold by the bureau for seven years in 1975. It was reinstituted under guidelines that limited participants to 1,200.
In recent years, the Barstow-to-Las Vegas race has ended at the Nevada border, although the name remained. More than 1,100 participants rode this year.
Off-road cyclists said Tuesday that their way of life was the real target in the Government's latest action.
''More ravens kill tortoises than off-road vehicles,'' said Ken Boyd, president of District 37 of the American Motorcycle Association, which oversees the Barstow-to-Las Vegas race. ''But you can't control ravens. It's easier to dictate to people.''
 
Vow to 'Do It Anyway'
Jim Hayes, owner of a Yamaha-Suzuki dealership in Beaumont, said that he has ridden motorcycles in the California desert since 1949 and that many riders will not stop.
''There are so many people who really love this sort of thing and they are going to go out and do it anyway,'' Mr. Hayes said. Some runnings of the Barstow-to-Las Veags race, which is held on Thanksgiving, have seen groups like Earth First! claim responsibility for mismarking courses and laying tire spikes.
A bureau spokeswoman, Barbara Maxfield, said there were problems despite legitimate controls.
''We did find at least two burrows adjacent to the course that were crushed,'' Ms. Maxfield said.
Members of the Sierra Club reported that they, too, had seen riders leaving designated areas and widening corridors that should have been narrow passages. ''To this date, not one single tortoise has been injured or killed,'' said Mr. Boyd of the motorcycle association.
 
Environment Is Also Protected
But because the tortoise is an endangered species, its delicate environment is also protected.
The tortoise's future became critical over the summer, when tortoises began dying of a respiratory ailment. Its survival rate is already threatened by urban sprawl and natural enemies like ravens that peck at its young.
Motorcyclists see a threat to their way of life - for instance, communal gatherings of families at favorite spots for weekends. And while Ms. Maxfield noted that about 100 desert races were not affected by the decision on Monday, motorcyclists interviewed said it was only a matter of time until the rules were widened.
''Don't close down the land,'' said Allen Barbor, of Palmdale. ''Most of it has been used for desert riding for years. You really can't get there by foot, so why not let motorcyclists enjoy it?''
The wear on terrain is precisely the problem, argued a Sierra Club official, Elden Hughes. ''The desert is not there for everyone to destroy,'' he said.
Steve Kassanyi, race director for Score International, sponsor of the Parker 400, called the decision unfair and said it will be challenged.
The ruling is sure to have an adverse economic effect on Barstow, 100 miles northeast of Los Angeles. Attendance for the race is estimated at 4,000 to 5,000 people, raising hotel occupancy to 90 percent of the city's 1,500 hotel rooms.

HEADLINE: With More Machines, That Phone Conversation May Be on Tape

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
A growing number of Americans, accustomed to taping everything from college lectures to television shows, now own answering machines or other devices that allow them to record conversations with their families, friends and business associates.
People tape conversations to keep track of business agreements, to preserve the voices of loved ones and to seek advantage in divorce cases.
They make recordings despite state laws and little-known regulations that ban such activity and in some states make it a crime. But in most states it is not a crime to record your telephone conversations. 
 
Equipment Cheap and Plentiful
And in recent years more and more people are recording their calls. Whereas in the past only telephone companies sold such recording equipment and showed little interest in doing so, today the equipment is as close as the neighborhood electronics store for a modest price.
A survey last June found that 28 percent of American households have answering machines, up from 3 percent at the end of 1983, according to a spokeswoman for the Electronic Industries Association. Major manufacturers say nearly half the models now sold have a feature that permits instantaneous and secret taping of both sides of the conversation.
The growing sales of devices that allow the secret recording of telephone conversations make it ''not at all problematic or unreasonable to conclude that a great many calls of a business or personal nature may be recorded,'' said H. W. William Caming, who retired in 1984 after 19 years as the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's senior counsel for privacy issues and who now advises the American Bar Association on privacy matters.
The technical difficulties of detecting such recording activity has prevented effective regulation, Mr. Caming said.
Federal law makes it a criminal offense for anyone without a court order to intercept other people's conversations without their consent. Sixteen states also make it a criminal offense for people to tape their own telephone conversations without the knowledge of all parties to the calls.
 
Rules Are Seldom Enforced
Little-known regulations passed by the Federal Communications Commission and most state regulatory authorities also bar taping without the knowledge of all parties or without the use of a beep tone. But the regulations are seldom enforced, and their legality has been in question since Congress passed a law in 1968 that said taping by one party in the conversation is not a Federal crime.
Yet, lawyers and sociologists specializing in privacy issues said, the ability to record telephone calls with a home answering machine that sells for less than $100 at most consumer electronics stores may be making Americans less disapproving of the practice and more guarded in their conversations.
Many people are becoming inured to secret recordings, said David F. Linowes, a professor of political economy at the University of Illinois who was the chairman of a Presidential commission that studied privacy issues after revelations in 1973 that President Richard M. Nixon secretly and routinely recorded his conversations.
''Right now, we're offended when that occurs,'' Mr. Linowes said, ''but we're becoming less and less so. We're becoming hardened, emboldened. We're learning to reflect on what we say in communications, especially on the telephone.''
The recording of telephone calls received national attention earlier this month when a kicker for the Dallas Cowboys football team, Luis Zendejas, said he had secretly taped a conversation with a Philadelphia Eagles coach. Mr. Zendejas alleged that Al Roberts, the Eagles' special-teams coach, told him a bounty had been offered to any player who could injure Mr. Zendejas or the Cowboys' quarterback, Troy Aikman.
After a game with the Eagles last Sunday, Mr. Zendejas said, ''I record all my conversations. I'm in the public eye. I record all my friends' calls.''
The National Football League said an investigation had found no evidence to support Mr. Zendejas's allegations of a bounty. He refused to release the tape, citing the illegality of his taping an interstate call.
 
Some Machines Have Beepers
Not all answering machines permit soundless taping. The Panasonic Company makes answering machines that generate a periodic warning beep when conversations are being recorded. But the answering machines made by four large rival companies, A.T.&T., the Cobra Dynascan Corporation, PhoneMate Inc. and the Code-A-Phone Corporation, do not produce a tone. And many consumer electronics stores sell small boxes that plug into a telephone line and activate a tape recorder whenever the phone receiver is lifted. Those boxes cost $20 to $50.
''People with money always had this at their disposal, but now you see people at a lesser economic scale wanting to do the same,'' said Jairo A. Cuenca, the owner of the Proof Company, a Manhattan firm that sells investigative devices. Mr. Cuenca and privacy experts said that the falling cost and improved quality of telephone recordings, coupled with growing public tolerance, accounted for the increased interest in taping.
The Federal Communications Commission, A.T.&T. and others have made fruitless attempts to measure the extent of secret home taping. ''There's no way to tell,'' Mr. Caming said.
An electronic eavesdropping detection consultant in Clinton, N.J., Kevin D. Murray,, said it remains virtually impossible to detect a tape recorder on the other end of a telephone line.
Demand for equipment to tape telephone conversations is strong, said salesmen at three telephone equipment stores in New York, while salesmen in Cincinnati, Denver and Los Angeles stores said demand was less there.
Most customers who want to record phone calls secretly are age 25 to 40, said Calvin Rowland, a salesman at the Phone Booth, a store in midtown Manhattan. Shoppers looking for an answering machine tend to be very enthusiastic when shown how to record a conversation, he said. ''When you mention that it's a feature on an answering machine, they say, 'That's great, I can really use that.' ''
 
Confusion Exists Over Laws
Other vendors say they suspect that few customers take advantage of the capability. ''It's just a feature that's on there; I don't think many people use it,'' said Robert B. Miller, the vice president for merchandising at Radio Shack, one of the nation's biggest retail sellers of answering machines.
Considerable confusion exists about the laws and regulations governing the taping of telephone conversations.
At the end of a recent telephone interview with somone in Manhattan, Jon S. Hiltunen, the manager of media relations at the Dictaphone Corporation headquarters in Stratford, Conn., was asked whether he had secretly taped the conversation. Mr. Hiltunen said he had, since Connecticut requires only one party in a conversation to consent to any recording.
''You bet I will exercise my prerogative'' to tape, Mr. Hiltunen said. ''I see nothing wrong with that.''
But a lawyer with the Federal Communications Commission, Angel M. Cartagena of the common carrier bureau, said Mr. Hiltunen's action, al though not a violation of Federal eavesdropping statutes, was nonetheless a violation of the commission's rules requiring that all parties to an interstate or international be aware they are being taped.

GRAPHIC: A variety of gadgets are now available to people who want to record their phone conversations. Yash Jesrani, owner of the Phone Boutique in Manhattan, demonstrated a device that silently activates a tape recorder (The New York Times/Linda M. Baron)

HEADLINE: Goldin to Open a Financial Consulting Firm

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

 BODY:
Harrison J. Goldin, who failed dismally in his attempt to spring from the City Comptroller's office to the mayoralty, plans to open a financial consulting firm specializing in advising troubled businesses and municipalities.
Mr. Goldin said on Friday that the firm, which will be called Goldin Associates, will open on Jan. 2 with offices in the General Motors Building. It will be a joint venture with Baker Nye Investments, a long-established firm in Manhattan. He described Baker Nye as ''my investors'' but said he will be the major owner of the new firm. 
The 53-year-old Mr. Goldin, who leaves the Comptroller's post this month after 16 years, said he is eager to begin his new career. He considered other job options after finishing at the bottom of a four-man Democratic mayoral primary on Sept. 12, but decided financial advising ''is a niche for which I am exceedingly well suited.''
 
Less Than 3 Percent of the Vote
''We are entering a period, unfortunately, of economic distress in this country,'' Mr. Goldin said. ''You can hardly pick up the newspaper every day without reading about companies that are over-leveraged when the underlying business is sound, ones in which the financial structure is killing what would otherwise be a workable enterprise. It's clear that a number of those situations are going to explode.''
Mr. Goldin received less than 3 percent of the vote in the Democratic mayoral primary, in which David N. Dinkins, the Manhattan Borough President, also defeated Mayor Edward I. Koch and Richard Ravitch, the former head of the Charter Revision Commission. Mr. Dinkins will be sworn in as mayor on Jan. 1, as will Elizabeth Holtzman, who succeeds Mr. Goldin as comptroller.
Mr. Goldin, who earned $105,000 for running the 1,000-person Comptroller's office, said he will enjoy the financial advantages of the private sector.
''I'm very satisfied with my financial prospects,'' he said. ''It represents an extraordinary opportunity to make up to my family what they might have had in the many years I was in public service.
 
Living Higher 'Off the Lamb'
''Maybe we'll live a little higher off the hog, or I should say a little higher off the lamb,'' said Mr. Goldin, who does not eat pork.
Mr. Goldin, who had a political reputation as both cerebral and ambitious, appeared serene while reflecting on his public career, including his failed attempt to become mayor.
''I think what happened was clear,'' he said. ''An early poll showed me at 20 percent and that seemed a very good base from which to launch a mayoralty campaign. What happened was the focus at one point became a two-man race and voters became convinced that if they did not choose one of the two front-runners it was the equivalent of staying home.''
He said the results did not make him cynical.
''I've lost before,'' he said, referring to his unsuccessful race for state comptroller in 1978. ''I've learned that whether you lose by a hair or lose by a country mile, either way they don't pay for place or show.''
Mr. Goldin, a lifelong New Yorker, was a civil rights lawyer and investment counselor before entering politics. He was elected to the New York State Senate in 1965 and served four terms before being elected in 1973 to the first of four terms as Comptroller. He said he viewed his accomplishments as Comptroller ''with immense satisfaction,'' particularly the modernization of accounting, budget control and information systems; the sound investment of city pension funds, and the creation of revenue by investing available city funds overnight.
Determined to leave office as a statesman, Mr. Goldin had kind words last week for Mayor Koch, with whom he has waged a long and occasionally bitter feud.
''Ed Koch can look back on some important achievements,'' he said. ''He inherited a city that was dispirited . . . and by sheer verve and energy he helped to create a sense of excitement and of possibilities.''
And the Mayor's failures? ''They've been so heavily written about, why should I try to discuss them?''

HEADLINE: New Yorkers of All Ages Receive Aid From Neediest Case Fund Agencies;
Helping 'Total Child' Takes a United Effort

BYLINE: By PHILIP COLTOFF; Executive Director, The Children's Aid Society

 BODY:
Now that the excitement of New York City's election is over and a new mayor is in office, a critical task lies ahead. A new beginning is at hand with the awesome responsibility of bringing this city out of a myriad of complex economic and social problems that affect the poor and needy. But the responsibility for these changes does not lie with the mayor alone. Guided by his leadership, we all share this responsibility and need to play a part to get the city back on track - and in particular, to help the thousands of poor children and their families who are in such desperate need.
While government can set the guidelines and play a major role in overseeing this effort, it cannot handle these problems alone. There needs to be a grass-roots effort led by New York's not-for-profit organizations to bring the community together, united in the pursuit of a better city. These organizations already make up the core of our neighborhoods. They understand the issues, the problems, the people. 
New York's not-for-profit organizations have been created by civic-minded individuals or groups to provide basic, essential services often complementing or substituting for government programs. They provide the children's services, run the local libraries, operate the zoos - often at a lower cost, more efficiently, with clearer accountability and more visible outcomes than those projects assumed by government. This is what The Children's Aid Society strives for and what will help us to meet the growing needs of our city's neediest people, its children.
The Children's Aid Society, one of New York's oldest private child-welfare agencies, has never settled for simply providing for basic human needs - food, clothing and shelter. As a full-service agency, we know that love is not enough, but certainly, neither are the basics. We strive to provide services to help the ''total child'' - insuring a safe and secure home life, providing health care, educational services and recreation for preschoolers through teen-agers. Perhaps our greatest contribution is offering each child a value system that will help to create solid, self-sufficient citizens.
As we look around us, we cannot avoid seeing and hearing about the problems of the city. There is more child abuse, more drugs, more crime and more spending of tax dollars to solve these problems. They are ever present and people often reach the saturation point, not wanting to hear any more bad news.
Not-for-profit organizations and social services agencies must take the lead on these issues. They have become our best hope as advocates for New York's poor, our best hope for creating solutions. We at The Children's Aid Society believe that advocacy is best accomplished through example. By tackling a problem head-on as it develops, we are best equipped to identify the cause and best qualified to argue a solution. To best serve the neediest in our city, the social service agencies must continue to work to solve these problems and then, when we propose a solution for others to carry out, we have already tested an effective cure.
And there is good news too. It is often hard to find, behind reports of crack addiction, AIDS and racial attacks. But there are young people concerned about racial tension who are getting together in Harlem, Yorkville, Greenwich Village and the Upper West Side to make sure what happened in Bensonhurst never happens in their neighborhoods. Many parents and teen-agers are concerned about positive values and are working hard to pass these values on to their children and community.
The Children's Aid Society continues to create programs to confront New York's pressing problems. Our Teen Pregnancy Prevention Program, now in its fifth year, stands as a sterling example of how a community-based effort can overcome a social dilemma, providing teen-agers with the tools to realize positive alternatives to teen-age parenthood. This autumn, as a response to the hundreds of requests from social-service agencies nationwide that seek to replicate this highly successful intervention service, we have opened our Bernice and Milton Stern National Training Center for Family Life Education, which will train social workers, educators and health professionals in our holistic approach to this crisis.
Our PINS - Persons in Need of Supervision - family court diversion and mediation program, which was begun as a pilot project 10 years ago, is now mandatory by state law. This counseling service has proven that, with proper guidance, even severe family problems can be resolved without the children having to be removed from their homes.
The Children's Aid Society Career Readiness Program provides more than 300 high school students with what it takes to reach career goals. Along with tutoring, educational guidance, preparation for job interviews, contacts and job leads, the program also provides financial assistance and lots of encouragement. This practical program has helped more than 90 percent of the participants stay in school, with some even attending prep schools and a large percentage attending college.
In further response to our concern for the ''total child,'' The Children's Aid Society is currently developing a Community Leaders Program meant to address all aspects of a child's development. The goal of the program is to foster young people with the strength of character, education, values and goals needed to transcend the problems of drugs, pregnancy and poverty - young people who can serve as community leaders and positive role models for future generations.
New York City's new administration offers us a great opportunity to take a fresh look at where we are as a city, where we need to go and how we are going to get there. It is an opportunity for the powerful voice of not-for-profits to be heard - including the hundreds of thousands of volunteers who are the backbone of New York. Not-for-profits represent every aspect of our lives and so together we can support not only the ''total child,'' but also the ''total city.'' With a strong wave of support from this city's broad volunteer sector, in the tradition and spirit of our ancestors, New Yorkers can and must come to the aid of its suffering citizens.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THEATERZ;
An Actor Relives the Sorrows of His Homeland

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG

 BODY:
John Kani wears a chip on his shoulder like a badge of honor. He has earned it, for his talents as South Africa's most prominent black actor have been forged against the anvil of apartheid.
''We look at 1989. Every white liberal and black moderate says there has been change,'' Mr. Kani said recently over lunch at Harridan's, a restaurant in the oasis of interracial informality defined by the Market Theater here. ''I still don't vote. I still live in a segregated area with inferior facilities. My children are still pumped with inferior education that makes them servants of the white man. There is now less work for more of my people. The important thing is I still haven't got the right to be.''
It is a testimonial to Mr. Kani's craftsmanship that he conveys an altogether different impression in Athol Fugard's new play, ''My Children, My Africa,'' which had its premiere at the Market Theater in June and which he is accompanying to New York for its American debut tomorrow at the Perry Street Theater in Greenwich Village. 
Mr. Kani plays Anele Myalatya, an amiable schoolteacher bubbling with a desperate good will; Mr. M., as he calls himself, hopes that by teaming up his favorite black pupil with a white schoolgirl in a national literary competition he will vindicate the ill-paid years that he has spent toiling in a separate and unequal educational system. His dream is shattered, and heself-destructs when racial unrest ravages his shabby black township. Both the play and Mr. Kani's performance were uniformly saluted in Johannesburg.
''It's a good part, it's a great part, it's a difficult part just to live with,'' said the 46-year-old actor. It is also a part he might not have accepted but for his long friendship with Mr. Fugard because he perceives of Mr. M. as a collaborator, however unwitting, with the white minority Government.
Mr. Kaniand his wife, Princess, now live in the middle-class area of Soweto, the segregated black township south of Johannesburg where they have brought up their five children, aged 5 to 22. But he came out of an areasimilar to that of Mr. M. One of his brothers spent five years as a political prisoner on Robben Island, South Africa's version of Alcatraz, and another was killed in the racial unrest that erupted across the country. John Kani himself spent 15 days in detention without charge or trial.
But when a plum role presented itself, an actor's instincts eclipsed those of a militant. ''It is an important part in the actor's career,'' Mr. Kani said of the role that Athol Fugard wrote for him. ''You can't always play the hero. You have to play the villain.'' His justification for accepting the role was that Mr. Fugard's play was based on a real incident. ''When I tell a story, I have to tell it honestly,'' he said. ''I know of teachers who are still ringing bells in the ruins of burned-out schools. All I ask is, is there a man like this who was there?''
Mr. Kani grew up in New Brighton, a black township srawling around the Indian Ocean city of Port Elizabeth. His father was a policeman who sometimes brought prisoners home for a meal before taking them to jail. He was forced into early retirement, Mr. Kani said, after he arrested a couple of white burglars and marched them handcuffed through downtown Port Elizabeth, outraging some whites who thought black policemen were paid to catch black criminals.
The family had no money to send John Kani to university. ''I woke up one morning and I stood in front of my father's house and I said, 'This is not my life.' I'd never be a lawyer, which I wanted to be. I would have a drab job like my next-door neighbor and it frightened me. I said, 'No, no, I deserve a little more than this.' '' So at 18 years of age, Mr. Kani said, he decided to become an actor because he had performed in a few school plays and loved storytelling. A friend told him that a troupe calling itself the Serpent Players needed a walk-on for a production of ''Antigone.'' The others at the rehearsal were black except for a wiry man wearing a beard and a shabby brown sweater. ''I thought he was the caretaker of the theater,'' Mr. Kani recalled.
In fact, he was Athol Fugard, at 29 the troupe's director and an emerging playwright. Mr. Kani didn't trust him. ''I was very suspicious of these white people,'' he said. ''I had heard stories of white people sucking the veins of black people and writing strange stories about us and making millions.''
But as Mr. Fugard drew a parallel between the resistance to tyranny in the ancient Greece of ''Antigone'' and the black struggle in South Africa, Mr. Kani's skepticism wavered. ''There was something about him talking to the actors that touched something within me that needed to be touched,'' he recalled. He refused Mr. Fugard's invitations to dinner, but he did begin borrowing his books. ''I'd ask, 'Give me a book to read,' and I'd stay up two nights and return it. A very important thing developed between us. I began to trust him and his motives. Then we became friends.''
It was not an easy thing to do in 1965, when crossing the color line was not only hazardous but also illegal. The authorities assumed there was something subversive about black actors and a white director putting on a play together.
Five members of the troupe disappeared into prison, Mr. Kani said, and the security police visited him at home. Mr. Fugard was labeled a Communist for consorting with blacks.
The security forces also sabotaged their performances. ''We'd work for weeks and weeks and hire a hall and the day of the opening, they'd come and close the hall,'' Mr. Kani said. But the Serpent Players managed to stage Mr. Fugard's early plays, including ''Sizwe Banzi Is Dead.'' In 1973, they were invited to perform ''Sizwe Banzi'' in London.
From London they took ''Sizwe Banzi'' and a new Fugard play, ''The Island,'' to the United States. Mr. Kani and his friend Winston Ntshona shared a Tony Award in 1975 for their performances of the plays on Broadway.
''We said, 'My God, the world is not like New Brighton. It's bigger than that,' '' Mr. Kani said. ''I came back with the realization that my dream of a nonracial society was not a hallucination. Apartheid is a lie, people can work together, people can create together.''
Mr. Kani moved through a succession of roles in Fugard plays like '' 'Master Harold' . . . and the Boys'' in which he brought the black experience increasingly to white audiences. He takes issue with those critics who have declared that black protest in the theater made its point and that it is time to move on.
Such theater, he said, is an integral part of the struggle against apartheid. ''Work that is called protest or black theater is actually work that reflects what is happening in the townships,'' Mr. Kani said. ''I should call it a theater that reminds people, talks to people, affects people.''
Even so, Mr. Kani, who has directed theater workshops in Soweto, conceded that a lot of political plays haven't been very good.
''I believe strongly that the word 'protest' is no excuse for bad work. The artist must create,'' he said. ''But we live in a country that is dominated by inequalities. We are eroded and damaged by Bantu education. There are young men with stories in their souls. Mistakes must be made. My part is to assist in my experience, to say this is the format, this is how it is done. ''We have people with stories they have to tell but no craft in telling it. But the truth they deal with is something I couldn't deny.''
Moreover, while the state's Arts Council has subsidized white theaters in South Africa - the self-supporting Market Theater is a penurious exception - Mr. Kani noted that there is not a single theater in a black township and that if he mounts a production in such a community, its quality is compromised by the poor facilities. Even the political climate, he said, will not allow it. ''The first problem black theater encounters in this country is South Africa itself. We live in a perpetual state of emergency.''
Mr. Kani said it was hard for blacks to survive as actors, politically as well as economically. ''Every artist who began to blossom was nipped in the bud by the security authorities, either by intimidation or detention.''
The current laws, he said, forbid more than a few people to assemble for political purposes under one roof. And army patrols through the townships have inhibited people from going out at night.
''Where do you do the play?'' Mr. Kani asked. ''When I as an actor want to be in a theater, I have to leave the black zone.''
The stage of the Market Theater is where Mr. Kani has usually performed. It wasintegrated long before other theaters and movie houses in Johannesburg. ''As a black person, I feel comfortable at the Market Theater,'' he said. ''I'm not here by permission.'' He refuses, he said, to perform in a theater for whites, even when it admits blacks by exception. He also turns down parts that he thinks demean blacks, which he said limited his earnings. He recently turned down a part in the action film ''Red Scorpion'' that would have required him to play a guerrilla beholden to whites. ''I don't play a role when a black takes his hat off to a white without showing he's a man,'' he said. ''That's not for me. A man must have respect and dignity.''
But he allows for those trapped in the quagmire of prejudice. His role as Mr. M. reveals the teacher's quiet rage at a flawed educational system he outwardly represents. ''I want my man to say, I am a man, not a 'boy,' '' Mr. Kani said.
Yet even Mr. Kani sometimes needs a holiday from apartheid. ''There is a side of me that must learn the craft, aside from being a fighter,'' he said. In 1987, he starred in a production of ''Othello'' directed by the South African actress Janet Suzman at the Market Theater. And earlier this year, he played the sassy chauffeur in a South African tour of the Pulitzer-Prize-winning American play ''Driving Miss Daisy.'' ''I'm not an example of how far a black actor can go in South Africa,'' Mr. Kani said. ''I am an exception. I cannot attribute it to change in this country. I am what I am without the compliments of the Government and the Arts Council.''
But Mr. Kani has matured in stature playing the kind of people that he grew up among in New Brighton. He has resisted directing, he said, because ''I'm still selfish as an artist. I want to be under the lights.'' Most of his work has been with Mr. Fugard, with the occasional film. His latest movie role was a supporting part as an investigator gathering depositions on police torture in ''A Dry White Season,'' which was filmed in Zimbabwe with Donald Sutherland, Marlon Brando and Janet Suzman.
Recognition as an actor has mellowed Mr. Kani since his angrieryouth. But his close friendship with Athol Fugard does not extend to many other whites, though he admitted that he had begun to see ''a lovely coming together among white and black South Africans.''
For now, if he had to count his white friends, the actor said, he could not complete the fingers on his hand. ''I do not believe that the black person qualifies as a human being in a white person's dictionary,'' Mr. Kani said. ''Even when white people come to understand a black person's situation, it is in the form of condescension or curiosity.''
 
HIS DAUGHTER, HIS PLAY
 Athol Fugard dedicated his new play, ''My Children, My Africa,'' to John Kani and to his daughter, Lisa Fugard, who, with Courtney B. Vance, co-stars in the New York Theater Workshop production at the Perry Street Theater.
''I wrote it with them in mind, hoping that they would take the roles,'' said the 57-year-old playwright (in photograph with his daughter), who is directing the play here, as he did its premiere production at the Market Theater in Johannesburg earlier this year.
But, he said, ''Both Lisa and I realized we were venturing into enormously dangerous territory. She is an emerging actress in her first major role, and what a responsibility for her to carry - the success of her father's play. If anything had gone wrong it could have had terrible consequences both for her career and for our relationship, which is very deep. She said she had to trust me completely, and she did, and from a potentially Oedipal situation we've developed a simple professional relationship between a director and a young actress.''
The 27-year-old actress, who has lived in the United States since 1980, has had some small roles in Off Off Broadway productions and soap operas. She said that at first she was ''sick at the thought'' of working with her father. ''It absolutely terrified me. I was afraid of being in a rehearsal room with someone who knew me so well - I wasn't sure I would allow myself to open up. But I had read the play and wanted to do the part, and when he told me that John would be playing Mr. M.''- the teacher who brings the white girl and the black student together - ''I couldn't pass it up.''
The actual process of being directed by her father was easy and direct, perhaps, she said, because ''I'm old enough now not to be connected to him in all sorts of complicated teen-age ways. Sometimes I'd look at him and think, oh, my God, that's my father, but I had to put that out of my head.''
''I had long wanted to bring John and Lisa together in the theater,'' said Mr. Fugard. ''John has known Lisa since she was very young and would bounce on his knee. That they can perform together in a play like this that tries to get at the challenges of being a South African - as they both are - is a wonderful act of defiance. It shows that you can beat the system.''
 
- Jan Benzel
