HEADLINE: PROSPECTS;
Why Gold Is So Bright

BYLINE: By JOEL KURTZMAN

 BODY:
Gold prices have risen sharply since September, from about $360 an ounce to $425 an ounce in early December before falling back to $408.25 at the close on Friday. Are we poised for another bull market in gold? Four precious metals analysts offer their views.
 
Vahid Fathi
Vice president, Prescott, Ball & Turben Inc., Cleveland.
When gold has consolidated itself so it has a solid base at $400 an ounce, then its next move will be to $425. This will occur in the first quarter. But over the long term, prices will be sharply higher. 
The key catalyst for the price of gold moving upward has been its price in foreign currencies. Western Europe is closer to Eastern Europe than we are and it feels the dramatic changes. The price of gold in Swiss francs, West German marks and in Japanese yen is now moving upward after declining in those currencies since 1980. This is an important factor. No one should consider it a bull market for gold if only the price in dollars goes up. It has to rise in the other currencies as well.
 
Frederick R. Demler
Metals economist, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.
Gold will reach higher levels in the first quarter of the new year. We think it will get to between $445 and $450 an ounce in the first quarter. We think a recession will occur in the United States next year and gold usually hits its high before a recession.
The fundamentals have improved for gold since last September. The world's finance ministers met at the International Monetary Fund and World Bank and agreed that the dollar was too high. The economy is showing weakness, which has led to an easing of interest rates and that is good for gold. Volatility in the equities market has meant that there has been a shift from equities to gold. Also, the Japanese Government now allows insurance companies that don't sell life insurance to have up to 2 percent of their portfolios in gold. This is bullish.
 
James R. Steel
Metals analyst, Refco Inc.
Gold will reach $450 an ounce over the next month or so. I think it will hold that level reasonably well. There is enough demand to keep it at that level for some time.
Next year, 10 percent less gold will be mined than this year and this year 10 percent less gold was mined than last year. The most easily accessible supply has already been tapped.
There is a school of thought that says the Soviet Union will get into worse economic trouble and sell its gold. I think this is unlikely. The Soviet Union will get ample credits from the World Bank and the I.M.F., so it won't have to sell its gold. This is the bullish side.
On the bearish side, this is the era of deflation, not inflation. Japan does not have strong inflation, nor does any European country, except Britain. As far as interest rates go, I don't think they will come down to the point where there is a bullish sentiment for gold.
 
Bette Raptopoulos
Metals analyst, Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.
I expect gold to be at $450 an ounce by February. It could go even higher if the situations in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union intensify.
Gold began to move higher when the dollar fell and interest rates eased. I expect interest rates to ease further, reflecting a slower economy. The sharp sell-off in the stock market last October moved fund managers to include gold in their portfolios. Also the Japanese have been buying bullion.
There is a credible view that the Soviet Union, the second-largest gold producer, may use gold to support the ruble. This will mean that it will not sell gold and prices will go higher.
The down side for gold would be if there were a strong improvement in the economy and firmer interest rates. This in turn would firm the dollar. However, turmoil in the Soviet Union remains the dominant bullish factor for gold.

HEADLINE: Arms Makers Gird for Peace

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS

 BODY:
WAR is a dirty business. But for makers of guns, tanks and planes, it is a profitable one.
Now, with the cold war coming to an end, a new age is upon those nations that pointed weapons at each other and the companies that make the weapons. Gone is the day when America's military contractors could count on a steady stream of Government projects to fatten the bottom line. For them, there is a new battle - a fight for profits in an environment where, unfortunately, peace is bad for their business.
Here, at the General Dynamics Corporation, the nation's No. 2 military supplier, this is a time of intense soul-searching. ''As individuals, we are extremely thrilled by the recent peace initiatives,'' said Stanley C. Pace, chief executive of the company, which makes the Air Force's F-16 ''Fighting Falcon,'' the Navy's nuclear-powered Trident submarine and the Army's M1 Abrams tank. But from a business perspective, the situation is far less thrilling. Mr. Pace speaks openly about downsizing, layoffs and possible mergers - not only for General Dynamics but for the entire industry. ''We've all come from smaller companies,'' Mr. Pace said. ''We can all go back to being smaller companies.'' 
They actually may have no choice. In response to reduced world tensions and to domestic fiscal pressures, Defense Secretary Richard B. Cheney last month proposed that deep budget cuts be made, which by some estimates could reduce military spending by 40 percent or more by the end of the decade. Clearly, the nation's military industry will be very different from what it is today. By all calculations, it will be significantly smaller, and getting there will be painful. Some military contractors will survive. Some will not. Some will merge and some will be taken over. And many will become shadows of their former selves.
''For military contractors, it will be rag tag, rough and tumble and dog-eat-dog,'' said William Anders, an astronaut and former Textron Inc. executive who will become vice chairman of General Dnaymics next month and replace Mr. Pace in 1991. ''It's going to be a bloodletting and the guy with the most blood will win.''
Thanks to the cold war military buildup, General Dynamics and its arms-making brethren have become corporate giants. Some 85 percent of General Dynamics' $9.5 billion in annual sales comes from Government contracts. At Lockheed, it is 91 percent; at Northrop, 92 percent; at McDonnell Douglas, 64 percent, and at Martin Marietta, 85 percent. For some, dropping just one program can spell trouble. At the Grumman Corporation, where 90 percent of sales come from the Government, the proposed cancellation of the Navy F-14 will wipe out 20 percent of sales.
Because General Dynamics sells so broadly to all three branches of the service, it is a microcosm of military spending and a proxy for the industry. ''As the defense budget goes, so goes General Dynamics,'' said Lawrence J. Korb, a Brookings Institution director and a former assistant Defense Secretary. ''If the defense budget goes down by 50 percent, General Dynamics goes down by 50 percent. It's hard to see how they will escape.''
 
Stick to the Knitting
While hardly sanguine, the company argues that it is better situated than many competitors because of a conservative strategy charted several years ago. It decided not to extend its resources by undertaking acquisitions or risky or experimental military projects, as many have. Instead, it took a stick-to-the-knitting approach by diversifying among all branches of the service and by specializing in ''heartland'' weapons - bread-and-butter armaments that may well be needed even in the post-cold war era. ''We feel the Government will maintain heartland programs at some level,'' Mr. Pace said. ''That makes us more insulated from the cuts than our competition.''
For instance, General Dynamics believes the Government will still need M1 tanks, although fewer of them, that the SSN-21 ''Seawolf'' attack submarine will probably still be made, and that the Air Force will still need new F-16 fighter planes. It also expects programs still on the drawing board, like the Navy's A-14 advanced tactical aircraft to be funded at some modest level.
Yet even General Dynamics concedes that it may have to shrink to survive. ''Nothing says we have to be a $10 billion company,'' Mr. Pace said. ''We cut to fit. If we don't have business, we have to cut.''
Wall Street seems to respect that realism. ''General Dynamics looks at the future through gray-colored glasses,'' said Gary J. Reich, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ''Rose colored is optimistic. With gray, they don't see too far and what they see, they don't necessarily like.''
How individual contractors fare depends, in part, on where the budgetary ax falls and how they manage with what is left. ''Some companies will do very well, said John F. Lehman Jr., a managing director of Paine Webber Inc. and a former Navy Secretary. ''But the larger number will face a very bleak future.'' Said Robert Paulson, a director at McKinsey & Company: ''Picture a defense budget that is a third smaller. You can't keep the defense industry alive on two-thirds rations. Something's got to give.''
That simple fact raises a host of public-policy questions: Are there national interests to consider in determining which contractors survive? Should the Government step in to ''protect'' critical technologies, even at the expense of propping up inefficient manufacturers? Who should decide which companies survive - the Government, Congress or free-market forces? Is a smaller industry a weaker one? And do we, as a nation, want to fund military contractors at minimal production levels to keep capacity in reserve, or can we no longer afford that luxury?
To some, the nation's military establishment is, in effect, undergoing deregulation. ''One could think of defense as the last industry to be deregulated,'' said Mr. Paulson of McKinsey. ''It will be affected the same as airlines, banking and trucking.''
 
New Targets
With Government budgets shrinking and the Pentagon less willing to pick up the contractor's development and manufacturing costs, these companies may have to look to new places for profits - to new markets overseas, to work that was once given out to subcontractors, and perhaps into entirely new lines of business. ''You expect that big companies will take market share from weaker, less well financed and less capable ones who made just pieces of tanks, ships and planes,'' said Joseph Campbell, an analyst at Paine Webber.
But no matter what strategy a contractor chooses, there will be problems. Ironically, military contractors are ill prepared to wean themselves from the comforting bosom of what many call ''Penatagon socialism.'' Despite the strength of their products and their gigantic size, military contractors are weak when it comes to playing by the rules of free-market capitalism. They complain about the stiff infighting for contracts. Still, they have operated in a rarefied climate that has insulated them from the rougher edges of real-world competition. After all, they must keep only one customer satisfied - one that, in industry lexicon, is simply referred to as ''The Customer.''
It is an unusual and forgiving customer: one that cares primarily about performance and little about price. It is a customer that has historically kicked in for research and development and picked up some of the manufacturing costs. If there were cost overruns, well, the customer picked up that tab, too.
As a result, military contractors are masters at superb engineering, but are less schooled in manufacturing with efficiency. ''The military will do anything for a 5 percent increase in speed or accuracy,'' said Eugene J. Carroll, the deputy director of the Center for Defense Information and a retired Rear Admiral. ''Improved performance has justified massive cost increases and this makes contractors ill suited to compete with products made at a reasonable price.''
What is more, this performance orientation breeds conservatism and risk-aversion. Victory, for contractors, comes from sticking to specifications - not from challenging them.
''The Pentagon tends to ruin a company for commercial business,'' said Mr. Lehman, the former Navy Secretary. Its demands, he said, ''drive very, very high overhead rates that make military contractors, generally, not competitive in the commercial environment. Most companies will have a difficult time because they don't have the management to shift the culture from Pentagon socialism to commercial competitiveness.''
Outside the protected Pentagon environment, however, competition is likely to be cutthroat. For instance, Europe, the largest foreign market, may turn out to be more of a competitor than a customer. Already, in anticipation of the lowering of trade barriers in 1992, many European nations - most notably, West Germany - are consolidating and strengthening their weapons-related companies. They will compete with American contractors in the global marketplace - as well as at a budget-conscious Pentagon. This also comes at a time when NATO nations are expected to cut back on military expenditures because of tapering global tensions.
 
A Sharp Turn
Diversification is equally problematic. Shifting from tanks to toasters is not easy, as the industry's dismal record of switching to consumer goods attests. Take, for instance, Grumman's ill-fated forays into buses, solar energy and refrigerators. ''Government contractors are quasi-utilities,'' said Mr. Reich of Shearson. ''Just because the Government changes its requirements doesn't mean they could turn around and instead of tanks, make ice cream blenders. They are really stuck.''
Besides, it is politically unwise for military contractors to abandon defense projects too quickly. ''The industry is being held hostage,'' said Mr. Paulson of McKinsey. ''Diverting the best talent and money away from defense will not get you any more defense business.'' Mr. Korb of Brookings agrees: ''The industry can't antagonize the folks in the Pentagon. They don't want the Pentagon to say that they are giving up.''
None of the huge contractors, of course, will go out of business tomorrow. There will be much political wrangling in Washington before specific programs are cut. Besides, even with the cuts, the Government's annual expenditure for military procurement is expected to be around $150 billion - still an enormous sum.
''General Dynamics has a unique collection of capabilities, which, in light of the fairly uninspiring record in terms of humanity's ability to maintain civil discourse, is likely to be needed,'' said Wolfgang Demisch, an analyst with UBS Securities.
Still, General Dynamics has already cut about 400 of its 100,000 workers because of an order slowdown. And it plans to cut its $400 million research budget. Mr. Pace has been traveling to Washington to stress the importance, from a defense standpoint, of continuing to improve the design and manufacturing of military hardware, even at low levels. ''We cannot allow our technological capability or our production ability to go to zero or the U.S. might not have them when we need it,'' he said.
The company, after all, is vulnerable. For instance, should the Government sign a strategic arms limitation pact, it would need fewer nuclear warheads and submarines to carry them. The Navy might need only 16 or 17 Trident submarines, a big-ticket product for General Dynamics, instead of some two dozen.
The company is phasing out production of the SSN-688 Los Angeles class attack submarine, a big money-loser. Submarines accounted for about 16 percent of the company's revenues, but for only about 6 percent of its operating earnings. While it hopes to do better with its successor, the SSN-21 ''Seawolf'' attack submarine, this product may also be ill fated. Mr. Pace expects the Seawolf to be built, but at a rate of perhaps two or so a year instead of four or more. The ''Seawolf'' is an offensive weapon, designed to go under the polar ice cap to attack. But if the Russians make fewer ballistic submarines, there is less need for attack submarines to go after them.
The most profitable product in the company's arsenal is the F-16 ''Fighting Falcon,'' an Air Force attack aircraft. In 1988, the F-16 accounted for about 60 percent of the company's operating profits - or $318 million - and 35 percent of its revenues. But the F-16's operating earnings are being eaten away by the high cost of meeting the requirements of foreign buyers and by the many versions of the plane available. Worse, orders for F-16 are expected to decline.
In development are two other planes whose prospects are equally chancy. One is the Navy's A-12 advanced tactical aircraft, a heavy carrier-based plane that can drop bombs. Mr. Pace said he expects it to be financed at modest levels, although some analysts disagree. The other is the ATF advanced tactical fighter for the Air Force, a ground-based plane that drops missiles on land sites and is the successor to the F-15. General Dynamics has joined Boeing and Lockheed to develop the ATF in competition with another team in a ''win or lose'' process. So far, the company has spent about $200 million to develop the ATF, with no assurance it will get any of it back.
The company makes the M1 Abrams tank, and has the only major tank-making operation in the West. But last year, the Army cut its M1 orders to 720 a year, from 840, forcing the company to seek new clients, in the Middle East, for example, where the terrain is suited for tank warfare.
For now, the company plans to stick to its current product line and not pursue acquisitions. Part of this is due to a deferred tax bill of $975 million, due over the next two years, that will use up free cash. Still, it is not saying no too emphatically. ''There are no obvious mergers, although something may arise,'' said Mr. Rogers, the company's president. ''We're not actively pursuing it. But we're not closing the door.''
Indeed, from General Dynamics' perspective, the future may not be all that bleak. Mr. Pace takes comfort in the company's $28 million backlog in Government orders, although he admits that many of these orders may get cancelled or stretched out.
And, Mr. Pace is proud of the role he says General Dynamics played in the current Soviet attitude. It was General Dynamics' ''Stinger'' lightweight shoulder-launched air-defense missiles that were used by Afghan rebels to knock out Soviet helicopters. Not only did a General Dynamics product perform well in the battlefield, Mr. Pace said, but the Soviet Union's defeat in Afghanistan helped soften its military posture.
Still, he doesn't thing this country has turned its back on so old an enemy. ''Some say these budget cuts are irreversible,'' Mr. Pace said. ''But I think nothing could be farther from the truth. Tiananmen Square proves that. The Soviet Union has all the military power its had for 70 years. All you need is some rat-a-tat like that and we're back 70 years.''
Others are more cautious. They argue that the Soviet Union is so weakened economically that it cannot pump money into military goods, no matter who is in power. ''If I were a defense contractor, '' said William Burnett, an analyst with Charles Rivers Associates, an economic consulting firm. ''I'd take these cuts about as seriously as I'd take the devil.''

PUB-DATE: December 17, 1989

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1, Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2255 words

HEADLINE: Persuading Americans To Save

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
POLITICIANS here finally appear to be waking up to what economists have been telling them: The long binge of overspending and undersaving by government, business and consumers threatens to depress living standards and reduce the nation to a second-rate economic force during the next decade. Already, there are symptoms, among them lagging productivity, slow wage growth, the sale of major assets to foreign investors, stubbornly high interest rates and the huge trade and budget deficits.
Now, the Government is pressing for some remedies. President Bush has pledged to ask Congress again to cut the tax on capital gains, which he argues would stimulate investment. And last week Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady outlined to the President's Economic Policy Council a new Family Savings Account, which would let families set aside as much as $5,000 a year. Depositors would receive no immediate tax deductions, but their interest income would be tax-free if the funds were left for at least 10 years. And to encourage corporate savings, the Treasury is considering more favorable tax treatment for dividends, and less favorable treatment for interest expenses. 
Members of Congress are also searching for new strategies, particularly to encourage investments in Individual Retirement Accounts. Some plans would permit the use of I.R.A. funds for education and first home purchases. Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat from Brooklyn, plans to propose an I.R.A. that would allow taxpayers to take deductions on their returns first, then have until the end of the calendar year to make their contributions.
The challenge for policy makers is twofold: to persuade the public to delay some gratification and make some sacrifices, and to be sure that any new programs actually do promote savings while not bloating the budget deficit.
Except when the Japanese step in to finance America's borrowing by snapping up a well-known asset - buying an interest in Rockefeller Center, for example - anemic personal, corporate and government savings rates are difficult to dramatize on television. No crack-infested housing projects, no corrupt savings-and-loan executives; just charts and numbers showing the United States saving rate falling well below most of the world's other big free-market economies. ''When we are stacked up against our major trading partners, we are always down near the bottom,'' Robert R. Glauber, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for Finance, said.
To date, Washington's measures to reduce debt, like limiting the deductibility of consumer interest, appear wholly inadequate. Like the drug plague, the low savings rate shows signs of becoming one of those perennial problems that mock the pronouncements of politicians.
At one time, the nation seemed to take seriously Benjamin Franklin's maxims about thrift. (''A penny saved is twopence clear.'') But now, the savings rate has fallen so low, and the federal deficit has grown so large, that the country is saving just three cents out of every dollar earned. According to public opinion polls, consumers believe that consuming less would throw the economy into a recession.
Economists, liberal and conservative, tend to disagree. Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan calls the low savings rate ''the most important long-term issue, from an economic point of view, that has to be addressed by policy makers.'' He says that replacing consumer spending with more savings would not risk a recession.
 
Curbing Consumption
Many economists call for the nation to almost double its savings rate to 10 percent by the middle of the next decade. But they are skeptical about achieving this goal, calling most proposals either politically impossible or marginally effective. ''There are some things we can do around the edges, but don't expect any one thing to do a lot,'' said James W. Christian, chief economist for the United States League of Savings Institutions.
American overspending has become deeply engraved in both laws and customs. The tax codes, as every corporate raider or buyout artist knows, give greater incentives for borrowing than saving, taxing profits that are distributed as dividends but exempting interest payments. Personal and corporate credit are plentiful, and Madison Avenue easily turns luxuries into needs. Baby boomers are said to treat B.M.W.'s and Rolex watches as talismans, with spending habits that Budget Director Richard G. Darman calls ''now nowism.''
The urge to overspend is actually nothing new. In 1899, Thorsten Veblen, the economist, observed the leisure class and commented, ''The standard of expenditure which commonly guides our efforts is not the average, ordinary expenditure already achieved; it is an ideal of consumption that lies just beyond our reach.'' Now, a much broader leisure class has extended its reach with Mastercard and Visa.
The argument that consuming too much today means consuming less tomorrow may seem paradoxical, but the economics are straightforward. Savings, whether deposited in banks or invested in stocks and bonds, give businesses the funds to invest in research, plants and equipment. Low savings limits these funds and pushes interest rates up. Businesses have to borrow less, forgoing new investment and allowing productivity to decline compared with well-funded foreign competitors. As companies become less profitable and competitive, they are less able to keep their workers or pay them rising wages.
To find capital, corporations then have to look overseas. ''It was necessary for the United States to incur nearly $120 billion in foreign debt last year even to attain a level of plant and equipment investment per worker that was half of Japan's investment rate,'' Lawrence H. Summers, an economics professor at Harvard University, said.
In return for their investments, foreigners often take ownership positions in these companies. ''People are worried about the Japanese buying Rockefeller Center. Well, if the average American saved the way the average Japanese does, there would be plenty of domestic capital for American companies and banks to bid for the Rockefeller Centers,'' Mr. Schumer, the Brooklyn Democrat, said. The United States was not always one of the world's lowest savers. According to the Federal Reserve Board, the American personal savings rate from 1870 to 1910 was close to 20 percent, while the rate in Japan and Germany was 15 percent and Britain, its pre-eminence fading, was close to 10 percent.
American savings hit a post-World War II low of 3.1 percent in 1947, as consumers who had put away more than 20 percent of their income during the war went on a buying spree. But then the rate steadily recovered, reaching 9.4 percent in the early 1970's. A long decline began in the second half of the decade, plunging to a 40-year low of 3.2 percent in 1987. Part of the drop may have been generational, as baby boomers married, had families and bought homes, economists say. Since 1987, the rate has edged up to about 5 percent, but economists point to factors like reduced auto sales and doubt there is any substantial reversal under way.
High spending has been fueled by feelings of wealth and security. The economy has been expanding for much of the decade. Pension funds and government social programs, including Medicare, Medicaid and workers' compensation, have given consumers a sense that they have no need to save for emergencies or retirement. ''I am not against Social Security and health insurance, but you have to understand that if the Government is going to give you everything you want, why save to get it for yourself?'' Joseph A. Grundfest, a commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission, asked.
Other major industrialized countries have seen their personal savings levels fall, but not as much as the United States. From 1973 to 1988, while the United States rate fell from 9.4 percent to 4.4 percent, West Germany's rate fell from 13.9 percent to 12.6 percent, Japan's from 20.4 percent to 15.2 percent and Canada's from 10.7 percent to 8.7 percent. These other countries encourage savings through lower taxes on corporate dividends, interest income and capital gains.
Mild prescriptions for healthier savings in the United States may be easy to come by, but strong medicine is unpopular. Consider the rise in mortgage debt, one of the major reasons savings declined during the 1980's. Although owners' equity in their homes counts as savings, downpayments by first-time homebuyers have been shrinking as a percentage of purchase prices. Congress has limited the deductibility of interest on mortgages for second homes, but tougher restrictions on mortgage interest and home equity loans, or higher required downpayments, are politically unpalatable.
The first challenge Washington faces is to bring down the budget deficit. ''The real savings problem is the Government absorption of savings,'' Edward F. McKelvey, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said. ''In the 1980's, it had clearly absorbed half the savings pool. So you've got to deal with the deficit.''
The Government's borrowing raises interest rates and makes the United States more dependent on foreign investors. But Treasury officials admit they have no new ideas on balancing the budget beyond hoping for a ''peace dividend'' from defense cuts and letting the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction goals go into effect.
 
Discouraging Debt
To encourage investment, President Bush has said he considers a capital gains tax cut essential. The Treasury Department, with a task force set to report on savings issues this spring, wants corporations to rely more heavily on equity financing than on debt. The department might propose giving businesses credit for taxes shareholders pay on stock dividends, while slashing the interest expenses that companies could write off.
The real savings push, many policy makers and economists agree, will have to come from the middle class. This quest inevitably leads to consideration of renewed, expanded I.R.A.'s. - a condition Democrats are likely to set in return for approving a capital gains tax cut. Other new incentives might include the Family Savings Accounts under discussion at the White House last week. Lawmakers say action is much more likely this year than last. ''The trade-off of a Republican desire to reduce capital gains is not likely to be a Democratic tax increase, but a tax decrease in the form of sweetening the I.R.A. provisions,'' Representative Jim Leach, Republican from Iowa, said.
Families with more than $50,000 in taxable income lost their entire I.R.A. deductions for their contributions as part of the tax reform package in 1986. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady has come out in favor of a proposal by Republican Senators William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware and Bob Packwood of Oregon to restore this benefit for almost everyone - except that the deductions would be allowed when funds are withdrawn from the I.R.A., not when they are deposited. Advocates say this approach would not drain current Treasury revenues and might attract investors who fear higher tax rates in the future.
Among Democrats, Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, chairman of the Finance Committee, has proposed expanding I.R.A. deductibility so that families earning more than $50,000 could write off up to half of their contributions. Mr. Bentsen would also permit I.R.A.'s to be used for first-time home purchases and education.
In the House, Mr. Schumer plans to introduce a carrot-and-stick I.R.A. that would let taxpayers take $2,000 in deductions and then give them the rest of the calendar year to save enough for the actual contributions. Those who then failed to contribute would be hit with back taxes plus interest and a 40 percent penalty on the taxes due. The penalty would be waived in cases of lost jobs or serious illness. And, as under Mr. Bentsen's plan, I.R.A.'s could finance homes and education.
Mr. Schumer, a leading member of the House Banking Committee, says that providing the deduction up front would give the middle class a strong new incentive. ''The aim here is really to force people to save,'' he said, ''make it so that once they enter into the agreement, it is very costly to get out.''
 
A New Surge in Saving?
Not all economists worry about the savings rate. Some argue that baby boomers will soon realize the need to save for retirement and their childrens' education. ''I think the boomers are going to surprise everbody,'' Edward Yardeni, the chief economist for the Prudential-Bache Securities Corporation, said. ''They were ahead of schedule in terms of consumption, and they will also be ahead of schedule in terms of savings. As they approach their 40's, they will have passed the material stage and probably own everything they want to own.'' He argues against Government incentives. ''The demographics all by themselves will push the savings rate up without assistance from macroeconomic policy.'' He points to the recent upturn in the savings rate as a possible indicator of this trend.
Though other economists expect baby boomers to save somewhat more as they age, few are as optimistic as Mr. Yardeni. The initiative for higher savings, Professor Summers says, must come from the Government.
''The U.S. saved more before World War II than the Japanese,'' he said. ''Our genes have not changed and Japanese genes have not changed since then. But they have changed their policies and we haven't.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: IMPROVING THE WORK FORCE;
Competitiveness Begins at School

BYLINE: By DAVID KEARNS; David T. Kearns is chairman of Xerox Corporation

 BODY:
AMERICAN businessmen must be smarting from the Japanese critique of our industrial and educational systems made as part of Japanese-American trade negotiations. I know that I am. If ever a challenge was issued to American educators and business people, this was it. Without subtlety, the Japanese told us that we are not likely to be competitive in the world economy of the future because we are failing to educate our youth.
The typical Japanese student goes to school 240 days a year while the average American youngster goes 180 days, and is exposed to a much less rigorous curriculum. Ninety-six percent of the Japanese students arrive at their first job having earned a high school diploma, which is the equivalent of a four-year degree from an American college. Japan, our major international competitor, has the best qualified work force in the world. Is it any wonder that Japan, with almost no natural resources, has become an economic miracle? 
The Japanese deliberately created a school system designed to advance their national interests and the well-being of their citizens; we must do the same. Business, which is spending more than $25 billion each year on remedial training for new employees, is doing the ''product recall'' work of our schools.
People in business who have been critics of public education, like myself, now realize that they must accept responsibility by suggesting ways to make the system work. Members of the Business Roundtable, which consists of the chief executives of 200 of America's largest corporations, are volunteering to form partnerships with the governors of each state. The objective is to dramatically improve our schools by the year 2000. There is no higher priority for business than this.
Dennis Doyle, senior research fellow at the Hudson Institute, and I have put forth a six-point plan to radically change the public education system in the United States. In brief, it calls for the following:
* Restructuring - Every public school district with 2,500 or more children would reorganize into a year-round system. Schools would be free to implement new teaching methods. Principals and teachers would have academic autonomy.
* Choice - Children would be able to attend any public school in their district. Teachers would not be bound to a specific school. States would insure a school's performance by testing students annually. Schools that persist in poor performance would get new management or be closed. States would spend equally on comparable children. Racial balance would be maintained.
* Professionalism - Teachers' undergraduate degrees would be in academic subjects - not education - with one added year stressing classroom teaching. Salaries would be based on performance and longevity. Teachers should create a national certification board along the lines recommended by the Carnegie Forum on Education and the Economy, a public policy research group.
* Standards - All students would be expected to master the basic skills that would allow them to function easily in our society. Just as it is the teacher's job to teach, it is the student's job to learn - no promotions for students without performance.
* Values - Schools would teach the ethical and democratic principles that are the foundation of our society. Our children should understand the great documents of American citizenship and the moral and religious basis of their creation.
* Federal Responsibility - Public education is a $150 billion-a-year business, but the Federal Government spends only $100 million on research to support it; it should spend more. College loans to student-teachers should be forgiven for specializing in critically needed skills or for teaching in hardship areas. The Federal Government should pay for Chapter One, a remedial math and reading program, and Head Start.
SOME people, on hearing this plan, have said that we can't expect academic performance from poor kids, or those from broken homes. A number of school districts have exploded this theory by succeeding in very difficult circumstances, including District 13 in Brooklyn's Bedford Stuyvesant section. It is frightening when people say we cannot educate everybody.
Improving our schools is not just another national priority that competes with the trade and Federal budget deficits. We must understand that adequate education is the eventual solution to these problems. Business leaders must show the way by devoting their energies and resources to seeing that this happens.
Without an educated populace we cannot have a strong economy. Without a strong economy our democracy will be at risk. Perhaps Walter Lippman said it best: ''No amount of charters, direct primaries or short ballots will make a democracy out of an illiterate people.''

GRAPHIC: David T. Kearns (The New York Times/Steve Miller)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: IMPROVING THE WORK FORCE;
Fixing the Schools Is Not Enough

BYLINE: By AMITAI ETZIONI; Amitai Etzioni is University Professor at George Washington University, director of the Center for Policy Research and author of ''The Moral Dimension.''

 BODY:
PLANS to reform our schools tend to overlook the fact that about half of our youngsters grow up in families that are not viable from an educational viewpoint. Frequent divorces, a bewildering rotation of boyfriends and parents who come home from work exhausted both physically and mentally, have left many homes with a tremendous parenting deficit. Instead of providing a stable home environment and the kind of close, loving supervision good character formation requires, many child care facilities, grannies, and baby sitters simply insure that children will stay out of harm's way.
As a result, personality traits essential for the acquisition of specific skills like math, English and various vocational skills are often lacking. Children come to school without self-discipline and they cannot defer gratification. Nor can they concentrate or mobilize themselves to the tasks at hand. 
Many studies find students deficient in math or English skills. This does not concern such advanced matters as whether students can craft a powerful essay or analyze a calculus problem. At issue is the ability to do arithmetic and write clear memos. Close examination of what is required points in one direction: the elementary knowledge involved can be taught quickly becasue it entails rather simple rules. The rest is self-discipline and adhering to the rules without jumping to conclusions.
Character formation has traditionally been viewed as a family matter, while the various commissions studying our nation's educational needs see schools as their purview. Also, cognitive deficiencies in areas like reading comprehension are more readily measured and less controversial than character defects, like the inability to delay gratification or concentrate on tasks. Mainstream psychology also has been highly cognitive in its outlook. Since the 1960's, it has tended to deal with skills rather than personalities. Still, studies lend support to the thesis that one needs to prepare the vessel before it can be loaded with skills and specific knowledge.
One of the best bodies of data regarding character formation was collected by James Coleman and his colleagues at the University of Chicago. The data show that children who study well also have well-developed characters. The youngsters doing well in high-performance schools have two main attributes: they do quite a bit of homework and they relate positively to their schools. Homework is the giveaway cue; those who can do a great deal of it, largely unsupervised, have acquired self-discipline. And, students need to respect their teacher and see their assignments as meaningful.
Several other studies reach similar conclusions. But the strongest evidence is found in the success of all-encompassing programs like the Conservation Corps, and some of the drug treatment programs. These programs take youngsters that often are disoriented, lacking in motivation and skills and develop their psychic stamina and their ability to mobilize and make commitments. Then the acquisition of specific skills becomes relatively easy.
Beyond being a prerequisite for good study habits, self-discipline is essential for making an employee show up for work regularly, be responsible for the quality of his or her production and take initiative. It is the basis of the work ethic.
HOW may one enhance the much neglected development of a child's character? It is important to start early. Companies would be serving their long-term interests by offering their employees (mothers and fathers) more leave in the first two years of the child's life. Parents ought to be advised that a premature emphasis on cognitive achievements and neglect of human development is self-defeating. One presupposes the other.
Recognizing that such a transformation in child care policy is unlikely, and that many parents probably will continue to spend relatively little time developing their child's character, the schools must step in. Schools ought to start earlier, say at age 4, and be open longer during the day and into the summer to make up for some of the lost parenting.
Resources must be shifted from the top-heavy end of the educational structure to early education. Currently we often prepare youngsters poorly in primary schools, mistrain them in high school, and then graduate them with poor working habits. But it is much more effective, from an economic viewpoint and a human one, to help young people learn things right the first time around.
If business leaders seek an active role in educational reform, they should concentrate on two related fronts: encourage character-formation before skill acquisition, and stress investment in the early years versus later ones.

GRAPHIC: Amitai Etzioni (The New York Times/Paul Hosefros)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: THE PEACE DIVIDEND;
What to Do With the Cold War Money

BYLINE: By SEYMOUR MELMAN; Seymour Melman is professor emeritus of industrial engineering at Columbia University, and chairman of the National Commission for Economic Conversion and Disarmament in Washington.

 BODY:
THE idea of a ''peace dividend'' first surfaced in 1969. A Cabinet Coordination Committee was set up to report to President Lyndon B. Johnson on what the Federal Government should do with its savings when the War in Vietnam finally ended. The committee proposed that the Federal Government dedicate $39.7 billion a year from its savings - in 1969 dollars - for the upkeep of the infrastructure.
The peace dividend was to provide money for roads, clean air, education, housing and foreign economic aid. But the war in Vietnam dragged on into the 1970's and the political energies needed to realize a peace dividend were exhausted. As a result, President Johnson's plans were never implemented and critical areas of our infrastructure, manufacturing sector and educational system fell into disrepair. 
With the end of the cold war - and a desire to terminate the 46-year-old arms race - there is once again the possiblity of a peace dividend.
Half of all Federal tax dollars go to the Pentagon. These large expenditures have hurt the competitive position of the United States and have kept the level of investment in the civilian economy, as a share of gross national product, lower than in Europe or Japan. For example, in 1983, for every $100 we spent on civilian capital formation, including new factories, machines and tools, we spent another $40 on the military. In West Germany, for every $100 spent on civilian investment, the military received only an additional $13. And in Japan, for every $100 spent on civilian investment, a mere $3 was spent on the military. Therefore these countries were able to spend more on their civilian needs.
As a result of years of neglect, our nation's infrastructure is failing to support a modern industrial society. Examples of the decay are everywhere. In New York City alone two water mains rupture every day. The scale of the problem is vast: estimates for repairing our nation's infrastructure - its roads, bridges, highways, waterways and so forth - are between $3 trillion and $5 trillion. The bill would have been far less had we been able to spend President Johnson's peace dividend.
Some of these repairs are the responsibility of our municipal and state governments, but a large part is the responsibility of the Federal Government. According to estimates prepared by the National Commission for Economic Conversion and Disarmament, a nonprofit research group, if we were to restore the nation's infrastructure , the Federal Government's share of the total would be more than $165 billion a year. This amount can be made available from savings from ending the cold war.
From 1947 to 1987, according to the Federal Government's own estimates, the United States spent $7.6 trillion on the military, a sum roughly equal to the total value of the nation's plant and equipment, plus the value of its civilian infrastructure. This means that since 1947, our military has used up resources sufficient to rebuild nearly everything that is manmade in the United States.
The military budget represents an enormous capital fund that could be put to productive civilian use. Military spending is 6 percent of G.N.P., but it pays for the services of 25 to 30 percent of all our nation's engineers and scientists and accounts for 70 percent of all Federal research and development money, $41 billion in 1988. These are resources that can be far more productive if used in the civilian sectors of the economy.
As a result of our military expenditures, by the close of the 1970's, the United States was no longer a first-class industrial economy with respect to productivity growth, research and development, the quality of infrastructure, average wages, competitiveness and standard of living. From this second-rate condition, the United States is headed for further decline. And if we become a third-rate industrial economy, we will lack forever the means of production necessary to repair our defiencies.
MANY barriers remain before we can reap the peace dividend and restore our nation to first-rate economic status. The cold war ideological and institutional systems remain in place and continue to influence our Government's leadership. For example, the central administrative offices of the Department of Defense has a staff of 120,000 and controls more than 35,000 prime contracting companies. Such managerial organizations do not readily relinquish decision-making power. And many members of Congress have become accustomed to functioning as virtual marketing managers for military companies, bases and laboratories in their districts.
That is why deliberate planning for conversion from a military to a civilian economy has become an indispensable requirement for obtaining and utilizing the peace dividend. Without a highly decentralized and mandatory two-year planning requirement, conversion to a civilian economy will fail.
To realize a peace dividend it is essential to give close attention to the proposed Defense Economic Adjustment Act (H.R. 101) sponsored by Representative Ted Weiss, Democrat of New York. This bill mandates a decentralized planning process in every large defense base and in our national laboratories and factories as well. It also includes the retraining of military engineers and managers to insure a competent changeover to civilian production. The bill encourages the preparation of concrete plans to implement a peace dividend. A serious peace-dividend program will raise Government revenues as a by-product of economic rebuilding.
Some voice the opinion that whatever savings accrue from a military wind-down should be used only to reduce the size of the Federal debt. That is a sure vote for a third-rate economy.

HEADLINE: Boston's Retail Doyennes Diverge

BYLINE: By FROMA HARROP; Froma Harrop is a business writer for The Providence Journal-Bulletin in Rhode Island.

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
VETERAN shoppers here say that except for the bargain basement at Filene's and the blueberry muffins at Jordan Marsh, New England's two stylish department stores - neighborly rivals for 136 years - seem indistinguishable.
Seven years ago, Jordan Marsh ran ads in newspapers and on television and radio to create its own distinct image. But shoppers shown advertisements with the stores' names cut out still could not tell which ad belonged to which store. Actually, Jordan Marsh sells housewares, a category Filene's gave up in the mid-1980's. But there is a far bigger difference between the Washington Street rivals these days, even though it may not be visible to Christmas shoppers jostling past the red poinsettias and white lights.
As the dust settles on an era of frenetic retailing takeovers, Filene's finds itself part of the robust May Department Stores Company of St. Louis, while Jordan Marsh remains mired in the troubles of the Toronto-based Campeau Corporation. A wide gap between the health of the parents' balance sheets could change the course of what has been a fairly evenly matched contest. 
''Filene's is in a better home,'' said Daniel D. Barry, a retailing analyst at Kidder Peabody in New York, who adds that May's long-term debt of $2.48 billion is modest for a retailer with $12 billion in sales. The company last year chalked up a profit of $534 million.
Filene's, which May bought last year, is forging ahead with a $125 million five-year plan of renovations and openings. With annual sales of $440 million, Filene's has just opened its 18th store at the Kingston Mall near Cape Cod. It plans other stores for Cambridge and Saugus, Mass.; Salem, N.H., and two other locations it will not name.
By contrast, Jordan Marsh, the bigger of the two chains with $750 million in annual sales, has put expansion plans on hold. It is spending much of its energy convincing nervous suppliers that its credit is good. The vendors' concerns center around Campeau's ability to continue payments on its $7.86 billion long-term debt, a burden that has overwhelmed a company with annual revenues of just under $9 billion. The debt load is the legacy of a two-year acquisition spree by its flamboyant Canadian namesake, Robert Campeau. IN 1986 he bought Allied Stores for $3.6 billion and two years later added Federated Department Stores of Cincinnati to his holdings for$6.6 billion. The purchases pushed the debt load of his retailing and real estate empire to more than $9.5 billion. As a result, Campeau last year doled out $877 million in financing costs, while bringing in operating profits of $881 million. After taxes, depreciation and paying preferred dividends, it ended the year with a loss of $34 million. Like other Campeau children, Jordan Marsh sees its revenues funneled into servicing massive debt payments.
In a cash crunch in September, the 26 Jordan Marsh stores, along with other Campeau retailers, were unable to pay their vendors' bills. As a result, many manufacturers froze deliveries of Christmas merchandise, and shipments resumed only after a $250 million loan from Olympia & York Developments Ltd., the Canadian real estate company and major Campeau shareholder. In return, Mr. Campeau surrendered control of his company's retail operations.
''We are well stocked and we are paying our bills,'' said Robert Gottlieb, Jordan Marsh's senior vice president for marketing. ''All it takes is a walk through our stores.''
The store's suffering comes through little fault of its own, retailing analysts say. ''Over the last six or seven years, Jordan Marsh had been undergoing a major upgrading of its stores,'' said Harris Gordon, senior manager at Touche Ross in Boston. ''At the operating level it has been run by smart retailers.''
But two years ago the chain had to cut more than 650 jobs, or 10 percent of its payroll, and purge much of middle management. Campeau's financial woes have held up construction of the $750 million Boston Crossing shopping center downtown, which would have included a rebuilt Jordan Marsh as well as a new Bloomingdale's, another Campeau chain currently up for sale.
Meanwhile, Jordan Marsh and other Campeau stores continue on a somewhat shaky basis with suppliers. The Credit Exchange, which evaluates retailers' ability to pay their bills, currently gives the Allied Stores a ''negative opinion,'' meaning that it is an unusually high credit risk. Although the exchange tends to be a stricter judge than the companies that actually grant credit, its dim view of the Campeau stores portends another cliffhanger in January, when many suppliers expect payments for goods shipped over the Christmas season.
In a quarterly statement filed Wednesday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Campeau said an expected cash crunch might force Federated and Allied to seek court protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code.
Analysts say Jordan Marsh is now running unusually aggressive sales to assure full coffers for paying those bills, leaving Filene's little choice but to cut prices too.
Mr. Gottlieb denied that Jordan Marsh's pre-Christmas price-cutting was out of the ordinary, saying retailers around the country were adopting the practice. ''We are no more promotional than anybody else,'' he said.
AND Charlotte Brewer, Mr. Gottlieb's counterpart at Filene's, disputed the notion that Filene's was reacting to Jordan Marsh. ''Filene's has the same promotional strategy it had several months ago,'' she said. But, according to Mr. Barry at Kidder Peabody, ''there has been more promotion between those two than others in the country.'' And other Campeau stores are not slashing their prices as much, he said. ''The situation in Boston seems to be relatively unique.'' Another impetus behind the sharp markdowns is an economic slump in New England that has sent retail sales down 5.5 percent in Boston and 5.3 percent in Providence, R.I. in the last year. In contrast, retail sales nationally have risen 4.8 percent.
''This is a very bad time for everybody in New England,'' said Carmen Pastore, chairman of Longcraft, a jewelry maker and wholesaler in Wakefield, Mass., and a Jordan Marsh supplier. ''Most of the manufacturers are having problems with collections.''
In a twist of fate, Filene's itself was headed for the Campeau fold last year when the Canadian company bought its former parent, Federated. But as owner of both Jordan Marsh and Filene's, Campeau would have controlled too big a chunk of the New England market for regulators' comfort. Out of antitrust concerns, Campeau decided to shed one of them, and it turned out to be Filene's. Other chains sold include Bullock's, Foley's, I. Magnin, Brooks Brothers and Ann Taylor. Filene's Basement, a 25-store off-price chain that broke away from Filene's in 1984, was sold last year to a management group (the Boston store still has its original bargain basement). Analysts believe that Filene's is now in a stronger position than Jordan Marsh to squeak through tough times. ''The May Company has a reputation for keeping close control of its inventories,'' Mr. Barry said. ''If there is a shortfall of expectations from a weak economy, then Filene's would probably do better.''
Mr. Gordon at Touche Ross is more concerned about what could happen to Jordan Marsh five years from now should its capital shortage continue. In a market that has nearly stopped growing, retailers will be able to improve performance only by controlling costs and wresting market share from competitors by fine-tuning their merchandise for the local market.
Both will require expensive technology, like scanners, that help retailers keep a close eye on the movement of merchandise. ''The ability to invest in that kind of technology gives you an advantage,'' Mr. Gordon said. ''That is the area where capital is playing a role.'' One result of shuffling the retailing decks is that Filene's is becoming a bit more democratic. Retailers are talking about the ''MAYonnaissing'' of Filene's, referring to the addition of more moderately priced general merchandise. Ms. Brewer balks at the notion that her store is inching away from the cutting edge of fashion. Rather, she said, it is bringing in more types of shoppers. ''We have broadened our base,'' she said. ''We'll still not be as broad as Jordan Marsh.''

HEADLINE: WEEK IN BUSINESS;
The Trade Deficit Takes Off Again

BYLINE: By WILLIAM S. NIEDERKORN

 BODY:
The U.S. merchandise trade deficit widened sharply to $10.2 billion in October, the biggest imbalance in 10 months, as imports reached a record level. The Government also reported that inventories climbed four-tenths of a percent in October, to a seasonally adjusted $793.9 billion. In November, wholesale prices edged down a tenth of a percent and capacity utilization also was down a tenth of a point, to 82.7 percent. But industrial production inched up a tenth of a percent that month and retail sales rose eight tenths of a percent. Sales of U.S.-built cars plunged 28 percent in early December, however.
* The Columbia Savings and Loan Association's chairman and chief executive, Thomas Spiegel, said he would resign at the end of the year and set up a separate operation that would own the institution's ''junk bond'' portfolio. Government officials said tight restrictions were placed last month on Columbia, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., after new accounting rules forced it to recognize large losses in the value of the bonds. 
* Shearson Lehman Hutton and American Express announced a plan to raise cash for the brokerage firm by selling assets and issuing new stock and debt. After the announcement, Moody's Investors Service affirmed Shearson's debt ratings.
* Troubled real estate loans are causing heavy losses for bankers in the Northeast. With office vacancy rates now reaching 25 to 30 percent in places like central New Jersey and Stamford, Conn., and with many condominium developments still half empty after two years on the market, a growing number of developers are having difficulty paying off loans.
* GAF and its vice chairman, James T. Sherwin, were found guilty of trying to manipulate the stock of Union Carbide in 1986. The verdict, on all eight felony counts, was a victory for Federal prosecutors, who had been criticized for pressing a criminal rather than a civil case. Two previous efforts ended in mistrials. Defense lawyers intend to appeal.
* Campeau's American subsidiaries that own Bloomingdale's, Jordan Marsh and other national chains said they might have to file for bankruptcy protection. The subsidiaries, Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores, said in quarterly statements to the S.E.C. that they expected to run short of cash to make debt payments, possibly as soon as late January. Following the announcement, Heller Financial discontinued providing credit to Campeau's retail chains. Campeau also reported a loss of $105 million for the third quarter.
* The Dow Jones industrial average rose 8.11 points for the week, to 2,739.55. Yields fell slightly on the 30- year Treasury bond, to 7.84 percent, while short-term yields were up slightly. The dollar fell against all major currencies, and gold rose $2.10 an ounce on the week at the Comex, to $413.90.
* Steel subsidies are to be banned by 18 nations that together supply two-thirds of the steel imported by the U.S. The Administration disclosed agreements with the countries in announcing its renewal of a quota program for two and a half years that will keep imports at a level below 20 percent of U.S. steel sales.
* Miscellanea. President Bush acknowledged for the first time that the $50 billion bailout of the savings industry might not be enough . . . The S.E.C. and its French counterpart signed an agreement to cooperate on securities investigations . . . France said it would end all controls on foreign exchange on Jan. 1 . . . Chrysler significantly broadened the scope of its rebates and low-interest financing . . . G.M. said it would pay $500 million for 50 percent of Saab Automobile A.B. . . . Xerox filed suit against Apple Computer, accusing it of copyright misrepresentation in Apple's Macintosh and Lisa computers . . . Bear, Stearns is resuming index arbitrage for its own account . . . BellSouth terminated its pact to buy Lin Broadcasting . . . Integrated Resources reported a loss of more than $1 billion for its second quarter . . . U.S. Memories is scaling back its goals in order to continue working toward a cooperative venture to make memory chips . . . A Federal magistrate ruled that both Amgen and Genetics Institute have valid patents on a genetically engineered drug to combat anemia.

HEADLINE: Chile's Example

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Mr. Nathan P. Gardels is incorrect when he states that there is no evidence in the developing world that opening closed economies has resulted in improved living standards (''Perestroika Goes South,'' Nov. 12). During the 30 years prior to the rule of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, Chile pursued an import-substitution policy. The Government set tariffs at an average rate of 100 percent and imposed a variety of non-tariff barriers. General Pinochet eliminated non-tariff barriers and reduced tariffs to a flat 15 percent.
Chileans have responded to this economic liberalization by rapidly expanding their exports. At present, exports exceed 30 percent of Chile's gross national product. This percentage is almost three times higher than during the last decade of import substitution. Significant trade surpluses and employment opportunities have been generated.
 
STEVE H. HANKE
Professor of Applied Economics
Johns Hopkins University
 Baltimore, Nov. 22

HEADLINE: REVIEWING THE TROOPS;
The Military Math of Peace in Our Time

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOR four decades, the Pentagon has based its budgets, its strategy and its public relations largely on one premise: the Russians are coming. But now the Russians are going, and the Pentagon is experiencing the painful process of adjusting to the new military reality.
In the past year, the Soviet Union has begun to withdraw tanks, troops and airplanes from Europe unilaterally and to cut military spending. Moscow has also acquiesced in the decision by its East European allies to cut their military forces and has supported the opening of the Berlin wall. 
With political reforms sweeping Eastern Europe, Moscow's Warsaw Pact partners are increasingly unlikely to participate in any attack on Western Europe - a remote possibility in the first place. But while Soviet military capabilities are lessening, they are still formidable. The Pentagon's task is to take account of the Soviet retrenchments that have already occurred while planning for the more sweeping cuts that would be required by arms control agreements.
The challenge is not an easy one. Military planners tend to err on the safe side, and the Pentagon is torn between its customary caution and the need to respond to budget-related domestic pressure to cut military spending. Nonetheless, the Defense Department took some steps last week to adjust to the changing world.
First, the Pentagon disclosed that it would sharply scale back and dispense with the use of tanks in the largest of its annual military exercises in Europe. Then Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, endorsing a recommendation by the Air Force's Strategic Air Command, proposed to halt the round-the-clock flights of its Looking Glass command post, which would be used to direct strategic forces if the President and other leaders were killed in a surprise nuclear attack. The recommendation reflected the view within the Pentagon that the threat of a surprise Soviet attack is lessening.
President Bush rejected the Pentagon proposal, which some Administration officials seemed to think would create the perception that the United States was moving too fast to cut its military. The Pentagon plan also appeared to run counter to the thinking of Mr. Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, who in the past has stressed the need to guard against the risk of a surprise nuclear attack.
 
The Reductions Begin
The dispute over the command post aside, more far-reaching changes in the American military are being planned. Army officials said last week, for example, that the service is planning to deal with the prospect of cuts in American and Soviet troops in Europe by reshaping itself into a fast-reaction force that would be based primarily in the United States. That prospect has drawn fire from the Marine Corps, which contends the Army's plans would overlap the Marines' mission.
The first major indication that the Soviet Union was reducing its forces came in December 1988, when Mikhail S. Gorbachev announced that Moscow would unilaterally withdraw about half of its tanks from Eastern European nations and make other cuts in its forces. Moscow said the trims were part of a larger plan to adopt a ''defensive'' structure that would not threaten the West.
Western analysts say that the unilateral cuts will indeed blunt Moscow's offensive strength, severely constraining its ability to launch a surprise attack, though they still leave the Soviet Union with a very powerful force.
Edward L. Warner 3d, an analyst at the Rand Corporation, told the House Armed Services Committee in September that the unilateral cuts announced by Mr. Gorbachev would indeed reduce Soviet combat power in Eastern Europe by about 20 percent. But Mr. Warner also cautioned that the remaining, revamped Soviet units would ''represent a highly versatile combat force that is equally capable of conducting modern offensive or defensive operations.''
In September, a further development called American military assumptions into question when United States intelligence experts concluded that the increased openness of Soviet society, Moscow's cuts in conventional arms and improved American intelligence-gathering would now give the Pentagon a month to three months of warning of a full-scale Soviet attack in Europe. For years, the Pentagon has assumed that it would have just 14 days' warning of a such an attack.
The new assessment of warning time has a potentially profound bearing on such decisions as whether the United States should spend billions on new planes or ships that would be used to move troops and equipment to Europe. It also bears on whether the Pentagon should try to make greater use of reserve units and less use of those on active duty.
But so far, Pentagon officials stress, no major military benefits have accrued to the West from the new policies in Moscow. A new East-West conventional arms agreement now under negotiation in Vienna would erase Moscow's traditional large advantages in ground forces.
But the American military faces the challenge of devising plans to project power around the world, and not just in Europe. Assessing global American responsibilities, members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff have told Mr. Cheney that they can live with the sizable cuts in spending over the next four years that are being considered but that any further reductions would undermine American security. Indeed, the chiefs have asserted that small after-inflation increases in military spending will be needed in the mid-1990's to maintain weapons modernization and personnel.
Mr. Cheney is studying reductions of about 5 percent in the current level of spending, after inflation, Pentagon officials have said. Until recently, the White House had projected a modest after-inflation increase over those years. The difference between the 1992-94 budgets the Administration had originally planned and those now under consideration is $180 billion. But military planning is not merely a matter of spending money. And the Pentagon, the President and the Congress must now agree on a new strategy for a new world.
Said Paul Wolfowitz, an Under Secretary of Defense, ''We are looking at revisiting a great many fundamental assumptions.''

HEADLINE: The U.S. Stake in the Philippines

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: MANILA

 BODY:
THE rebel members of the Philippine armed forces who tried to overthrow President Corazon C. Aquino earlier this month made many political and tactical mistakes. But perhaps their biggest error was in thinking that the United States might remain neutral during a rebellion and support them if they prevailed.
The rebel soldiers' expectations turned out to be completely unrealistic. On Dec. 1, after rebel planes had bombed and strafed the presidential palace and military camps, President Bush ordered American warplanes to fly combat air patrols. Without firing a shot, they grounded the rebel air effort and doomed the coup attempt. Most of the military remained loyal to Mrs. Aquino even though some of the rebels' fellow soldiers were sympathetic. 
The intervention showed the extent of American determination to support democracy in the Philippines and Mrs. Aquino as the country's elected President. It also created a new atmosphere for negotiations on the future of United States military bases in the Philippines, expected to begin within a couple of months.
One factor in the evident overconfidence of the Philippine rebels was that they never expected the United States to intervene directly in a fight within the Philippine armed forces. The American bases have been considered an instrument of American global strategy, not a tool for influencing policy in the Philippines. Agreements on use of the bases expire on Sept. 16, 1991, and the terms for renewing them have become an issue here.
 
A Major Employer
Despite the undeniable military significance of the bases, the American view that they are indispensable has clearly changed in the last decade. Washington has hinted that it could relocate the bases if it really had to, and now, with the decline in tensions between Washington and Moscow, it is unclear whether the United States will try to justify the bases in the same terms. Last week, American officials said the Soviets were packing up MIG-23 fighter jets based at Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam, in a move that could signal Soviet military cutbacks in Southeast Asia.
Polls of Filipino public opinion show there is support for retaining the bases. But many Filipinos also believe that American compensation for use of the bases should be increased. The United States armed forces are said to be the second largest employer here, after the national Government, providing jobs for 68,500 Filipinos and accounting for at least 3.5 percent of the gross national product.
Moderate politicians say the bases undermine Philippine sovereignty by fostering dependence, and a small but vocal anti-American faction sees them as a symbol of American imperialism. Critics of Mrs. Aquino say her acceptance of intervention during the coup weakened her ability to bargain with the United States. She denies that, but she has asked for a short postponement of talks about the bases, saying her Government will be too busy dealing with the aftermath of the rebellion.
Jovito R. Salonga, president of the Philippine Senate, said the United States has lost the support of the opposition Nacionalista Party, which once favored retaining the bases. Many party members now say the bases should be phased out because they permitted the intervention.
Mrs. Aquino, for her part, says she is keeping her options open. Her associates suggest that she might agree to continued operation of the bases in return for economic and political concessions from the Bush Administration. Within the constraints of a tight Federal budget, the Administration has shown itself willing to consider almost any request to accommodate so close a friend as Mrs. Aquino.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
A Debate Over Access To U.S. University Research

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THANKS largely to American university research, Toshiba Inc. is developing a new technology for recording images on disks, the Toyota Motor Company is devising new engineering stress sensors, and the Asahi Chemical Company is computerizing its manufacturing processes.
These were among the recent payoffs to foreign companies from ''industrial liaison'' programs at top American universities, a recent Congressional study found. For an annual fee, corporations become members of these programs and thereby gain an early look at unpublished research and a chance to acquire exclusive rights to exploit patents held by the schools. Participants may have access to new research as much as a year or more before it is made public. 
In many if not most cases the research is paid for by the Federal Government. In recent years, foreign participation in these programs has increased, and lately, amid rising concern about American competitiveness, some in Government and industry have begun to question the practice of allowing outside companies to buy academic research. But the universities contend that the open flow of ideas is essential, with scholars depending on cross-fertilization. These programs bring scholars into the real world of commerce, they say, and they also generate income.
''We look to corporations for substantial financial support, and our industrial liaison program is a way of lubricating that process,'' said Dr. Paul Gray, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. ''Research depends on openness, and restraints could kill the goose that lays the golden egg.''
In a 1988 study, the General Accounting Office found that 41 universities sold their research to a paying membership. The programs had 2,848 American corporate members and 496 foreign members, with 76 percent of the foreign companies concentrated in programs at three institutions: M.I.T., the University of California at Berkeley and Texas A. & M. University.
The practice is not new. M.I.T.'s program was created in 1948 as part of a broad effort to spur the postwar economy. But most of the large ones were created after 1980, when a change in the law gave universities proprietary rights to patents developed with federally financed research. While American companies have the same opportunity as other participants, the fact that foreigners profit from the universities' work is nevertheless objectionable to some members of Congress. And some in academia object to the practice on more general grounds.
Dr. David Noble, professor of history at Drexel University and a critic of the programs, said they ''have become a conduit of a massive giveaway to industry, including foreign companies.'' Dr. Noble, who formerly taught at M.I.T., has sued the school, claiming that he was denied tenure because of his criticism of the programs. Dr. Gray said the denial of tenure had nothing to do with this issue.
In Congress, the main questions have been about foreign participation.
''Our concern is that these programs provide privileged access to federally financed research before the research results are published,'' said Representative Ted Weiss, a New York Democrat who heads a human resources subcommittee. ''They're selling federally funded research to Japanese, German and other foreign companies, and that's wrong.''
This year the M.I.T. industrial liaison service had 291 members, 161 American and 130 foreign. They paid annual fees of up to $50,000, earning the school $4 million to $5 million. The foreign members include 56 Japanese corporations, 13 French and 13 Italian.
At a Congressional hearing earlier this year, the issue of technology export was addressed by Dr. Erich Bloch, director of the National Science Foundation, a Federal agency that provides about one-third of the $6 billion a year that the Government spends to underwrite university research. In response to a question, Dr. Bloch said he was ''pretty sure that the Government is subsidizing the export of technology indirectly, because that information is available to anybody in the country or outside the country.''
Representative Donald Payne, a New Jersey Democrat, said that at a time when the United States was ''losing its edge,'' the expenditure of tax dollars on research that benefited other countries was ''exacerbating an already bad situation.'' But Dr. Bloch and others who generally support the programs say that if American companies fail to take advantage of them, they have only themselves to blame.
While Dr. Gray shares Dr. Bloch's view, concern about foreign participation varies at other schools.
''Since all our research is published in the open literature, we believe that these programs are neutral in technology slippage,'' said Frank J. Giunta, director of industrial liaison programs at the University of California at Berkeley, which have 350 corporate members, of which 15 percent are foreign.
But Nancy Hay, Stanford University's assistant director for foundation and corporate relations, said that ''there have been discussions about whether foreign companies should be included in the Center for Integrated Systems,'' the university office in charge of selling the university's research. ''We decided not to encourage Japanese companies to join, because of the technology transfer problem,'' she said. About two dozen American companies pay the Stanford center $120,000 a year each for advance peeks at research. But 52 foreign companies are among the 325 members of Stanford's less far-reaching affiliate programs.
Bernard Schwartz, chairman of the Loral Corporation, a defense electronics manufacturer, said it was ''extraordinary'' that the sale of research to foreigners is allowed. He added, ''We need to develop strategies that give American companies an advantage.''
