HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Among Historians, The Old Frontier Is Turning Nastier With Each Revision

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
ONE of the standard college textbooks still in use puts it this way: ''The history of the American West is, almost by definition, a triumphal narrative, for it traces a virtually unbroken chain of successes in national expansion.''
Patricia Nelson Limerick, who teaches history at the University of Colorado, sees that summation of the Western experience as evidence of a problem that has to be overcome. For decades descriptions of the glories of American nation-building have been balanced by sober accounts of the mistreatment of Indians, aggressiveness toward Mexico, the greed of settlers and the economic hardships of life. But Professor Limerick is among the leaders of a group of historians who, over the past decade or so, have promoted a view of history much bleaker than what has prevailed before. 
One of their primary goals is to go further in demolishing what they see as a battered but durable old myth: the image of the West as an empty land that instilled in its settlers the habits of rugged individualism, freedom and self-reliance, all of which gave America its special character. Instead, the new historians are scrutinizing the dark sides of the West's past, and they are drawing the conclusion that it was all too often a place of deep, unredeemed tragedy and failure. Their articles and books, reflecting trends in other disciplines, stress the despoilation of the environment, the contributions and abuse of minorities and women, and the injustices of what they portray as untrammeled greed.
''The grandiose history that white Americans once thought they were making out here, in this land beyond the Mississippi River, has come apart and does not compel belief as it once did,'' said Donald Worster, a practitioner of the new Western history, at a recent conference in New Mexico.
If it sounds as though this is negative history, a history emerging from the leftward movement of academic departments during the 1960's, some older scholars would agree. The West is a vast territory where many millions of people have enjoyed freedom and prosperity. By treating it as a human and ecological failure, the advocates of the new history are open to charges that they have pressed so far in trying to demolish the old myths that they have embraced a negativism as faulty as the romanticism of the past.
 
Re-Examining an Icon
A new history generally starts off by denying the validity of what preceded it, and in this sense, the new students of the West have a ready-made target - Frederick Jackson Turner, whose frontier thesis dominated graduate schools and writing about the West in the first half of the century. Though also criticized by later generations of historians, Turner remains an icon, the founder of the most influential school of thought ever in American historiography. In his view, the frontier gave America its character, promoting its individualism and its democratic culture. ''The existence of an area of free land, its continuous recession, and the advance of American settlement westward, explain American history,'' he wrote in a celebrated essay of 1893.
Extreme critics, throwing verbal caution to the winds, call him ''ethnocentric, racist and sexist.'' Moderate critics like Yale's Howard R. Lamar, who taught many members of the new generation of Western historians, say that the frontier thesis still has considerable validity. But they believe it only partly explains what made America different from other countries and does not at all deal with the West in the 20th century.
''Mr. Turner gave Americans the first theory that told them they had made their own culture and history,'' Mr. Lamar said. ''He tapped so many feelings that he has to be celebrated, but that was 100 years ago, and you can't go back to 1890 to explain everything.'' Mr. Lamar is troubled by the zealotry of some new historians, but he maintains that they have opened up unexplored areas, giving to the conception of the West a complexity and richness that it has not had.
One of the main notions of the new history is that the West was the most racially diverse large region in the country, a place where whites did not escape the rest of the world, as Turner suggested, but found it. There were Indians, of course. There were also black and Hispanic settlers and large populations of Chinese laborers. Women, both those who resemble the stereotype of the courageous pioneer killed by an Indian and those who were prostitutes, led hard and grim lives.
 
Revisionists' Bible
Many of these themes make up the contents of a book generally recognized as the fullest expression of the new history: Ms. Limerick's ''The Legacy of Conquest: The Unbroken Past of the American West.'' Rather than look at the West as the receding frontier, she sees it as ''a place undergoing conquest and never fully escaping its consequences.'' She shatters, for example, ''the fantasy that the West set Americans free from dependence on the Federal Government.'' Western economic exploitation, she argues, depended on Congressional favors and complicity between businessmen and politicians who were often one and the same.
An important theme is that settlers, rather than escaping the problems of the East, re-created them - like the asthmatic searchers for good air in Phoenix who planted fruitless mulberry trees, which produced vast quantities of harmful pollen. The often harsh conditions of Western life, she argues, ''will not let us take refuge in sentimental and nostalgic images'' of the sort she believes the Turner thesis sustains.
Ms. Limerick allowed that there might be some excess in the new history. But she argued that a scholarly imbalance had to be redressed. ''We have had such a long regime of the model of Western history as a success story,'' she said. ''We are against that, and you could say, perhaps, that we have pushed the pendulum too far.
''I don't think everybody has to buy Kleenex and weep over how unusually unhappy the Western experience was,'' she continued, ''but it had the usual quota of tragedy and failure, cruelty and inhumanity, and situations of invasion and conquest often raise the stakes on things like that.''

SECTION: Section 4; Page 20, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 818 words

HEADLINE: A Second Chance for Vision

 BODY:
America had a fair idea of what it was getting in George Bush: a competent, cautious steward with a slim agenda and no taste for what he called ''the vision thing.'' He would make changes at the margins of the Reagan Revolution without disturbing its core. The nation would be kinder and gentler. Taxes would stay low, defenses strong. He would be a prudent leader in placid times. Uncharismatic, for sure, but the voters found that preferable to the uncertain candidacy of Michael Dukakis.
Now, thanks largely to Mikhail Gorbachev and the long-stifled emotions of millions of Eastern Europeans, the world George Bush inherited has changed dramatically. The end of the cold war does more than challenge old assumptions. It inspires high hopes that America will shift resources from receding foreign threats to neglected domestic needs. 
A few months ago, Mr. Bush seemed well matched to his times - in The Economist's words, ''a President without a vision when visions are out of fashion.'' Yet a visionary named Gorbachev now invites more than stewardship from the President in Washington. Is Mr. Bush up to the task? His first year in office offers grounds for hope - and worry.
Mr. Bush's inaugural provided no grand plan, just a sensible approach to governance. The country, he said, had grown weary of ideological combat and was eager for bipartisanship. So he moved quickly to defuse controversy. On Central America, for example, he cut a deal with Congress to send humanitarian but not military aid to the Nicaraguan contras, removing at one stroke an issue that had paralyzed Mr. Reagan's relations with Congress.
Mr. Bush kept the Reagan faith by opposing abortion, though his views increasingly antagonized Republican women - and dismayed Republican officeholders. He shamelessly exploited the flag burning issue. Yet he broke cleanly with Mr. Reagan on important environmental questions like acid rain, faced up to the savings and loan crisis and offered an original approach to third world debt. And unlike his predecessor, who had ears only for good news, Mr. Bush acknowledged that America suffered from drugs, poor housing and poor schooling.
He brought a new style, too. Jimmy Carter cared little for Congress, Ronald Reagan even less for the press. George Bush held 24 formal news conferences in his first nine months. He pitched horseshoes with reporters, herded Congressmen on tours through the White House living quarters, composed handwritten notes by the bushel. There was no escaping his relentless bonhomie. These have been welcome adjustments to the Reagan legacy. Other aspects of Mr. Bush's first year give pause.
For a man who personifies openness and prudence, the President has sometimes displayed a disturbing penchant for secretive, even impulsive behavior. He arranged the Malta summit meeting without telling his Defense Secretary, Dick Cheney, who was himself involved in sensitive discussions with Soviet officials.
Just a week ago, Mr. Bush dispatched two aides on the furtive mission to Beijing. A patient explanation of his strategy might have allayed the sense of betrayal felt by Americans sickened by the slaughter of Chinese students last spring. The two episodes were unhappy reminders of how Mr. Bush startled the public, and even some of his closest aides, by choosing Dan Quayle as his running mate.
If Mr. Bush has sometimes seemed oddly impetuous, he has often been surprisingly insubstantial. The sound emanating from Washington is the sound of wind machines. The whirr is intended to make people think America is moving.
The education summit meeting conducted by the self-styled Education President was all wind. The housing plan, ditto. The famous War on Drugs, mostly ditto. There's little new money, and no will to find any. The deficit - and Mr. Bush's stubborn refusal to budge from his no-new-taxes pledge - have paralyzed Congress. Mr. Bush doesn't shout charge! He whispers it.
That defines the central worry about Mr. Bush in the Gorbachev era. The President is right to approach enormous matters like the reshaping of Europe with prudence. He is right when he says there can be no instant peace dividend; reductions in defense will have to be made gradually.
But if Mr. Gorbachev can sustain his vision of a more peaceable Soviet Union, he invites Americans, and their President, to imagine, too. George Bush can be more than what he thought he would be, a capable shepherd of the status quo. He can, over the next three years, begin a transformation of American priorities.
That means doing all he can to help Mr. Gorbachev survive. It means honoring his pledge at Malta to push the bureaucracy ''as fast as I possibly can'' toward agreement on strategic nuclear weapons and conventional forces. And it means seizing this moment to plan for peace - a precious and unexpected opportunity that asks the unexpected of George Bush.

LENGTH: 730 words

HEADLINE: To Repair Our Nation

BYLINE: By Felix G. Rohatyn; Felix G. Rohatyn, an investment banker, is chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

 BODY:
The need for large-scale investment in public works is obvious to anyone who travels about the United States. And there is a way to make it possible despite the Federal Government's budget deficit: the creation of state infrastructure banks.
Roads and bridges need extensive repairs. Airports are overwhelmed and need to expand, and the nation's air traffic control system should be revamped. Every large city needs new schools, hospitals and public transportation systems. 
New York City alone requires an investment of $50 billion during the next decade to bring its infrastructure up to a tolerable level. The country as a whole is said to need $2 trillion to $3 trillion in infrastructure improvements.
It is also obvious that the United States needs a modern infrastructure if it is to compete effectively in the global economy. An up to date road and air transport system, greater environmental protection and better schools and hospitals all are needed to support a competitive private sector economy. Over the long run, a national policy of support for greater public investment should involve a direct shift from military expenditures to public-works spending. In the short run, however, a more aggressive stance should be taken, using the considerable assets of public pension funds to meet social needs. A policy could be evolved that would respond to these needs and, at the same time, protect retirees. Here's how it might work. State infrastructure banks could be set up, financed by a combination of the assets of public employee pension funds and the proceeds of a tax of some variety, perhaps a statewide gasoline tax. The Federal Government would guarantee the portion of pension fund assets, say 10 percent, that would be invested in the development bank. The states would levy the tax.
The public investment that could be generated by public employee pension funds - the amount would be limited by law to a certain percentage of their assets - would be considerable. In New York State alone, for instance, the assets of public employee pension funds amount to approximately $100 billion. Moreover, the funds are growing steadily at a rate of about 8 percent a year. Ten percent of those assets would amount to $10 billion, growing to about $20 billion over 10 years, as the funds' assets increase.
A statewide gasoline tax of 15 cents a gallon would produce revenues of about $1 billion a year. The combination of the pension fund assets and the proceeds of a gasoline tax, plus additional borrowings against future revenues, could permit public investment of at least $30 billion to $40 billion statewide during the next decade.
In 11 states alone, public employees' pension fund assets amount to about $350 billion. A similar formula involving 10 percent of pension fund assets plus a reasonable taxing effort could generate, in the aggregate, $75 billion to $100 billion of public investment in those states.
It is obviously impossible to commit pension fund assets without protection for the retirees. The most obvious protection would be Federal guarantees.
The possibility of direct Federal expenditures on public works seems remote at this point. Secretary of Transportation Samuel K. Skinner has urged the nation's governors to help meet the nation's infrastructure needs by raising local gasoline taxes. It is pointless to argue whether it is appropriate for Washington to pass the buck to the states. However, given the nation's inability to deal with the Federal budget deficit, there is no practical way to get Federal outlays.
On the other hand, Federal guarantees would be totally appropriate within the context of a state infrastructure bank and a state taxing effort. Federal guarantees need not affect the Federal budget; they have been used again and again in a variety of cases.
Obviously, the governance of the infrastructure banks would have to insure a businesslike approach to investment. These are details that can be worked out. But the combination of a state taxing effort, public employee pension funds and Federal guarantees to insure needed public construction would seem an appropriate combination.
A multistate effort in the Congress, with the support of business and labor, should generate significant political support and influence the Administration to come aboard. We, in New York State, should lead the effort.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 3, Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 1355 words

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
A Bill of Rights for the Disabled Nears Passage

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
LEGISLATION designed to provide equal treatment and broad changes for disabled people in the United States, estimated to number at least 43 million, is expected to be enacted early next year.
The measure, known as the Americans With Disabilities Act, has been described as extending the Civil Rights Act of 1964 to those with disabilities. Already approved by the Senate, it is expected to pass the House and return to the Senate for any changes to harmonize the bills before being signed by President Bush, who supports it.
Generally, the measure says that when new things are built, bought or overhauled by travel companies they should be ''readily accessible to and usable by'' people with disabilities. The bill calls for existing places to be made accessible if the modifications are ''readily achievable,'' which the bill's sponsors said means if it can be accomplished without much difficulty or expense. 
The big areas where the bill touches on travel involve bus transportation, both public and private systems, rail systems, both rapid transit and long-distance, motels and restaurants and other places that accommodate the public - museums, theaters, transportation terminals, parks and zoos and recreation areas.
The bill seeks to deal with all the areas where there is no Federal legislation to protect the disabled; for instance, the bill has a section on telephone services for the deaf.
As for travel, it does not discuss air transportation, which is already governed by a number of Federal laws and rules on the disabled, some of which have not yet been fitted together. It also does not consider facilities that have been built with Federal aid, including most airports, since the Federal money means they were subject to earlier Government requirements for access for the disabled.
 
The Key Areas
There are key areas of the bill that are visible: wide bathroom doors, for example; lifts on bus doors; elevators in shopping centers; grab bars in bathrooms. But when advocates for the disabled discuss the impact of the bill, they shy away from focusing on the visible. Many disabilities, like retardation or deafness, they say, are not visible and the solutions may not be visible either - a telephone relay system for the deaf uses a central operator to translate a visible message (either printed out or on a computer terminal) into a voice message and then to type in the reply.
Advocates of the bill point to the provisions that would make it illegal to refuse admission or use on the basis of disability, and say that their most valuable testimony has been from people who have been kept out of places because they use wheelchairs. These advocates say that this core of the bill may require changes in transport equipment or places of accommodation but that the need to rebuild existing facilities is not great.
The area that has caused dispute in Congress, and where the debate has spilled out into the public print, is the issue of putting lifts on buses for long-distance travel so that people in wheelchairs can get aboard without getting out of their chairs. The issues are how much the lifts add to the cost of new buses, how much luggage space they pre-empt and how many seats they eliminate.
Marilyn Golden, a policy analyst with the Disability Rights Education and Defense Fund, a principal supporter of the bill, testified in Congress this fall: ''Bus travel is the only travel available to poor Americans, and disabled Americans are three times more likely to fall below the Federal poverty line than nondisabled Americans. Bus travel is also the only route available to rural Americans, and disabled Americans live in rural areas in higher concentrations than the nondisabled.''
Wayne J. Smith, executive director of the United Bus Owners of America, writing for the Op-Ed page of The New York Times last month, said: ''By economically crippling the private bus industry with costly and unwarranted mandates, this bill would virtually eliminate the last form of public transportation available to most rural communities . . . . Not all bus companies would fail, of course. But the few surviving that charged enough to stay in business would be priced out of the range of today's primary riders . . . .''
As the bill was finally approved in the Senate, it would be six years before big scheduled private bus companies buying new buses would have to buy models with lifts; for small companies, the delay would be seven years.
In the meantime, the bill provides for a three-year study of the cost impact on the bus industry.
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, the main sponsor of the bill, said that cost claims of the industry were not true.
He cited the experience in Denver where a regional transit agency used a lift that added $10,000, or 5 percent, to the cost of a $200,000 bus - the bus association put the additional cost at $35,000 - with no loss of luggage space and loss of ''maybe one seat.''
In local transit, new vehicles would have to be accessible and, in addition, a ''comparable'' system of vans or similar vehicles would be provided for those who could not use regular buses, unless this resulted in an undue financial burden. The advocates of the bill as the Senate passed it oppose total reliance on a van system of the sort often provided for the disabled and elderly because it requires calls in advance and usually operates only in daytime hours.
As for charter and tour bus companies, the bill says that if a company is already able to accommodate the requests it receives for transporting the disabled, it does not need to get special fittings on its new equipment. A company would have to get lift-fitted vehicles when it bought new ones if it was not meeting demand.
For rail transportation, the main requirement would involve platforms that provide level - that is, roll on - entrance. Key subway stations would have to be made accessible within three years, with exemptions of up to 20 years for difficult stations.
These schedules are moot in a few cities, including New York, where the transit agency has agreed to a timetable of changes as a result of lawsuits by the Eastern Paralyzed Veterans Association.
Amtrak stations would be allowed 20 years. According to Amtrak, many problems over 10 years have held up ''barrier free'' access to Penn Station in New York. Most recently, bids on a street-level elevator at 33d Street came in higher than the budget allowed but the line will seek added money. Four platform-level elevators await city inspection, according to a spokeswoman, Pat Dorica. Bus and rail depots that were built without Federal money would have to be adapted to allow access.
 
Public Accommodations
In the area of public accommodations, the bill covers 12 categories: lodging places, restaurants and bars, places for exhibitions or entertainment, assembly places, retail sales places, service establishments, transportation terminals, places of public display or collection, schools, parks and zoos, social service establishments and exercise or recreation places.
It exempts from the requirement that new buildings must have elevators those buildings under three stories or under 3,000 square feet per story unless they are health-care facilities or shopping centers. Buildings undergoing renovations would have to make the renovated area accessible to the disabled, and the toilets in the renovated areas would have to be built for use by the disabled.
Ms. Golden was asked for her view of the world after the Americans With Disabilities Act was in force.
''I envision a day,'' she said, ''when of course buildings will be accessible, of course public transit will be available, when the disabled can work, travel home, have vacations with their families.
''We will look back and be astonished at what our world was once like, as we look back and are appalled at a time when we tolerated slavery and child labor.'' Her words were inadvertently echoed by a recent visitor to Australia who said that everything for the tourist was adapted for the disabled and that no one appeared to find it out of the ordinary.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 28, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 835 words

HEADLINE: A VICTORY HALF WON

BYLINE: By DAVID J. GARROW; David J. Garrow is the author of ''Bearing the Cross: Martin Luther King, Jr., and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference.''

 BODY:

FREEDOM BOUND
A History of America's Civil Rights Movement.
By Robert Weisbrot.
Illustrated. 350 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $21.95.
For well over a decade the historiography of the civil rights movement has featured many admirable middle- and small-gauge studies. Some have treated particular groups - the Congress of Racial Equality, the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee - or single leaders, especially Martin Luther King Jr. Others have focused on individual locales - Greensboro, N.C., Tuskegee, Ala. - or singular events, such as the 1955 lynching of Emmett Till or the 1965 Selma voting-rights campaign. 
Until now, only several books from the early 1980's, including Harvard Sitkoff's ''Struggle for Black Equality, 1954-1980'' and Rhoda L. Blumberg's ''Civil Rights,'' have sought to provide comprehensive, single-volume surveys of the black freedom struggle after World War II, and readers have not had a dependable, scholarly introduction to the civil rights era.
Robert Weisbrot's ''Freedom Bound'' is a commendable and often beautifully written effort to fill this gap. Ranging widely and inclusively from World War II to the Reagan Administration, Mr. Weisbrot's cogent survey describes the better-known events in the South - the Montgomery bus boycott in 1955-56, the 1963 Birmingham demonstrations - while also giving full and fair attention to Northern activists and commentators, from Malcolm X to Imamu Amiri Baraka (LeRoi Jones) to the social critic Harold Cruse. In many instances, such as his depiction of the generational tensions that troubled the Southern movement in the early 1960's and of the political ambivalence that marked the Kennedy Administration's dealings with Southern black activists, Mr. Weisbrot's account is interpretively astute and superbly phrased.
''Freedom Bound'' is based more on secondary sources than on original oral history or archival work. Although much of that research appears to date from 1984-85, only rarely - such as in his accounts of the 1964 Democratic National Convention in Atlantic City and the 1966 Chicago freedom movement negotiations between King and Mayor Richard J. Daley - does Mr. Weisbrot err seriously by relying excessively on single sources. Those sections and some others should be corrected and improved before ''Freedom Bound'' makes its way into the paperback college-course market, along with the mangled names and erroneous photo captions that also mar what otherwise would be a first-rate piece of work.
Such errors detract and distract, but they are easily correctable in a book that should enjoy a relatively long life because of its unrivaled breadth and perspicacious analyses. Mr. Weisbrot, a professor of history at Colby College in Maine, stumbles by repeatedly using ''underclass'' far more loosely than social policy analysts do, and ought to rephrase a characterization of the Watts ghetto as ''a squalid human anthill''; otherwise, his fluid prose and apt diction capture the ascent and the descent of the civil rights struggle.
The young organizers of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee were on the cutting edge of the Southern movement during both those successive stages, and ''Freedom Bound'' astutely portrays what Mr. Weisbrot terms ''SNCC's political journey from faith to cynicism.'' His account of how '' 'Black Power' could mean all things to all people'' is similarly trenchant, and he straightforwardly addresses how the Johnson Administration and the civil rights movement failed to mount massive or sustained assaults on black poverty and economic exclusion. King recognized in Chicago in 1966 that poverty would be a far more intractable opponent than Southern segregation, but only in the last six months of his life did he turn his full attention to economic issues. King's growing realization that questions of class were equally if not more important than distinctions of race foreshadowed many of the conclusions that analysts such as William J. Wilson have recently reached regarding black America's economic bifurcation and decline over the past 20 years. King warned that deep economic division was just as great an evil as deep racial division, and no scholar or even casual observer can fail to note, in any major city, that the cost of America's failure to heed that warning continues to grow every day.
Mr. Weisbrot correctly observes that ''the roots of racial inequality have proved too deeply embedded in centuries of American history to be washed away'' by the reform statutes of the 1960's. ''Freedom Bound'' more often than not does a praiseworthy job of explaining both the familiar and the unheralded aspects of this chapter from our recent history, a history we all should know, if only better to appreciate the growing economic and racial divisions that mark the United States today. As Mr. Weisbrot concludes, ''In important respects the society's newfound emphasis on interracial harmony has been more rhetorical than real.''

SECTION: Section 7; Page 32, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 930 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy

BYLINE: GEORGE JOHNSON

 BODY:

UTZ, by Bruce Chatwin. (Penguin, $7.95.) A petty aristocrat named Kaspar Joachim Utz becomes trapped in Czechoslovakia by the priceless collection of porcelain that he refuses to leave behind. The last novel of Bruce Chatwin, who died earlier this year, shows him ''at his most erudite and evocative,'' Robert Stone said here in January. '' 'Utz' provides its readers with a rich and rewarding meditation.''
 
THE MASTER OF THE GAME: Paul Nitze and the Nuclear Peace, by Strobe Talbott. (Vintage, $10.95.) In the third installment of his chronicles of arms control, Strobe Talbott tells how the ever-practical negotiator Paul Nitze turned Ronald Reagan's utopian Star Wars plan into a bargaining chip. Mr. Talbott ''demonstrates his own mastery of bureaucratic drama, combining a gift for characterization and an eye for the revealing anecdote with a firm grasp of his subject,'' Lawrence Freedman said in The Book Review in 1988. ''His sources are enviable, allowing him to offer an instant history that rings true throughout.'' 
 
CAT'S EYE, by Margaret Atwood. (Bantam, $5.95.) An artist goes home to Toronto for a retrospective of her paintings and finds herself haunted by memories of a disturbed childhood friend. ''All this is vintage Atwood,'' our reviewer, Alice McDermott, said in February: ''the precise and devastating detail, the sense of the ordinary transformed into nightmare, the quiet desperation of characters trapped, silenced, utterly alone.''
 
DESPERADOS: Latin Drug Lords, U.S. Lawmen, and the War America Can't Win, by Elaine Shannon. (Penguin, $4.95.) A reporter for Time magazine tells why she thinks economic and diplomatic relations between Mexico and the United States interfered with the investigation into the death of Enrique Camarena, the Drug Enforcement Administration agent who was murdered in Guadalajara. This ''well-reported reconstruction of the investigation'' raises ''disturbing questions,'' Jeff Gerth said here last year.
 
THE FIFTH STATION, by Kevin McIlvoy. (Collier/Macmillan, $6.95.) When their brother is killed in a mill accident, two steelworkers move to New Mexico and try to forget. Last year our reviewer, Patricia Dobler, said this first novel is ''rich with details of both mill life and life in a rural New Mexican community.''
 
TOCQUEVILLE: A Biography, by Andre Jardin. Translated by Lydia Davis with Robert Hemenway. (Noonday/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $14.95.) This biography of the visitor who explained the American mind to both the French and the Americans is ''written with admirable thoroughness,'' Joan Wallach Scott said here in February.
 
THE VEILED ONE, by Ruth Rendell. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Like a patient with his psychiatrist, the suspect in a parking-garage murder develops a fixation on his interrogator. Last year our reviewer, Josh Rubins, said Ruth Rendell's ''uncompromising psychological suspense novels . . . offer harrowing, coolly ironic excursions into the minds of genteel psychopaths and secret sex offenders, the lonely and obsessed and deluded. . . . [Her] prose - lean, sly, almost clinical - reinforces the bleakness.''
 
THE SIGNIFYING MONKEY: A Theory of African-American Literary Criticism, by Henry Louis Gates Jr. (Oxford University, $10.95.) Looking to both ancient African myths and contemporary literary theory, a scholar develops a new theory of black literature. ''This somewhat intimidating, quite serious essay in literary criticism can be enjoyed by a variety of readers,'' John Wideman said in The Book Review last year. Oxford has also reissued Mr. Gates's 1987 book, FIGURES IN BLACK: WORDS, SIGNS, AND THE ''RACIAL'' SELF ($10.95), in which he applies the ideas of modern critics like Michel Foucault and Jacques Derrida to the works of Ishmael Reed, Alice Walker and other black writers. Howard University Press has republished BLACK IS THE COLOR OF THE COSMOS: Essays on Afro-American Literature and Culture, 1942-1981 ($15.95). The pieces, written by Charles T. Davis and edited by Mr. Gates, analyze such authors as Jean Toomer, Richard Wright and Ralph Ellison.
 
WAVERLY PLACE, by Susan Brownmiller. (Signet/New American Library, $4.95.) In a fictionalized account of the Joel Steinberg-Hedda Nussbaum case, Susan Brownmiller tries to fathom how a couple in her Greenwich Village neighborhood dug themselves into a sadomasochistic life that led to the killing of a 6-year-old girl. Last year The Times's Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said that, while the book is not satisfying as a novel, it ''serves a potentially constructive purpose. It tries to fill the emotional void created by any incomprehensible human act. It proposes how such a thing could have happened and allows us to participate in the drama of its answer.''
 
ALICIA: My Story, by Alicia Appleman-Jurman. (Bantam, $4.95.) After losing her family, a teen-age girl helps her fellow Poles escape the Nazis. This autobiography is ''so profoundly observed, and the life it records so remarkably lived, that no amount of prior immersion in the sad community of witnesses to the Holocaust can dull the reader to its heroine,'' Sonia Taitz said in The Book Review last year.
 
KOKO, by Peter Straub. (Signet/New American Library, $5.95.) Three Vietnam veterans suspect that a member of their old platoon is the infamous Koko, a serial killer in Southeast Asia who leaves a playing card with a picture of an elephant in his victims' mouths. ''In this fable of men undone by the ultimate horror, evil is anything but banal,'' Richard Fuller said here last year.

HEADLINE: HE LEFT HER FOR A WOMAN CALLED PINKY

BYLINE: By TIM SANDLIN; Tim Sandlin's most recent novel is ''Western Swing.''

 BODY:

THE CHINCHILLA FARM
By Judith Freeman.
308 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $19.95.
The Southern border state is not so much a location as a state of mind. For me, Kentucky, Tennessee, Arkansas, Oklahoma, Utah and parts of Maine qualify as Southern border states. And border state fiction is not so much a technique as an economic class. 
In this fiction, at its most cliched, MeMaw puts her hair up in paper curlers, drives the Rambler 40 miles to a Wal-Mart to buy Mason jars and afterward feels sinful as she splurges at Burger Boy. But in the hands of a writer who neither cutely condescends nor wallows in romantic nostalgia for the good old days - Bobbie Ann Mason, Charles Portis and now Judith Freeman - it can ring with authenticity and compassion for people living 1950's family values in a high-tech 1980's world.
Judith Freeman knows her people. First, in her short-story collection, ''Family Attractions,'' and now in her remarkable first novel, ''The Chinchilla Farm,'' she moves into each scene and chooses the one detail that makes it all true, that brings the rest of us who grew up in border states back to lost images.
The novel is at its best during the many flashbacks of its narrator Verna Flake's childhood in a large Mormon family living on the edge of the Great Salt Lake. In the Flake household, newspapers are carefully spread on the kitchen table for the weekly ritual of polishing the Sunday shoes; bags of clothes are sprinkled with water, then stored in the deep freeze to await ironing; on the front porch, a sign carved in yellow knotty pine reads KWITCHURBELLYACHIN. Life revolves around the family and the church.
Honestly portraying the lives of modern Mormons is a tough trick. Most writers - in fact, all writers I've read except Ms. Freeman - are so prejudiced either for or against Mormons that their characters run from God's own down-home saints to silly hypocrites, with little in between. But the people in this book have flesh - and contradictions, triumphs and failures. They can be petty and generous at the same time.
When Verna is 34, her husband of 17 years collects all his outdoor sports gear and leaves her for a former Miss Wyoming runner-up named Pinky. Until that moment, every detail of Verna's existence has been dictated by church, family and husband. Freedom blows the boundaries off her life, leaving more options than she ever dreamed possible. The first option Verna chooses is to load her possessions into a horse trailer, gas up the pickup truck and drive to Los Angeles to start a new life.
In California, she briefly comes in contact with the snooty set, with men who say things like, ''His music was emotional in the romantic manner, poetically conceived, but nevertheless cast in the formal molds of the classical school. A very interesting composer, Schubert.'' To which Verna replies that her favorite musician is Patsy Cline. The Los Angeles upper-crust scenes don't have quite the authenticity of the Utah bowling alley. Maybe people in Los Angeles actually say, ''nevertheless cast in the formal molds.'' I doubt it, but then I never met anyone who prefers Schubert to Patsy Cline.
Soon Verna finds a job and an apartment on the seedier side of the city, and we get back to Ms. Freeman's amazing eye for details - the mixed sounds of air conditioning, produce trucks and domestic violence, the smell of bums in the library, the shininess of a wino's blanket. Verna reconnects with her dead brother's wife, Inez, who is now married to an abusive gun freak. With no more forethought than she gave the move to California, Verna takes flight to Mexico with Inez, her daughter, Christobel (who ''may be slow, but she's no dummy''), and a broken alcoholic named Duluth Wing.
After 305 pages of an almost Tolstoyan insight into the human plight, at the end of the novel Ms. Freeman jumps ahead several years for three pages of tying up loose ends. To use a literary term, these three pages suck eggs.
The last three pages aside, Judith Freeman has written a beautiful book, beautiful because of the compassion of Verna Flake. Verna could easily fall back on the excuse of victimization by men and Mormons, but she rejects any hint of self-pity. ''I'd stick with you now,'' she tells her husband, ''but I don't think it would work . . . you, me, and Pinky. You got every right to walk out if that's what you've decided. I'm not going to give you any argument.'' Nor is Verna a passive, put-upon woman drifting helplessly between crises. Her revenge on the husband-stealer Pinky is swift and Western.
The special thing about Verna is the way she treats each person in her path with equal openness. Verna approaches each individual with pleasant good intentions and expects the same in return. Her journey from Utah to Mexico puts her in touch with a strange variety of users, abusers and lost souls leading colorless lives with little hope of any improvement. And Verna, like her creator, Judith Freeman, accepts without judgment the good and bad in each one. She not only survives the morass of 1950's family values in a high-tech 1980's world, she is quietly triumphant.

HEADLINE: IN SHORT;
NONFICTION

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON

 BODY:

THE BIG FIX. Inside the S&L Scandal: How an Unholy Alliance of Politics and Money Destroyed America's Banking System. By James Ring Adams. (John Wiley & Sons, $19.95.) Finance - and financial fraud - can be dry and arcane. But in ''The Big Fix,'' James Ring Adams offers a front-row seat at a three-ring circus. Mr. Adams presents the downfall of some high-flying financial empires, including the Butcher brothers' Tennessee banking system and Charles Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. He also chronicles the bumbling efforts of financial regulators, who seemed unable to rein in banks and savings and loan associations when their examiners found problems. And Mr. Adams shows members of Congress - from former House Speaker Jim Wright to Senators Donald Riegle and Alan Cranston - juggling political contributions with one hand while using the other to interrupt the regulatory process. But Mr. Adams, a financial journalist, means to do more than tell tales. He argues persuasively that the system of Government insurance for bank and thrift deposits - instituted after the banking crises of the 1930's - was ''a deeply flawed notion,'' bound to go haywire. Such guarantees, he explains, allow financial institutions to keep attracting funds even as they make risky investments and lose money; depositors do not care because they know that the Government will reimburse them even if a bank or a savings and loan institution closes. Now that Americans are faced with a bill estimated at more than $150 billion to make good on the deposits of failed savings and loan associations, Mr. Adams should find a ready audience.

HEADLINE: Incentive Exists In N.F.L.

 BODY:
To the Sports Editor:
Gerald W. Scully, who wrote recently on National Football League labor relations (''Tackling the N.F.L. Labor Impasse, The New York Times, Nov. 28), ignored current N.F.L. economic trends disproving his contention that there is little financial incentive to win in pro football.
Scully theorized that N.F.L. revenue sharing dampens economic incentives. Yet, the primary source of shared revenue, the league's television contracts, has not increased in three seasons while expenses, particularly player salaries, have skyrocketed. And when franchises have been sold huge debt service payments have been acquired by the new owners.
In this economic climate, the financial incentive to win is clear. Winning teams have a greater opportunity to generate revenues that can mean the difference between breaking even or a financial loss.
Even cursory research would have refuted Scully's position that revenues do not rise much with a winning season because games are sold out. Experience shows that few noncompetitive teams sell out their games, while losing teams that become winners sell more tickets and increase their revenues.
The Buffalo Bills, for example, had a 12-4 regular-season record in 1988 and set an N.F.L. in-stadium attendance mark with 622,793 fans. The Bills sold 40,117 season tickets. Four seasons earlier, the Bills' record was 2-14. The club sold 19,031 season tickets to 80,290-seat Rich Stadium and played before 303,145 home fans.
Scully's research was also inaccurate regarding average N.F.L. career length, which he incorrectly stated as less than three years. The average experience of N.F.L. players in the 1989 season is 4.4 years, up from 4.05 years last season. In this decade, the average N.F.L. career has not dropped below 4.0 years.
 
JOHN M. JONES
Director of Public Relations
 N.F.L. Management Council

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES: East Side Zoning;
Adjusting the Rules for Avenue Buildings

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
IN New York City, zoning change is always in the air. Ever since the basic change of 1961 there have been refinements and additions to the law, sometimes tending to encourage, sometimes to discourage, redevelopment. And at times the goal is to alter the style of new residential construction.
So it is with a new ''discussion document'' on the issues and options in regulating residential towers and plazas in Manhattan, brought forward last month by the Department of City Planning. Its goal is to open discussions leading to zoning changes that would alter the standard residential building that might rise in the future on the wide cross streets and avenues, from Third Avenue eastward, of the Upper East Side.
Currently that building is normally a straight tower behind an open plaza. But the planners are envisioning a more ''contextual'' building - after the fashion of new zoning on the West Side - of a tower over a substantial base built to the streetline. 
In current contextual zoning on the West Side, this base on the avenues is typically 150 feet - about 12 stories. Then the building is forced to step back under a formula that allows little additional height above the base. On the East Side the base might be lower, perhaps 60 to 85 feet, or six to eight stories. And a rule is suggested to force a significant percentage of the building's bulk toward its base.
This would limit the height of the tower and, in the process, limit the transfer of unutilized development rights above existing adjacent occupied buildings.
The consequences of this proposed change would be significant. The policy questions, as the Planning Department acknowledges, involve complex technical issues in urban design and economics. Community groups, architects, developers and planners are likely to differ as much on what the problems are as they will on their solution.
From the community perspective, Constance Adamec, chairwoman of the planning and development committee of Community Board 8, noted that the proposals would produce ''lower, squatter buildings, which is more in keeping with what we would like to see.''
''Our concern is huge towers that are overshadowing the community,'' she said. Similar concerns have been voiced by influential East Side civic organizations - among them Civitas, the Friends of the Upper East Side Historic Districts, the Yorkville Civic Council, Carnegie Hill Neighbors.
The higher towers are in many cases a direct result of rent regulations and its strong occupancy protection for tenants, which are both the cause and result of the East Side's tight housing market.
To avoid displacement pressure on these tenants, and yet allow for reasonable redevelopment, builders have been allowed to shift unutilized development rights above occupied buildings from abutting plots to a building plot within a ''merged zoning lot.''
There are other causes as well. In a study done for Civitas, Craig Whitaker, an architect, found that a significant amount of the bulk in post-1961 avenue buildings could be attributed to the added 25 feet of depth that the ordinance gave to the higher-density avenue zones, previously only 100 feet deep into the midblock.
Genie Rice, president of Civitas, expressed disappointment that the planners had not proposed to restore the 25-foot strip to a lower midblock density. She called this the ''missing element'' in a proposal that goes far to meet the organization's concerns.
''It needs work,'' said Mrs. Elizabeth Ashby, president of Carnegie Hill Neighbors.
The Planning Department, for its part, has focused its attention on reducing the emphasis of the 1961 law on creating open plazas, and on ''packing the bulk'' in new buildings at the base rather than in the tower. Indirectly, this has the effect of reducing the use unutilized development rights from nearby lots on a single building lot.
The Planning Department has avoided a direct assault on merged zoning lots, mainly on the ground that an enforceable, loophole-free definition of zoning lot mergers could not be devised, and that in any event such a restriction could have unintended and unwanted consequences.
NOR is there, in a direct sense, a downzoning involved in the planners' proposals. The basic zoning on the East Side's avenues and wide cross streets between 59th and 96th Streets would remain with an F.A.R. of 10 or its equivalent (10 square feet of allowable building square footage for each square foot of land) and the 20 percent bonus would remain, but in altered form.
On large sites, only half the bonus would be available from a plaza; the other half would have to come from inclusionary zoning. In new construction on private land, this is the bonus builders are allowed for producing new low-income housing within the community district or within half a mile of it. They are allowed four square feet of building area for each square foot of low-income housing produced, up to the benefit limit of a given site.
On the West Side, where new contextual zones have been introduced on the avenues and major cross streets, the plaza bonus has been eliminated entirely and the inclusionary housing bonus is the only as-of-right mechanism still left to get the 20 percent bonus.
On smaller East Side avenue sites (12,500 square feet or less) the planners propose to eliminate the plaza bonus. Only the inclusionary housing bonus would be available.
The planners did an exhaustive study of residential development in Community Board 8's area from 1978 to 1988. It turned out that there were 77 projects in the R-10 or R-10 equivalent zones, 31 of them with plazas providing nearly five acres of publicly accessible open space. The study notes ''significant'' increases in the heights of buildings, as well as decreases in the size of floorplates and zoning lot coverage. Towers averaged 40 stories, instead of 30 to 32 in the original prototypical tower building.
IN a handful of situations, unusually tall and thin towers have been built behind plazas next to permanently preserved streetline buildings. One such is on view at 54 East End Avenue, at 82d Street, where a 40-story building has a tower occupying only 19 percent of its zoning lot. Older buildings on the zoning lot are preserved. Current zoning law provides a maximum of 40 percent of the zoning lot that the tower can occupy, but no minimum.
In another instance, on the southwest corner of 88th Street and First Avenue, a new 46-story tower building with 163 apartments and no plaza uses more than 50,000 square feet of unutilized development rights from its zoning lot to produce eight more 6,000-square-foot floors. About 75 apartments in the older abutting buildings are permanently preserved; ''contextuality'' is sacrificed.
But for those who argue for lower new buildings on the ground that they favor contextuality, there is the problem that along many blocks of the Upper East Side avenues the context has already turned to towers. And elsewhere it is hard to make a case for contextuality because existing housing is too diverse. Specific locations may be exceptional - East End Avenue, as an example - in which case the traditional zoning approach would be to identify contextual locations and zone them according to their context.
Another issue builders must consider is the marketability of space in the fat bases of East Side buildings. Views sell. But would buyers pay at least $300 a square foot to live on the fourth floor of a new building fronting on Second Avenue? Or even more important, would a building project on Second Avenue be economically feasible if, for example, 60 percent of the floor space had to be sold at the prices obtainable on the first 12 floors?
ANOTHER problem that arises with bases that are too bulky and towers that are too skimpy is that floor space is less effectively usable. Many rooms become too deep and too dark. But where contextuality is deemed the issue, some architects say, a base of 60 feet, or about five floors, would put a new avenue residential structure in context with a surviving five-story tenement nearby, while still allowing for a usable tower.
A strong case can be made for not growing too restrictive and narrow about the types of new residential buildings that can be designed for the broad eastern avenues of the Upper East Side, which even with no zoning changes might take decades to redevelop. The planners have tried to avoid that, while restricting the plaza bonus. But the discussion is only starting on what should be achieved in the way of new building design on the Upper East Side.

LENGTH: 2356 words

HEADLINE: Linking 421a to Low-Income Housing

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
MOST of the people in the Spring Creek Gardens complex in the East New York section of Brooklyn earn considerably less than $20,000 a year, while those in the Belaire condo minium tower, on Manhattan's Upper East Side, make whatever is needed to buy half-million dollar condominium apartments and million-dollar penthouses.
Yet the two communities, so different in resources and life styles, are neighbors in a way, linked by law and a kind of municipal symbiosis. For the people in the Belaire, probably without knowing it, paid for the housing at Spring Creek Gardens. The Brooklynites, also unaware, will return the favor over the next 10 years by reducing the expensive con dominium development's real estate tax es through the city's 421a program.
The program works like this: A builder of low- or moderate-income housing re ceives from the city five transferable real estate tax abatement certificates for each unit of new affordable housing, or 3.3 certificates for each renovated apartment. 
That developer then covers much of the cost of building the low-rent housing by selling the certificates - currently for about $20,000 each - to builders of market-rate condominiums and rental apartments in Manhattan. For each certificate, the Manhattan developer gets a 10-year graduated tax abatement on one new apartment. He then recoups the cost of the certificates through the lower taxes and higher selling prices of the market-rate building.
More than 900 low-income apartments outside the prime Manhattan residential area are now in various stages of development under this program, but not entirely in the way the city had planned. When the trade-off was established in 1985, the city expected the tax abatements alone to raise enough money to pay for low-income housing, but the de velopers of big low-income projects such as Spring Creek Gardens have coupled the city program with the Federal Low Income Housing Tax credit.
Critics accuse the developers of low income housing of doubling subsidies and inflating their profits in this way, but the builders themselves insist that the city program alone does not produce enough cash to pay for the affordable housing.
Besides raising charges of ''double dipping'' by developers - one City Councilman calls it a giveaway - this practice has also meant that only housing for the lowest-income families, those making no more than $13,000 for a family of four, can be built under the rules of the Federal program. The city wanted moderate-income housing included in the 421a deal with developers, and the City Council recently amended the city law to require such housing in developments with more than 130 units.
MEANWHILE, the 421a tax-abatement certificates have quickly become big business, to the surprise of some city housing officials and the dismay of critics of the program, who fear the mounting cost - $177 million this year alone - to the city in lost taxes. With the certificates currently selling for about $20,000 each, the five-for-one formula works out to a cost to the city of $100,000 for each unit of affordable housing built.
General Atlantic Realty Corporation, which built Spring Creek Gardens, sold 184 of the 1,425 abatement certificates the development has generated to Zeckendorf Properties, which Zeckendorf then used to lower the taxes on the 184 condominiums at its Belaire at 524 East 72d Street. The Zeckendorf company then used the abatements as a marketing tool, lowering prices to draw customers while saving on taxes during construction.
''I think it's the finest program for the production of low-income housing in the country,'' said Philip E. Aarons, president of General Atlantic. ''It produces the highest quality housing at the lowest cost.''
The developers of Davidson Court, a new 38-unit low-income project built by Davidson Court Associates in the Mariners Harbor section of Staten Island, sold 200 of their tax abatement certificates to a second condominium project being built by Zeckendorf and Peter Malkin, another developer, on the corner of 72d Street and Broadway.
In some cases, the developer of low-income housing uses the certificates himself, as Lawrence Smiley, a partner in Lexington Avenue Properties, did with 71 of the abatements he gained by doing a gut rehabilitation of 32 apartments in an adjoining pair of city-owned apartments at 1130 College Avenue in the South Bronx.
The abatements, at the ratio of 3.3 to 1 for renovated low-income housing, have been transferred to Mr. Smiley's 72-unit high-end condominium at 127 East 30th Street, at Lexington Avenue, where they were used as a marketing tool. Part of the saving went to the buyers, Mr. Smiley said, and part came to him as higher profits.
Once the rehab is completed, it will be turned over to the South Bronx Community Management Corporation, a nonprofit group that will own the renovated property debt-free and operate it. Spring Creek Gardens in Brooklyn is being operated by Phipps Houses, another nonprofit housing management corporation.
The city imposed the linkage between low-income housing and market-rate housing in Manhattan south of 96th Street and north of Spring Street in 1985. Before then, developers were using the 421a abatements to build expensive apartments in Manhattan, a trend that brought the Koch adminsistration under fire from housing advocates for subsidizing housing for the rich.
Developers insisted then, as they do now, that the combination of taxes and higher development costs in Manhattan make the abatements essential for building even market-rate housing on the island.
The program is by far the more productive of the city's two that link the development of expensive housing with affordable housing, said Kenneth Lowenstein, deputy commissioner of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development. It is also more expensive, prompting a minor revolt in the City Council earlier this month against extending key portions of the law.
The other linkage program, called Inclusionary Zoning, gives 20 percent density bonuses to builders who create low-income housing near the building receiving the bonus. About 100 such units have been produced, all in the central Manhattan residential area to which it is limited, the city's housing agency said.
Mr. Aarons and his associates sold the tax-abatement certificates from Spring Creek Gardens for $28 million and paid the additional $4 million cost of the development from their own equity, recouping it and a profit - Mr. Aarons declined to say how much - by syndicating income tax credits granted the project by the Federal Government under its Low Income Housing Tax Credit program.
BESIDES Spring Creek Gardens, Davidson Court and Mr. Smiley's rehab project on College Avenue, the following 421a low-income projects have been approved for tax abatement trades by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development:
* Girard Gardens, a 121-unit new apartment building on Girard Avenue, just north of Yankee Stadium, the Bronx, by Victor Politis in partnership with Mr. Aarons.
* A 129-unit rehabilitation project involving three separate buildings on West 143d, 146th and 147th Streets by Jason Carter.
* A four-unit rehab by Izak Namer, developer, yet to begin work on 128th street.
* An 18-unit rehabilitation at 911 East 165th Street in the Morrisania section of the Bronx, by Elliott Hirschfeld.
Because the sale of the tax abatements, the 421a program pays almost all low-income housing construction costs. The developments are being turned over to their nonprofit sponsors for management mortgage-free. Rents therefore stay low, because they need only cover operation and maintenance.
Some City Council members have complained that the program costs the city too much in a time of fiscal austerity, considering that of the seven projects now completed or under way, four are new construction projects that use the Federal Low Income Housing Tax Credit program, which issues tax credits to investors in low-income housing.
This use of a Federal and city cross subsidy prompted Councilman Stanley E. Michels, a Manhattan Democrat-Liberal, to ask if the city is giving away millions in lost taxes to encourage housing that would be built anyway with Federal tax largesse.
''We're hearing that the Federal program is what's building these projects, so why the hell are we giving away $100,000 per apartment?'' he demanded in an interview.
The charge is an echo of the complaints made against the Koch administration in the mid-80's, when the 421a tax abatement was available for all apartments. The program had been started in 1972, when the city's economy was a mess and the rate of housing abandonment exceeded the rate of new construction.
But in the boom years of the mid-80's, the 421a program became an expensive public subsidy, the City Council concluded, for the construction of expensive private apartment buildings.
The Koch administration came under fire for the resulting expense in lost taxes on those buildings - a half billion dollars by 1985 - and the law was amended to exclude tax breaks for market-rate buildings south of 96th Street and north of Spring Street in Manhattan unless they were tied to low-income housing built outside that zone.
City officials and housing advocates defend the 421a program by arguing that housing might be built without the 421a subsidy but that the financing costs would be so high that rents would not be affordable to many tenants.
''Without 421a, there is no way you could build low-income housing without massive city subsidies,'' said Mr. Lowenstein, of the city's housing agency. ''With the program, the luxury developer pays for the construction of low-income housing instead of the city.''
But the luxury builder then takes his abatement from the city at the rate of $177 million for the current 1990 fiscal year, the largest residential tax abatement on the city books and a figure that has been rising steadily since the abatements were made ''portable'' between the low-income housing site and the luxury building in Manhattan.
In the 1987 fiscal year, the cost to the city of the program was $88 million in lost taxes; in 1988, it was $114 million, and for the 1989 fiscal year the figure was $151 million.
GEORGE ADRONIS, vice president of Phipps Houses, the nonprofit housing agency that manages Spring Creek Gardens, said that the issue was not just building apartments, but putting them on the market at rents that are affordable to the target population of low-income families.
''You wouldn't have seen those affordable units built without the 421a program,'' he said. ''To the extent that no one else is building affordable units now, there at 285 who are living at Spring Creek now who would either not have been able to find housing at all, or would be paying more in their rent than they could properly afford.''
According to an analysis of the 421a program by lawyers for the City Council, the city-Federal cross subsidy that developers have thought up on new building in Manhattan works like this:
The developer obtains an agreement from the city's housing agency to put up an affordable housing development outside central Manhattan, with the tax abatement certificates to be delivered when the units are occupied. On the strength of this agreement the banks make short-term construction loans, while the developer obtains rights to the Federal low-income housing tax credit, which is administered by the state.
The tax credit allows its holder a credit equal to about 9 percent of the development costs of a low-income housing project over a 10-year period. The tax credit is syndicated to other investors, each receiving a share of the credit proportionate to his share of the investment pool that, the program assumed, would go toward building housing for low-income families.
Under the cross-subsidy system instituted by developers in conjunction with the 421a program, however, the Federal tax credit produces not housing but profit - ''the whipped cream on the icing,'' Councilman Michels complained - because the market for city tax abatements has grown so lucrative.
Mr. Lowenstein of the housing agency said officials were surprised that the market for tax abatements would be so hot, but the reasons for this are plain: The abatements save $30 to $50 a square foot in development costs, depending on tax assessment. With overall development costs routinely hitting $400 or $500 a square foot, that is an important saving.
For developers, those savings on taxes and in construction borrowing - with fewer taxes due, borrowing needs diminish - spell the difference between success and failure in the Manhattan housing market.
''We have demonstrated that the developers of market rate housing in fact need the abatements for rental and condo project to work economically,'' Mr. Aarons said. ''Anyone who has been in the market knows that 421a is important for condos and essential for rentals because without them you cannot bring a project in at prices people can afford to pay. The combination of costs and taxes are just that high.''
TWINNING the city subsidy with the Federal program has produced another unexpected, and, to some, unwelcome, development. The Federal tax credit goes only to developments whose average tenant income is very low, no more than 60 percent of the city's median income of $20,280 for a family of four.
Since the 421a program is intended to produce housing for both low and moderate income families, those earning up to $30,000 a year, some affordable housing advocates and legislators who represent the new developments complain that the law is having the effect of creating housing segregation of the poor.
To meet the complaint, the City Council on Dec. 5 amended the law to require that in any 421a-subsidized low-income development of more than 130 units at least 20 percent of the units must be for moderate-income families. But officials say privately that the unavailability of the Federal subsidy for such housing will only keep developers away from that threshold.

HEADLINE: >Study Finds Divorce Benefits Men's Incomes

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
DIVORCE in Connecticut, aside from its emotional drain, is a severe economic drain for women and children, but the financial picture for men improves, according to a new study.
The study, which was released last week, found a 16 percent drop in weekly income for each person in a woman's household after a divorce; the weekly income for each person in a man's household after a divorce increased 23 percent.
The report was commissioned by the Connecticut Women's Education and Legal Fund, the Permanent State Commission on the Status of Women and the Women's Research Institute of Hartford College. 
''It's a little early to talk about what this will mean for public policy,'' said Fredrica Gray, the executive director of the commission.''But we do know we'll be looking harder at child support enforcement and divorce mediation. We now have even more evidence of the poverty extant in Connecticut among women.''
 
Findings Are Disputed
Bob Adams, the president of the Divorced Men's Association of Connecticut, disputed the findings, which were based on court records of 1,566 divorces issued in 1980 and 1984.
''They make it sound like women are scraping by,'' Mr. Adams said. ''But things have been changing for years. Many women are out in the marketplace competing for jobs. All I know is, there are groups vigorously going after fathers for child support. Would they enforce a father's visitation rights as vigorously?''
Four judicial districts were included in the study: Fairfield, Hartford, New Haven and Windham. The researchers also conducted a random telephone survey of 400 people divorced in Connecticut since Jan. 1, 1980.
The court records showed that divorced men received $182 a week for every person in their households. Divorced women received $124 a week for every person in their households.
The study says lawmakers wrongly assume that most divorce settlements are fair to both parties in terms of money. Women usually received more than half of the family's pre-divorce income, but in reality, the study says, the costs of rearing children - coupled with the high rate of men who do not pay child support - put a huge financial burden on women.

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Give Families a Choice of Schools

BYLINE: By Daniel B. Walsh; Daniel B. Walsh is president of the Business Council of New York State Inc.

 BODY:
SIX years after studies first warned that mediocre schools make America a nation at risk, the need to improve schools is so dire that it drew some of the country's top leaders to a nationwide summit just a few weeks ago.
On Long Island, as this year's tax revolt has pointed out, there are twin imperatives for school reform: Reduce the crushing costs that threaten to impoverish many taxpayers, and help all schools reach the excellence that so many already display.
Half a decade of spending new billions of dollars in an effort to improve New York State schools, including those on Long Island, has proven that more money is not the answer. State school aid had increased by $3.3 billion in six years. That increase amounts to 71 percent, roughly three times the rate of inflation. Does anyone seriously argue that the results have been equal to the new costs? 
Because it must fight the twin battles of cost and quality, Long Island is in a good position to benefit from a concept that is already in use in several New York State school districts: public school choice.
Giving families a choice allows them to select the school whose program most closely meets their children's needs. Students who want to focus on science and math should be able to do so; those whose talents lie with the arts or language should have a chance to develop their abilities as well.
But another element of school choice is equally important: parents can choose a school they believe is not just different, but better. In other words, schools may compete to provide the best education for students. Businessmen and women know firsthand how competition leads to higher quality. The same force that pushes manufacturers to build a better mousetrap, and service industries to work harder for their customers, can be a strong impetus for schools to provide better education.
Community School District 4 in Manhattan is a good example. In the mid-1970's, the East Harlem district was an icon of what's wrong with many schools in New York. One year, only 7 percent of students in a district high school graduated. On the most widely used indicator of success, reading achievement levels, only 15 percent of students could read above grade level.
East Harlem was also one of the poorest communities in the United States, and remains so. Yet, in the last decade, District 4 has proven that even the toughest environment cannot kill the desire for excellence. As of 1988, its pupils ranked 16th academically among New York City's 32 community school districts - not in the top ranks, to be sure, but a significant leap from its last-place status a few years earlier. Two-thirds of students scored at or above grade level in reading. District officials give their school choice program much of the credit for the turnaround.
A handful of other districts in New York - Syracuse, Buffalo, Rochester and Yonkers - have also put choice into effect and have seen it pay off in a variety of important ways. Typically, school choice leads parents to become more involved with their children's schooling, a step that almost invariably leads to better education.
Without school choice, parents will not truly be involved in the kind of restructuring called for at the recent education summit. Most of the crucial decisions about children's education options will continue to be made by administrators rather than families. The poorer the family, the fewer the options that will be available for the children in school.
Parental involvement is not the only benefit of a well-designed school choice program. Attendance improves dramatically. Schools are able to offer a greater variety of programs that meet different needs and interests. Integration is made easier.
Many observers have called for merging some of Long Island's 126 school districts as one step toward more cost-effective education. Allowing parents to choose their children's school within larger districts would eliminate many of the concerns that have been raised about such a change. Together, consolidation and choice could let students select from a much greater menu of educational programs and approaches.
Regardless of the consolidation issue, the bottom line with public school choice is a simple one: Students learn more. That result is clear not only in higher scores on standardized tests, but in the testimony of the educators and parents who have experienced school choice.
Public school choice is a matter of simple fairness. Families should have the right to choose which school within a district is best suited to their children's needs. The lack of choice suggests that children are products of cookie cutters, that each learns the same way and has the same interests.
Yet parents know that each child has his or her own abilities and interests. Typically, in a school district that has a handful of elementary schools, and perhaps two junior high or high schools, each school building or program often develops particular strengths and weaknesses. Why should school districts' organizational structures ignore such variety?
If money were the answer to New York's - and Long Island's - education problems, we would have solved them billions of dollars ago. It is time that education policymakers at both the state and local level look for the kind of progress that can't be bought, the kind of progress that's possible through public school choice.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Geriatric-Care Managers Face Growing Demand

 BODY:
The graying of New Jersey described in John Paul Marosy's article, ''When the Aged Need Care, Their Families Need a Hand'' (Opinion page, Oct. 15), coupled with the anticipated growth of the state's economy resulting in an increasing need for qualified workers, causes a new concern in the workplace.
Seventy percent of all home care for the aged is provided by family members, the majority of whom are women, and 70 percent of women between the ages of 35 and 54 are employed outside the home. These facts point to the critical need - one that demographers tell us will grow into the 21st century - for a qualified network of geriatric-care managers who can provide the help that families will require to cope with the stress of work, separation of families, multiplicity of community services, a confusing array of benefits, frequently changing regulations and various options for alternative living arrangements. 
As Mr. Marosy states, some help is being provided by forward-thinking corporations whose employers are offering flex-time, caregiver leave and informational handbooks. Beyond that, families need individually tailored care plans for their elderly relatives.
Private geriatric-care management, a profession that has grown in the last decade in response to a need, takes the family from the information-gathering stage to the implementation and supervision of a care plan combining resources within the family with community resources. The ultimate goal is to help the elderly person maintain independence to the greatest extent possible.
In several counties in New Jersey, geriatric-care managers are directing small private agencies that provide such services. Some of these professionals are members of the National Association of Private Geriatric Care Managers, which is committed to assuring the highest quality of care through education, advocacy and high standards of practice.
When the aged need care, their families do indeed need a hand, and that hand is often available through the services of a geriatric-care manager.
 
ELEANOR S. RUBIN
 Older Adult Resources and Services Inc.
 
South Orange
 The writer is co-director of a private geriatric-care management agency.

HEADLINE: Updating Needed In 'Oil vs. Fish' Debate

 BODY:
Factual errors and flawed arguments pervade Thomas Belton's call for ''constructive debate'' on offshore oil and gas exploration off New Jersey's coast (''Oil vs. Fish? No, a Way to Have Both,'' Opinion page, Oct. 29).
Mr. Belton paints drilling opponents as extremists by comparing them with drill-at-any-cost extremists on the other side. But the middle ground that emerges from this skewed picture - drilling with safeguards - is in fact one side of the current debate. Even the most ardent drilling supporters accept that stringent safeguards are necessary. And opponents, far from being flaky fish-huggers, are raising serious questions about the economic and environmental sense offshore drilling. 
Mr. Belton cites the Georges Bank, the rich fishing grounds off the Massachusetts coast where limited exploratory drilling took place in the early 1980's, and the ''cooperative plan'' that required a monitoring program to assess impacts. ''Monitoring results to date,'' he concludes, ''indicate that the Georges Bank has not been significantly affected by drilling activity. The fishing industry continues to flourish side by side with the oil company rigs.''
Mr. Belton should update his files. The drilling on the Georges Bank ended some eight years ago (with no finds), after fierce interagency battles, and the fishermen have not had to share space with any rigs since then, partly because of several court decisions that halted planned lease sales because of the great risks and uncertain benefits of exploration.
In addition, I am sure Mr. Belton would agree that a short-term monitoring program, in a single field where no commercial finds were made, is hardly a basis for conclusions about the risks of oil drilling.
Tighter regulation and better technology are the answers, according to Mr. Belton. But his arguments beg the most important question in the current debate: whether offshore drilling in general, and off New Jersey in particular, should play an important role in our energy picture.
Energy development policy is already well developed. Opponents of oil drilling are calling for an overall national energy policy that emphasizes conservation and safer sources, so that residents of coastal states will not have to choose between the security of their fisheries and recreational resources and the uncertain benefits of oil drilling.
 
PAUL HAUGE
 Metuchen
The writer is a biologist who was a staff scientist for the Conservation Law Foundation of New England in Boston, which successfully challenged several planned Georges Bank lease sales.
