LENGTH: 999 words

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Let's Reduce Hazardous Waste

BYLINE: By John H. Dorsey; John H. Dorsey, Republican of Boonton Township, is the Senate minority leader.

 BODY:
SOMEWHERE along Interstate 195 in western Monmouth County, on the stretch of highway between Trenton and Freehold, two huge wooden structures display graphic messages to passing motorists. Residents of this rural, undeveloped, horse-breeding region are, to say the least, unhappy with a proposal to site a hazardous-waste incinerator on one of the state's few remaining pieces of virgin land.
About 50 miles north, in a middle-sized blue-collar town where huge oil tanks and chemical companies dot the landscape between the truck-filled New Jersey Turnpike and the polluted Arthur Kill, billboards display similarly graphic messages. Residents of this overdeveloped, chemically saturated neighborhood, like their fellow New Jerseyans in Millstone, are opposed to the building of a toxic incinerator in their community. They believe that their area has suffered long enough from the effects of industrial pollutants. 
No one wants a hazardous-waste incinerator in his backyard. But until now, it was a foregone conclusion that if New Jersey was to continue to reap the benefits of a healthy economy and low unemployment, fueled to a great extent by industrial progress, the hazardous by-products of manufacturing, while the subject of strict regulations, would have to be tolerated.
State officials have spent at least a year arguing over whether it is safer to build incinerators in the wide-open, sparsely populated regions of the state - places like Millstone Township - or in densely populated areas like Linden. Placing these facilities at either location could be a death sentence for residents of the community and ultimately could lead to the deterioration of the municipality itself, which would most certainly lose its desirability as a place to live,work and raise a family.
A recent proposal by the Department of Environmental Protection, however, would change the focus of the problem from disposal of to minimization of the amount of hazardous waste produced, a far easier and more solvable problem with which to deal and one with which all of us, private citizen and public official alike, can live.
The source reduction approach is nothing new, and, as a matter of fact, has been touted as an alternative method of dealing with hazardous substances for several years by some members of the Legislature.
The department's plan to shift the focus of its anti pollution efforts to source reduction strategies for the industrial community highlights a series of Republican proposals that reflect a dramatic shift in strategies undertaken to preserve the environment for future generations.
The plan proposed by the Department of Environmental Protectionespouses the same theme as a package of bills introduced in the State Senate, but never acted upon, during the 1986-87 legislative session. The idea is that by reducing waste at its source, we can substantially prevent hazardous pollutants from entering the waste stream, cut down on our need for disposal space and save industry the expense of purchasing pollution control equipment, hiring personnel to monitor and operate it and researching methods of disposing of it.
Among the components of the legislative program were plans to implement an Office of Hazardous Waste Minimization and a Hazardous Substance Source Reduction Advisory Board, whose duties would be similar to those outlined by the Department of Environmental Protection for the Office of Pollution Prevention. Incentives, such as a more efficient and quicker permit process, were also part of this package, geared toward encouraging industry to use methods to reduce waste at its source as both a supplement and alternative to controlling it once it enters the waste stream.
In other words, this package effectively changes the focus from dealing with what's coming out of the pipeline to what's being done at the production line.
Source reduction is an economically sensible alternative that simultaneously addresses the need to protect the public safety and the need to protect jobs. It takes advantage of the latest technological developments and sets reachable goals for reducing the production of hazardous wastes.
Industry would benefit from reducing the generation of toxic chemicals because it would spend less money on purchasing, operating and maintaining pollution control equipment. These companies would also realize a saving in the transporting, storing and disposal of hazardous waste as well as in the analyzing, recordkeeping and personnel training involved. This is especially important since waste disposal costs are spiraling out of control; this is particularly true in regard to more volatile hazardous chemicals and substances. Minimization could also result in lower insurance liability for companies that handle hazardous materials.
Society would benefit from the efficient use and conservation of resources and energy and the reduced need for land disposal space.
Most importantly, the general public would benefit because health and safety hazards are reduced with smaller amounts of hazardous waste in the environment.
Unlike most plans addressing controversial issues, everyone comes out a winner with this proposal: industry, the Legislature and, above all, the public.
It is the type of plan that should be implemented as quickly as possible, regardless of political considerations. By decreasing the amount of hazardous waste generated, we will significantly reduce the amount of toxic substances that enter the atmosphere each day, poisoning our wildlife, polluting our lakes and rivers, damaging our green fields and putting further burdens on already deteriorating industrial centers and the inhabitants of the communities surrounding them.
The time has come for state environmental officials, as well as the State Legislature, to focus their attention on reducing waste at its source. By doing that, we can eliminate a serious threat to the health and well-being of the people and cities of the Garden State.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE WELL-STOCKED BRAIN ...

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SHENKER; Joseph Shenker if president of the Bank Street College of Education.

 BODY:

A FIRST DICTIONARY OF CULTURAL LITERACY
What Our Children Need to Know.
Edited by E.D. Hirsch Jr. and Michael Stanford.
Ilustrated. 271 pp. Boston:
Houghton Mifflin Company. $14.95.
The debate is not about Kermit the Frog versus the Three Little Pigs, Willie Mays versus Babe Ruth, or investment versus savings. Some of these terms are defined in E.D. Hirsfch Jr.'s well-presented new effort, ''A First Dictionary of Cultural Literacy'' and some are not. The issue is really whether our primary educational focus should be on rote memory of certain facts -- any facts -- or developing the tools and processes by which students learn. 
This new book, which succeeds Mr. Hirsch's philosophic treatise ''Cultural Literacy'' and its successor, ''A Dictionary of Cultural Literacy'', presents 21 neatly designed categories of terms, definitions, and concepts in such subjects as American history, geography, the natural and physical sciences, mathematics, literature and mythology. Accompanied by photographs, line drawings and well-made maps, this compendium was compiled with the assistance of hundreds of teachers, administrators and parents from all 50 states. According to the author, it represents nothing less than 80 percent of what every child should know by the end of sixth grade.
In essence, the Hirsch dictionary purports to add up to much more than the sum of its definitions. Not only does it propose to serve as a measuring stick for the youngsters' store of culture-based knowledge, but it also pretends to serve as a vehicle for a successful life. The subtitle proclaims directly and emphatically that these are the facts that students ''need to know.'' The introduction elaborates, stating that schools are widening the gap between haves and have-nots by teaching skills rather than facts, thus sending a clear if misleading message to parents: If your child knows these facts, he or she will be part of the ''haves'' society.
Underlying this book is Mr. Hirsch's belief that the lack of a common knowledge base is widening the gap between the privileged and underprivileged in our society with growing numbers of dropouts contributing to a growing underclass of have-nots. According to Mr. Hirsch, who teaches English at the University of Virginia, creating a body of facts, information and concepts that everyone learns in common would lead to greater ease of communication among all classes of people.
The problems Mr. Hirsch is concerned about are hardly new; they've been with us ever since the great wave of immigration at the end of the 19th century -- ever since, that is, we became a truly pluralistic society. And the debate about how to achieve community amid diversity is not new either. Then, as now, some argued for a set body of knowledge to be learned across the country, while others argued for a curriculum that was more locally determined and that took into account the needs and capabilities of the learners. Then as now, educational reform was seen as the care for social and economic ills.
Can we honestly put an entire country's economic shortcomings at the doorstep of our schools? Aren't there other major factors that have helped to create and in fact widen the gap between the privileged and the underprivileged -- factors like racism and the recent decline in funding for social programs, for example?
Mr. Hirsch also ignores a lot of what we know about how children learn. First of all, learning is active. Gone is the day when we naively believed that children were pure empty tablets waiting to be printed on, or empty receptacles to be filled (to use two common metahors). Children are active, curious, opinionated and selective. Tell a 7-year-old that a cloud is a mass of condensed water or ice particles (a term defined by Mr. Hirsch in the directory); and the child's eyes are bound to glaze over. But set up an experiment that demonstrates condensation, and the child is bound not only to become interested but to remember what condensation and clouds are all about. Experiencing the reality behind the concepts, an essential part of learning, insures understanding and knowledge that becomes a part of the learner.
Second, learning is social. Children learn in the classroom through interaction with their teachers and with one another. This back-and-forth human exchange about the curriculum provides motivation and excitement, helps children to be engaged in their learning, and supports them in their struggles to learn what they need and want to know.
Third, children come to school already knowing a great deal; they learn in many other places, and often they learn more profoundly there than they do in school. The confidence and self-esteem all children need in order to achieve and to become productive adults is more likely to develop in schools where their knowledge, their experiences and their cultures are respected and taken as a starting place for their schooling.
Addressing the issue of educational content without simultaneously considering processes whereby children learn creates an unnatural dichotomy. In learning, form and function are inseparable. Children need healthy, positive, common schooling eperiences, in additionn to a common curriculum core, if they are truly to acquire the kind of knowledge that will prepare them for the pluralistic society in which we live. Simply remembering the same facts will not produce a classroom of tolerant, curious and participatory citizens.
If one wanted to ignore Mr. Hirschs' assumption and look specifically at the definitions, there is no end to the arguments that one could have. For example, under United States Geography, Arizona is defined as ''a state in the Southwest.'' Is this definition an appropriate indicator of cultural literacy? If one is to know what Arizona is, shouldn't one know a little something about it -- that it is where the Grand Canyon is, or that it is populated, in part, by Navajos?
In sum, this dictionary is much less than it appears to be. Taken without its pretentious introduction and organization, the book is worthy of shelf space in the young reader's library -- just as a specialized crossword puzzle dictionary is useful for the crossword game. But beware of considering it as a trusty guide, index or dictionary for the pursuit of precise knowledge - for use by parent, teacher or child. And clearly, Mr. Hirsch's ''First Dictionary of Cultural Literacy'' is not a tool for a fulfilling, successful life.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
The BBC Faces Up to Technology - and the Till

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
The British Broadcasting Corporation knows it is going to be in business at least thorugh 1996.
That appears to be the only certainty within the British broadcasting industry, which is now facing a competitive revolution wrought by legislative upheaval and advances in technology. Within the next three years, significant parts of the television and radio landscape in Britain could be dramatically altered. By the early 1990's, Britain will have another national television network and, for the first time, a national commercial radio network. Many of the broadcasting companies that have provided the best and the brightest of programs, which American viewers have come to associate with British television - for example, ''Brideshead Revisited,'' ''The Jewel in the Crown'' - could lose their broadcast licenses to companies more committed to good profits than good television. The BBC itself, feeling the pressure of ever-higher production costs, has begun aggressively marketing its programs to commercial networks all over the world and could soon go into business with CBS, ABC or NBC.
''Technology is inevitably making changes in British broadcasting,'' said Michael Checkland, the director-general of the BBC, in an interview during a visit to New York last month. 
For Americans to appreciate these prospects, it is necessary to keep in mind that the British television system is not direclty comparable to American television. At the moment, there are four national networks in Britain: two are run by the BBC; another, ITV, is made up of a consortium of regional broadcasting companies; the fourth, Channel 4 is a specialized channel created to promote quality and ethnically varied programming.
Both ITV and Channel 4 earn income through advertising, as the American networks do. The BBC, though its sweep is much greater (its programing reaches more than 90 percent of British homes), is roughly analogous to the Public Broadcasting Service in that it carries no commercials and is publicly supported. The BBC is financed by an annual fee - currently the equivalent of about $100 - on every household that uses television.
The changes to take effect in the early 1990's will have the most prominent effect on the television companies that make up ITV, such a Grenada and Thames - known in the United States for producing, respectively, such programs as ''The Jewel in the Crown'' and ''Rumpole of the Bailey.'' There are 15 regional broadcasting companies in the Independent Television Association (ITA), the organization that runs ITV. Proposed legislation calls for auctioning the frequency licenses of the ITV companies. The legislation would make it possible for a British company not previously involved in broadcasting to outbid an established ITV company and take away its license.
It would also mandate the creation of a fifth national television network in 1993.
All of these proposals are aimed at providing the British with a wider range of viewing options, already increased in recent years by the introduction of both satellite-delivered channels and cable television.
A factor driving these proposals, according to British broadcast analysts, is political ideology. Most of the forthcoming changes will spring from the broadcasting bill introduced into Parliament a week and a half ago by the Thatcher Government, which is intent on increasing competition among broadcasters. The Government has stated that it favors additional choices for British viewers and listeners; but the Government also clearly will take in considerable additional revenue from commercial broadcasters under the new legislation.
All this activity is taking place at the same time that expanding opportunities for selling English-language programming to new markets around the world are likely to lead to an increased number of co-production deals between British and American broadcasters. The BBC, already an active production partner with the Public Broadcasting Service, the Arts and Entertainment Channel and other American cable channels, is now talking to CBS, ABC and NBC, Mr. Checkland said, about co-producing entertainment series, both comedies and dramas.
What the eventual effect of all these changes on the home screen in the United States will be is difficult to project, but, like the BBC, all the existing British broadcast companies are seeking co-production deals with American broadcast companies and cable channels.
In hopes of navigating these currents of change, Mr. Checkland is trying to chart a course that preserves the BBC's economic stability as well as its traditional position of pre-eminence in British broadcasting.
''The threat we see is that the audiene will be more fragmented,'' he said. ''The test we see as we move into the next decade is whether we keep to a position of more than 90 percent of homes watching or listening to our programs week in and week out.''
The ''white paper'' recently issued by a Government committee examining the industry reaffirmed the BBC's ''special role'' as what it called ''the cornerstone of British broadcasting.''
The BBC is the offical broadcast service of Britain by royal charter, which expires at the end of 1996. The commercial broadcasters who make up ITV face more immediate cncerns - beginning with staying on the air. Each of the companies is licensed to broadcast to a specific area of the country. For example, in the case of the five main companies, Thames broadcasts to London during the week, while London Weekend - known to American viewers most notably as the producer of ''Upstairs, Downstairs'' - broadcasts in London during weekends; Grenada broadcasts to the northwest; Yorkshire, which sent ''Last Place on Earth'' to PBS's Masaterpiece Theater, broadcasts in the Yorkshire region, and Central (whose espionage series ''The Sandbaggers'' was shown on PBS) covers the Midlands.
The ITV companies have produced many outstanding programs, a consideration they would like to use to counter the Government's insistence that the franchises go to the highest bidders. Andrew Clark, a spokesman for the Independent Television Association, said in a telephone interview that the companies, fearful of new major non-broadcast companies in Britain armed with larger bankrolls than the relatively small ITV companies can call upon, hope to have the bill modified to put more emphasis on a broadcaster's qualifications.
All the companies are production studios as well; most could stay in business as programing sources if they lost their broadcasting licenses - though obviously in a much reduced capacity.
Some of the ITV companies are also trying to hold back on production costs to build up a war chest for use in the auction. But these companies face a difficult challenge: They must bid high to fend off competitors, but if they overcommit themselves, they risk depleting their programming budgets, making it harder for them to produce the quality programming they have promised.
''I would be concerned if the frachise application didn't have a very serious quality threshold built in,'' Mr. Checkland said. ''We believe that the BBC is better if it's challenged in all areas of programming. So, we wouldn't want to see the ITV companies moving away from areas like science and documentary programs.'' Clearly, the BBC would be concerned if the quest for commercial success - determined in Britain, as in the United States, by ratings - resulted in the kind of lowest-common-denominator progamming that the American networks have long been criticized for.
Yet, American programs have and will continue to play an important part in the BBC's schedule. Mr. Checkland said the current amount of American programming, rather arbitrarily set at 14 percent of the overall schedule, both for the BBC and ITV, will be maintained. For the most part, he said, the BBC looks to American programs to fill gaps in its schedule. That generally means children's shows, feature films and action-adventure series, which, he acknowledged, the American networks do far better than anyone in Britain.
So far no specific plan for co-production between the BBC and an American network is in place, Mr. Checkland said. During his visit to the United States last month, he met with the chief executives of the three commercial networks as well as with studio heads from Fox, Warner and Paramount. None of the networks has reported any significant developments from those talks so far. One network executive, who asked not to be identified, was skeptical of the value of co-production arrangements with the BBC. ''Americans still don't like anything with an accent,'' he said.
But Mr. Checkland said that raises in the annual BBC fee, which are tied to the retail price index in Britain, simply cannot keep up with labor and production costs. The BBC takes in more than $2 billion a year. But that's not enough.
Fortunately, the BBC finds that its programs are an avidly sought commodity in a growing market for programming. The BBC has the largest programming library in the world, more than 150,000 hours of material, and it has only begun to plumb the potential for sales. One reason is that until recently the BBC actually resisted marketing itself. ''When I started,'' said Mr. Checkland, who is 53 and is a 25-year veteran of the BBC, ''trade was considered improper.''
Now it's considered invaluable. Mr Checkland said that the income from the sales of programing would be plowed back into production costs.
The BBC sees oportunity in new technology as well. Home video is only beginning to be explored, and the potential is vast. Last year, the best-selling videocassette in Britain was a 20-year-old black-and-white children's program called ''Watch Your Mother.'' Nostalgia buffs bought up 350,000 copies.
Far from cowering at the threat posed by satellite systems, the BBC is entering into a series of deals with the satellite companies to share costs on purchases of major theatrical movies and sports events.
One experiment that intrigues Mr. Checkland is a late-night subscription service, which will provide specialized programming for audiences willing to pay a fee. (Most nights, the BBC goes dark after 1 A.M.) Already a series of medical shows has been sent out to doctors and others interested.
Mr. Checkland also forsees sports events produced in the newest television breakthrough, high definition, once that technology becomes available. The Wimbledon final, for example, could be replayed at 2 A.M. in high definition for those willing to pay to see it with the visual enhancement high definition promises.
As relieved as the BBC is about remaining relatively undisturbed by the changes soon to affect television, the corporation is at the center of the changes that will affect radio. Under the new standards the BBC's radio operations will face competition from a commercial network for the first time and will have to give up two of its networks to make room on the frequency dial for the new national network as well as more regional competition. The BBC will maintain its World Service, an all-news and information service that broadcasts in 37 languages and is also publically financed.
Assessing the realigned broadcasting terrain, Mr. Checkland called it ''an exciting and interesting time. It's clear what we've got to do. We've got to keep up the quality of our programs. That's what makes us distinctive.''
As the American networks learned in the 1980's, the challenge is to remain distinctive as audiences realise they can be more and more selective. In British broadcasting, that will be the story of the 90's.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Pop Operetta Set in a Diner on Christmas

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
BY now, theatergoers who favor traditional holiday fare may have had their seasonal share of the Scrooge saga. As ever, it seems that a slew of ''Christmas Carols,'' or variations thereof, were already under way just after Thanksgiving weekend, in community and college theaters. Most have passed, although there is still time, through next Sunday, to attend the McCarter Theater's annual Dickens extravaganza in Princeton.
And now, for something different. How about a modern morality urban pop operetta? It has a romantic air, a metaphysical twist, a synthesizer and a sidewalk Santa Claus who fights for - and gets - the girl. 
The title: ''Occupation: Troubadour.'' (That's Santa, whose real name is Al.) Written and composed by Bryan Williams, the piece began the fifth season of the Passage Theater Company when it opened on Wednesday at the Mill Hill Playhouse, where performances continue through Saturday.
The plot concerns a teen-age runaway (Mara) who is spending her first Christmas alone. She wanders into a diner. The only ones there are the owner-waitress (Harriet) and a local eccentric (the Duchess). An unscrupulous businessman (Steve) whose limousine has broken down comes in. The chauffeur is waiting outside.
And then there's the unemployed street musician, dressed as Santa Claus. Both men vie for Mara and indulge in an ideological argument over the real meaning of Christmas. To Steve, it's all about money. Enticed by Steve's show of success, Mara leaves with him, but quickly returns. After a strange turn of events, the audience is left to figure out whether Steve - or Al - was really there.
The message-bearing mini-musical piece, which lasts just over an hour, had its beginnings as a 10-minute exercise that Mr. Williams was commissioned to compose for a musical laboratory series sponsored by the New York Shakespeare Festival several years ago.
After Mr. Williams's play ''In This Fallen City'' was seen at the Passage Theater last season, Veronica Brady, the theater's artistic director, asked him to expand ''Occupation: Troubadour'' into a holiday musical, although it was not intended to be one in the first place.
The 36-year-old Mr. Williams, who began studying music at the age of 4, grew up in Wood-Ridge and attended Juilliard. His new comedy, ''I, Lionel,'' which he describes as a satiric look at growing up in New Jersey, is on the Passage Theater's schedule for June.
On the evolution of the current work, ''Occupation: Troubadour,'' he said: ''I wanted to create a joyous evening that would have something to say about contemporary conditions, about the loneliness of people - something that was all about values, in a holiday-like atmosphere. The whole score grew out of one song I had originally, 'Lonely Strangers' -and it goes off in different styles to suit the realities and the dreams of the characters.''
''The girl has a pop-style number,'' he added, ''the waitress, a jazzy one and a mock opera aria, and the Duchess sings in old burlesque style. Santa Claus has a folk ballad and the rich guy does 'Crocodile Rock' - it's supposed to be grating, because he's an aggressive character. And I'm on the synthesizer, which is better than out-of-tune violins.''
Ms. Brady, who staged the show, said: ''This is 'The Gift of the Magi' comes to Trenton - which is known for its diners. They feed the whole city, and this one is modeled upon Manuka's, which is right across the street from the theater.''
''The show is about choosing between good and evil, and maybe we could only get away with this kind of magical story during the holidays, but it feels right,'' Ms. Brady added. ''A lot of our young people are disenfranchised - and we see kids like Mara around here all the time. They hang out around here all the time. They hang out with us and they need direction. It ties right into this story.''
Ms. Brady, who has been teaching playwriting to teen-agers in a drug rehabilitation program here, said: ''Usually, the Passage Theater's work is more gritty. This time, everyone gets what they want - and they get it early on.''
About the musical's message, Mr. Williams said: ''Whenever the Christmas season starts, you know money is at the forefront - and when a young girl is forced to choose between notoriety, with riches, and just plain decency, what is she going to do - and what would her family support?
''We've come to accept poverty as pathology, instead of an accidental economic condition. I'm not trying to be philosophical, but I guess I'm asking, 'Is it still possible to give people something intangible for Christmas, something that brings out the dreams and the music in them?' ''
The Mill Hill Playhouse is at Front and Montgomery Streets. For tickets and a schedule of performances, call (609) 392-0766.

HEADLINE: THE VIEW FROM: NORWALK;
City's Once-Hoped Boon to Revitalization Becomes Its Burden

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
NORWALK officials and residents are bracing for more bad news this week about the city's major tourist attraction, the Norwalk Maritime Center. The center is to present a financial report to the City Council on Wednesday and it is expected to show that the Maritime Center will need more money to survive.
The center, which opened in mid-1988, was supposed to attract as many as 700,000 visitors its first year, but the actual number was just over half of the goal. Now, it looks as if it will be years before the center can even begin to make payments on a $30 million loan Norwalk made to the center built. 
''I would think it's going to need some more money, in fact,'' said Mayor Frank J. Esposito.
Some of Norwalk's citizens, though, wonder whether the city should continue its support. The Norwalk Zoning Coalition, an affiliation of several smaller neighborhood groups, advocates a referendum before the city sinks any more money into the project.
''People are beginning to call it a white whale, instead of a white elephant,'' said Dolores Buzzeo, a member of the steering committee of the coalition.
''When taxpayers find out how much it's going to cost to keep this center open, they may want it to find some other way of supporting itself,'' Mrs. Buzzeo said.
Coalition members are also upset that the center, which has received so much public money, has not disclosed information about how its money has been spent, or how much of a deficit it has. Sarah E. Gorman, a lawyer who was on the City Council until last month, said the center has not even filed complete disclosure forms required of nonprofit corporations by the Internal Revenue Service.
''We haven't taken any position on how it should be handled because we can't make an assessment until we find out how much red ink it's actually bleeding,'' Ms. Gorman said.
The Maritime Center was proposed in the early 1980's as a means of revitalizing the blighted South Norwalk section of town, near the waterfront.
It opened in mid-July of last year, with 20 fish tanks, a seal pen, a large-screen theater for maritime films and display areas for rotating exhibits.
 
$30 Million in Bonds
Norwalk sold $30 million in bonds to help build the project, and the center was supposed to raise $6.5 million privately, and $1 million from government grants. Earlier this year, the city gave the center $300,000 for advertising. The center is to release a report on how close it has come to its goals, and its first-year financial results on Dec. 20.
How long it will be before the cen ter is self-sustaining ''depends on what you call self-sustaining,'' said Dr. Vilma P. Allen, the executive director of the center. ''Certainly it will be quite a while before we can start paying the debt.''
But, she said, an optimistic estimate of current operations is that the center's revenues come within 10 percent of its expenses.
In addition, she said, the center is seeing a large volume of repeat visitors for its school programs, lecture series and cruises aboard its research vessel, the 40-foot Oceanic.
 
Inadequate Marketing
Dr. Allen, who took over in May, said part of the problem was marketing. The $300,000 spent this year was the center's first campaign, she said.
''That should have been done a year or two years before the facility opened,'' Dr. Allen said. ''When we opened, no one had heard of us, and we've been playing catchup ever since.''
Membership, though, is approaching 6,000, ahead of expectations, she said, and attendance is expected to climb from 372,000 the first fiscal year to 420,000 this year, and continue increasing 10 to 15 percent a year for the near future.
Mrs. Buzzeo was on the council at the time the city agreed to finance the center, and was opposed at that time.
 
Missed Fund-Raising Goals
''I said it wasn't going to be financially stable, but I'm not happy to see my predictions come true,'' Mrs. Buzzeo said. ''Even if attendance had met projections, they wouldn't have been able to meet their debt service.''
She said the center had also fallen short of its fund-raising goals, although just how short, the coalition has been unable to determine. In any event, consultants had said the first year would be the best for fund raising, Mrs. Buzzeo recalled.
''If it wasn't all that good this year, what can we look forward to?'' Mrs. Buzzeo asked. ''No big sponsors, either corporations or individuals, have come forward.''
Ms. Gorman said she was also disturbed that, until recently, five of the nine members of the Maritime Center Authority, organized to watch over the city's interest, were also members of the Maritime Center's board. The number of people on both boards has dropped to two.
 
Situation Is Improving
''What kind of a watchdog is that?'' Ms. Gorman asked. ''It's really not appropriate to have that kind of overlap.''
But Dr. Allen said despite some initial problems, the Maritime Center's situation was starting to improve, with a growing membership base and an increasing number of visitors. ''The problem at the start was everyone was wildly optimistic, too optimistic,'' Dr. Allen said.
Mr. Esposito, who is a member of the center's board and the city's authority, agreed. ''I think we expected too much too soon, and everybody got downbeat when it didn't live up to expectations.'' ''I wasn't here when the initial decisions were made, and it would be easy for me to say, 'I wouldn't have done it,' '' Mr. Esposito said. ''But it's here now, and I'm going to do everything I can to make it succeed.''
Mr. Esposito also credited the Maritime Center as one of the reasons developers have started the $70 million Maritime Square office project in South Norwalk, and the reason another developer has proposed 300 apartments and 35,000 square feet of retail space in the long-vacant South Norwalk railroad station.
''You have to look at what it's doing for the city, for its economy, for its grand list,'' Mr. Esposito said. ''If you look at the broader picture, I don't think it's as bleak as people are making it out to be.
''It takes time for something like this to get on its feet. The hope is in a few years, it will be self-sustaining, but for now there's no easy way out of it.''
''Whatever has to be done has to be done,'' he added, ''because we can't let it go belly up. We've got to protect our investment.''

HEADLINE: LONGPORT JOURNAL;
History's Echoes in a Town Changed by Storms and Wealth

BYLINE: By JAMES RUTHERFORD

DATELINE: LONGPORT

 BODY:
RESIDENTS of this seaside town have weighed equity against history - and history has come up light.
That was evident in Mike Cohen's face as he bent over a cardboard U-Haul box one recent gray morning and lifted out and unwrapped its contents. Mr. Cohen's face shone in the dark of the Guild Hall of the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer. The windows were shut tight against the rain blowing in off the mainland. They locked in the dampness and the smell of mildew and rotting newsprint.
The Longport Historical Society's museum is stored away for the winter in a few boxes and wooden crates, alongside stacks of the Book of Common Prayer and piles of hand-held wicker fans, also in winter hibernation - no more than a couple of loads in Mr. Cohen's Ford Bronco. 
Mr. Cohen speaks of Longport and its history with the admiration of a tourist, which, in a way, he remains. Mr. Cohen, a successful Pennsylvania marketing research consultant who is president of the Longport Historical Society, collects things like boardwalk rolling chairs, nickelodeons, old sheet music and Atlantic City postcards.
But the prize of his collection is one of the last of the lavish Victorian cottages built at the turn of the century on this tiny spit of sand at the southernmost tip of Absecon Island. The house towers three stories above the concrete sea wall and the few yards of beach still left. The exterior retains its white frame charm. Mr. Cohen has completely remodeled the interior. He comes down from Feasterville, Pa., two days a week.
He looked down suddenly at the cardboard boxes and frowned. ''I think I have to get this stuff out of here,'' he said. ''It's just too damp. I didn't realize it was going to get so damp so quick.'' He also acknowledged that it is wealth, not mildew, that is devouring Longport's memory of itself. Another frown came to his face.
Tucked away in the shadow of Atlantic City's casinos five miles to the north, Longport happens to be half a square mile of some of the most desirable and expensive real estate on the New Jersey coast. The average resale value of a house here is $438,000, nearly three times higher than in the North Jersey-New York metropolitan area.
Consequently, seasonal residents, investors and developers are tearing down and rebuilding the appearance of the borough faster than Mr. Cohen and the society can keep up. And they are doing it almost as dramatically as the violent northeasters and the hurricanes of 1944 and 1962, which all combined over the years to pull down the huge old cottages, the boardwalk and the amusement pier and pushed the better part of 10 blocks across Great Egg Harbor Inlet to Ocean City and buried the rest under water.
To the borough, the development has been a windfall. With the assessed value of residential property alone exceeding $260 million, the tax rate has been stable for years at about $1.50 for every $100 in assessed value, the lowest in Atlantic County. Half of the year-round population is over the age of 55. There are few children whose education needs to be financed.
There are also no slums, no rundown summer rentals and no supermarket. The total of Longport's commercial life, aside from the Arco gas station at the entrance to town, is contained in three attached stores - a Wawa convenience store, Ozzie's Diner and a liquor store. After that, there is only the venerable Longport Inn, a cozy landmark with live lobsters in tanks of murky green water and with casino executives, lawyers and politicians at tables with white linen tablecloths.
Howard Kupperman, a lawyer and the Mayor, said: ''We do not intend or hope to increase that in any way. The town fathers want to keep it residential.'' Mr. Cohen said, ''It's just a lovely little town.'' But some say there is a blot on this otherwise serene scene. The modern, streamlined palaces that have replaced the old gingerbread and latticework ones - flat-roofed structures that are efficiently divisible into income- and tax-producing duplexes, triplexes and quadplexes - are covering the oceanside and crowding out the trim bungalows and Cape Cods along cozy Risleys Channel on the opposite side.
''The people who are year-round residents are upset,'' Mr. Kupperman said. ''They want single-family homes on single lots, detached. The seasonal people want to cram as much building into a lot as they can. Those who are affluent enough to pay $1 million for a beach-block lot and another $2 million to $4 million to develop it - what can you say? These are great people. They don't have children. It's not as if they represent a tax burden. This is difficult for the locals to understand. The importance of a view is not something that can be understood.'' Then there was the warning that the State Division of Coastal Resources issued a few years ago: that rising ocean levels and eroded beaches leave Longport as vulnerable as ever to major storms. The division recommended limiting, not encouraging, more density; enforcing deeper setbacks of property from the sea wall, which the borough will have to maintain at ever-increasing cost, and preserving more beachfront as open space. But, Mr. Kupperman said, ''we couldn't comply.'' ''Longport is pretty much all developed,'' he said. ''There was nothing we could do. We couldn't tell people, 'Tear down your lots.' ''
There are not many people left who remember the storms or the boardwalk or the pier, and only a few who remember the 10 blocks that no longer exist. The historical society tries to remind them of the borough's past through the publication of an annual newsletter. And there is the high point of the society's activities - the reopening of the museum in the summer in the Guild Hall of the Church of the Redeemer.
Thirty or 40 people might turn out on a Sunday afternoon. The gray folding chairs are opened and arranged in five neat rows for Mr. Cohen's homemade videotape presentation. Mr. Kupperman takes a seat next to Richard DePanphlis, the former police chief, and two members of the Borough Commission, Bill Fiore and Frank Toner.
Mary Sue Lovett, the museum's curator, would be there, and so would Billy Krechmer, a retired bandleader and a museum trustee, who had a gazebo built in the center of town and named the Krechmer Gazebo in honor of his parents. Assemblywoman Dolores G. Cooper, Republican of Atlantic City, might show up, and maybe a few curious summer residents or a tourist.
Afterward, there is time to stroll among the lead and wood and porcelain curios in the glass cases; to stop at the faded photographs, bleached yellow like the sunny sky outside - photographs of broad sand dunes, of an old farmstead, swallowed, like a little Atlantis, by the sea; to admire ancient framed pressings of marine flora; to feel the warm ocean breeze by the open windows and to smile and greet one another.
Mr. Cohen may know how much this event resembles a dutiful visit to an old aunt, how everyone wants to be assured of a pleasant stay and will come back as long as the aunt is not going to become a burden.
''It would be nice if they had some incentive to preserve the town the way it was,'' he said. ''Now it's a question of how you are going to get the most value for a property. I guess you can't stop change. We try to preserve memories. It's not economically feasible to save a lot of the rest.''

HEADLINE: Seattle Journal;
In Defense Of Quirks, A Market And a City

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Dec. 17

 BODY:
The streak of regional chauvinism that is running through this city as it copes with hyperactive growth has generally targeted Californians, who make up one of every five newcomers to the Seattle area. New Yorkers, by and large, have been spared.
But that abruptly changed this month when it was revealed that this city's most cherished institution, the Pike Place Market, is owned by New York investors.
And the investors, who have been silent since they bought the 11 historic buildings on a bluff overlooking Puget Sound in the early 1980's, now say they want a better return on their money. 
To many of the hundreds of merchants who hawk king salmon, footlong clams, winter pears, hand-knitted sweaters and other treasures of the Pacific Northwest from their stalls in the Pike Place Market, the call for higher profits was a straitjacket for the market's quirky character.
Suddenly, the newspapers were full of New York-bashing sentiment, and public meetings overflowed with residents demanding that ''our market'' be bought from the absentee owners.
''Let's buy out New York and send them home!'' Robert Wilmot said at a loud and angry meeting of Pike merchants last week.
A cartoon in one newspaper showed the market's landmark clock changed to Eastern standard time and a neon light blinking: ''Produce . . . or else.'' A columnist for the Seattle Times envisioned the market with a New York theme, complete with outlets for Donald Trump, Leona Helmsley and Ivan Boesky.
The investors, from a Manhattan-based property management firm, the Urban Group, have tried to reassure the city that they have no intention of changing the Seattle landmark. The chaotic, personal nature of the market is what makes it a draw to more than 15 million tourists a year, said Arthur Malman, a vice president of the group. Any tampering would hurt the investment, he said.
Mr. Malman said the Urban Group bought the buildings as a tax shelter. From an initial $3 million payment in the early 1980's, the investors have gained about $10 million in tax writeoffs, he said. But recent changes in the Federal tax law make it harder for investors to get a good return on aging buildings.
The furor here illustrates a larger issue of how historic districts can balance their need for outside money with their desire to remain basically unchanged.
The Urban Group, which manages historic buildings in cities around the nation, ''does not seek quick profits,'' the investors said in a letter to Pike Place merchants, but the group does seek ''a fair economic return on the rental of our Pike Place Market buildings.''
Just how to increase the profit margin is a matter of much debate. Mr. Malman said the Pike Preservation and Development Authority, a quasi-public corporation that acts as the market's Seattle landlord and manager, should reduce overhead costs and perhaps raise rents. The Urban Group has hired Arthur Anderson and Associates, an accounting firm, to conduct an audit.
The preservation authority, which sought out the New York investors, also provides day care, meals and housing for the poor and elderly in the market area. The authority says it cannot reduce its costs without cutting back on social services.
The market opened in 1907 as a way for farmers and fishermen to sell directly to consumers, and it has never been short of defenders. Its vibrant pulse has inspired artists like Mark Tobey and writers like John Steinbeck.
In the early 1970's, when the Downtown Seattle Association, a business group that has promoted high-scale development, wanted to tear down the market, an overwhelming majority of Seattle citizens voted to save it and designate it a historic district.
A tony new market, the Westlake Center, has since been built a few blocks from the Pike market. And defenders of the Pike market are worried that the demand for higher profit will push the Seattle landmark in the direction of Westlake.
''We're not looking for a Westlake,'' Mr. Malman said, in a meeting with merchants. ''The market's a special place, a community. We're just looking for more accountability.''
But many of the merchants vowed that the market will never answer to a new bottom line.

HEADLINE: The Editorial Notebook;
It's Not Japan's Fault

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN

 BODY:
Everybody knows how to solve the nation's trade imbalance: buy less from the Japanese and get them to buy more from the U.S. This seemingly sensible prescription is featured daily in virtually all the news media. Repeated often enough, it assumes the status of a canon of correct thinking.
But what everybody knows just ain't so. The trade deficit is the mirror image of excessive spending. As long as Americans collectively buy more than they produce, the U.S. must import the difference. Restricting imports from Japan might lower the trade deficit with Japan, but do nothing to reduce the overall trade deficit unless consumption was curbed. Otherwise, imports from other countries would just take the place of those from Japan. 
The implication for policy is profound. Acting nasty toward the Japanese and other trade partners is no solution. Yet that's exactly what the new U.S. trade law does. The United States threatens to retaliate against nations that engage in trading practices it unilaterally decides are wrong. That's saber-rattling. Unrelated to domestic consumption habits, it cannot cure the trade deficit. But it will undermine America's commitment to universal trade rules.
The new law replaces a set of reciprocal obligations with what the trade expert Jagdish Bhagwati of Columbia University calls ''the law of the jungle.'' Bullying might pry open foreign markets. It is more likely to trigger retaliation, from which every nation will lose.
Bluster will not reverse the U.S. trade imbalance. Raising domestic savings will. That requires hard choices and sacrifice. The surest way to increase domestic savings is to lower the Federal budget deficit, which offsets private savings by individuals and corporations. This must be done carefully. It makes no economic sense to gut public investments in education, research and infrastructure that determine future capacity to produce.
To do the job right, Congress will have to restructure taxes, to penalize consumption and reward savings. It knows how. It could raise the Federal gasoline tax and resurrect universal deductions for individual retirement accounts. No one policy change will dramatically alter personal savings. But a combination of many wise changes will, over time, make a difference.
Blaming the Japanese isn't even accurate, let alone effective. Dr. Bhagwati, citing recent research, finds no compelling evidence that the Japanese in fact import less than their fair share, no matter what everybody thinks they know. What Congress needs to recognize is that blaming Japan misdirects both blame and policy.

HEADLINE: How New York Can Tap A Medical Reservoir

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I recently had a discussion with several physicians whom I had met at a social engagement. These men were retired and indicated that if they could afford to pay for the current required malpractice insurance, they would likely contribute their time on a free and voluntary basis at some hospital or medical institution. 
However, because they can't pay the very high insurance cost, they cannot offer their services nor will any hospital engage them.
It seems to me that a great reservoir of experienced medical talent is being untapped. I believe it would be to the interest of society to have New York State provide an insurance fund so that such volunteers would be covered and the public would benefit from their care and experience.
It would be clear that these physicians would then probably furnish their services to an economic segment of the community for whom very active physicians with lucrative practices would most likely have neither interest nor time to provide services.
 
MAX MASON
Spring Valley, N.Y., Dec. 6, 1989

HEADLINE: Getting Ready to Beat Swords Into Plowshares

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Defense Cuts: Little Pain, Modest Gain'' says the headline on Gordon Adams's examination of the proposed military budget cutbacks of Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney (Op-Ed, Dec. 4). Yet, past and announced layoffs have hit more than 30,000 defense workers. Many more workers will suffer as the growth in the military budget comes to a halt. 
The areas hit by these cutbacks extend far beyond the areas identified by Mr. Adams and include not only military regions in Long Island, Seattle, Los Angeles and Dallas-Fort Worth, but also Colorado Springs; Marietta, Ga.; Lynn and Pittsfield, Mass.; St. Louis; Evandale, Ohio; Philadelphia, and Plainfield, N.J. Laws on the books have not saved defense worker jobs in these areas, and so more extensive Federal intervention is required.
A key issue is to ready military facilities for civilian work by having civilian plans blueprint-ready before military cutbacks are announced. Mr. Adams discusses the need for retraining, relocation assistance, income supplements and job search programs. These provisions, along with civilian planning for military industrial facilities, laboratories and bases, are found in the defense economic adjustment bill (H.R. 101), sponsored by Representative Ted Weiss. Without this measure, we will be economically unprepared to match the large-scale military cutbacks that easing cold-war tensions requires.
Mr. Adams fails to recognize the potential long-run gains of such a measure for the economy. These gains will come when the 30 percent of our scientists and engineers engaged in military pursuits are channeled into new jobs to rebuild the country's damaged technological and physical infrastructure. And, like the Soviet Union, we too are facing tremendous budget deficits that warrant significant military budget reductions. Marginal military cuts have displaced thousands. We need new policies to insure that a future peace economy brings more than modest gain without associated economic difficulties.
 
JONATHAN FELDMAN
Washington, Dec. 4, 1989
 The writer is program director, National Commission for Economic Conversion & Disarmament.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
One Good Man

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
''Profound thoughts arise only in debate, with a possibility of counterargument,'' the great dissident wrote clandestinely in 1968, ''when there is a possibility of expressing not only correct ideas but also dubious ideas.''
Sakharov (no honorific or first name needed now; he ranks with Gandhi and Einstein, whose roles he uniquely combined) drew confidence from the conviction that truth emerged from the clash of open minds.
Mikhail Gorbachev, whose need for Sakharov's untainted record and world prestige brought the scientist back from the torture of isolation, was not as confident. This was the ''debate'' between them at the party congress last year about reducing the size of the Red Army:
Gorbachev: Anyway, finish up, Andrei Dmitriyevich. You've used up two time allotments already. 
Sakharov: I'm finishing. I'm leaving out arguments. I have left out a great deal.
Gorbachev: That's it . . . That's all. Take away your speech, please. I ask you to sit down. Turn on the other microphone.
Just before Sakharov died, he was attempting to debate the idea - so dubious to the man in control - of ending the corrupt party's monopoly of power. But Mr. Gorbachev's imperious ''that's all!'' cut him off again. Debate was dangerous.
Later, with the best man in Russia safely dead, apparently (an adverb that cannot be left out) of a heart attack, the Soviet leader raced to hail ''an honest man who suffered great injustice.''
His funeral will be a field day for such hypocrisy, as his longtime silencers hurriedly ''get right with history'' in eulogizing the man they long tormented and lately tolerated. The Kremlin denied Natan Sharansky, an emigrated dissident Sakharov helped set free, a visa to attend; Mr. Gorbachev will handle the official mourning. (The Bush Administration is sending a low-level delegation, claiming that is what the Sakharov family wants. I wonder about that; a downplaying of our concern for human rights is what Mr. Gorbachev wants.) A deeper question arises: What kind of justice blesses tyrants like Pol Pot, Castro and Ceausescu with longevity while a crusader for freedom is snatched away at the crucial moment?
That issue of the suffering of the sinless was raised by the near-heretical poet who wrote the book of Job, and answered with a refutation of the pious notion of divine retribution. Don't look to God for justice; life is unfair. Cherish instead the God-given right to challenge unjust authority.
Perhaps that reflects the mixture of dismay, puzzlement and anger of millions of freedom-lovers at the sudden destruction of this generation's Job. Freedom is the most personal of matters; that makes the loss of the person who exemplified the gutsy insistence on freedom a personal blow to all of us.
I met him in Washington last year, before a dinner given by the National Academy of Sciences. When I identified myself as an anti-Communist columnist, he gazed half-lidded through thick glasses and replied kindly: ''There is no more important commentary than that about the relationship between the U.S. and the U.S.S.R.''
My notes on the back of the menu record his response when asked if American economic cooperation would aid the cause of freedom in the Soviet Union. ''Extend assistance to perestroika with open eyes,'' he advised. ''Ensure that your money does not disappear into the sand.''
He then gave a speech to the assembled scientists about the instability of the proton, calling into question, I think, the law of the conservation of particles.
He could see he lost more than a few of us on that, and apologized for his impromptu reach into the arcane: ''I am a poor popularizer and a poor orator. If I had written my speech, it would have been more logical and sequential. But perhaps it would have lost a sense of spontaneity and gratitude.''
He had the humility that rolls over arrogance and the gentle courage that ultimately throttles brutality. No wonder so many of his countrymen thought of him as saintly; he exhibited the infuriating self-confidence of a saint.
Few in the Soviet Union's era of glasnost dared to deliver his message about the accretion of authority in the name of ''democratization'': that democracy could never come from the supreme empowerment of one man.
Prime movers die but movements go on. Look at that picture of the Supreme Soviet in its moment of silence, the huge statue of Lenin looming over the memorial bouquet in Sakharov's empty chair.
Those are the symbols of the Soviet debate. The obscene statue will crumble; the cut flowers will bloom.

HEADLINE: A Legacy for Rutgers: Pride and Growth

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 12

 BODY:
For five years, Rutgers University has bustled with change as New Jersey has pumped millions of dollars into its state university in a carefully drawn plan to raise its image and the state's.
Construction is filling the woods and fields of once-peripheral campuses. A new thrust into high-technology research has begun with advanced work in fiber optics, ceramics and plant biology in research centers intended to benefit New Jersey's economy and environment. Admissions standards are up, the faculty is stronger, and Rutgers' national prestige is growing.
About the only big disappointment among top administrators is the football team's failure to do well with its strengthened big-college schedule and to earn a major bowl bid. 
 
Bloustein 'Left Footprints'
The architect of Rutgers' campaign to shed its second-class image was Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, who became president of the university in 1971 and guided it until his death on Dec. 9. And only last February did he achieve one dream, when Rutgers was invited to join the Association of American Universities, a group of 58 private and public universities that emphasizes high standards in doctoral studies and research.
Since Dr. Bloustein's death, his peers in higher education have praised his efforts to move Rutgers toward the upper echelons of the nation's public universities.
''Ed Bloustein was one of those rare educational leaders who left footprints,'' said Donna E. Shalala, chancellor of the University of Wisconsin. ''He moved Rutgers a giant step toward becoming a major public university in this country. He knocked heads. He pulled people along.
''It is not in the first rank,'' she said, ''but it's moving in that direction and becoming an increasingly important institution.''
Stanley O. Ikenberry, president of the University of Illinois, said, ''Rutgers has made more progress over the last 20 years than any other public institution I can think of.''
Though spending priorities and the new emphasis on research have troubled some professors and students, Rutgers officials say the direction set by Dr. Bloustein is firmly entrenched.
''Everybody is committed to this program,'' said Michael Bongiovanni, chairman of Rutgers' board of governors. ''It's hard for me to see how somebody's going to sidetrack it.''
Like Gov. Thomas H. Kean, Dr. Bloustein chafed at so-called ''Jersey jokes'' and at the state's - and the university's - weak self-image and sense of being overshadowed by New York City and Philadelphia, associates say.
''He hated the syndrome of being willing to settle for second best,'' said Donald B. Edwards, Rutgers' vice president for development and public affairs. ''He felt New Jersey and Rutgers were shortchanging themselves in terms of ambition.''
Change was considerable in the Bloustein years.
 
Growth Across the River
A $550 million building campaign, the biggest in the university's 223-year history, is concentrated heavily in the 1,700 acres of the once-isolated Busch and Kilmer campuses, the sites of Livingston College, the School of Business, and the College of Engineering.
Busy Route 18 and the Raritan River separate both campuses from the compact 64-acre downtown campus where Rutgers was founded in 1766 and administrative offices are now situated.
The expansion across the river has created an atmosphere of sprawl and forced many students to shuttle from dormitory to classroom by bus.
At the heart of the building boom are the new centers for advanced research.
One center is seeking new uses for ceramics - extremely hard, heat-resistant materials - in computers, auto engines and aerospace equipment. Rutgers officials say they believe a $10 billion worldwide market for advanced ceramics will exist by 2000.
 
Fiber Optics for Surgery
Another is exploring applications of fiber optics - the hair-thin glass strands that transmit light at great speed - to manufacturing and medicine, including their use to destroy cancers without surgery and burn plaque from clogged arteries.
A new center in agricultural molecular biology is working on the development of plant varieties less dependent on chemical fertilizers and pesticides. Others are seeking advances in plastics recycling, food technology, biotechnology and medicine, and are analyzing coastal overdevelopment and diseases of salt-water fish and shellfish.
Corporations help underwrite most centers. Their donations will allow them to set some research agendas and later apply the results to new products. Such marketplace research is increasingly common at major universities, education experts say.
 
Tougher Admissions Standards
Under toughened admissions standards, the average Scholastic Aptitude Test score of freshmen at Rutgers College, the university's oldest and most select school, is 1,169. On all campuses here and in Newark and Camden, the average now is 1,098, up 57 points since 1984.
In the same period, the average national S.A.T. score has increased 6 points, to 903 from 897, said Elizabeth Mitchell, director of admissions.
Despite the improved scores and the fact that 88 percent of undergraduates are state residents, Ms. Mitchell said the university remains disturbed by the continued migration of the state's best high school graduates to private colleges outside New Jersey.
''New Jersey has sent too many of its brightest kids out of state and too many have not come back to pursue careers,'' she said.
 
Luring the State's Brightest
To lure them to Rutgers, officials are considering extending annual $5,000 scholarships, now offered to high school valedictorians, to the second- and third-ranked students in graduating classes, she said.
The faculty is more prestigious, according to a 1988 re-accreditation report of the Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools. Members in the National Academy of Sciences have increased from 3 to 12 in six years. And top-level public universities around the country say they are noticing Rutgers' recruitment raids.
In an otherwise favorable report, the Middle States group criticized a shortage of dormitories and the smallness of student centers. Officials say a new capital project will address those shortcomings of student life. In addition, a university-wide, $53 million library expansion is under way.
Both Dr. Bloustein and the Kean administration viewed the football team as a potential builder of image and pride for Rutgers and New Jersey. Six years ago, its training centers were upgraded with $3 million in state funds, and tougher teams like Tennessee, Florida, Alabama, Michigan State, Penn State and Syracuse were scheduled. The goals were national recognition and bowl invitations.
 
Football Success Eludes Rutgers
But neither materialized. The team's head coach, Dick Anderson, who compiled a record of 27 wins, 34 losses and 4 ties since 1984, was dismissed a few days after Dr. Bloustein's death.
The school's improved image has also brought some disharmony.
A 66 percent tuition increase over five years has embittered many in the student body of 47,000. Fifty were arrested last spring during protests. Yet annual costs for tuition, room, board and other fees remain under $7,000 for New Jersey residents and under $10,000 for out-of-state students.
There is a sense among students that undergraduate education has been overlooked in the rush to expand high-technology research. Although the Middle States agency has high praise for undergraduate academics, Dr. Bloustein ordered a complete review of the program several months ago.
 
Students Unhappy With Priorities
The action did not seem to appease undergraduates.
''I still don't see that as the number-one priority,'' said Susan Kohn, a senior majoring in economics and French, who represents students on the board of governors. ''I think the number-one priority is to make Rutgers a nationally recognized research university.''
Some faculty grumble about overconcentration on research and sciences at the expense of the humanities and social sciences. Some found Dr. Bloustein strong-willed and forceful in pursuing his ambition, and egos were bruised.
''Had he been able to incorporate opponents into his plans, we would have had a more unified faculty,'' said Dr. Joseph G. Rosenstein, a faculty representative on the board.
Rutgers' turnaround in image and reputation has hinged on two developments this decade, administrators say. In 1980, Dr. Bloustein changed Rutgers from a splintered institution to a cohesive one by merging - despite howls of protest - the separate and overlapping faculties and academic departments of Rutgers' five undergraduate colleges. And, over the last five years, money has poured in, including about $150 million from state bond issues in 1984 and 1988; $45.6 million in Federal grants (a 100 percent increase in 5 years), and about $45 million in grants from foundations and corporations.
Annual operating revenues from the state have increased nearly 83 percent, from about $150 million to $274 million, since 1984. And a separate fund-raising campaign that opened in 1986 with a goal of $75 million has now reached $142 million, with half of it coming from major corporations.
T. Edward Hollander, New Jersey's Chancellor of Higher Education, views the largesse as acknowledgement of Rutgers' improving reputation.
''If Rutgers tried to raise $10 or $15 million 15 years ago, it would have been lucky,'' he said.

HEADLINE: As a Hospital Grows, Debts Threaten It

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

 BODY:
Even as it nears completion of a $500 million rebuilding project that will make it one of the country's largest and best-equipped health-care institutions, the Presbyterian Hospital finds itself in a financial crisis that threatens its survival as a teaching center.
The 120-year-old hospital, part of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, is the sole health-care provider for a large and increasingly poor swath of Upper Manhattan. Because many of its patients are low-income residents or recent immigrants, many of whom do not have medical insurance, officials say, the hospital's resources have been badly sapped.
While hospitals throughout the city say insufficient state reimbursements for indigent care are leaving them underfinanced, Presbyterian, at 168th Street and Broadway, is by all accounts the hardest hit of New York's teaching hospitals.
Losing large amounts of money on its more than 500,000 clinic and emergency room visits each year and facing daunting financing costs and overruns from its building project, the hospital where oxygen tents were invented and cardiac catheterizaton was pioneered must now struggle to maintain operations from month to month. 
 
'Now the Endowment Is Gone'
''We are losing $50 million a year,'' said Seymour Milstein, the hospital's chairman, who estimated that in the last decade, the hospital has ''dissipated'' more than $250 million of its endowment of about $300 million, mostly to meet operating costs. Public health experts say no other large teaching hospital in the country has spent so much endowment money to meet operating costs.
''As long as they had the endowment, they were saying we will continue to eat it,'' Mr. Milstein, who became chairman last July, said, referring to the hospital's losses. ''Now the endowment is gone.''
The demise of Presbyterian's endowment coincides with the hospital's ambitious building plan.
Last month, at a ceremony for more than 100 members of the health-care community, Presbyterian opened a new 745-bed hospital named for Mr. Milstein's family, which donated $25 million toward its construction.
The sandy-hued 10-story structure, with up-to-the-minute medical and computer technology, comfortably appointed rooms and sweeping views of the Hudson River, is the keystone of Presbyterian's rebuilding program. It represents both the hospital's hopes for the future and - because of its high cost - its tremendous new financial burden.
Eighteen months ago Presbyterian also opened the Allen Pavillion on 220th Street, at the northern tip of Manhattan. The pavillion, a 300-bed community hospital, which had difficulty recruiting nurses and other staff, is close to fully operational.
''If you had to pick the worst time in New York City to open a new hospital, that was it,'' said Kevin W. Dahill, the vice president in charge of the Allen Pavillion. He was referring to several months of $1 million losses, largely because of a lack of staff, after the building opened in July 1988.
Presbyterian, like New York's other teaching hospitals, began its rebuilding project in an effort to keep pace with modernizations at rival academic medical centers in cities like Boston and San Francisco, and at younger institutions in places like Alabama and North Carolina.
 
Not a Good Place to Be In
To cover cost overruns estimated at $94 million, Presbyterian recently applied for state authorization for mortgage increases that will for 20 years add about $4 million in annual financing costs to the hospital.
''That is not a comfortable place for the institution to be in,'' Robert D. Gumbs, director of the New York City Health Systems Agency, a public planning group, said of the hospital's finances. ''They have a short-term crisis, and when they are through with that, they will have long-term difficulties.''
Discussions of Presbyterian's troubles invariably produce muted recrimination among hospital, industry and state health officials.
The state, which controls many of the factors that determine hospital income, has raised questions about the hospital's management.
 
'Losses Just Started Ballooning'
''Presbyterian had been accepting bottom line losses of $8 million to $10 million for years to meet its community responsibilities,'' said Dr. David Axelrod, the state health commissioner. ''Then the losses just started ballooning.''
Asked how the losses had spun out of control, Dr. Axelrod, who praised present leadership at the hospital, said in the past, ''somebody wasn't watching the store during construction'' of the new hospital.
Presbyterian officials blame much of the cost overruns on a building moratorium issued by Gov. Hugh L. Carey in the early 1980's. They say the moratorium significantly delayed rebuilding plans, adding greatly to costs.
Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, dismissed the question of hospital management, too. He said Presbyterian is investing in ''outpatient care as much as anyone in the country,'' and is losing money because of the rate at which Medicaid reimbursements are made. Medicaid payment rates for outpatient clinic visits in New York have been frozen since 1981.
 
'For the Poor of New York'
At Presbyterian, officials suggest that by aggressively following the state's call for more primary care to low-income communities, the hospital became overexposed to a money-losing activity.
Since its creation, Presbyterian's credo has read, ''For the poor of New York without regard to race, creed or color.''
Dr. Thomas Q. Morris, the hospital's president, said Presbyterian had upheld and would continue to uphold that spirit, but he acknowledged that a solution had to be found to the hospital's financial problems.
''Our clinic losses in 1981 were between $1 million and $2 million,'' he said. ''Now they are in the range of $30 million. That is intolerable. #35 Percent Without Insurance ''We have served an increasingly large Medicaid population,'' Dr. Morris said, explaining one dimension of the hospital's financial problems. ''From 10 percent of our inpatients 10 years ago the number has gone up to 30 percent now. On the outpatient side, as many as 35 percent of our patients don't even have insurance.''
By comparison, about 47 percent of the inpatients at the city's public hospitals receive Medicaid. At the city's four other academic medical centers, an average of about 17.5 percent of the patients receive Medicaid, according to state and city data. No similar data were available on payments to hospitals for outpatient care.
At one of Presbyterian's outpatient clinics, a large pediatric office, more than 30 mothers with children competed for space in a modest waiting room last week.
''This is nothing,'' said Joan Maloney, a nursing care clinician, who explained the crowd was smaller than usual because of a predicted snowstorm. ''Usually we are backed up into the hall.''
 
Large Volume and Large Losses
''Most of these patients cannot afford our care,'' said Dr. Matilde Irigoyen, director of the clinic, adding that 70 percent of the parents were Mediciad recipients. ''For the people who live in this area we have to use a sliding payment scale.''
So far this year, Presbyterian officials say, the hospital has received more than 500,000 outpatient and emergency room visits. Alluding to one of the city's largest public hospitals, Mr. Milstein said, ''We take care of more people - by 50 percent - than even Bellevue does.''
Because of its extraordinary volume and the losses it suffers, especially on its outpatient care, hospital and public health officials say Presbyterian has recently considered drastic relief measures.
One plan abandoned recently would have had the hospital request designation by the state as a ''financially distressed'' institution, a measure that would have made it eligible for special financing.
 
A Potential Embarrassment
''In my opinion that would have meant the death of Presbyterian as an academic medical center,'' said one official, who asked not to be identified. Explaining why the plan was rejected, he said, ''If you were a world-class scientist or physician would you come to work at a distressed hospital?''
Dr. Gerald E. Thomson, executive vice president for professional affairs at Presbyterian, said the hospital was now contemplating a major reorganization in which specialty clinics would be de-emphasized, while basic primary care would be expanded.
Hospital officials hope that this idea can be sold to the state, which has sought to increase primary care, in exchange for significantly increased reimbursement for clinic care.
Public health officials and experts say that new relief measures are likely, because failure by Presbyterian, one of the country's best known hospitals - and with 6,000 employees, one of the city largest employers - would be an unacceptable embarrassment for leaders in both Albany and New York City.
''The academic medical center community nationally is watching us,'' said Dr. Thomson. ''They see us as a financially troubled center trying to do the right thing in a struggling community, not being reimbursed adequately.
''We have a responsibility for producing the best care for our community, one of the most medically needy in New York, and for training some of the world's leading teachers, researchers and physicians. The question is whether the public will provide the resources to keep doing all of this.''
