HEADLINE: Huge Japanese Realty Deals Breeding Jokes and Anger

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
Richard Colby was upset. There he was, standing on the studio-audience line for the ''Donahue'' show at 30 Rockefeller Center, saying he did not like it one bit that a Japanese corporation was now the building's majority owner.
''Certain things are sacred,'' said Mr. Colby, a Long Island Rail Road engineer. ''Radio City, the tree. What are they going to do, have a bonsai now that it's 51 percent Japanese?''
Outside, a woman has been selling T-shirts that say, ''Welcome to Wokafellar Center.'' 
Upstairs, where NBC has its New York studios, the comedy shows have been making joke after joke in the weeks since the Japanese-owned Mitsubishi Estate Company agreed to pay $846 million for a controlling interest in the Rockefeller Group, which owns Rockefeller Center.
One night soon after the deal was made public, the longtime NBC announcer Bill Wendell began, ''From New York, a subsidiary of Mitsubishi, it's 'Late Night With David Letterman.' '' Later, three Japanese men with briefcases were shown handing Mr. Wendell fistfuls of cash in return for buildings on the New York skyline behind Mr. Letterman's desk. And last Wednesday, Mr. Letterman showed off a paperweight replica of Macy's. ''A New York City landmark,'' he said, ''the perfect gift for any Japanese child.''
 
Big Bucks for Visible Chunks
Of late, Japanese investors have been paying big bucks for sizable, visible chunks of the American landscape, from Hollywood to Wall Street. Weeks after the Rockefeller Center deal was announced and Sony said it was paying $3.4 billion for Columbia Pictures, the inhabitants of that landscape are still anxious and, to some extent, angry. And the gloom-and-doom predictions and the nasty humor about the Japanese continue.
There are people who do not pretend to understand the intricacies of high finance that went into the Rockefeller Center deal - people who under ordinary circumstances have a hard time balancing their checkbooks. But now they are asking each other whether the Japanese buying spree is a sign of confidence in the American economy or a sign of its demise.
On another level, some people are expressing their concerns about Japanese investors and investments in ways that others find distasteful. Norman Siegel, the executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, said verbal assaults against Japanese-Americans had surged since the Rockefeller Center deal.
'It's a xenophobic, knee-jerk response that some people still think they're fighting World War II,'' he said. ''Character assassination and jokes, though First Amendment-protected, are un-American. They violate the principles of diversity and pluralism that America is supposed to be all about and New York, especially. We too were immigrants once, and some of our parents and grandparents had it heaped upon them unfairly, and we shouldn't be doing it now.''
Some say that with all the changes in Eastern Europe, Communist-bashing has lost its sting and the Japanese suddenly are easy targets of humor or, worse, hate. That has made the last few weeks a difficult time for Japanese who work in the United States, even though less than a fifth of the first-class commercial office space in Manhattan is foreign-owned. The Japanese rank well behind the Canadians in their holdings and have only recently surged past the British and the Dutch.
''The judgment of the American people about Japanese buying American real estate is a cause for concern,'' said Akiko Iimura, the editor in chief of OCS News, a newspaper published for Japanese in this country. ''They feel they are very good to Americans. However, they see a lot of anti-Japanese feelings.''
 
A Harder Edge
Similarly, Americans who work for Japanese companies say that when the conversation turns to where they work, it suddenly takes on a harder edge.
''The first thing people say is you're a traitor,'' said one woman who works for a Japanese-owned trading company in Manhattan. ''I turn around and explain that the Japanese don't own as much as you think they do. The problem is the Japanese have a much higher profile in the U.S. right now.''
Perhaps nowhere in New York is that higher profile a source of more anxiety than in Rockefeller Center, where, even weeks after the deal with Mitsubishi was announced, people criticize the Japanese in ways that they do not criticize British or Canadian investors.
''You want to know the truth -they're getting back at us for the atomic bomb,'' said Charlie Cacioppo of Franklin Square, L.I., who had come to Rockefeller Center to see the Christmas tree. ''What we did to their cities, now they are trying to do to us by taking over our city. It's time to play hardball. We worked hard for this, and now they're taking it away. Soon everyone will be working for them.''
Mr. Cacioppo already does. He said he is a salesman for a Nissan dealer in Queens.
''It's terrible,'' declared another visitor to Rockefeller Center, Madeline Aquila of Dix Hills, L.I., who said she had been having nightmares about a television program that enumerated all that the Japanese have bought up. ''America should wake up. Nobody can step on you unless you let them.''
 
A 'Monolithic View'
Gerald Curtis, the director of the East Asian Institute at Columbia University, said the way American look at Japanese purchasers and their purchases reflects a ''monolithic view that is not real.''
''When it comes to the British or the Canadians,'' he said, ''we think of individuals: Murdoch or Goldsmith. We don't think, 'The British or coming' or 'The Canadians are coming.' But for a lot of reasons that have do with a lack of American knowledge about Japan and the Japanese, we talk in terms of Japan Inc.''
That view, Mr. Curtis said, is much like the view Europeans had of Americans in the 1950's.
''There was a lot of intense European concern about the dominance of American money,'' he said. ''Now there's American concern about the power of Japanese money. Well, in retrospect American investments in Europe helped revitalize the European economy, and Japanese investments in this country are going to help revitalize the American economy.''
Some, like Mr. Siegel of the civil liberties union, maintain that anti-Japanese sentiment is rising at a time when ''few politicians are willing to speak out on this issue because they're playing to a large audience that's engaged in this activity.''
''If there's this growing climate of Japan-bashing and they don't have that many Japanese in their districts,'' he said, ''why stand up for an unpopular group?''
 
'Relying on Stereotypes'
Scott E. Pardee, co-chairman of Yamaichi International (America) Inc., the New York subsidiary of a Japanese investment house, said he was troubled that people ''are relying on stereotypes based on some image they have in their minds that doesn't relate directly to the people I'm working with or the people I know.''
''The problem with it is the numbers are big and they've happened very quickly,'' Mr. Pardee said.
But, as Mr. Pardee and others point out, the numbers are not as big as most of those who criticize the Japanese seem to think. Before the Rockefeller Center deal, which added 15 million square feet to Japanese holdings, the Japanese owned or controlled 14.3 million square feet in Manhattan.
''It's getting more negative attention than it deserves,'' Mr. Curtis of the East Asian Institute said. ''The Japanese may buy a big building or part of Rockefeller Center, but they can't bring it back to Tokyo. It's still there - it means that Japanese money is in the U.S. economy. It's one way to recycle Japanese surpluses.''

HEADLINE: A Neighborhood Battle: Apartments or a Park?

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

 BODY:
At first glance, the parcel of city-owned land running west from the corner of Ninth Street and Avenue C hardly seems worth the fuss. It holds a few battered pieces of playground equipment, three willow trees, four American lindens, a makeshift amphitheater built of railroad ties, a vegetable garden, a pigeon coop and four scrawny chickens.
But for more than two years now it has been fought over by those who want the site for a 79-unit apartment building for the elderly and those who want to keep it as a park.
The tussle over the land has heightened racial, ethnic and class mistrust on the Lower East Side, a neighborhood where Hispanic residents, blacks, aging hippies, artists, squatters, street people, anarchists and young professionals maintain an uneasy coexistence. 
''It's a very eclectic group around here, and it's hard to get a consensus on almost anything,'' said the Rev. Robert Wollenburg, pastor of the Trinity Lower East Side Lutheran Parish, which runs a shelter and a soup kitchen in the neighborhood.
The housing project, which is to be known as Casa Victoria and built with a $7 million loan from the Department of Housing and Urban Development, has come under more scrutiny since October, when a H.U.D. regional economist said he had been pressured to approve it, against his better judgment, by administrators who were associates of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.
Those trying to block Casa Victoria's construction are mainly young whites, including artists and musicians, who moved into the neighborhood during the last two decades. They insist that they favor inexpensive housing for the elderly but feel there are better sites.
 
'It's Quite Hypocritical'
''Until there are no more abandoned buildings and vacant lots, the city shouldn't come along and destroy parks and gardens,'' said Don Yorty, a poet who has lived on Ninth Street for 10 years.
The project's developer and many of its biggest boosters are members of the neighborhood's old-guard Hispanic political establishment who view opponents as outsiders or politically naive idealists who do not understand the neighborhood's real needs.
''I think it's quite hypocritical,'' said Antonio Pagan, executive director of the Lower East Side Coalition for Housing Development Inc., a nonprofit corporation that is the project's developer. ''Instead of targeting the powers that are gentrifying our neighborhood, they choose to attack a small, community-based agency that has been providing low-cost housing for years. There's something weird about that.''
Both the local community board and the Board of Estimate have approved the project.
Opponents of the development have brought several lawsuits, the latest seeking to halt the project until charges of undue influence by Senator D'Amato can be fully explored.
In October, David Burns, H.U.D.'s regional economist, said he had been pressured by two of the agency's former regional administrators who were close associates of Mr. D'Amato to approve Casa Victoria. Mr. Burns said he wanted to reject the Lower East Side Coalition's application for H.U.D. funds because there was already too heavy a concentration of publicly assisted housing in the neighborhood. No evidence has been revealed suggesting wrongdoing by officials of the coalition.
Mr. D'Amato, a New York Republican, and the former regional administrators have denied any impropriety.
In the mid-70's the city leased the land to Charas, a local Hispanic cultural organization that said it wanted to build a park with a playground and a site for concerts, art shows and theater. Chino Garcia, the group's secretary director, said Charas cleared the vacant lots of rubbish, planted trees and built a type of geodesic dome. Charas called its creation La Plaza Cultural, a name many of those opposed to developing the site still use.
Residents say Charas lost interest in the park and began to neglect it. By 1986, papers filed in a lawsuit brought by opponents of Casa Victoria described the site as ''nothing but an abandoned, rubble-strewn, litter-filled lot used only by drug addicts and derelicts.''
The situation worsened, all sides in the dispute agreed, after an itinerant musician opened an outdoor soup kitchen for homeless people encamped in nearby Tompkins Square Park. By all accounts, the soup kitchen degenerated into an open-air drug bazaar.
''This was the biggest drug den we ever had down here,'' said Mr. Pagan.
Opponents of the housing development say they now realize it was a mistake for them to let the soup kitchen open. But they insist it was they who closed it down and cleaned up the site. The park is now virtually empty of drug dealers during the day.
''It used to be a terrible place,'' said Bernard Leroy, the owner of Bernard's, a nearby restaurant. ''But it hasn't been that way for six or seven months because the community has really been on their backs.''

HEADLINE: Third World Borrowing Still Growing

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
The total debt of third world countries is still rising, and an increasing number of countries are accumulating arrears, the World Bank said today.
The increase came despite American initiatives intended to reduce outstanding loans that began this year.
The World Bank, a lending institution with 152 member nations, also found encouraging developments, particularly in the experience of Mexico, an early beneficiary of the new strategy. Mexico has seen cuts in interest rates, a return of flight capital and a revival of domestic investment. 
Under a plan formulated in March by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, in which both the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund advance money for debt relief to countries willing to accept strict economic discipline, ''a good start has been made,'' the bank said in a review of the debt situation.
The assessment appeared in the publication ''World Debt Tables 1989-90,'' which projects total developing country debt at year-end at $1.165 trillion, $9 billion above the 1988 level, but $11 billion below the level at the end of 1987.
The share of developing country debt held by the World Bank, the I.M.F. and other so-called official creditors owned by governments has also continued to rise, providing further evidence of the lack of enthusiasm of many commercial banks for third world lending.
By the end of 1989 official creditors are expected to account for 48 percent of the total. In 1982, when the debt crisis began, their share was 38 percent.
Of the projected $26 billion that is going to developing countries in 1989, nearly 90 percent will be from official lenders.
The bank reported a 25 percent increase in total outstanding arrears, from $41 billion at the end of 1987 to $52 billion at the end of 1988. It made no projection for the end of 1989, but many analysts think arrears continued to rise, both to commercial banks and to the official lenders.
 
'Value Impaired'
In June, the buildup in arrears of Argentina led Washington regulators to instruct American banks to classify Argentine loans as ''value impaired,'' forcing banks to establish reserve accounts and subtract the new reserves from earnings.
Most interest payments to commercial banks by Argentina have been interrupted since April 1987.
The bank said the rising arrears reflect ''the impasse between creditors and debtors.''
The growth of official debt combined with the higher arrears could cause some problems for the Bush Administration next year when it seeks approval in Congress for increases in capital for both the I.M.F. and the World Bank's International Development Association.
The United States is prepared to back a 35 percent increase in the I.M.F.'s $120 billion pool of resources. Most other leading industrial nations want more, and a compromise is expected early next year.
 
Loans to the Poorest
Negotiations have just concluded between the United States and other donor nations to provide new funds for the International Development Association, which makes 35- and 40-year loans at no interest to more than 50 of the poorest countries.
Thirty-two donor countries agreed to contribute $15 billion over a three-year period to the association. The Bush Administration would ante up $3 billion.
There will be opposition in Congress, which has little enthusiasm for foreign economic assistance. In addition, some lawmakers feel that giving additional resources to the I.M.F. is the equivalent of transferring the burden of bad debts of developing countries from private banks to American taxpayers.

HEADLINE: Eastern Europe's Lures and Hurdles

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
American businesses are rushing to Eastern Europe with visions of tapping new markets for consumers and developing low-cost manufacturing bases, but experts on the region warn that formidable obstacles remain.
Among them are underdeveloped communications and transportation networks, people unfamiliar with Western ways of doing business and currencies that largely have no value outside their countries' borders.
For these and other reasons, it may be many years, if ever, before many of the new American ventures return profits to their parent companies, analysts and executives with experience in the region say.
Still, in recent weeks there has been a flurry of announcements of new undertakings in the East bloc, spurred by the rapid changes in governments and movement toward freer economies.
Reflecting one of the most promising early opportunities, American telecommunications companies have made deals to lay fiber-optic lines across the Soviet Union, establish cellular telephone service in Budapest and take cable television to Poland. 
On the financial front, Chubb & Son Inc., the insurance company, announced that it had formed a joint venture in the Soviet Union to offer property and casualty insurance to Western companies setting up businesses there.
And in an attempt to bring Western service standards to the Eastern bloc, the Marriott Corporation has opened a hotel in Warsaw.
In the last year alone, the number of American joint ventures in Hungary has doubled to 70, said William Winter, a specialist on Eastern Europe at the Commerce Department. That is not surprising, given that Hungary began to open up to foreign businesses several years ago. In Poland, where the basic law governing business was liberalized late last year, the number of joint ventures involving American companies has jumped from 4 to about 40 this year, Mr. Winter said.
Czechoslovakia and East Germany are just beginning the process of political change that precedes economic restructuring, but economists regard them as better long-range prospects for economic development because of their strong industrial bases.
Even the Soviet Union, long the most bureaucratic and inflexible of East bloc nations, now has close to 100 joint ventures with American companies, a number that increases almost daily. American business executives say the Soviet Union's potential for Western ventures is much larger, but remains hobbled by its central planning system.
''There were just a few United States-Soviet joint ventures when we began negotiations nearly a year ago,'' said Henry G. Parker 3d, a senior vice president of Chubb. ''Now there are almost 100.'' He said the company's subsidiaries in Italy and Germany were even more interested than its domestic units in seeking Eastern business agreements since companies in those countries have been more aggressive in establishing Soviet operations than American-based firms.
 
U.S. Companies Are Behind
United States companies, in general, have lagged behind those based in Europe in developing business ventures in the East bloc. In Poland, for instance, West German companies have formed more than 400 joint ventures, or 10 times as many as American companies, the Commerce Department said.
But some American companies stand out in their quickness to set up business. United Parcel Service has started delivering packages in Moscow, Budapest, East Berlin, Warsaw and Cracow. So eager was the company to begin operations that it is demanding payment in hard currencies, which could severely limit the amount of East-to-West business it develops.
Earlier this year, the General Electric Company agreed to acquire control of a Hungarian light bulb manufacturer for $150 million, and the General Motors Corporation has acknowledged that it is seeking to increase the number of automotive components it buys in that country so it can increase car imports.
 
'Enormous Pent-Up Demand'
''There is an enormous pent-up demand for products from the West in Eastern Europe,'' said Michael A. Petrilli, director of international development for the Monsanto Company, which is based in St. Louis. ''You do not have to convince them.''
Ralph Land, who manages Eastern European activities for the Xerox Corporation's British subsidiary, Rank-Xerox, said: ''The recent trend toward market economies is inexorable. The need to update their economies and fill store shelves with goods is so enormous that there are many opportunities to do business.''
Certainly Eastern Europe represents a vast, untapped market for Western companies. The population of Hungary, Poland, East Germany and Czechoslovakia exceeds 80 million, or as much as France, the Netherlands and Belgium combined. Adding the Soviet Union's 285 million produces a market of 365 million, which is larger than the European Community's 325 million, although not nearly as well off.
As the elaborate planning and regulatory structures are abolished in each country, doing business in Eastern Europe will come to resemble operations in other developing countries, experts say. ''In two or three years it will be that way in Poland, with Czechoslovakia and East Germany not far behind,'' said David M. Kemme, an economist at the Institute for East-West Security Studies in New York. ''In Hungary, the future is here. Companies are allowed to set up shop without hardly any restrictions.''
Increasing economic activity with an emphasis on private initiative will mean more consumer spending power, business executives say. ''Economic growth is going to make life better for us,'' said Christoph W. Admaski, vice president for world trade for Pepsico Inc., which has had operations in the Soviet Union since 1974.
But Western analysts and executives caution that Eastern Europe is not a place to make a quick buck. Virtually everyone involved in trade with East Bloc countries say the biggest single problem is finding a way to get paid in a spendable currency.
 
'Need to Build a Structure'
''We need to build a satisfactory structure that addresses convertability,'' said Ed Mattix, a spokesman for U S West, which announced plans last week to put fiber-optic cable across the Soviet Union. ''We strongly feel that it can be handled, but we'll have a group working on it for the next few months.''
To bring profits home, Western companies have had to persuade governments to dip into scarce reserves of hard currency. Another way has been to produce goods that can be sold in the West or finding something in the local economy that can be exported to pay for imports, a process known as countertrade.
For example, the foreign exchange that has paid for the import of concentrated Pepsi-Cola syrup to the Soviet Union since the mid-1970's has been provided by sale of Stolichnaya vodka. More recently, Pepsico helped buy bottling equipment for its Soviet operations by selling two oil tankers made there to Western companies.
 
Wider Opportunities
The decentralization of Eastern economies is making these countertrade operations more difficult to set up, participants say. But it is also providing wider opportunities.
Another obstacle is the accounting systems that are geared almost solely to recording production with little regard for financial performance. East bloc enterprises usually have ''very good books and records on production, but the last thing they are designed to do is reveal how much profit a company is making,'' said Philip Wright, a partner in the London office of Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm.
Bankers in particular seem wary of the rush eastward, possibly because some of them made loans in Poland in the 1970's that have not been repaid. Citibank, which has a local currency bank in Hungary, said no other offices are planned.
Kari Seppala, a New York-based vice president of the Kansallis Banking Group of Finland, said bankers in general are uncertain how the political changes in Eastern Europe will work out. ''There is so much happening in the Soviet Union and the East bloc that no one knows what is going on, and not even Mr. Gorbachev knows what course events will take,'' Mr. Seppala said. Still, Kansallis, four Western European and three Soviet banks have formed the International Moscow Bank, to assist Western companies in the Soviet Union.
In addition to political and economic uncertainty, communications and transportation networks in the Eastern countries are rudimentary, making it hard to conduct business. In places like East Germany and Czechoslovakia it is not always clear which officials actually have the authority to sign agreements.
''We are seeing a lot of things signed, but not much actual business being done,'' said W. Douglass Lee, the head of Intertech Resources Ltd., a London-based trading company.
''Everyone wants to get on the bandwagon, to get there first,'' he added. ''But you cannot go to Eastern Europe for two days, sign a deal and open up a business in a month. You need to be involved in discussions now for a project that might come to fruition in two years.''
With both Hungary and Poland heavily in debt to the West, economic leaders there are more eager to build export industries than simply be buyers of Western products. That too presents opportunities for doing business, executives say.
''If, as Western companies, we can do things like bring the quality of East bloc products up to Western standards, that puts us in a favored position to sell,'' said Mr. Petrilli of Monsanto. ''We have to find ways that make it possible for them to buy.''

HEADLINE: Business Digest

The Economy
Banks are becoming increasingly active in selling senior debt used to finance leveraged buyouts. The effort is the latest by participants in the leveraged buyout boom to try to forestall or avoid more serious problems. Thus far, the number of bank loans sold either publicly or through private placements is but a trickle. But participants said more deals are likely. Credit Markets. [Page D1.] 
Sales of costume jewelry have risen strongly. What some retail executives call ''anchorwoman influence'' is said to have bolstered the increase. [D1.]
 
The Media Business
People-watching is the newest big trend in consumer research, marketing experts say. A rather daring technique only five years ago, the hiring of cultural anthropologists to observe and often videotape consumers in stores, shopping malls and even their own homes has become a standard practice for most large corporations and some of the nation's leading advertising agencies. [A1.]
New York State's main newspaper publishers have pledged to raise their use of recycled paper to 40 percent by 2000. [B6.]
Veco International says its purchase of The Anchorage Times insures that pro-oil, pro-development sentiment in Alaska will be heard. Seldom in recent memory has a new owner had an inherent credibility problem as daunting as that. [D10.]
Changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union are affecting U.S. publishers. Manuscripts and books in galleys are rapidly being rewritten, publishing schedules are being revised almost daily, and competition for Soviet and East bloc works has intensified. [D10.]

International
American businesses face tough hurdles in Eastern Europe. Among the obstacles are underdeveloped communications and transportation networks, people unfamiliar with Western ways of doing business and currencies that largely have no value outside their countries' borders. [D1.]

Companies

HEADLINE: Sales of Costume Jewelry Sparkle

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
You could pin it on Deborah Norville and Jane Pauley.
In one of the few bright spots in a dull Christmas selling season, sales of costume jewelry - inexpensive, fashionably designed earrings, necklaces, pins and bracelets that do not contain precious metals or stones -have been registering strong gains in recent weeks.
The May Department Stores Company, which owns more than 300 stores, including Lord & Taylor, Robinson's and Filene's, is reporting increases ''much better than planned,'' said Kenneth Kolker, chief executive of May's merchandising unit. ''We are very, very pleased.'' 
Claire's Stores Inc., a Miami-based national chain of 832 boutiques that specializes in costume jewelry, reports sales gains of more than 17 percent this season over last year's season. Crystal Brands Inc. and Victoria Creations Inc., the two largest United States makers of costume jewelry, say many department stores to which they sell are reporting increases of up to 20 percent over last season.
 
The 'Anchorwoman Influence'
Some retailers attribute the sales increases to an ''anchorwoman influence,'' stemming from television personalities like Ms. Pauley and Ms. Norville of NBC's early-morning ''Today'' show wearing elegant costume jewelry before a bathrobe-garbed and groggy nation. Other executives mention the designer Coco Chanel and the First Lady, Barbara Bush, both of whom favor classic, pearl-necklaced looks.
Costume jewelry sales have been rising steadily for a decade. The Commerce Department estimates that the combined sales of domestic and foreign makers of costume jewelry to United States stores this year will total more than $2 billion, up nearly 80 percent from sales in 1980. About $1.3 billion will come from United States manufacturers.
''When the price of gold and precious stones - like diamonds, emeralds and sapphires - shot up in the early 1980's, the design quality of costume jewelry increased and many department stores started stocking up on it,'' said John Harris, an economist with the Commerce Department.
Also, more women have been working outside the home, requiring a more formal appearance that might warrant jewelry. ''Career women buy more jewelry than housewives,'' Mr. Harris said. Manufacturers and retailers say costume jewelry has finally shed its image as a cheap substitute for silver and gold or as a dodge against thieves. Many women regard costume jewelry as desirable for its own sake and buy 15 or more pieces a year.
Because costume jewelry is relatively easy to make, with little marketing and scant brand loyalty, low-cost foreign competition accounts for much of the overall industry rise.
American company sales have increased 40 percent this decade, but the sales of overseas rivals in the United States market have nearly quadrupled. The American share of the wholesale market dropped to 65 percent this year, from 83 percent in 1980, with overseas producers, especially from Taiwan and Hong Kong, accounting for the rest. There are hundreds, perhaps thousands, of manufacturers in the industry.
The least expensive pieces of costume jewelry, like a $2 set of earrings, are made by foreign companies. Domestic makers account for most of the more expensive, more elaborate items sold in department stores. There, pieces can fetch as much as $500, although most sell for less than $30.
 
Handsome Profit Margins
Like cosmetics, costume jewelry items are impulse purchases that carry handsome profit margins of up to 20 percent, about twice the average margin for department store goods.
Costume jewelry is usually featured prominently on the high-traffic first floors of department stores, where about 33 percent of industry sales occur. Direct sales representatives, mainly from Avon Products Inc., account for 30 percent of sales, with specialty stores, discounters like the K Mart Corporation, and small shops accounting for the rest.
Costume jewelry ''has that irresistible combination of good growth and excellent profitability,'' said James A. Northrop, president and chief executive of the Crystal Brands Jewelry Group, which sells most of its products to department stores.
The company is part of Crystal Brands Inc., of Southport, Conn., a maker and marketer of apparel and accessories that had $889 million in revenue in 1988. It has the Monet, Trifari and Marvella brands of costume jewelry. With about $250 million in projected 1989 sales for those three lines, Crystal Brands is by far the largest company in the industry.
 
Little Brand Awareness
Monet, which had more than $110 million in 1988 sales and is the largest single brand, probably has the greatest consumer awareness in an industry where few consumers look for a brand. The brand's marketing is aimed specifically at working women, prime buyers of costume jewelry.
That most buyers are drawn to an individual piece, not its brand, is a source of frustration for industry executives. Without customer loyalty to brands, costume jewelry makers must prove themselves daily, piece by piece, in a struggle for consumer attention.
Monet, for example, has more than 6,500 products, and nearly 75 percent of those are changed every 12 months in an effort to keep up with changing tastes.
There is also pressure to maintain selling space. Most customers buy costume jewelry from carousels on top of a counter. But profitable cosmetics lines have proliferated, putting the squeeze on the counter space allocated to costume jewelry.
Costume jewelry also has fewer dramatic displays, no free gifts with purchases or fashion makeovers and other marketing gimmicks that cosmetics makers use to beef up sales.
 
Tricks of the Trade
Still, the industry has learned a few tricks. Take market segmentation, for example, the strategy of aiming at a particular group of buyers and trying to hit a home run in their direction.
Crystal Brands has aimed its Monet line at career women in their 30's with a family; Trifari is for younger customers, and Marvella, with its Victorian appeal, is for women who like romance novels.
Retailers do it, too. Claire's Stores, the Miami-based company that had $127.2 million in sales last year, has Claire's Boutiques for women aged 12 to 40 who like their jewelry ''cheap and cheerful.'' Its Dara Michelle is for the more restrained, ''fashion-conscious woman,'' and its Topkapi is for those whose tastes are in between.
Despite the strong recent sales, it is still relatively easy to make a mistake in costume jewelry. Inventory is key, since manufacturers must produce so many items to survive the competition.
Victoria Creations, a subsidiary of United Merchants and Manufacturers Inc. and the industry's second-largest manufacturer with six brands and about $76 million in sales, reported a $1.4 million operating loss for the year ended June 30.
Paul B. Markovits, who has been Victoria Creations' chairman for less than two months, said the company suffered from ''concept proliferation.'' It had more than 11,000 different products.
''When you have too much stuff,'' Mr. Markovits said, ''it's easy to lose focus. You have too many concepts and you wind up confusing customers.'' He plans to do a major pruning of concepts.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Theory of Decline Fails to Hold Up

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
EXPERTS try furiously to explain why the United States is in decline as a manufacturing center while Japan and West Germany flourish. The blame has fallen heavily on the work force (inadequately educated), consumers (wasteful spenders) and the Government (lacks a trade policy). Now a new explanation is becoming popular - the high cost of capital - and like the others, it provides some useful insights.
The argument is that raising money in the United States is too costly to justify huge investments in automated machinery, new factories and cutting-edge research. The forced outcome is that American companies go for projects that pay off in a few years - a tire factory, for example - and not those that require a decade to show a profit. Financing the development of a supersonic commercial aircraft is considered too costly, although producing one would be a feather in America's cap. 
That's the theory. Many executives, however, say it is an overstatement of what actually happens, among them Stephen R. Hardis, vice chairman of the Eaton Corporation, a machinery maker. He says returns from Eaton's investment are always high enough to cover capital costs.
Nevertheless, Mr. Hardis acknowledged that the high cost of capital was one reason that Eaton refrained from bidding in 1986 for the Robertshaw Controls Company, a maker of thermostats and other control devices, a field that interested Eaton. The Virginia-based company went instead to a British acquirer for $470 million.
Figuring the true cost of capital is complicated. Most capital is raised by borrowings - bond issues and bank loans - or by the sale of stock. The cost of borrowed money is, of course, the monthly interest payments, but the cost of selling stock or equity in a company is more than the quarterly dividend payments. Total profit must be high enough to persuade investors to buy and hold stock.
Borrowing money does not put American companies at a disadvantage. Although interest rates are higher in the United States than in West Germany and Japan, the differential almost disappears once allowance is made for inflation and tax breaks, according to a study by Robert N. McCauley and Steven A. Zimmer, of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Adjusted in this fashion, the average borrowing costs from 1983 through 1988 were 1.8 percent in the United States, 1.7 percent in Japan and zero in Germany, the two economists found.
But American companies have greater difficulty talking potential equity investors into paying a high price for stock in a company whose current earnings are low. To lure investors, American companies had to earn 10.8 cents each year for every dollar invested in stock in the 1983-1988 period, compared with 6.4 cents in West Germany and only 4.9 cents in Japan, the Fed study found. American companies have not yet sold a big percentage of their shares to foreigners - so the demands of American shareholders determine the cost of capital, even though many companies borrow abroad. The total capital costs, through stock sales and borrowing, averaged 6.4 cents annually for each dollar raised by an American company in the 1983-1988 period. The comparable figure for Japanese companies was 2.7 cents and for German companies 1.6 cents, the Fed economists said.
Their much-cited study helps to support several contentions. One is that Americans should save more, thus making more funds available for investment. Another is that the investment tax credit should be restored to lower investment costs. A third is that American companies are being forced to raise more capital through debt than new stock.
But like so many explanations of why the United States is not the manufacturing powerhouse it once was, the cost-of-capital argument falls short of being the final word. That is mainly because other factors besides the cost of capital determine competitiveness, among them labor costs and the dollar's steep devaluation since 1985. ''The devaluation alone has swamped any disadvantage in capital costs,'' said Alan Auerbach, a University of Pennsylvania economist.
Even without devaluation, Mr. Auerbach argues that the cost differential is illusory. Japanese investors, he says, pay a lot for stock in companies that merely appear to have low earnings. That is partly because balance sheets do not include earnings from subsidiaries, the requirement in America. And they do not include gains from rapidly rising real estate values.
Whatever the truth, Japanese capital costs are rising - partly because equity capital is perhaps costlier than the Japanese acknowledge, but also because Japanese companies have recently increased the equity portion of their capital. Eventually, the process might bring capital costs in Japan and the United States close to each other.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press;
Journalistic Issue in Alaska: Do Oil and Newspapers Mix?

BYLINE: By Alex S Jones

 BODY:
THE ANCHORAGE TIMES, Alaska's second-largest daily, is now owned by the state's biggest oilfield-services company.
Veco International Inc., which the Exxon Corporation hired to clean up its monumental oil spill last spring, completed its acquisition Thursday. It has declared that it was buying the paper to insure that pro-oil, pro-development sentiment in Alaska was heard.
To Billy James Allen, the owner of Veco and now the publisher of The Times, that means strong advocacy on the editorial page and ''true facts'' in the news columns, as opposed to what he terms the anti-development bias of The Anchorage Daily News, the state's largest newspaper. 
''I think that it's real important that the state of Alaska has two voices,'' Mr. Allen said, adding that The Times's news coverage would be fair and full, even if that means publishing unflattering articles about oil companies or Veco itself.
But seldom in recent memory has a new owner had an inherent credibility problem as daunting as Mr. Allen's, and he concedes that he has a lot to prove. The stakes are high. For Alaska, where there is much debate about development, a perception that The Times's news coverage is tainted could discredit the very political views that Mr. Allen hopes to promote, and he could lose a fortune.
If Veco succeeds in winning the confidence of Anchorage's readers, other corporations with strong political agendas could decide that going into the newspaper business is a good idea. In the past, this has been considered highly suspect.
Robert B. Atwood, the 82-year-old former owner of The Times, said he thought that most Alaskans cared little whether the newspaper they read was owned by a company with ties to the oil industry.
When Veco made an offer for The Times last summer, at a price that has not been disclosed, Mr. Atwood was concerned that under Veco's ownership readers would consider the paper ''a house organ for the oil industry.''
In July, Mr. Allen hired Hellenthal & Associates, a polling organization, to ask people whether they were ''more likely or less likely to read a newspaper that is owned by an Alaska company associated with the oil industry.''
A representative of Hellenthal said 25.7 percent of those interviewed in the Anchorage area said they were more likely to read it, 24 percent said they were less likely and 50.3 percent said it made no difference.
Mr. Atwood said he wanted to sell The Times to someone based in Alaska who shared the pro-development and pro-oil views that the paper has vigorously championed since he acquired it in 1935.
For instance, barely a month after the Exxon Valdez dumped millions of gallons of crude oil into Prince William Sound in what is generally considered Alaska's worst ecological disaster, The Times editorial page declared: ''Every cloud has its silver lining, they say. And that's certainly true of the oil spill.''
That silver lining, the editorial said, was the large cleanup effort that in turn prompted the ''biggest economic bonanza'' since the height of pipeline construction.
The Daily News, which has been owned by McClatchy Newspapers since 1979, viewed the spill much less positively. Because of chain ownership, The News was able to spend lavishly to cover it.
Howard C. Weaver, the managing editor of The News, said his paper published more than 600 articles on the spill. He cited McClatchy's willingness to spend money as a critical factor in The News's success in surpassing The Times in circulation over the last decade.
Mr. Atwood noted that The Times had to cover the event with fewer people and had not been able to match The News's financial muscle.
He also said Veco's huge resources, including windfall profits from cleaning up the oil spill, were an important reason he chose the company as the buyer. Mr. Allen declined to give profit figures on Veco, but he said revenues this year would total about $250 million.
Mr. Allen, who is 52 years old and came to Alaska to start a construction business in 1969, said he was prepared to invest heavily in The Times.
While there was some concern expressed by staff members when the sale was announced, he said, no one has resigned, perhaps because one of his first acts was to grant across-the-board raises of 5 percent. He also advised the staff of The Times that like all Veco workers, they would be subject to random drug testing.
Mr. Allen is no stranger to the power of the press. Articles in The News prompted an investigation that eventually led to Mr. Allen being fined $28,000 in 1985 for violating state campaign finance laws.
But Mr. Allen says he is not out for revenge. Indeed, he says, The News's position of dominance over The Times is justified.
''They put out a better newspaper,'' he said.
For Mr. Weaver, the prospect of competing with a newspaper owned and operated by a prominent member of the oil fraternity is unsettling in that there is now a powerful Alaska institution in the hands of a person with what he sees as a conflict of interest.
''We're obvious enemies,'' he said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Japan Outpaces U.S. in Income

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
The average income in the United States rose slightly in 1988, but was far outpaced by Japan, the World Bank reported on Friday.
The average per capita income in the United States last year was $19,780, compared with $18,580 in 1987. In Japan, the average income rose from $15,840 to $21,040, the World Bank said. The bank gave all incomes in United States dollars.
The Swiss continued to rank first in per capita income with a 1988 average of $27,260, up from $21,310 in 1987. Mozambique ranked lowest among the 152 members of the World Bank with a 1988 annual per capita income of $100.
The United States, which in 1987 ranked second only to Switzerland, was fifth last year, behind Switzerland, Japan, Iceland and Norway.
The average in Iceland was $20,160, while in Norway it was $20,020.
Much of the rise in Japanese income can be attributed to an increase in the value of the yen in comparison with the dollar, as well as to increased Japanese production. Elsewhere, differences could be linked to shifts in the value of the dollar compared with other currencies. The dollar has been rising in 1989 after a fall that began in 1985.

HEADLINE: Absent Watchdogs - A Reagan Legacy;
Regulators Say 80's Budget Cuts May Cost U.S. Billions in 1990's

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
In their zeal to cut the fat out of Government, Reagan Administration officials also cut the managerial muscle that was responsible for watching over the Government's financial liabilities and obligations, reports by Congressional and Government investigators show.
Past and present Government accountants and management experts say the result is tens of billions of dollars in losses and the potential for untold billions more.
But the costs are not just financial, these experts said. As more and more essential functions have been turned over to private parties as part of ''privatization,'' the Government's control and its accountability to the public have been eroded.
These developments have been most visibly illustrated in the Federal Government's bailout of the savings and loan industry and the repeated revelations about the political manipulation of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. But they represent just the edge of much deeper Government-wide management problems that are at the heart of an estimated $300 billion in past and future losses, said the head of the General Accounting Office. While about half of that represents the cost of the Federal bailout of the savings and loan industry, the rest is spread throughout the Government. 
 
'Really Pound-Foolish'
During the Reagan years, ''we tried as a Government not to get on anyone's back,'' said Frederick D. Wolf, until recently responsible for accounting and financial management at the accounting office, an arm of Congress. ''But if you do it in the oversight area, you're going to have a problem.''
He said the Reagan Administration failed to distinguish between reducing the paperwork burden imposed by the Government on businesses and individuals and maintaining oversight over its own liabilities. As a result, he said, ''budget cuts fell disproportionately on enforcement, oversight, management and accounting functions.''
Charles A. Bowsher, who heads the General Accounting Office, told a Senate panel last month: ''When you look at what happened in the S&L crisis and look at the situation at H.U.D. and things like that, if we had proper systems, if we had the adequate financial reporting, if we had the right number of auditors to go out and check on this, we would have saved billions of dollars. In other words, we have been penny-wise and really pound-foolish here.''
Mr. Bowsher estimated that recent past losses in the $5 trillion Federal insurance and credit assistance area ''total in the $200 billion range,'' with $139 billion of that stemming from the insolvency of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. And he said the Government stands to lose another $100 billion in the near future, including $38 billion in credits from the Agriculture Department, $10 billion to $20 billion owed the Pentagon for foreign military sales, $5 billion in delinquent student loans, at least $5 billion at the Housing Department plus tens of billions in debts owed the Internal Revenue Service.
''It's a very scary situation for the Federal Government and the American taxpayer,'' Mr. Bowsher said.
 
Tougher Stance Now
In the last six months, the White House budget office, which oversees the budgets and management of all the departments, has begun to take a firmer hand in managing the Government, in hopes of heading off another crisis. It has ordered agencies to identify their problems and prodded them into follow-up action. More people have been hired by some departments for supervision. And private contractors are being more closely supervised.
To be sure, the Reagan Administration inherited problems, like neglected nuclear production plants, bad loans made in previous administrations and outdated information and accounting systems. And economic downturns in the Southwest have contributed to loan defaults.
But Mr. Bowsher said in an interview that improper management magnified the losses from the economic misfortunes.
 
Private vs. Public Interests
The Reagan Administration did improve how the Federal Government manages its cash and also updated some financial and accounting systems.
One of Mr. Reagan's pet managerial projects was to contract out Government services to private parties, who are less accountable to the public than Federal employees. Whereas the public has a right to find out a Federal employee's salary, job description and potential conflicts of interest, this information is not available for contractors, even as they play an increasingly larger role in essential Government functions. Private contractors also cannot be disciplined or supervised as easily as civil servants.
Right now, the White House budget office says it does not know how many consultants the departments have under contract. Nor can many departments keep track of their financial risks because they have been slow to implement the more rigorous audit and management practices that are standard in private industry.
The budget office cut the staff of its own management division by 42 percent during the Reagan Administration in its drive to set an example for other agencies, the General Accounting Office has reported. And it is now clear that the budget office had one person, working part time, evaluating annual management reports by every department and compiling what the current budget director, Richard G. Darman, calls simply ''statistical tallies'' of the problems listed in the reports.
 
'A Level of Detail'
James C. Miller 3d, budget director in the Reagan Administration, says he never read any of those reports. ''That was a level of detail I didn't follow personally,'' he said in an interview, adding that the Administration was more focused on the philosophy of reducing Government than on the financial details. ''We tried to zero out programs,'' he said. ''That meant less attention was paid.''
Mr. Miller added, ''Our perception was that waste came out of Congress in the form of wasteful programs.''
Now, said Mr. Darman, who was Deputy Treasury Secretary in the Reagan Administration, and Frank Hodsoll, now the top management official at the budget office, the management reports are the centerpiece of efforts to keep track of performance and risks in the departments.
Under questioning from Senator John Glenn at a Senate Governmental Affairs Committee hearing, Mr. Bowsher agreed with the Ohio Democrat's statement that the recent drive to turn over more Government functions to the private sector ''has had the perverse effect in increasing waste, fraud and abuse instead of decreasing it.''
 
The Problems
More Bad Debts, Neglect of Services
Dozens of interviews, Congressional testimony and a review by The New York Times of hundreds of management reports and audits issued each year since 1983 reveal this formidable array of problems:
* Growing losses. The total of the Government's annual losses from defaulted loans to uncollected debts like taxes owed by people and companies, is now bigger than the annual Federal budget deficit. The losses have steadily risen from less than $40 billion a year in the early 1980's to $115 billion last year.
* Identifying liabilities. Though tracking of bad debts has improved, total losses are actually higher than reported and not quantifiable, the budget office says.
* Neglecting basic investments. Basic functions like collecting taxes, maintaining bridges and controlling air traffic have been deprived of resources, Mr. Bowsher of the General Accounting Office says. To make up for the neglect of these services, the Government will end up paying hundreds of billions of dollars, adding to the Federal budget deficit, he said.
* The brain drain. The widening disparity between salaries paid by private industry and the Government has resulted in the loss of crucial technical expertise in areas like computers and accounting.
''The Government has a hard time attracting qualified people due to low pay and turnover,'' said Gerald Riso, who was the top management official at the White House budget office until early this year. As a result, he said, the Government's information technology is ''contracted out to consultants a lot with sparse institutional monitoring of their work.''
Senator David Pryor, the Arkansas Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Governmental Affairs subcommittee on Federal services, said the reliance on contractors throughout the Government has gone far beyond hiring private security guards or janitors. It has become so extensive that ''neither O.M.B. nor the Congress is aware of the degree to which the basic management of our Government has been delegated to contractors,'' he said.
Senator Pryor has estimated that the Government had as much as $26 billion in consulting contracts in 1987, but he was relying on Government-generated figures. Mr. Hodsoll said, however, that the Government is unable to compile accurate data on consultant use.
In an interview, Mr. Hodsoll described the Government's growing use of consultants as a ''horrible problem'' that has reached the point that at some agencies ''you have contractors supervising contractors.''
Senator Pryor noted that raises more fundamental questions than those of efficiency. ''Contractors, not Government officials, often have effective responsibility for the most basic decision making,'' he said. The Environmental Protection Agency, for instance, is relying on private contractors for everything from rule writing to rule enforcement, he said. At the Energy Department, contractors are drafting Congressional testimony for top officials and helping to interpret and write legislation.
Indeed, the situation is so confused that the Energy Department in 1988 hired a management consulting firm, Booz Allen & Hamilton, to develop the department's plan to keep track of how many consultants it has and what they do.
 
The Abuses
Housing Programs To Nuclear Plants
Senator Pryor is upset that Federal information laws classify as ''business secrets'' the names, salaries, job descriptions and potential conflicts of interests of contractor employees, information routinely available for Federal employees.
Nor, he said, are contract employees subject to salary limitations. At the Energy Department, consultants earn 15 percent to 50 percent more than senior managers at the department's headquarters for doing comparable work, according to a recent internal study disclosed to a Senate subcommittee last month. The Energy Department's top management official told the subcommittee that contractors are paid up to twice as much as comparable Federal employees on contracts to operate weapons laboratories around the country.
And unlike the marketplace, there is little incentive for efficient performance. At the Energy Department, in fact, contractors are reimbursed for fines or penalties they may incur for violating Federal safety procedures.
Revelations about neglect at the Energy Department's contractor-run nuclear plants have shown that during the early years of the Reagan Administration, cuts in Government safety and technical personnel at the plants proved to be costly mistakes. More recently, additional people have been added in this area.
Similarly, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has become so reliant on contractors that its senior officials have said it may be losing its ability to manage its operations and maintain safety. A Presidential inquiry into the cause of the 1986 explosion of the space shuttle Challenger recommended that cuts in safety and technical personnel during the Reagan years be restored.
Contractor dependence is also an issue at the Environmental Protection Agency. The agency was one of the few that had an overall increase in staff in the Reagan years. But while its Federal work force increased by 11 percent in the last decade, its budget for contractors increased by 300 percent. A report by the Office of Technology Assessment, also an arm of Congress, on the agency's $10 billion Superfund to clean up toxic wastes found that contractors ''play a major role in conceiving, analyzing and structuring policies and tasks.''
''Privatization of Government programs is not in conflict with public interest, but ONLY if there is effective Government management and oversight,'' the report said.
The office's report found similar contracting practices at the E.P.A. and the Pentagon, including the revolving door phenomenon in which individuals move freely between Government work and private industry. A General Accounting Office report issued in 1987 found that the percentage of political appointees in the higher ranks of five Cabinet agencies went up by about 50 percent in the Reagan years. And that has caused problems for those agencies as political appointees worked for Government for only a short time, and then left to capitalize on their experience.
The revolving door is a crucial issue in the abuses found by Federal investigators in Pentagon contracting. Since the abuses surfaced last year, about three dozen consultants, former Pentagon officials and military contracting executives have pleaded guilty to charges stemming from attempts to defraud the contracting process.
Domestic programs as well have suffered costly losses from lack of oversight.
The inability of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, the now-defunct agency that supervised the savings and loan industry, to hire additional examiners several years ago played a major role in the savings and loan crisis, said Edwin Gray, the former head of the board. ''If we had gotten help earlier we could have reduced, headed off the whole crisis, period,'' he said in an interview. When they turned down requests for additional examiners in 1984 and 1985, officials at the White House budget office told him, ''The policy of the Administration is to get the Government off the backs of business,'' Mr. Gray recalled.
As part of deregulation, the Housing Department shifted its role from lender of Federal money to guarantor of private loans. Under the new system, private lenders underwrite the mortgages and collect much of the interest while the Federal Government insures the loans and thus takes most of the risk.
A recent outside audit of the Federal Housing Administration, a Housing Department unit that insures $305 billion in mortgages, found that the department underestimated the F.H.A.'s losses in 1988. The losses were actually $4.2 billion instead of $850 million, the auditors found. The losses stemmed in large part from Washington's lax supervision of its private partners, the audit by Price Waterhouse-U.S. found.
Similar audits, by private firms that use more rigorous accounting methods than the Government does, have not been conducted at other agencies holding large Federal loans and loan guarantees.
At other agencies, where private lenders assumed a greater role in lending programs, there was lax supervision, the inspector generals of the agencies and the General Accounting Office have found.
One agricultural unit, the Farmers Home Administration, alone faces losses of $26 billion in farm loans, in part because of the faltering farm economy but also partly because of the reluctance by the Farmers Home Administration to crack down on deficiencies in the way private lenders were processing the loans for fear of alienating them, the department's inspector general reported in 1988.
A report this fall by the General Accounting Office found that the fast growth in loan guarantees at the farm lending agency has increased the Government's overall financial exposure while benefiting private lenders by reducing their risk. In a separate report, the accounting office found that in 1987 the farm lending agency withdrew tighter criteria for loans to farmers after Congress expressed concern that some borrowers would be ineligible for further assistance.
 
The Response
More Supervision, More Investment
In his first week in office, President Bush called the inspectors general for the Cabinet departments to the White House. Throwing away his briefing notes, the new President appealed to the inspectors to serve as his early warning system against budget disasters like the failures in the savings and loan crisis industry and the cleanup of the Energy Department's nuclear weapons complex.
Over the last six months, more oversight personnel with expertise in technical, safety and information processing are being hired in the environmental and space agencies as well as the budget office. Contractors at departments like Energy and Housing and Urban Development are being more closely supervised and more money is being spent on long-term investments like upgrading the Internal Revenue Service computer system.
''The I.R.S. has enormous computer problems,'' Mr. Hodsoll said. ''By the early 1990's they won't be able to process tax returns.'' He added that ''the I.R.S. is at the top of the list'' of areas requiring more resources.
Mr. Hodsoll said the budget office has also imposed more stringent guidelines when departments sell off Government loans to the private sector, a major ''management improvement'' initiative of the Reagan Administration that Mr. Bowsher said had ''terrible problems,'' in part because the government ''sells off the better loans.''
Nonetheless, some critics in Congress as well as the executive branch think more is needed. Management is a neglected Washington art, Mr. Darman told Congress, and he acknowledged in a recent interview that he had neglected it, too, when he was Deputy Treasury Secretary. He attributed Washington's inattentiveness, in part, to the ''Hollywood East syndrome,'' in which senior department officials are infatuated by political and media glitter and not the dull work of bureaucracy and supervision.

HEADLINE: What the U.S. Said About China in June

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The Bush Administration secretly renewed high-level contacts with China in early July, shortly after imposing sanctions over Beijing's crackdown on dissent in June. Here is the text of the statement on the sanctions issued by the White House on June 20. 
The President today directed that the U.S. Government suspend participation in all high-level exchanges of Government officials with the People's Republic of China, in addition to the suspension of military exchanges previously announced. This action is being taken in response to the wave of violence and reprisals by the Chinese authorities against those who have called for democracy. The United States has supported the legitimate democratic aspirations for freedom of peoples throughout the world. The United States will continue to voice its concern and its support for these aspirations.
The United States hopes that the current tragedy in China be brought to a peaceful end and that dialogue will replace the atmosphere of suspicion and reprisal. China is an important state with which we hope to continue productive relations.
In addition to the ban on exchanges, the United States will seek to postpone consideration of new international financial institutions' loans to China. The situation in China is of international concern, as witnessed by the variety of voices that have spoken up on the issue. We urge continued international expressions of concern.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
German Momentum

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST BERLIN, Dec. 18

 BODY:
While politicians in Washington, Moscow, London and Paris debate whether the two Germanys can unite, and when, Germans are rushing ahead with practical steps that could soon make unification either inevitable or superfluous.
All the major political parties in both East and West Germany, and both Governments, have pronounced themselves in favor of far closer association of the two countries, for different reasons. Every one but the East German Communist Party has also expressed support for some kind of confederation, the distinctions being not whether political integration should proceed but how much of it there should be.
The East German Prime Minister, Hans Modrow, the most widely respected political leader in his country at the moment, has said that in parts of the West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's 10-point plan for German unity he saw a positive answer to his own earlier proposal for a ''treaty-community'' between the two states. 
 
Modrow and Kohl to Meet
Mr. Modrow and Mr. Kohl will meet in Dresden on Tuesday to discuss concrete terms of closer association. But more important, both Governments will probably agree then to accelerate a more significant process of change, one that has already begun - economic integration.
''West Germany has the highest rate of savings in Western Europe,'' Ulrich Pfeiffer, a consultant in Bonn, said recently. ''We have enough capital to finance the reconstruction of the East German economy all by ourselves.'' Talks are already under way among dozens of West German firms and East German state enterprises on joint ventures and other forms of cooperation that would build on decades of low-key contacts.
From the urgency with which Gregor Gysi, the East German Communist Party leader, keeps warning of a ''sellout'' of the relatively backward, impoverished economy of his country, it is evident that many East Germans fear that the result will be practical economic annexation by West Germany.
For that reason, Mr. Gysi appealed to the United States in an interview last week not to leave the question of aid to East Germany to West Germany alone.
The speed with which Germans are moving toward each other these days could, paradoxically, make Western support for East Germany's continued separate existence its most powerful political bargaining tool with Bonn. The same factor has also set the stage for serious conflict between West Germany and its Western allies, and possibly to a lesser extent between East Germany and the Soviet Union.
 
Allies Want to Have a Say
The United States, France and Britain, which signed away the occupation rights of sovereignty in their zones of Germany from 1952 to 1955, carefully kept their rights to have a say in the affairs of Berlin and Germany as a whole, including the reunification question. They were therefore annoyed when Mr. Kohl announced his 10-point plan on Nov. 28 without consulting them, just as the Soviet Union had been irked when East Germany announced on its own the opening of its western borders on Nov. 9.
The American, French, British and Soviet Governments reasserted their presence in a meeting of their Ambassadors here on Dec. 11, and the United States Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d, gave much-appreciated symbolic support to Mr. Modrow the next day by going to visit him in Potsdam.
In West Berlin today, the West German opposition Social Democratic Party, which when in power in the 1970's all but recognized East Germany as a separate state, met to approve a policy statement calling for ''conditions of peace in Europe in which the German people achieve unity in free self-determination.'' The Social Democratic leadership also called on the four World War II Allies to give up their rights over Berlin and ''Germany as a whole'' and sign a peace treaty with the two German states, together or separately.
Commenting on the Western allies' irritation over the German insistence on unity, Rudolf Augstein, publisher of Der Spiegel magazine, wrote sarcastically today, ''They always act as if we wanted something indecent.'' In fact, the problem is that while the Western powers formally support reunification, they have not really meant it - or thought seriously about what it would mean - for years.
 
Support for Separate Country
Der Spiegel and the West German television network Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen commissioned a public opinion poll of 1,032 East German voters in the first week of December. It showed that 71 percent of those polled wanted their country to remain separate and sovereign, the magazine reported today. Merger with West Germany was supported by 27 percent, but by only 7 percent of the Communist Party members polled, the magazine said.
The non-Communist parties and other political movements in East Germany are less afraid than the Communists to embrace the idea of confederation. ''The catastrophic situation in our plants can only be cured by very high investment of capital from Western countries,'' said Lothar de Maiziere, the new chairman of the East German Christian Democratic Union, at a party conference over the weekend that dropped all commitment to socialism, which it had supported for 40 years.
''This isn't blackmail by Western monopolies,'' he said. ''It's not a sell-out of the East Germany economy. It's just the logic of the market.'' He called for ''the most far-reaching adaptation and integration'' of the two countries' economies.
Somewhat by surprise, several leaders of West Germany's Christian Democratic Union, which had previously avoided any contact with the East German party, dropped in on the conference to express their support for its new course.
 
Visit From Two Bonn Officials
And Mr. Genscher and Norbert Blum, the West German Minister for Employment, were present in Leipzig last weekend as Democratic Awakening, an East German protest movement, constituted itself as a political party.
It, too, debated the reunification question, adopting a program calling for eventual German unity in a framework of complete disarmament. Democracy Now, another movement that has not yet decided whether to form a political party, has also come out with a program for unification in stages, the first of which would leave East German sovereignty intact.
Mr. Gysi said last week that like Mr. Modrow, he believes that what Germans need now is not a theoretical prescription for unity but practical negotiations to get the two Governments working together for the common good. Drawing an unusual parallel to the long cooperation between the Lutheran Churches of East and West Germany, Mr. Gysi said, ''The Protestant churches have worked very closely together for a long time, while recognizing each other's independence and sovereignty. Here is experience that could also be useful for others.''

HEADLINE: When Life Is a Medical and Not a Legal Issue

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Right to Die? Yes. Medical Issue? No'' by Yale Kamisar (Op-Ed, Dec. 6) represents outdated, legalistic thinking on medical decision making. My fear is that the Supreme Court in the case of Nancy Cruzan, a Missouri woman in a vegetative state as the result of an auto accident, whose family's plea to remove her feeding tube was denied by Missouri's highest court, will adopt similar reasoning. 
According to Professor Kamisar's legalistic approach, the state maintains the right to preserve the patient's life, even though health care providers and family members agree that treatment should be withdrawn. But the state has no legitimate interest in a case such as Nancy Cruzan's, where the patient is in a persistent vegetative state. This is a diagnosis involving irreversible brain damage in patients who pass from deep coma into a state of apparent wakefulness, but without any awareness or response to their surroundings. Patients in a persistent vegetative state virtually never regain awareness.
The state interest asserted in the life of a person in this condition is purely theoretical. Where an individual has no meaningful interaction with her environment, no recognition of people or objects, nor any human feelings or experience, the state interest in ''life'' is no more than an abstraction.
All the emotional and economic burden is borne by the family, which suffers from the refusal of the law to allow a decision to dignify a natural death process. The right of a person in a persistent vegetative state to be allowed to die, whether by withdrawal of artificial respiration or of hydration and nutrition, is well grounded in bioethical thinking. What greater purpose could a constitutional right to privacy achieve than to reject unwarranted state intrusion into such an intimate moment as death? The only state interest here is to require a process that insures both a reliable diagnosis of a persistent vegetative state and properly motivated decision makers.
Lawyers sometimes believe that by framing medical issues as legal ones, and by requiring court intervention, human rights are preserved. But to thrust a lengthy judicial process on so private a decision in so clear a case is merely an obstacle to the justice and decency the dying and their families deserve.
 
LARRY GOSTIN
Executive Director, American
Society of Law & Medicine
 Boston, Dec. 11, 1989

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
A White House Ghost

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
Were President Reagan and Vice President Bush, as he was then, more culpably involved in the Iran-contra scandal than either has admitted? We may never know for sure, but the possibility, like some vengeful ghost, keeps coming back to haunt them.
Former Adm. John Poindexter, for example, will attempt in his forthcoming trial to portray Mr. Reagan as an informed, active participant in the sale of arms to Iran and the attempt to divert the proceeds to the contras in Nicaragua. Such a portrayal contradicts the picture Mr. Poindexter, the former national security adviser, painted of Mr. Reagan during Congressional hearings in 1987. 
Also, Joe Pichirallo and Walter Pincus have reported in The Washington Post that a State Department document - curiously overlooked in previous searches - shows George Shultz, when he was Secretary of State, to have approved a plan to expedite aid to Honduras in 1985 to assure continuing Honduran support for the contras.
That ''quid pro quo'' has been denied by officials of two Administrations, including Mr. Shultz and Mr. Bush. On May 4, 1989, the latter told reporters that ''the word of the President of the United States, George Bush, is that there was no quid pro quo.''
Yet the newly discovered document, a memorandum to Mr. Shultz from Langhorne Motley, then the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, was quoted by The Post: ''It was agreed [by senior officials meeting Feb. 7, 1985] that some combination of efforts was needed to encourage the Hondurans to remain firm in their support for [the contras]. . . .''
The memorandum was initialed by Mr. Shultz. It specified expedited economic and military aid, recommended a letter from Mr. Reagan to President Suazo of Honduras assuring him of support and calling for cooperation, and suggested an ''oral demarche'' to Mr. Suazo in which ''our intentions and expectations would be made clear.''
During the trial of Oliver North this April, a related memorandum of Feb. 19, 1985, was disclosed. Addressed to Mr. Reagan by Robert C. McFarlane, then the national security adviser, it detailed ''incentives'' planned to persuade Honduras to continue supporting the contras. Mr. Reagan approved the document with his initials.
In his May 4 statement, President Bush denied that he made the ''oral demarche'' to Mr. Suazo when he visited Honduras on March 16, 1985, within weeks of the Motley and McFarlane memos.
Mr. Poindexter is scheduled for trial in January on charges of obstructing Congressional inquiries and making false statements to Congress about the Iran-contra affair. His defense, Judge Harold H. Greene disclosed in a court order, will allege that Mr. Reagan ''formulated the Administration's position for the guidance of Poindexter.''
That would be at sharp variance with Mr. Poindexter's testimony to Congress, in which he took sole responsibility for the diversion of arms-sales funds to the contras at a time when Congress had prohibited aid to them, and described Mr. Reagan as a detached President uninterested in details.
Mr. Poindexter was granted immunity for his Congressional testimony, which now cannot be used against him. But the difference between that testimony and the defense planned for his trial raises the possibility that he then was protecting a President still in office, and now seeks to defend himself by accusing a former President, who may be immune from prosecution.
Mr. Reagan, by refusing to provide documents requested by the Poindexter defense, may contribute further to the already prevalent impression that he was more involved in the Iran-contra matter than has been disclosed. If, moreover, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh - George Bush's appointee - blocks use of other classified documents Mr. Poindexter claims are essential to his defense, Judge Greene might have to dismiss the charges on grounds that the defendant cannot be accorded a fair trial. Mr. Thornburgh recently took that drastic step in another Iran-contra case, forcing Judge Greene to dismiss charges against Joseph F. Fernandez, a former C.I.A. official.
A forced dismissal of the important Poindexter case not only would leave Oliver North as a real Iran-contra scapegoat, the only high Reagan Administration official to be convicted of wrongdoing. Inevitably, it also would heighten the suspicion that President Bush, too, has so much to hide that he fears to put Mr. Poindexter on trial.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed
