The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 19, 1989

SECTION: Section A; Page 27, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 698 words

HEADLINE: The 'Peace Dividend': A Rubber Check

BYLINE: By Jim Sasser; Jim Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In what is being billed by the Administration as a victory for ''deficit reduction,'' the Pentagon is settling for a fiscal 1991 budget of $292 billion.
This nod toward fiscal responsibility follows Administration announcements that it is contemplating dramatic Pentagon reductions in response to the relaxation of world tensions: $180 billion in cuts over four years; cuts of up to 290,000 from the nation's 2.1 million troops; a cut of some 23,000 jobs from the 580,000-strong procurement bureacracy.
On the basis of those promised economies, we are seriously debating the question of what to do with the ''peace dividend.'' But how can we speak of a peace dividend with a military budget of $292 billion? The peace dividend, as currently constituted, is a rubber check. 
The $292 billion defense budget for fiscal 1991 actually represents an increase of some $5 billion from 1990. It would save only about $4.7 billion from current inflation-adjusted spending levels - a mere fraction of the $40 billion to $60 billion we'll need to hit next year's deficit target under Gramm-Rudman.
Worse still, the purported $180 billion ''cut'' actually takes, as its starting point, the Administration's ''wish list'' budget, which would have raised Pentagon spending by some $200 billion above a true freeze level between now and 1994.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has apparently concluded that even a $20 billion increase over the next five years is more austerity than the Pentagon can absorb. But it is clear that the Secretary's worst case scenario - the deepest ''cuts'' he's currently considering - would produce a ''peace dividend'' that is actually a $20 billion debit.
To put all of that as simply as possible, the Pentagon gets $287 billion in the budget just passed for fiscal 1990. Under the exercise in ''austerity'' proposed by the Secretary, the Pentagon would get more than $290 billion annually through the mid-90's.
The Secretary's proposal appears to have been driven wholly by the desire to offer some public acknowledgment that the world has indeed changed. But it is a grudging acknowledgment at best.
It assumes continuation of virtually all of the Pentagon's priorities and programs, and it eschews entirely a fundamental re-evaluation of our military establishment in light of our changing security needs. Such a reappraisal has to be the beginning point.
Fully half of our $287 billion military budget is devoted to defending Western Europe against the now remote threat of a Warsaw Pact invasion.
Earlier this month, the Pentagon acknowledged that its estimate of a two-week mobilization period for a full-scale Soviet invasion seriously overstated the threat: 33 to 44 days is a far more likely projection. That profoundly exaggerated threat assessment was inflating our defense budget long before the Iron Curtain began to rise and the potential for hostilities in Europe began to decline.
After we make adjustments for ''the common European home,' which now appears to be under construction, the entire frame of reference for America's defense expenditures changes radically.
If we add to all this the potential for completing treaties to slash strategic nuclear arms and conventional forces in Europe, we should be aiming for a military budget that returns to the post-Vietnam Nixon-Ford era average: somewhere in the range of $215 billion in constant 1990 dollars.
That is a legitimate target, once we cast a critical eye on all our military assumptions, from our entire force structure to the weapons systems now in the pipeline: from the $35 billion advanced tactical aircraft to the $45 billion advanced tactical fighter to the $70 billion B-2 bomber.
Our allies and our former adversaries have already begun to respond decisively. West Germany is talking about reducing its ground forces by 20 percent. Hungary has unofficially asked that Soviet troops be removed from within its borders, and Czechoslovakia seems to be following suit.
Those countries, and many others in both the East and the West, are poised to advance into a world in which the strength of nations will be measured in economic output. We should prepare to do the same.

HEADLINE: New York's Sinking Child-Care System Awaits Help

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY

 BODY:
With evidence mounting that New York City's child welfare system is overwhelmed, experts are increasingly suggesting radical changes, including the virtual dismantling of the system.
It could be rebuilt, they say, as a network of small, neighborhood centers at which parents could get help near their homes and abused and neglected children could go into foster care with local families.
The experts are also calling for a range of new services, policy changes and better management to deal with inefficiencies in the system. A lack of computers and the need for paperwork now use up as much as 60 percent of a caseworker's time.
Some suggestions are meant to keep children from needing foster care, others to improve a child's stay in foster care and still others to get better decisions about how long a child should stay in foster care. 
''There is no question that there is a new landscape out there and it's probably going to require changes in the whole continuum of law, policy and practice,'' said Philip Coltoff, the director of the Children's Aid Society, one of the city's largest private foster-care agencies.
In interviews, the experts - Family Court judges, advocates for children and officials working in the system - have made several specific proposals:
* Moving more quickly to free some children in foster care for adoption and finding new alternatives for others.
* Creating new therapeutic institutions and a cadre of highly trained foster parents who can care for children with special medical or emotional needs.
* Raising salaries and creating other career incentives to stem the high turnover rate among workers.
* Paying for a parent's housing with foster-care money, if that is what is needed to reunite a family.
* Making it a crime, punishable by jail, to give birth to a drug-addicted baby.
How much all this would cost is unclear. But most experts agree that while there may be considerable savings in the long run, initially it will be costly.
Major changes may be in the offing. Last summer, as Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins campaigned for office, he denounced the city's efforts as a failure and issued a report on the child welfare system calling for more community-based programs to prevent abuse.
Mr. Dinkins's report, written by a panel of 45 experts he appointed in 1988, called for family-service centers in each of the city's 32 community districts, rent subsidies for parents so children can leave foster care, and better training and pay for caseworkers, among other measures.
''We would expect the report would be used as a blueprint for change,'' said Donna Lawrence, a senior policy adviser to Mr. Dinkins, who has not yet said whom he will appoint to head the Human Resources Administration, the city's mammoth welfare agency that administers child welfare programs.
Even current H.R.A. officials support some of these ideas, or at least support studying them.
Brooke Trent, who heads the Child Welfare Administration in the H.R.A, declined to comment on her agency's shortcomings and any suggested solutions. But one high-ranking official who helps oversee child welfare said speedier adoptions, better salaries for caseworkers and more community-based services should all be considered. The official did not want to be identified because of uncertainty over the direction that the H.R.A. will take under Mr. Dinkins.
 
Rising Needs and Costs In an Ailing System
The number of children in foster care has been rising rapidly in the last four years. There are more than 44,000 children in New York's system, compared with about 16,500 in 1985.
Spending on the system has more than doubled in that time, rising to more than $1 billion this year and making it one of the most expensive systems in the nation, according to the Child Welfare League of America. The Federal Government pays for half the cost, the city and state 25 percent each.
Yet despite the cost, the care given to children has often been shabby, even dangerous. At times children have had to sleep on desktops in city offices. Hundreds have lived like nomads, bouncing from one overnight stay to another for weeks or months because no long-term foster homes were available. Toddlers have languished in overcrowded, unsanitary group homes, and handicapped children have been placed in dilapidated housing with inadequate supervision.
At the same time overburdened workers have been unable to do their jobs properly, resulting in sloppy investigations of abuse, failure to arrange adoptions and poor supervision of troubled families. In a case this year, a baby died after his mother left him all night in an overheated apartment while she went to visit a male companion. The city had been under a court order to watch the mother, but no one had visited her in more than eight months.
Across the country, child welfare systems are feeling many of the same strains as New York, struggling with growing caseloads and new problems brought on by crack addiction, homelessness and AIDS. Possible solutions vary widely because of the differing populations.
In New York City, the system is a huge and complex bureaucracy. It is largely made up of two components: the H.R.A.'s Child Welfare Administration, which investigates charges of abuse and neglect and also supervises and provides some foster homes, and more than 60 private nonprofit agencies that also provide homes and help troubled families.
 
Neighborhood Solutions Viewed as Promising
Some suggestions aim to improve the system across the board. One idea is that the city's child-welfare bureaucracy could be broken into more manageable pieces, organized not by task, but by neighborhoods.
Proponents of the idea see it as creating a more sensitive system in which people might know one another's names and better-informed workers could make sounder decisions about a child's future.
The idea has several variations, but one model of how it might work - often pointed to by experts - is an unusual organization in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn called the Center for Family Life and run by Sister Mary Paul.
Operating from a small brick building at 345 43d Street in the largely poor and Hispanic neighborhood, the center provides a host of traditional community-service programs, like counseling, after-school activities, parent groups and employment counseling. But in the last year and a half, the center has also gathered a cluster of local families to act as foster parents for neighborhood children, so the youngsters can usually keep going to the same school and see their friends and parents often.
This is in sharp contrast to what usually happens now. Most children in foster care are dispatched to distant parts of the city or suburbs, separated from brothers and sisters and virtually all that they know. Parents, who are striving to reunite their families, must travel great distances to see the children and often can do so only once a month at best.
Proponents say that keeping children in the neighborhood is not only better for them, but also makes it easier for the agency to supervise the foster homes and decide on the child's long-term needs.
Over time relationships are built up in the community. Teachers from the local schools call and give advice or can be called on. Workers learn what it means if a mother is seen out on a certain street corner. Neighbors speak up if a family seems in crisis.
And if the worker sees that a family could be reunited by parent participation in counseling or some other activity, this can often be done at the center.
''We've got to get away from this massive scattershot system with agencies responsible for children all over the city,'' said Barbara Blum, the head of the Foundation for Child Development, which has helped finance the Center for Family Life. ''Part of the reason the system is a mess is that things are being done in such volume.''
One drawback to this idea, noted by H.R.A. officials and others, is the possibility that some neighborhoods are so ravaged that good foster homes cannot be found.
 
A Preventive Approach Is Favored by Some
Apart from administrative reorganizing, many experts think far more could be done to buttress troubled families so that fewer children would need foster care.
This preventive approach, which some say would be economical in the long run, would emphasize more day care, recreational activities and prenatal care, as well as intensive services for families considered at high risk of becoming abusive.
But others say this route could be costly. Since there is no way to determine with certainty that a parent will become abusive, many of the services could go to the wrong families, critics say.
One program that many experts consider very successful is that conducted by Homebuilders, an organization that spends a great deal of time with a family for six to eight weeks. In about 80 percent of its cases, foster care is avoided.
Each ''homebuilder'' works with only two families at a time; other programs often assign 15 cases to a worker. On call 24 hours a day, the homebuilders usually spend about 20 hours a week in a household, diagnosing its problems and helping the family members get day care or other services they need. The workers also teach everything from housekeeping skills to methods for dealing with discipline.
 
A Need to Address Troubles and Drugs
While more community centers and support services for families might help, some experts say these changes alone would not address the problems of many children.
In the last few years the foster-care system has been taking in a growing number of children with acute medical problems and emotional and developmental difficulties. A greater percentage of the children are entering the system as babies, and many have parents so devastated by crack addiction or AIDS that they may never be able to provide homes for them.
There are not enough institutions or trained foster parents to care for these children. Many of the neediest children end up shuttling from home to home because foster parents quickly become overwhelmed by them.
''We have to start planning not only for the volume of kids, but for the kinds of beds we need,'' said Fred Brancato, head of the Council of Family and Child Caring Agencies, composed of the city's private foster-care agencies.
In addition, some experts say, the system needs to decide how to handle children of drug addicts. The city's child welfare laws seek the reunification of a family whenever possible. But because little is known about whether a mother who is heavily addicted to crack can be rehabilitated, is that the right approach? And how long should a child be made to wait for a mother to be rehabilititated?
''In many cases,'' said Andrew Stein, the City Council President, ''you need some much quicker decisions. Sure, the mother should have a chance, but long waits may not be fair to the kids.''
Many specialists favor the creation of more drug-treatment centers for mothers. But others also suggest that those who give birth to drug-addicted babies should face jail terms.
''I'm not sure it would work,'' said Judge Judith B. Sheindlin of Family Court, ''but I think it would send out a very strong message. And there would be some sanction, other than not having your child live with you, for this kind of behavior.''
Some H.R.A. officials, however, scoff at this idea, noting that drug-addicted mothers may be afraid to seek medical help for themselves or their children.
 
Housing Problems And Staff Turnover
Many children - 1,000 or more last year, according to surveys - go into foster care or stay there simply because their families lack housing. Many experts say rent subsidies or other housing aid should be used to send these children home.
New York's Chief Judge, Sol Wachtler, recently urged such a measure, saying that a Family Court judge ought to be allowed to order rent subsidies equal to a set percentage of the cost of keeping a child in foster care.
A rent subsidy of up to $300 a month is now available to families whose children remain in foster care solely because the parents have inadequate housing. But more than a year after the subsidy program was approved by the State Legislature, many advocates say this promising program has foundered because few people know about it, and those who do must contend with burdensome paperwork. So far just 33 families have received the aid.
Another problem throughout the system, many experts say, is an undertrained and inexperienced work force.
In the last few years, the city and the private foster-care agencies have had to hire thousands of workers because of both an increasing need and a huge turnover in personnel. In many parts of the system, more than half the workers quit each year.
Often this means that supervisors have barely a year or two of experience and troubled families must deal with a constant parade of new caseworkers. It also means that the system may be making many mistakes because the workers are unseasoned.
Suggestions for correcting this problem include increasing certain salaries and creating career incentives, like tuition aid, for those who stay in the field and want to pursue advanced studies.
To accomplish the vast changes that they say are necessary, many experts also see a need for a more powerful advocate for children's issues at City Hall - or perhaps completely outside City Hall. Some like the idea of a deputy mayor for children's issues or the creation of a child welfare agency separate from the H.R.A. Still others would have an independent agency headed by a board of governors, an arrangement that would help insulate it from administration politics.
''There's no single, simple solution,'' said Kathryn Conroy, the assistant general director of the Comunity ServSociety. ''There are all kinds of ingredients out there being talked about, and they don't necessarily make a nice, neat cake.''

HEADLINE: Man in the News;
A Chief Known for Turning Strife Into Calm; Lee Patrick Brown

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Lee P. Brown has made a career of taking over strife-torn police departments in racially troubled cities and bringing a relative sense of calm.
He does so with a personal style that is cool - some say cold - earning him the nicknames ''the Iceman'' and ''the Sphinx.''
He is a maestro of bureaucracy, believing that almost any problem can be solved with the right amount of organization and planning.
When he became Public Safety Commissioner in Atlanta in 1978, the Police Department was mired in a series of anti-discrimination suits and a scandal over cheating on promotional examinations. And when he became the Houston Police Chief in 1982, police officers were being charged with murdering prisoners and harassing black citizens. 
 
National Praise
But by the time he left Atlanta -and as he prepares to leave Houston - the police departments had received national praise and many begged him to stay.
Now he will see if his approach will work at the New York City Police Department. ''I take with me a process,'' he said today, referring to his management method. ''When I get there I will apply that process.''
His cerebral style is a reflection of the time he has spent in classrooms and managers' offices, rather than walking a beat. By the time he was interviewed to be Houston's police chief, his resume was 31 pages long.
Lee Patrick Brown, was born on Oct. 4, 1937, in Wewoka, Okla. He received a bachelor's degree in criminology from California State University at Fresno. After eight years as a patrolman in San Jose, he returned to school and earned a master's degree and a doctorate in criminology from the University of California at Berkeley and a master's degree in sociology from San Jose State University.
In 1968, he founded the Criminal Justice Program at Portland State University in Oregon, and in 1972 joined the faculty of Howard University in Washington as associate director of the Institute of Urban Affairs and Research.
Mr. Brown and his wife, Arlene, have two children.
His reputation as unruffled was reinforced in Atlanta, where, as Public Safety Commissioner, he was responsible for not only the Police and Fire Departments but also the Departments of Correctional Services, Emergency Management Services and Taxis and Limousines.
He promoted scores of minority officers and thereby resolved a series of anti-discrimination suits that had stalled the promotion process. He established what was to become his trademark - a neighborhood approach to law enforcement, with substations throughout the city.
Most notable, Chief Brown oversaw the two-year investigation into the murdering of 29 children in Atlanta, which ended shortly before he left the job in 1982 with the conviction of Wayne Williams.
Throughout the investigation he arrived at work at 6 A.M. and left at midnight, for which he received high praise. He also provided few details to the public and issued an order prohibiting police and fire officials from speaking about department activities. Critics said his close-to-the-chest style created mounting anxiety.
 
First Outsider in Job
The Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, said at the time: ''A few of us wanted him to kick over a chair, or use a few bad words, like a Kojak, and say he was going to get to the bottom of the case. But he kept his cool and did his job.''
When Chief Brown joined the Houston Police Department, he was the first outsider in that job in 40 years. The tradition of promoting from within ran so deep that his nomination was delayed until City Hall could debunk the generally accepted belief that it was against the law to appoint a police chief who had not served on the force.
He was also the first black police chief on a force whose black members accounted for 8 percent of the department, and his appointment was met by racial jokes from his officers. His first days brought a taste of the chaos typical of the department then. The week before he was hired, seven officers were dismissed and six were suspended for terrorizing and beating black residents at a local hotel.
Though he arrived to doubts, he has stayed to praise from most sectors of the community. He increased the percentage of black officers to 14.1 percent from 8.5 percent, and has dramatically improved the image of the Police Department.
He still faces some animosity from beat officers, however. The oil-bust economy of the last six years has meant virtually no salary increase for officers. With no money for new staff, the force is now 1,000 officers short of the number recommended by a recent internal report.
''He is not a savior,'' said Mark Clark, president of the Houston Police Officers Association. ''He is a successful black man with a number of degrees. He is more interested in posturing for his own benefit than thinking of the men and women who are out on the streets.''
Some of the harshest criticism he has faced in years has come while he was being considered for Police Commissioner in New York. The last two months have brought a spurt of unfavorable news involving Houston police officers.
 
Attributed to Bad Luck
In that time, two officers have shot and killed motorists after stops made for suspected traffic violations; two other officers were found guilty in rape cases; one officer was arrested for heroin possession; one was reassigned amid charges of police harassment, and two officers' houses were searched as part of a drug investigation.
This morning, Chief Brown described those events as ''abnormal'' and attributed them to bad luck, not bad management. For the most part, Houston leaders seem to agree.
''Even though some undesirable things have happened recently, there is no question Brown really turned around this department,'' said State Representative Al Edwards.
Mayor Kathryn J. Whitmire said: ''This will be a blow to the city. We would have liked to have him stay.''

Elayne; they have four children, not two.

HEADLINE: New System Warns of Volcano Dust, but a Plane Still Flies Into Trouble

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
A NEW satellite system to warn aircraft of dangerous plumes of volcanic dust got its first test last week, with dismal results.
Although the new system spotted dust from Redoubt Volcano in Alaska, and the Federal Aviation Administration issued warnings about it, a KLM Boeing 747 carrying 231 passengers and a crew of 14 flew through it Friday night. All four of its engines suddenly went dead, and the jet fell from 25,000 feet to 12,000 feet in eight minutes. The crew was finally able to restart the engines and the plane, traveling from Amsterdam to Tokyo, limped to a safe landing in Anchorage. 
This is just the kind of accident the system was designed to prevent.
It relies on an elaborate, worldwide system of satellite and human observers to spot plumes of volcanic ash, which are often invisible to radar. The program focuses on the heavily traveled international air routes near active volcanoes, like those in the Alaska-Aleutian chain. But after last week's alarming events, F.A.A. officials say it may take more than elaborate equipment to make the system effective.
The system was devised after several near catastrophes in which jet engines failed after ingesting and melting volcanic dust.
The F.A.A. used the new system soon after the first eruption of Redoubt Volcano on Thursday. So far, the agency has issued 14 bulletins about the volcanic cloud, its direction of movement and its expected path. Paul Steucke, a spokesman for the F.A.A. in Anchorage, said the agency knew of four airlines, Alaska, Markair, United and Delta, that had halted most operations into Anchorage as a result of the warnings.
But he added that it was up to individual airlines to decide what to do about the alerts. Mr. Steucke said the KLM airliner's captain had acknowledged receiving the dust alert, but it could not be learned what action, if any, the pilot took as a result.
''I don't know what more we could have done,'' said Nicholas P. Krull, who heads the F.A.A. effort. ''But if we find a way to improve the system, we'll do it.''
KLM Royal Dutch Airlines would make no comment on the incident, which is being investigated by the National Transportation Safety Board.
Such episodes worry not only civilian specialists but also American military planners, who fear dust from a nuclear war might cripple long-range bombers and airborne command posts. For several years, the military has investigated the nuclear dust threat, throwing dirt and debris into roaring engines in ground tests of wear and tear.
Pentagon critics say the military's jets are becoming increasingly vulnerable to such threats as nuclear dust, especially advanced models like the B-1 bomber and the B-2, or Stealth, bomber.
Awareness of the problem first arose after the 1980 eruption of Mount St. Helens in Washington. Its ash shut down several jet engines. In the worst episode, two of four engines on a military transport caught fire, forcing an emergency landing.
 
Malaysian Incidents Were Impetus
But it was back-to-back near tragedies on civil airliners that finally pushed the dust issue into prominence. On the night of June 23, 1982, a British Airways Boeing 747 carrying 240 passengers was flying from Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, to Perth, Australia. One by one, mysteriously, all its engines died. The plane fell an alarming four miles as cabin pressure was lost and oxygen masks dropped into the passenger cabin.
''We have a small problem,'' the captain said over the plane's public address system. ''All of our engines have stopped.''
Eventually, three of the jet's four engines were restarted in time to make an emergency landing at Jakarta. It was later found that the jet had encountered ash from Galunggung Volcano in western Java, some 100 miles away.
Three weeks later, a Singapore Airlines 747 jet with 230 passengers also ran into ash from Galunggung, falling a mile and a half with engines ablaze before leveling off in time for an emergency landing.
After the incidents, the International Civil Aviation Organization asked its members to study ways to prevent the problem, while engine makers, including Pratt & Whitney and Rolls Royce, carefully dissected stricken engines. Examination showed that the 1,800-degree heat in the combustion chamber had melted particles from Galunggung's ash cloud, building up a glassy coating on the relatively cool aft turbine that choked air flow and caused engines to flame out.
 
Avoiding Dust Was Difficult
Developing ways to avoid dust was far from easy, experts said. It turned out that radar on planes could not usually identify ash clouds, and that using meteorological observations to predict cloud movements was next to impossible.
After much research, the solution adopted by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the F.A.A. was to rely on satellite photographs of the Earth to try to track volcanic plumes. The service, which went into operation this year, primarily uses N.O.A.A.'s four weather satellites, two in a fixed orbit 22,300 miles above the Equator and two in lower orbits.
Mike Matson, who heads N.O.A.A.'s dust effort, stressed that the focus was on monitoring known eruptions, rather than looking for new ones.
''We cannot unambiguously distinguish ash clouds from meteorological clouds,'' he said. ''They both look white. The only way to distinguish is to have somebody tell us, 'Hey, there's a volcano happening,' and then go look at it. Within a half hour to an hour, we can say, 'Yeah, this is definitely a volcano,' and start to track it.''
To initially locate eruptions, the service relies on reports from American military bases, research stations operated around the world by the United States Geological Survey, and the worldwide Scientific Event Alert Network operated by the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.
 
Advisories Every 2 Hours
During an eruption, F.A.A. advisories on plume movement are made every two hours, providing pilots with forecasts of how high and far the dust cloud is expected to move over the next 4 and 12 hours.
Nicholas P. Krull of the F.A.A. said the new satellite system should help airline economics, as well as save lives.
''In October of last year, we closed down two of the most heavily traveled air routes between Japan and the U.S. because of a report of a volcanic dust cloud,'' Mr. Krull said. ''Flights were diverted or held overnight. The airlines had some rather unhappy passengers in Alaska that had planned on nonstop flights.''
''With more data,'' he noted, ''you could make informed judgments about the hazard and its location so we don't have to close down a large area of airspace if it's not necessary.''
He also noted the system's limitations. For instance, a volcanic cloud cannot be tracked at night, or if it is obscured by heavy rain clouds. The eruption of Redoubt Volcano in Alaska was the first test of the new system, and Mr. Krull said it worked fairly well given its limited abiliites.

PUB-DATE: December 19, 1989

HEADLINE: What's Under the Tree? Clues to a Relationship

BYLINE: By DANIEL GOLEMAN

 BODY:
WHAT'S in a gift? Telling clues to the relationship of the giver and receiver, social scientists say.
Gifts, of course, can be simple tokens of affection and caring. But the holiday gift list can also be read as a social and emotional inventory, researchers say. In the careful calculations that go into deciding just what to get for whom, people in effect summarize their relationships. There are clues about the interpersonal balance of power, as well as about what to expect in the near future from the relationship.
''There's an unstated rule in society that says you don't take unless you give in return,'' said Dr. Robert Cialdini, a social psychologist at Arizona State University. ''That leads to a strong sense of social obligation if you get much more than you give. With holiday gifts, for instance, people want to find that what they've given to people equates in value or thoughfulness to what they got.'' 
Dr. Cialdini points to a well-known study showing that something as minor as a Christmas card can provoke feelings of social obligation. For the 1976 study, Dr. Phillip Kunz, a sociologist at Brigham Young University, sent Christmas cards to 189 strangers.
When he sent a low-quality card, signed ''Mr. Kunz,'' 10 percent of the people sent him a return card. But when he sent a better card and changed the signature to ''Dr.'' Kunz, 37 percent responded.
''The sense of indebtedness induced in people by getting and not giving in return is an unpleasant tension, a sense that there is something wrong that needs to be made right,'' Dr. Cialdini said. ''It's that sinking feeling you get: 'Oh gee, they gave us a much bigger gift than we sent them.' ''
''It's tied to what we're taught as children, that people who take and don't give in return are moochers or ingrates,'' Dr. Cialdini added.
Social scientists use the term ''exchange theory'' to refer to the web of social obligations of which gift giving is a part. The theory, proposed in the 1950's by George Homans, a sociologist at Harvard University, holds that the rule that gifts must be reciprocated in some way reinforces essential social bonds and alliances. The theory allows that not all gifts need be returned in kind; a favor, for instance, can be given in return for a gift.
There have been just a handful of direct studies on gift giving since the seminal essay on the topic was written by the French sociologist Marcel Mauss in 1925. ''In theory, gifts are voluntary,'' he wrote. ''In fact, they are given and repaid under obligation. People who give desire something in return. People who receive want to give something in return. Both are involved in the quest for reciprocity.''
The relative size of gifts people give to each other implies a statement about who is more powerful in the relationship, social scientists say. Peers give gifts of approximately equal value, while those who are more powerful give a gift of far greater value than they are likely to receive.
The equation between the value of a gift and power is obvious, for example, in the gifts parents give their children. But research by anthropologists and sociologists shows this to be one of the universal symbolic meanings of gifts, whether between Trobiand Islanders or between a doorman and a building resident giving a holiday tip.
 
'Between Vassals and Chiefs'
''Between vassals and chiefs, between vassals and their henchmen, the hierarchy is established by means of gifts,'' Marcel Mauss wrote. ''To give is to show one's superiority, to show that one is something more and higher. To accept without returning is to face subordination, to become a client and subservient.''
In the most recent study on the topic, researchers asked people how satisfied they were with gifts they had received over the last year. One line of questioning involved gifts from people who were not close to the respondents, like business associates. The people who got back a gift of equivalent value to one they had sent said they were satisfied. But they were uncomfortable if they received either a gift of much less or much greater value than one they had given.
The research is by Dr. Margaret Clark, a psychologist at Carnegie-Mellon University, and Judson Mills, a psychologist at the University of Maryland. A report on it was published in the December issue of The Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin.
''The unhappiness for those who got more than they gave is because they now feel obligated; they owe the gift-giver something more,'' Dr. Cialdini said. ''Those who got back a gift of much less value were unhappy for another reason: they were miffed becasue the gift indicated they were undervalued.''
But within a family, different rules applied, the study found. People said they did not keep track of the size of gifts they were given by their family or close friends.
''In families, something else is involved in a gift exchange,'' Dr. Cialdini said. ''It's not the value that is most critical to people, but the fact of the gift itself. The gift states implicitly, 'You're someone I value, and I'll be there to give you what you need.' ''
The same effect in which gifts in the family are weighed differently than those to associates has been found in other cultures, including Sweden and Japan, in research conducted by Dr. Kenneth Gergen, a psychologist at Swarthmore College.
On the other hand, some social scientists point out that even within families, gifts are evaluated to some degree as a signal of what the relationship means to the giver. Part of the tension of holiday gift shopping comes from the recognition of this fact, which makes for a certain social risk in giving gifts, said Dr. David Cheal, a sociologist at the University of Winnipeg in Manitoba, Canada.
 
More Gifts for Women
On the basis of studies he has conducted in Canada, Dr. Cheal finds that most gifts from both women and men are for women. Also, women give more gifts. Dr. Cheal said the primary reason for this is that women traditionally take responsibility for maintaining family and social ties, and gifts are a major way to affirm such ties.
Another study indicated that gifts are a signal of a person's estimate of how important that relationship will be in the future. The study was conducted by Dr. Colin Camerer, a sociologist at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, and was published last year in The American Journal of Sociology. In his view, the investment in the gift symbolizes the future investments the person intends in that relationship.
Evidence supporting this theory comes from a study by Dr. Theodore Caplow, a sociologist at the University of Virginia. Dr. Caplow interviewed 110 men and women in Muncie, Ind., about the Christmas presents they had given. He found that when people did not give a gift to somene who had been on their list before, it meant that they expected the relationship to wane in importance or end over the coming year.
Some sociologists believe that the exchange theory even has an economic impact. They say that one reason that holiday spending has grown over the last two decades is that people increasingly rely on gifts to shore up family and friendship ties. As rising divorce rates and increased mobility have weakened social and family ties, gifts have taken on a new importance, these sociologists say.
But some social scientists say the tendency to give increasingly expensive gifts to counter flagging emotional ties has backfired, as people realize that gifts are no substitute for emotional closeness.
''Many people feel that gift-giving has gotten out of hand,'' said Ivan Karp, an anthropologist at the National Museum of Natural History of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington. ''They feel that measuring emotions by how much they spend is a false standard which, coupled with the customary obigation to give, leaves them feeling caught up in a system of gift-giving which is out of their control.''

HEADLINE: In Poland, a Small Capitalist Miracle

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOMASZOW MAZOWIECKI, Poland

 BODY:
This sooty industrial town, surrounded by potato patches and hog farms, might be the last place in the world one would expect to find a venture capitalist. But Jan Bednarek, a 51-year-old engineer who heads a state-owned synthetic fiber company here, has given life to 18 start-up companies by forcing his way through the narrow openings the Communist system has traditionally left for entrepreneurs.
In the dreary universe that is Poland's economy, Mr. Bednarek is one of the few stars, having used some profits from his antiquated textile factory as seed money to establish, just to mention a few, lighting-fixture and furniture-making companies, a trucking concern, and industrial ceramics and factory automation companies. 
 
A Key to the Future
As many Eastern European countries seek to divorce themselves from Communism, resourceful, far-sighted managers like Mr. Bednarak may well make the difference on whether and how fast their economies improve. In a part of the world desperately short of ventures and capital, Mr. Bednarek is showing how to combine an old company's earnings with some new imagination to build an investment engine that can help transform his nation's ailing economy. [Indeed, it is Mr. Bednarek's brand of entrepreneurial flair that the Solidarity-led Government is hoping to stimulate with a sweeping legislative program of economic reform, introduced on Sunday, that would trim the state budget deficit, cut off most subsidies to Government-owned businesses and free prices.] ''The Polish system has been eating up people who have tried to build something,'' Mr. Bednarek said, complaining about the straitjacket that centralized planning has placed on Poland's economy. ''We're trying to change that.''
While Mr. Bednarek's venture capital efforts might seem like small potatoes in Silicon Valley, they seem like a small miracle in Poland. Notwithstanding such obstacles as antagonistic Communist bureaucrats, 500 percent inflation and telephones that do not work, he has reshaped, almost singlehandedly, the economy of this town of 70,000 people, 60 miles southwest of Warsaw.
''You have to be crazy to try to do something like this in a traditional so-called Socialist economy,'' said Andrzej Kozminski, president of the International Business School in Warsaw. ''He is the pioneer of this, and now some other people are beginning to follow him.''
Wistom, a textile company of which Mr. Bednarek is general manager, places notices in newspapers, telling people that if they have an original idea they should get in touch with him and he might help them start a business. Instead of laying off people from his hugely overstaffed factory, he pushes them to pursue a good idea and start a business, aided by the start-up money he pledges to them.
 
'Creating Possibilities'
''If the idea is good, they can make a lot of money,'' he said. ''I am trying to give them independence. I am creating possibilities.''
His enterprising attitude is the opposite of that of most Eastern European managers, who when told by central planners to make bolts, spend their lives making bolts, without ever daring to make nuts, not to mention furniture or ceramics.
Mr. Bednarek, in a blue pinstripe suit, and with a thick mustache and bushy red-brown eyebrows, looks like a Scottish businessman. But he does not have billions, or even millions, of dollars to spread around. In a nation where the average weekly wage is $15 at current exchange rates, he sprinkles $10,000 here, $50,000 there, and that is enough to get a good-sized company off the ground.
This fall he underwrote a company that makes lighting fixtures. Eager to reduce Wistom's bloated work force, Mr. Bednarek suggested to Leszek Jozefowski, a 26-year-old assistant manager, that he set up a company to design and produce improved lighting fixtures for the grim, poorly lit Wistom factory. Mr. Bednarek urged him to take several dozen employees with him.
 
'It's Not Easy'
''When we really get going, we hope that just 10 percent of our sales will be to Wistom,'' Mr. Jozefowski said. ''It's not easy to start a company it Poland. It helps to have the support of the general manager.''
Mr. Bednarek's most successful start-up may be a company specializing in factory automation and industrial processing equipment. The year-old concern has 125 employees, half of them from Wistom. Half of its orders come from outside Wistom as it helps companies throughout Poland upgrade their plants.
Wieslaw Pawlowski, a 29-year-old Bednarek assistant who heads that company, said it was easier to win the boss's backing than that of Wistom's workers. ''It was hard to persuade workers to try this with us and join a new company that did not assure them all the security and conveniences of a big company,'' Mr. Pawlowski said.
He said those workers who left Wistom were now happy they took the risk, since the new company was thriving and they could often earn 50 percent more than their pay at Wistom. Mr. Bednarek complained that he could not raise Wistom's wages as much as he would like because of Government-imposed wage controls.
 
A Polluting Factory
In his unpretentious office in Wistom's aging headquarters, Mr. Bednarek is quick to outline his vision. He wants to transform his company from a colorless caterpillar into a brilliant butterfly.
Wistom's main factory dates from 1911, when the company was founded. The smokestacks that dominate the town foul the sky as Wistom churns out 120 tons a day of cellulosic fiber used in suit linings.
''This might be the oldest synthetic fiber plant still in use,'' said Douglas Kay, a retired American chemistry industry official working as a volunteer consultant for Wistom.
Mr. Bednarek looks to the day when he has created so many start-ups that he can shut his polluting factory without the area suffering a drop in profits or employment. Wistom, one of Poland's largest companies, earned $13.5 million on sales of $50 million last year.
''We want to change from a company that is hurting the environment, to one that is not harmful,'' he said.
His proudest possession is a blueprint of a glass-sheathed ''high-technology center,'' to be built on pillars. He dreams of building it next to the factory.
 
Hour-Long Coffee Breaks
But there is more to his vision. Mr. Bednarek also wants to create an efficient company - and nation. Wistom has 5,000 employees, but he says it needs only 2,000. A stroll through the factory finds workers taking hour-long coffee breaks and others chatting idly behind doors next to the rusting jumble of machinery.
''It's an apple tree with too many branches and not enough fruit,'' he said about his company. ''Too much strength goes to the branches, and not enough to the fruit.'' He wants to prune the unnecessary branches. ''In the United States, these people would simply be dismissed, but I prefer a more humane approach.''
Thus he strains to place them in start-up companies, which now employ almost 500 people.
''Most other managers don't want to take risks,'' said Mr. Pawlowski, who heads the factory automation venture. ''They worry that if they make a mistake they'll be removed by the Government or by worker pressure.''
 
Early Profits
Mr. Bednarek discounts complaints about the new ventures, saying Wistom is making a solid return on its investment in them. In the factory automation venture, Wistom invested about $30,000 and gained majority control. Employees hold one-fourth of the shares.
Mr. Pawlowski said his company, housed in an unused wing of the fiber factory, already had $70,000 in monthly revenues and more than $20,000 a month in profits. He said he was eager for the factory automation employees to buy out most of Wistom's stake in the company.
In another project, Wistom is working with professors at Poland's Academy of Sciences to establish a company that will make superhard ceramics to be used in turbines, engines and military tanks. Wistom will own 30 percent, the professors 40 percent, and employees most of the rest, Mr. Bednarek said.
''Mr. Bednarek is the godfather of everything,'' Mr. Pawlowski said. Through force of will and by using one of the few sources of capital in Poland - the profits of a state-owned company - he has turned this town into a diversified industrial showcase for Poland.
 
Difficult Conditions
Mr. Bednarek has worked his successes in conditions that might drive Western executives into early retirement. The phone system is so bad that on many days it is impossible to reach Warsaw. Raw materials are often obtained only through a bureacratic struggle. ''We don't buy raw materials,'' he said. ''We conquer them.'' And his annual salary is $3,000 at the official exchange rate.

GRAPHIC: Jan Bednarek, shown in the fiber spinning room of the state-owned synthetic fiber company he heads, has taken advantage of loopholes in Poland's Communist system to give life to 18 start-up companies. The 51-year-old venture capitalist is one of the few stars in the Polish economy. (NYT/Aleksander Wiechowski)

HEADLINE: Community And Soviets In First Pact

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The Soviet Union and the European Community today signed a commercial accord that calls for ending most European Community quotas on Soviet products.
The 10-year agreement also provides for cooperation in numerous areas, including food processing, tourism, banking, insurance, oil and gas, and nuclear energy. At the signing ceremony here, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union, said the agreement ''brings the construction of the economic foundation for a common European house one step higher.''
He said the accord should be viewed as a first step toward closer economic and political relations between Moscow and the community. 
 
'Support for the Soviet Policy'
Frans Andriessen, a vice president of the European Commission and its Minister for External Relations, commented, ''The agreement is a clear demonstration of the community's support for the Soviet policy of economic reforms and greater openness to the world economy.''
He said one of the community's aims in signing the accord was to help achieve ''far-reaching market-oriented economic reform in the U.S.S.R.''
The trade pact comes after the community signed similar but less wide-ranging accords with Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland. Community officials say they are negotiating with East Germany and Bulgaria.
 
Two-Day Good-Will Tour
Mr. Shevardnadze signed the agreement during a two-day good-will tour of Brussels, where he met King Baudouin, Prime Minister Wilfried Martens and Jacques Delors, president of the European Commission, the community's executive branch. He dined tonight with the Foreign Ministers of the 12 community nations.
On Tuesday, Mr. Shevardnadze is scheduled to meet with the Secretary General of NATO, Manfred Worner of West Germany, in what will be the first visit to NATO headquarters by a Warsaw Pact minister.
Mr. Shevardnadze's overtures to the European Community come a few days after Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d called for greater cooperation between Washington and the community to strengthen American relations with Western Europe.
At a half-hour news conference today, Mr. Shevardnadze did not comment upon Mr. Baker's ideas. But several European officials said they expected Mr. Baker's proposals to be discussed at the dinner with the Soviet Foreign Minister.
European Community officials seemed as excited by today's agreement as Mr. Shevardnadze.
''This agreement opens up the future hope for improvement in economic and political relations,'' said Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France. Since France holds the community's six-month rotating presidency, Mr. Dumas is acting as one of the community's top foreign-relations officials.
 
Cocom Is Criticized
But Mr. Shevardnadze, in urging closer economic ties with Western Europe, repeatedly criticized the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, or Cocom, the organization that has long set policies restricting exports of high-technology goods to the Soviet bloc.
''Cocom's position has to be softened,'' he said. ''That's only a first step. I think I would liquidate it if I could.''
His criticism of Cocom comes at a time when many European officials, most recently Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, have called for liberalizing Cocom rules. On Saturday, Bush Administration officials said the export agency was close to a significant relaxation of rules on high-technology sales to the Eastern bloc.
Under the agreement signed today, the European Community will remove quotas on Soviet manufactured products in three stages by 1995. But restrictions will remain on Soviet farm goods because the community produces a surplus.
The agreement calls for allowing European corporations to negotiate contracts directly with Soviet business leaders. In the accord, Moscow, seeking to reassure investors, agreed to guarantee that Western companies be allowed to send their profits and dividends back home.
Mr. Shevardnadze said the pact ''has an imporant political and, I would say, conceptual aspect, being a large-scale European blueprint for the future.'' For him, that blueprint is the ''gradual formation of an integral economic complex on our continent,'' which he said was a long-term goal.

HEADLINE: Study on Trade Fails To Reach a Consensus

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
So divisive have trade issues become that a group of eminences assembled by the Twentieth Century Fund was unable to develop a consensus about how the United States should proceed.
As a result, the group published two separate reports instead of the consensus document it had hoped for when the late Murray J. Rossant had the idea for the study group two years ago.
The division is between those who favor free trade and those who opt for so-called managed trade, in which the Government would play a bigger role in trying to cut the trade deficit and shape industrial policy.
The split reflects divisions within the Bush Administration. In February the Advisory Committee for Trade Policy Negotiations, a business group advising the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, recommended a ''results-oriented'' trade strategy to cope with Japanese barriers. 
It called on the Administration to pick industrial sectors where American exports - based on their performance in other foreign markets -should have a bigger market share in Japan, and then undertake negotiations to achieve those shares.
The Twentieth Century Fund held a Washington news conference today to issue the two reports, which were published in a single 232-page volume called The Free Trade Debate.
 
'It's a Disappointment'
It was the first time in the history of the fund that its luminaries, normally drawn from academia, government, business and labor, have been so torn they could not reach consensus, said Beverly Goldberg, director of publications.
''It's a disappointment, but it reflects the deep divisons in the country,'' said Richard C. Leone, director of the New York-based organization. ''I think it's good for people to understand how difficult these issues are.''
Herbert Stein, one of the study group's members, commented: ''We could have agreed had we produced a wishy-washy document, but no one wanted to do that. ''Let's face it; there have been disagreements on this subject for 200 years.''
The organization is one of the oldest research centers, founded in 1919 by the department store owner, Edward A. Filene, to analyze economic, political and social policy issues. It publishes more than 20 volumes a year.
 
A Participant Is Chided
The arguments between the free traders and those contending that a new policy approach is needed, chiefly because of huge American trade imbalances, carried into the news conference itself.
Mr. Leone had invited some members of the study group to attend the conference and respond to reporters' questions. Discussions became so heated that Mr. Leone at one point gently chided one expert, Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., formerly of the Commerce Department and now a senior associate at another research center, the Carnegie Endowment, for hogging the microphone.
Both Mr. Stein, former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers and now a senior fellow at still another study center, the American Enterprise Institute, and Gary Clyde Hufbauer, professor at the School of Foreign Service at Georgetown University, both of the free trade faction, interrupted with some passion at other points.
In one intervention, during a long response by Mr. Prestowitz on failures of free trade, Mr. Stein, his face growing red with pique, snapped: ''Efforts of managed trade have been very costly to the consumer.''
He was apparently referring to so-called voluntary restraints in automobile trade and import quotas in sugar and textiles, among other products, that have raised domestic price levels.
 
Stein Sees an Irony
The study group of 11 members was led by Anne Krueger, professor of economics at Duke University and consultant to the World Bank. Of the 11, 6 favored free trade and 5 managed trade.
Speaking for the free traders, Mr. Stein said it had worked for 40 years to provide unparalleled prosperity in the world. He said it would be ironic now that Eastern European countries had chosen free-market domestic policies to have them participate in controlled international trade.
Mr. Prestowitz, leading the managed trade forces, said free trade orthodoxy was at odds with conditions in the real world, where markets are not open and where laissez-faire policies enable countries like Japan to pick off one American high-technology industry after the other.
''This side is not seeking protection, but we care about the composition of the U.S. economy,'' added Alan W. Wolff, former deputy United States trade representative who was allied with Mr. Prestowitz.
While some officials in the Commerce Department are sympathetic with this approach, Mrs. Hills and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, oppose any greater Government intervention in trade policy.
A copy of the trade study report can be obtained for $8.95 from the Twentieth Century Fund, 41 East 70th Street, New York City, N.Y. 10021.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Rise in Slow Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher in thin trading yesterday, aided by a sharp selloff in the stock market.
''Before stocks started to slide, we were doing absolutely nothing,'' one government bond trader said. ''But by and large we are closed for the year, whether the Fed eases policy or not.''
The slide in the stock market came as members of the Federal Reserve Board's policy-making Open Market Committee began two days of meetings in Washington. Some bond market participants said the two events were related. 
 
'Brink of Recession'
''This seems a pretty clear equity protest going into the F.O.M.C. meeting,'' said Victor Chang, president the of VC Management Company. ''Economic developments over the past few weeks have shown that the economy has moved to the brink of recession. This is one point in time when the stock market is saying that if you stay tight for too long you will have to pay for it.''
Although most analysts seem convinced that recent economic reports will once again lead the Fed to lower the overnight Federal funds rate by at least one-quarter of a percentage point, to 8.25 percent, the Fed gave no indication that any change would be forthcoming.
The central bank refrained from conducting open market operations, and the funds rate traded in a narrow range of 8 1/2 to 8 9/16 percent.
''I think the Fed will vote to ease policy at this meeting,'' said Michael J. Moran, chief economist at Daiwa Securities America Inc. ''The only question is when they will implement it. It could be they will wait until next week before they signal that they have eased.''
A delay beyond 1 P.M. today would probably come as a disappointment to traders, who will be placing bids on $10 billion worth of two-year notes this afternoon. 2-Year Notes at 7.64% The notes were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 7.64 percent. The four-year Treasury notes, which will be sold tomorrow, were offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 7.67 percent.
As it does every week, the Treasury auctioned three- and six-month bills yesterday. The three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.62 percent, up slightly from 7.60 percent rate a week ago. Six-month bills were sold at an average rate of 7.43 percent, up from 7.41 percent at last week's auction.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered late yesterday at a price of 103 10/32, up 6/32, to yield 7.83 percent.
Among note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 3/4, up 5/32, to yield 7.76 percent. And the 7 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 10/32, up 1/8, to yield 7.66 percent.
 
'Junk Bonds' Under Pressure
In other developments, prices of high-yield ''junk bond'' issues were under some pressure yesterday, dealers said.
Prices of a number of issues declined by about half a point, and bids on securities issued by troubled retailing companies fell by about a point. But trading was very sparse.
''It's a very thin market, and unless there is an accident I expect it will stay that way through the end of the year, '' said Kate Montgomery, head of the high-yield research department at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, Merrill Lynch Capital Markets acted as lead manager on a negotiated $255 million offering of water and electric bonds from the Orlando, Fla., Utilities Commission.
The issue consists of three term bonds. The largest, $112 million worth of bonds due in 2017, was priced to yield 6.85 percent.
The other term bonds mature in 2020 and 2023. Those bonds were priced to yield 6.92 percent and 6.90 percent, respectively The issue is rated AA by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, dealers said that prices of most issues rose by about an eighth of a point in light trading.
In the secondary municipal bond market, participants said that prices of most issues rose by an eighth to a quarter of a point.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed and Gold Dips; Lower Rates Are Foreseen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mixed yesterday against primary foreign currencies in quiet, directionless trading. Gold prices declined.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $411.80 an ounce, down $2.10 from Friday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $412.75 an ounce, off $1.75.
Currency dealers said market activity was light since many traders have started to close out their books for the calendar year.
But Earl I. Johnson, a trader with Harris Trust and Company in Chicago, said, ''The dollar is vulnerable on the downside,'' as evidence of a weaker economy continues to appear.
Some of the traders have turned their attention toward the Federal Reserve's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee, which began meeting yesterday for two days.
Economists maintain that the Fed is likely to decide to push interest rates lower because of softening economic growth, thereby lowering the value of the dollar.
''Interest rates should head down, while West German rates are firm,'' Mr. Johnson said. ''That's a prescription for a weaker dollar.''
In New York, the dollar ended at 143.725 yen, down from 144.15 yen on Friday. The pound rose to $1.60685 in New York, from $1.6030.
Other late-dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday, included: 1.7210 West German marks, up from 1.7190; 1.5410 Swiss francs, down from 1.5480; 5.8800 French francs, up from 5.8785; 1,285.00 Italian lire, up from 1,283.50, and 1.16075 Canadian dollars, unchanged.
Silver prices also declined. On the Comex in New York, silver for current delivery closed at $5.565 an ounce, down from $5.607 Friday. Silver fell in London to $5.55 an ounce, from $5.62.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Job Help For Laid-Off Employees

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
THANKS to downsizings and mergers, the outplacement industry is growing fast.
For a fee of about 20 percent of a dismissed person's annual salary, paid by his or her company, outplacement firms help the job seeker. Services usually include counseling to alleviate the trauma of losing a job and help in writing resumes. Office space and a telephone are also provided. 
Outplacement services, which used to be given mainly to top managers, are now offered to lower-level managers and, often on a group basis, to clerical and other workers.
The Association of Outplacement Consulting Firms said its members generated more than $350 million in revenues in 1989. The association's president, Louis LeHane, president of LeHane Consultants Inc. of Leesburg, Va., thinks revenues increased about 15 percent in 1989 and he expects a similar gain in 1990, more if there is a recession.
The firms are expanding nationally, as evidenced by the merger of J. J. Gallagher Associates of New York and King Chapman Broussard, a Texas-based firm, to form King Chapman Broussard & Gallagher Inc.
Mr. LeHane says well-established firms are also opening offices in smaller cities, where they compete with local firms. ''It means that the local firm must find a niche because it will be harder to stay alive with the competition,'' he said. ''Fees will tend to flatten.''
The niche might involve special services. Instead of idled employees receiving only a cubicle, they might get an office. ''Financial consulting might be offered as part of an outplacement package,'' Mr. LeHane said.
Outplacement has expanded abroad. The association, which began in 1982 with 13 firms, none of them foreign, and 115 consultants, now has 55 firms, including a total of 11 in Japan, Canada and in Europe, and more than 2,000 consultants.
The largest outplacement firm, Drake Beam Morin Inc., has 21 offices in 13 nations in Europe. Recently, James C. Cabrera, its president, said the firm's European business more than doubled in the last year, partly because of a growing number of mergers.
In 1983, he said, there were only 117 sizable mergers in Western Europe - a figure that rose to 450 in 1988, and probably increased again this year.
The industry has also been reaching into new areas. For example, Right Associates was hired to help top-level New York officials. Mayor Edward I. Koch found money to provide job guidance for 80 New York City commissioners and deputy commissioners, many of them long-term job holders. Right Associates said that in its 11-year history it had never ''provided assistance to members of a public administration.''
Frank P. Louchheim, Right's chairman, spoke last week of a new development - the organization of an outplacement group with individuals as members, aimed at increasing professionalism. So far members include officers of the Chemical Bank Corporation and Citicorp banks who handle outplacement within their organizations; some professors interested in the field, and a few consultants who work for association member firms.
''The association contributed $1,000 and we collected another wad of money at a recent meeting to seed the idea,'' Mr. Louchheim said, adding that the ''the group does not have a name yet.''
There has been a growing need for quality, ethical job advice for middle managers whose companies do not provide outplacement. Unfortunately, some so-called consulting companies that handle that type of ''retail'' business, for which individuals pay, have not offered much service in relation to the large fees charged. Several were forced out of business by state attorneys general.
With competition threatening profits in some cases, outplacement firms have become more creative to keep market share. For example, Lee Hecht Harrison Inc., a large firm that has expanded recently, sends out quarterly lists describing the talents and experience of its job candidates. The list goes to companies and others that might be hiring.
Pro bono advice has become another marketing tool. Chicago-based James Challenger of Challenger, Gray & Christmas Inc. said last week that for the fourth year he will hold his annual career advice by telephone for anyone calling his Chicago office on Dec. 28 between 9 A.M. and 5 P.M., central standard time. Last year 2,500 calls were received, necessitating a second day.
The association offered a two-day hot line in the fall during which outplacement experts answered questions from almost 10,000 people. In January and June, Right Associates holds all-day meetings for college students to teach skills on obtaining a job.

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WAIVES SOME CHINA CURBS

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
President Bush waived a Congressional ban today on loans to companies that do business with China and also approved the export of three communications satellites that will be launched by the Chinese.
The ban on loans was imposed in a law passed in November as part of Congress's reaction to the Chinese Government's bloody nationwide crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators. Export of the satellites and equipment that could be used for military purposes was blocked by sanctions ordered by Mr. Bush himself in June, immediately after the crackdown.
The decisions, which the White House said were ''in the national interest,'' came as Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was forced into an embarrassing admission that he ''may have misled'' the public about how many secret missions Mr. Bush had sent to Beijing. 
On Dec. 10, a day after the White House announced that two top officials had gone to Beijing this month in hopes of improving relations with China, Mr. Baker said in an ABC television interview that the trip had been the first by high-level officials to Beijing since Mr. Bush banned such contacts in the aftermath of the Chinese crackdown.
Mr. Baker never mentioned what the White House acknowledged on Monday - that Brent Scowcroft, the White House national security adviser, and Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the Deputy Secretary of State, had been in China in July, only weeks after the crushing of political dissent and the announcement of Mr. Bush's ban on high-level meetings.
Two of the three satellites affected by Mr. Bush's order today are being built by Hughes Aircraft for Aussat, an Australian concern that intends to launch them on the Chinese Long March rocket. The other satellite, which would be the first actually put into space, is a refurbished Westar satellite that will be used by Asiasat, a British-Chinese concern based in Hong Kong.
Export licenses for the satellites were suspended when Mr. Bush ordered a halt to the sale of all military equipment to China. The satellites are not for military use, but some of their components, and the devices themselves, were included on the list of proscribed items.
Today, Mr. Bush notified Congress that he was exempting the three satellites from the sanctions.
Noting that the satellites were worth $300 million in business for American firms, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said the move was ''consistent with the President's expressed determination, in imposing sanctions last June, to maintain commercial relations with China.''
 
Rationale for Decision
In a two-page memo explaining the decision, the White House said the satellites ''will be controlled for civil use'' after they are launched.
''It is in the national interest of the United States to approve export licenses,'' the statement said.
The same reasoning was given today for Mr. Bush's decision to waive Congressionally imposed restrictions on the Export-Import Bank's power to grant loans to American companies that do business in China. The waiver ''preserves a level playing field for U.S. business,'' the White House said. ''Additional business activity with China will be considered on a case-by-case basis as part of a continuing review process.''
 
A Protest From Gore
Mr. Bush's decision on the satellites drew immediate criticism from Senator Albert Gore Jr., the Tennessee Democrat who sponsored a law that requires special licenses for the launching of American-made satellites on Chinese rockets.
''The statement that this is in the national interest simply does not hold water,'' Mr. Gore said in an interview. ''He's doing this as a favor to the hard-liners in Beijing. This is a fresh insult to the memory of those who died for democracy in Tiananmen Square.''
Mr. Baker's admission entangled him in the debate over the wisdom of Mr. Bush's attempts at personal diplomacy with the Chinese, something that Mr. Baker appeared to have been avoiding with careful public statements that expressed his support for the President's decisions but repeatedly made it clear that the China overture was ''the President's policy.''
State Department officials said today that Mr. Baker knew about the first trip, but chose not to disclose it during the television interview.
Margaret D. Tutwiler, Mr. Baker's spokeswoman, said the Secretary ''regrets that he may have misled some.'' She said Mr. Baker felt that ''by acknowledging his own direct involvement, it was sufficient to make the point that this was not the first case of high-level contact.''
Mr. Baker had said Dec. 10 on the ABC news program ''This Week'' that he had met with the Chinese Foreign Minister in Paris and at the United Nations in meetings that were widely known.
Miss Tutwiler said the Secretary had not intentionally lied. She defended Mr. Baker's actions by saying he felt obligated to withhold his knowledge of the earlier trip out of his friendship to Mr. Bush and a feeling that as Secretary of State he could not disclose a classified Presidential mission.
''Secretary Baker does not feel that he lied,'' she said. ''He certainly understands, as we stated, that his statement could have misled some.''
 
A Select Group
State Department officials said Mr. Baker was one of four people, including the President and his two emissaries, who were aware of two trips that were conceived and directed by the tighest possible group of aides, leaving out not only Congress and the State Department bureaucracy but most of Mr. Bush's own White House staff.
The White House disclosed the first trip, which was made in July, on Monday after a report about it on Cable News Network. That began a new round of criticism from some lawmakers and foreign policy analysts. In a sign of some opposition within the Administration itself, officials said today that Mr. Bush had authorized the trips to Beijing even though his Ambassador there, Joseph Lilly, was pessimistic about the possibility of a quick improvement in either China's human rights policies or in the Chinese-American relationship.
Although there was some criticism of the first trip to China by Mr. Eagleburger and Mr. Scowcroft, Mr. Bush won some praise for trying to keep alive a relationship that many experts view as critical to the United States.
But the White House's acknowledgment on Monday that the two officials had also visited Beijing in July prompted more widespread criticism.
Even Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State, who was strongly supportive of the December trip, was at a loss today to explain why Mr. Bush had sent his secret emissaries to China in July, so soon after the violence in Tiananmen Square and the President's own ban on high-level meetings with Chinese officials.
''I support the objectives of the second trip and I agree with the general analysis of the President on relations with China,'' Mr. Kissinger said. ''But on the first trip, I have neither the knowledge to know what they were trying to do, nor even a theory to explain it.''
