HEADLINE: Israel-Iran Oil Deal Disclosed and Tied to Captives

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Israel informed the United States a month ago that it had concluded a deal with Iran for the purchase of Iranian oil, the State Department said today.
NBC News disclosed the transaction Monday night, saying that Israel had paid Iran $36 million for the oil and that one purpose of the deal was to encourage Iran to use its influence to help free three Israeli soldiers being held in Lebanon.
Although Iran's leaders are avowedly anti-Israel, the deal would give the country's struggling economy badly needed foreign currency.
NBC said that in addition to winning Iran's help in seeking the release of Israelis, the oil purchases and a potential spare parts deal are intended to bolster Iran's position against a common enemy, Iraq. 
The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said the United States was notified of the deal after it was concluded. She would not say whether Washington approved of the Israeli action.
''Foreign countries do not seek U.S. approval for oil purchases from a third country,'' she said.
 
American Hostage Issue Raised
Asked whether Israel might negotiate with Iran on behalf of American hostages being held in Lebanon, Miss Tutwiler said that the question should be directed to Israel, adding that the United States will not make deals for hostages or reward terrorists.
The United States is backing the deal in hopes that it could lead to the release of American hostages held in Lebanon, NBC said.
NBC, citing American and Israeli intelligence officials, said Israeli representatives have discussed the possibility of selling Iran spare parts for its Western-made military hardware.
Spokesmen for Israel's Energy, Foreign and Defense Ministries today refused to comment on the report. The Defense Ministry also refused to allow reporters to talk to Uri Lubrani, mentioned in the NBC report as the man who dealt with the Iranians in Switzerland.
Mr. Lubrani is responsible for Israel's Lebanon policy and served as Ambassador to Iran before the revolution that swept Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini to power.
 
Israeli Rationale Offered
The shipment of two million barrels was delivered in November, NBC said.
With a world oil glut, Israel has no problem buying enough oil to meet its 170,000-barrel-a-day requirement.
Joseph Alpher of Tel Aviv University's Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies said Israel had other considerations that could justify ties with Iran, apart from seeking the release of its prisoners.
''Iraq is getting stronger every day by acquiring chemical and nonconventional arms that threaten us,'' Mr. Alpher said on Israeli television. ''There is a reason to see to it that Iran can continue confronting and diversing the Iraqi forces.''
''Beyond that,'' he said, ''Iran has oil, Iran has Jews and all these are good reasons for renewal of connections with Iran, without any relation to the governing regime.''
The two nations have dealt secretly with each other in the past. In 1985 and 1986 during the Iran-contra affair, Israel provided some of the American-made missiles shipped to Iran in hopes of freeing American hostages in Lebanon. Israel also provided Iran with spare military parts during the Iran-Iraq war.
Over the weekend, Israeli officials said the Iranian Government had custody of at least one Israeli captive, Capt. Ron Arad, a navigator whose F-4 Phantom fighter jet went down in south Lebanon in October 1986; Israel called on Iran to free Captain Arad, whose whereabouts are unknown.
 
Israelis Disavow Knowledge
JERUSALEM, Dec. 19 (Special to The New York Times) - The Ministry of Energy said today that it had no knowledge of a purchase of Iranian oil by the Israeli Government.
Speaking after Washington said Israel had reported the deal last month, the Energy Ministry spokesman, Eliahu Ben-On, said his office ''does not need to relate to'' the State Department announcement.
''We buy 60 to 70 percent of our annual oil needs from Egypt, Mexico and Norway according to longstanding contracts,'' he said. ''The rest is purchased on the seasonal spot market, and where it comes from we don't know.''
Defense Ministry officials refused to comment on the NBC assertion that the oil deal was to be used as leverage to free captives in Lebanon.

HEADLINE: U.S. Delegate Calls U.N.'s Session 'Constructive'

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 19

 BODY:
As the 44th United Nations General Assembly moves toward a close, the American representative, Thomas R. Pickering, described the session today as ''one of the most constructive and realistic within memory'' and said it had promoted a ''nondogmatic approach'' to world problems.
At a news conference called to give the United States view, Mr. Pickering described the Bush Administration as ''pleased not only with the accomplishments of the 44th session'' but also with ''the positive signals'' it has sent about prospects for resolving world conflicts, jointly addressing problems no country can solve alone and carrying out agreed United Nations changes.
Mr. Pickering's assessment was broadly similar to that offered last week by Deputy Foreign Minister Vladimir F. Petrovsky of the Soviet Union, who said the Assembly has ''moved beyond ideology'' into ''the post-confrontational world.'' Earlier this week, Maj. Gen. Joseph N. Garba of Nigeria, the General Assembly's President, said ''a new constructive and cooperative spirit'' is abroad in the world. 
All three attributed the Assembly's positive tone this year to reduced superpower tension, a recognition that many problems require cooperative solutions and the Soviet Union's new interest in the United Nations.
 
On Drug Trafficking
Summarizing what he called the session's more positive achievements, Mr. Pickering mentioned record support for Israel's membership as well as record or unanimous support for resolutions barring the Khmer Rouge from sole power in Cambodia and calling for peace in Afghanistan.
He also listed the unanimous agreement on an action program against drug trafficking, the agreed ban on drift net fishing, a declaration of guiding principles for South Africa's shift away from apartheid and the likelihood that a consensus will be reached before the Assembly ends Friday on steps to protect the world from climate change On what he referred to as the negative side, Mr. Pickering listed the ''unbalanced'' resolutions adopted on the Middle East, the Arabs' attempt to get the Palestine Liberation Organization recognized as the government of a proclaimed Palestinian state and a third-world campaign to weaken human rights enforcement by increasing the size of the Human Rights Commission.
Most delegates agreed that this 44th General Assembly was a turning point in United Nations history, with a sharp decline in ideological confrontation and a new search to unanimity on critical global questions. Nevertheless, many called the American assesment optimistic and said it ignored dangers of America's own making now facing the organization.
 
British Effort Blocked
A common observation, glossed over in the American assessment, is that better superpower relations have coincided with an upsurge in North-South tension in the world.
At this year's Assembly, developing countries blocked a British-led effort at reorganizing the United Nations economic and social agencies. Under Chinese leadership they called for the world organization to stop criticizing governments for human rights abuses, saying this constitutes interference in internal affairs. They also fought aggressively to secure economic concessions in return for cooperating on environmental and other issues.
Such resurgent North-South tensions have aroused fears that the industrialized powers might eventually tire of trying to win third world backing for environmental and other projects they favor and press ahead alone outside the United Nations framework.
The upbeat American view, critics also contend, takes no account of the bitter feelings left by the Bush Administration's threat to withhold future contributions to the United Nations if the Assembly upgraded the P.L.O.'s representation, at a time when it owes the organization more than $500 million in unpaid dues.
 
On Zionism Resolution
Neither does it reflect the apprehension aroused by Vice President Dan Quayle's sudden announcement that the United States will seek to repeal a General Assembly resolution passed in 1975 that equates Zionism with racism.
The Soviet Union has come out publicly against the proposal, calling it divisive. And many Western countries think repeal impossible without a breakthrough in the Middle East peace process. But they fear that Congress will engineer a confrontation with the United Nations next year by threatening to withold funds unless the Assembly cancels the Zionism resolution.
This has led to bitter accusations that the United States wants to extend its Security Council veto into the General Assembly's debates by warning it may cut back funds if it does not get its way.

HEADLINE: Kinshasa Journal;
Getting Rich in Zaire: An American, 33, Tells How

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire

 BODY:
He is young, brash, wealthy and seems to be buying up everything in sight.
Edwyn Blattner, a 33-year-old entrepreneur from Bayonne, N.J., is an increasingly rare species in black Africa: an American investor. And by his own accounting, he is tantalizingly close to becoming the biggest foreign investor in all of Zaire.
Fresh out of Syracuse University with a undergraduate degree in chemical engineering and a master's in business, he joined his father's business, a modest textile mill here in Zaire's capital. 
Over the next few years, with leverage and luck, Edwyn Blattner bought a succession of other businesses: a Goodyear tire factory, Kinshasa's only slaughterhouse, a canning factory, rubber, coffee and palm-oil plantations.
 
Owns 60,000 Square Miles
He also bought a lot of land at what he said where bargain prices, although he declined to give figures. The family now owns 60,000 square miles spread through virtually ever section of Zaire.
Last June, the Blattners made their biggest acquisition, the conglomerate Agricom, based in Belgium. The Blattner family organization, African Holding Company of America, is now an umbrella for more than 40 entities, employing about 17,000 workers, of which the largest and most striking properties were developed by the younger Blattner.
''He's just like that American, Donald Trump, but even more so,'' said Nzanda Kasole, a Zairian businessman who has traveled widely in the West. ''What he's been able to do here in such a brief period is phenomenal.''
 
He Buys Dead Companies
Asked to explain his family's business success, Mr. Blattner said, ''Buy cheap.''
''All the companies you now see are purchased companies, companies that were bankrupted, or dead practically.'' He said most of the companies were bought from Belgian nationals.
Business acumen aside, Mr. Blattner has also benefited from the fact that he has spent most of his life here. He was born in America, and his family moved to Zaire in 1960. He speaks French, and the main languages of the interior, Lingala and Swahili.
What is especially striking about the Blattner empire is that it appears to be flourishing in what is among the most difficult places on earth to do business.
Many of the services that entrepreneurs even in neighboring African countries take for granted simply do not exist here. The network of about 88,000 miles of usable roads built by the Belgian colonialists, for example, has shrunk to about 12,000 miles of which only about 1,400 is paved, and much of that is rutted and riddled with potholes.
 
Phones Aren't Much Good
The country has no telephone system to speak of; dialing into the country's vast interior is virtually hopeless, and international calls are among the world's most expensive -more than $10 a minute to Europe or the United States.
''We're getting into a lot of businesses that we're not supposed to because the infrastructure that the country gives us is so poor,'' Mr. Blattner said as he gave a tour of his modern canning factory near the Cite, the sprawling community where most of Kinshasa's four million people live.
In the interior, for example, the Blattners operate a small fleet of their goods on company-owned boats.
Unlike the practice of Belgian nationals, from whom Mr. Blattner bought most of his properties, he said his practice is to fill the ranks of his company with Zairians, especially at the management level.
''My reputation is that of a guy who uses very little expatriate labor,'' he said, ''because I believe that the locals give much better job performance and much better stability in their work, because it's their country.''
 
He Reproaches the Belgians
Indeed, he is especially critical of Belgian nationals, who form the largest group of expatriates and who he said often failed as businessmen here because they were arrogant and abusive managers.
''They have this authoritarian, paternalistic attitude,'' he said. ''And the workers don't respond to it.''
Although the wages of most of his employees are low by American standards - a skilled factory worker makes about $200 a month - they are considered generous in a poor country. A Secret Partnership? Still, to some Zairians, Mr. Blattner's success is a bit unsettling. For one thing, the theory goes, the Blattners must on some level be in partnership with President Mobutu Sese Seko to have done so much, so quickly. But Mr. Blattner says that because of the huge size of his holdings, the graft and corruption that permeate much of business life here are not problems he has to deal with.
''Mismanagement is a much greater problem than corruption,'' he said. ''Not because the people here are incompetent, but because there's very little stability within the Government.''
 
Revolving-Door Rule
Indeed, President Mobutu habitually shifts ministers and executives of state-run industries from job to job at a rapid rate, a maneuver critics say is intended to prevent them from acquiring a political constituency independent of himself.
''There's no continuity,'' Mr. Blattner complained. ''You talk to somebody, explain your problem, and when he starts to look at it and understand it, he gets replaced. And you start again. And this can happen five or six times in one year.''
Despite the often decrepit conditions, the corruption and mismanagement, Mr. Blattner said he cannot imagine being in business anywhere else.
''Nowhere else in the world could I have been able to do what I've done, at 33 years of age,'' he said. ''That's why I call this the wild west. If you're willing to put yourself on the line, it's wide open out here.''

HEADLINE: BEFORE THE CLASH, AN OUTWARD CALM

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, Dec. 19

 BODY:
While tensions between the Government here and the United States were rising today, throngs braved steamy heat in search of Christmas bargains.
The Government newspapers denounced the United States and warned of an impending invasion, but the war of words between the two countries over two shooting incidents in three days was belied by the calm on the streets.
''It's Christmas and I'm not going to let anything get in the way of that,'' a retired schoolteacher said as a salesman loaded a 20-inch Sony color television she had bought into a taxi. 
After 18 months of American-imposed economic sanctions, many Panamanians appeared to be more concerned about the price of gifts than the likelihood of an American invasion.
 
Looking for a Bargain
A 37-year-old laborer, who lost his job more than 14 months ago with the collapse of the Panamanian construction industry, sadly rejected one radio alarm clock after another that he wanted to buy for his wife. The salesman brought him a knockoff that sold for $14.95.
''Do you have anything smaller?'' the laborer asked the harried salesman in a crowded electronics store in the central business district.
The salesman showed him a brown plastic radio clock that sold for $8.95.
''Is that the smallest you have?'' the laborer asked in the polite lexicon of this country's bankrupt shoppers. ''Yes,'' the salesman said. ''Sorry,'' the laborer said before leaving.
 
Sales Slowest in Recent Memory
Traffic in the central business district appeared lighter than in years past. There were fewer buses, and businessmen said sales were the slowest in recent memory.
''Nobody has anything in their hands,'' noted one taxi driver as he drove along the streets that are usually blocked. ''Everybody's just window shopping.''
But the old city remained a newly created labyrinth of blocked streets patrolled by soldiers guarding Panama's military headquarters and the official residence of the Panamanian ruler, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.
 
News Personnel Detained
PANAMA, Dec. 19 (Reuters) -Three journalists, one from The New York Times and two from Reuters, were briefly detained today by United States troops as they sought to investigate details of an apparent American airlift into Howard Air Force Base. Those detained were two reporters -Lindsey Gruson of The Times and Lerna Llerena of Reuters - and Malcolm Linton, a photographer on assignment for Reuters.

HEADLINE: Western Europe Seeks Arab Economic Ties

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 19

 BODY:
A meeting of 22 Arab and 12 European Community foreign ministers is scheduled in Paris this week to revive a stumbling political and economic discussion between Western Europe and the Arab world.
The large-scale gathering, scheduled for Thursday and Friday, is the most ambitious attempt yet to establish a process of economic and political negotiations between the Arab League and Western European members of the European Community on important economic and political issues, according to French and Arab diplomats. Despite repeated efforts since 1973, such regular talks have failed to materialize. 
Senior Arab diplomats said they would concentrate their effort primarily on beginning a program of economic cooperation, focused on the flow of Arab agricultural and petroleum products to Europe, instead of seeking agreements on difficult political issues of the Middle East such as the Arab-Israeli conflict, the Iraq-Iran conflict, and the crisis in Lebanon.
''We mean this to be a very soft, very low-key beginning,'' a senior Egyptian diplomat here, who asked not to be identified, said. ''If we can help it, there is not going to be any big political declaration. The focus will be on starting some form of economic cooperation with Western Europe with an eye on the big European Community merger planned for 1992.''
The caution with which Europeans and Arabs appear to approach this week's talks follows a string of failures since the effort began in the aftermath of the Arab oil embargo against the United States and the Netherlands in November 1973.
The embargo severely disrupted Western European economies, pushing a number of European nations, most notably Italy and Spain, to advocate closer ties to the Arab countries, particularly Arab oil producers in the Persian Gulf region.
The talks held since the embargo have stumbled over differences about the role of the Palestine Liberation Organization in such talks, European objections to the suspension of Egypt from Arab League membership after it signed a peace treaty with Israel in 1979, and the European Community's imposition of sanctions on Syria and Libya on the grounds that the two countries sponsored acts of terrorism in November 1986.
In addition, French and Arab diplomats said, American expressions of hostility to anything resembling negotiations between poor and rich nations over the last decade also weighed heavily in delaying the process.
The talks are to be held under the joint chairmanship of President Francois Mitterrand of France and King Hassan II of Morocco, who will open and close the sessions. France and Morocco respectively chair the European Community and the summit conference of the Arab League this year.
''We must retain and deepen Western European interests in the Middle East as a strategic region and a major source of energy supplies in the 90's and beyond,'' said an Arab ambassador in Paris, adding that political issues can wait in view of the economic changes ahead for Europe.
Arab diplomats said that among their primary concerns is the fear that the political upheaval taking place in Eastern Europe may divert Western European economic resources to the nascent markets of the Communist bloc at the expense of Arab economies.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
With Reform, Tough Times for the Warsaw Pact

BYLINE: By BERNARD E. TRAINOR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
In a few months, political turmoil in Eastern Europe has transformed the Warsaw Pact military alliance from a force feared in the West to an increasingly hollow organization without a clear purpose.
Although the pact's armies remain intact -there have been no defections and discipline is being maintained - the alliance has been neutralized by popular discontent in the streets of Leipzig and Prague, Dresden and Sofia, and other Eastern-bloc cities.
Organized for the dual purposes of offsetting the armies of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and insuring conformity to Soviet directives, the Warsaw Pact forces can no longer be counted on to do either, many military experts say.
Only in hard-line Rumania, a member of the pact in name only where no Soviet troops are stationed, is the regime willing to use the army to retain power. experts say. 
The weakening of the alliance is one of the reasons that the Bush Administration is reconsidering American military strategy and has moved in recent weeks to consider large reductions in arms spending over the next five years.
 
Western Threat Seen as Receding
American officials and experts in this country in and out of government say that the armies of Poland, East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Bulgaria and Rumania will not fight to preserve Soviet power, and few among them reportedly now see a threat from the West.
Nor can Warsaw Pact armies be used against their own people or their neighbors, as was the case in Czechoslovakia in 1968, said David Isby, an expert on the Warsaw Pact. In August of that year, five armies of the Communist alliance joined in putting an end to Prague Spring, Alexander Dubcek's liberalization movement.
The Soviets and their allies have admitted that the suppression of the Czechoslovaks was wrong and have embraced the right of nations to determine their own political futures.
Moscow's ability to take unilateral military action is another matter. Given President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's desire to focus Soviet resources on reviving his country's economy, the threat of Soviet military action in Europe has receded. Despite the formidable Soviet armored formations that are still based in East Germany, few Western military experts believe that the Kremlin has the stomach for confrontation.
But American military analysts agree that the loss of allies does not seriously undermine the Soviet military itself. With the exception of the East Germans, the Kremlin has always been uncertain of the reliability of its allies in wartime. As a result, Warsaw Pact plans have been based on the assumption that the Soviet Army would bear the brunt of the fighting.
 
Russians in Key Positions
Soviet units make up four-fifths of the alliance's force of about six million troops and bear 80 percent of its costs. With the exception of Rumania, the armies of Poland, East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Bulgaria include Soviet military officers in every division.
All pivotal wartime command and staff positions are in Soviet hands, and national units are integrated into Soviet formations. Military communications and control measures already run directly to the Soviet Union. Uniformity has been the rule. The pact must use Soviet equipment and adhere to Soviet training methods, doctrine and tactics. To insure uniformity, officers of the alliance are trained in Soviet war colleges.
The pact armies seem now to be in a state of suspended animation, with nobody giving many orders, much less ones that might not be obeyed, like calling out the military to suppress public demonstrations or prevent the fall of Communist governments.
 
Role of Military Deferred
The reformers ascending to power in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union have been careful to isolate Warsaw Pact military forces from the events around them. It is as though by unspoken agreement, questions of the role of the military are being left for quieter times.
Administration officials say the Soviet military leadership, through its Warsaw Pact command channels, made it clear that armies of the alliance would not intervene in political events. They were to remain in garrisons and see to their own security.
In all pact countries, the military portfolios remain in Communist hands. Soviet and national armies remain in garrisons, and other than increasing security, they go about the tasks of military life as though nothing unusual was taking place.
Defense Department officials say the Soviets are routinely carrying out their scheduled twice-a-year troop rotations, when large numbers of soldiers due for discharge are returned to the Soviet Union and replaced by new conscripts. There have been no changes or cancellations reported in the annual pact exercises scheduled to begin in Eastern Europe in the spring.
It is as though the Warsaw Pact armies have a life independent of the nations that staff them. And in a sense that is true. Unlike NATO armies, which are independent, co-equal national forces with their own equipment, doctrine, training and command mechanisms, which would operate within a multinational command structure in wartime, the Eastern European armies ''are the world's most non-national armies and simply part of the Soviet Army,'' said Mr. Isby, the Warsaw Pact expert.
 
Rendered Essentially Absurd
But those arrangements cannot last with the rejection of Communism and the rebirth of nationalism among its members. The Soviets recognize this and are readjusting to the reality. While maintaining the current pact organization, they have begun withdrawing their forces behind their borders and reorganizing their army under a new defensive doctrine. Ray Garthoff of the Brookings Institution says Eastern Europe is becoming a buffer between the West and the Soviet homeland rather than the front line of the Soviet Army.
To maintain the Warsaw Pact as a military alliance, radical changes must occur within it to allow for national self-determination and the existence of non-Communist governments within its ranks. This might mean that membership would be voluntary and subject to multinational cooperation instead of rigid military orthodoxy.
Such an alliance could serve to allay fears of a reunited Germany, particularly for Poland. It could also provide a framework for stability throughout Central Europe. There are traditional enmities between Warsaw Pact members. Bulgaria and Rumania, and Hungary and Bulgaria, for example.
Up until now, those have been held in check by the Warsaw Treaty Organization because the Soviets saw to it that the members had no independent ability to plan hostilities against their neighbors. With Soviet control removed, national antagonisms could re-emerge, particularly if discontent and disillusionment replace the current euphoria of national independence.

HEADLINE: Make Room for West Side Students

 BODY:
Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts may be one of America's most successful urban renewal projects. Over the years it has weathered scary economics and disputes among temperamental artists. Yet its esthetic whole continues to exceed the sum of its constituent institutions. 
Now one of those institutions, the West Side Manhattan campus of Fordham University, needs to build housing for students who study at Lincoln Center. Tomorrow the Board of Estimate can help provide that important benefit to the university, at no cost to anyone else.
The urban renewal plan for Lincoln Center set aside almost all the two southerly blocks for Fordham. The university purchased the land, subject to the plan, and built academic buildings. It reserved a dormitory site but needs a new infusion of money to make its rooms affordable by students.
To raise the money, Fordham would sell off a small piece of its Lincoln Center site to a developer for $16.5 million. The developer would erect a 42-story tower, consistent with an apartment house next door. The Planning Commission has approved the plan for the new tower. Opponents, including Community Board 7, resist any further development. They point out that the Lincoln Center plan forbids the land to be used for anything but institutional purposes until 1997.
Thus Fordham's dormitory plan depends on the Board of Estimate's changing the Lincoln Center development plan. There is good reason to do so. The restriction on Fordham's use or resale for a non-institutional purpose was intended to assure that the site would remain dedicated to the performing arts and education. That plan is complete. There are no new plans for additional artistic or educational institutions at Lincoln Center. The 1997 date was a safety valve, allowing the institutions to sell their land if the original plan failed.
It is entirely consistent with the Lincoln Center plan to allow the use of underutilized land, with Planning Commission approval, by one of the institutions to further its program. When Lincoln Center was built, cheap housing was easier to find and dormitories were not essential to urban universities. In today's housing market their importance has grown.
Creating living space for students enrolled in classes at Lincoln Center will help Fordham, the Lincoln Center enclave, the surrounding community and the city as a whole. The Fordham plan merits approval.

HEADLINE: Doubleheader for Democracy;
A Promising Renewal in Chile

 BODY:
After 16 years of cruel tyranny, Chile now stands poised for a remarkable political transformation. Patricio Aylwin's triumph in last week's presidential election means a return to democratic life under particularly promising circumstances. Washington has a clear interest in giving strong support to what could become the region's model democracy. 
Chile benefits from a deep-rooted democratic tradition. But it could not withstand the pressures that buffeted the elected Socialist Government of Salvador Allende in the early 1970's. Passionate political divisions and economic turmoil caused by mismanagement, strikes and deliberate U.S. pressure culminated in Gen. Augusto Pinochet's successful military coup.
The Pinochet years brought executions, disappearances, torture and mass exile. They also brought state terrorism against perceived enemies of the regime in Chile and other countries, including the murder of a prominent Chilean exile and his U.S. co-worker on a Washington D.C. street.
Yet while almost every other Latin military regime converted mere economic crises into disasters, the Pinochet Government achieved a healthy reorientation of Chilean economic life. It reduced Chile's historic dependence on copper, pared down the bureaucracy and permitted private enterprise to flourish.
In a continent crippled by low growth and high inflation, Chile has enjoyed stable expansion. That hasn't brought much consolation to union labor or the very poor, who have lost ground. But Chile's overall economic performance has been so impressive that even left-wing parties now endorse the market-oriented approach.
President-elect Aylwin will face real problems. The Constitution leaves uncomfortably large powers in military hands. Appointive Senate seats will unfairly dilute his congressional backing. A broad coalition from left to center-right backed his candidacy. As the component parties strike out on their own, these problems could be compounded. And Chile retains a heavy burden of foreign debt. Happily, democratic Chile needs no bailouts or emergency aid from abroad. What it does need from America is consistent support. Washington can encourage the continuing retreat of the Chilean military from politics, can shield Chilean exports from protectionist pressure and can lobby for appropriate relief on the foreign debt. The prospect of a model democracy warrants no less.

HEADLINE: High Cost of Becoming Yellow-Cab Driver Discourages Recruits

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You report on the shortage of taxi drivers in New York City and what is being done about it, including a fare increase approved Nov. 30 by the Taxi and Limousine Commission (news article, Dec. 4). The situation is worsened by high fees the commission charges prospective new drivers.
The up-front costs for anyone seeking a hack license is $234. That comprises the fee for the Taxi Institute, which has just been increased to $125, $25 for a bus tour, $24 for fingerprinting and $60 for the license. The $234 is paid at least two to four weeks before a worker may start earning a living. 
We believe that the $60 hack license fee should be enough to cover all costs! It is an outrage that an unemployed person, or anybody for that matter who chooses to become a taxicab driver, should be subjected to these exorbitant fees.
The excess fees also make it difficult for the taxi industry to recruit part-time and fill-in drivers. Traditionally, students drove cabs in the summer or on breaks. Workers on furlough or on strike in other industries would drive a taxi for extra income. Many workers drive a taxi one or two days a week to help make ends meet. The $234 discourages many of these people from coming into the industry.
A note on our competition: The yellow cab industry competes for personnel with radio cars, limousines and liveries. Prospective drivers for any of those need only make a change in driver's license to a class 4 chauffeur's license at the Department of Motor Vehicles. They can go to work the same day.
Only potential drivers of yellow taxis are subjected to high costs and delays before they can go to work.
We are not against the concept of the Taxi Institute. Local 3036 originated the program years before it was adopted by the Taxi Commission. We continue to run traffic and safety classes for our members.
We object, however, to a worker's being charged a fee for city-mandated classes. We would like to see a system that would allow workers to earn while they learn. We believe this would be fairer to the worker while providing increased taxi service to the public.
 
LAWRENCE GOLDBERG
Secretary-Treasurer, Taxi Drivers
and Allied Workers Union
 Long Island City, Queens, Dec. 6, 1989

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
The Unequal Alliances

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
The cold war bred an assumption that the two sides of the East-West equation should be considered equals. That has been the basis of arms control negotiations up to now. But it is breaking down.
As the transformation of Eastern Europe develops, the old idea of overcoming the division of Europe by dissolving alliances has to be discarded. Each will still have certain functions, but they will be different, from the present and from each other. 
Negotiators in Vienna are working doggedly to cut conventional forces in Europe, what a Soviet analyst recently called ''these monstrous war machines,'' to parity at a lower level. That became possible with Moscow's major concession of accepting ''asymmetrical reductions,'' as the jargon puts it, because it has more troops and weaponry than the West.
But a new, reverse asymmetry will emerge from changes in the East. The Warsaw Pact will be hard pressed to sustain the force level the West wants as a ceiling.
Already the interim, and still Communist, Government in Hungary has signaled that it wants Soviet troops to withdraw. Czechoslovakia's new Foreign Minister pointed out that there was no valid basis for the 70,000 to 75,000 Soviet troops stationed in his country since Moscow admitted that the 1968 invasion was ''illegal.''
Poland's new Government appreciates Soviet sensitivity about forces on its territory assuring links to the 400,000-strong Soviet garrison in East Germany. But Warsaw wants cuts and treaty revisions. And Moscow can have little confidence now in the reliability of its Warsaw Pact allies.
Yet Mikhail Gorbachev told President Bush in Malta that American forces should stay in Europe, which means preserving NATO. As Secretary of State James Baker said last week, the alliance is the central link between the U.S. and Western Europe and will remain vital to both.
For some time the two alliances will be needed, if only to oversee coming arms reductions. Beyond that, the probability of German reunification is a powerful motive for Europeans on both sides of the divide to keep the balancing weight America provides.
The idea of a neutral Germany at the center of Europe is as obsolete as the Berlin wall. It is much too powerful economically and, increasingly, politically to be credible as a giant Austria or Switzerland. It needs to be anchored in institutions, both the European Community and NATO, as Mr. Baker said, if it is not to become a dreaded loose cannon.
This is not a matter of trust, but of European dynamics. And embers of fear of Germany are live. That showed in the irrational reaction to Chancellor Helmut Kohl's speech outlining conditions and steps toward some kind of German unity.
Mr. Kohl was rightly criticized for going off on his own, failing to consult his coalition partners and allies in his haste to seek domestic political gain. And he was rightly criticized for refusing to include assurances on Poland's western border.
But his speech was useful. It offered to Germans on both sides the hope of an orderly, democratic approach to the unity issue. That doesn't hurry the process. It's probably the only way to slow it down, by pre-empting crowds in the street chanting slogans of German nationalism.
Whether it includes East Germany or not, the Warsaw Pact may also be needed to maintain peace in Eastern Europe until its inhabitants reach the kind of reconciliation achieved in the West. At present, the surge to democracy is releasing suppressed nationalisms that could turn dangerous.
But its function as the basis for a Soviet bloc, set against the West, will disappear. This will seem at first an unacceptable imbalance to Moscow, alongside a politically strengthened NATO. Soviet analysts should ponder carefully Mr. Baker's milestone Berlin speech saying, ''A legitimate and stable European order will help, it will not threaten, legitimate Soviet interests.'' America's contribution to that order remains essential in what NATO's Secretary General, Manfred Woerner, called ''the long period of transition that we are now entering.''
As the East European countries make the painful switch to market economies, they will loosen their ties to the Soviets. But they can also work as a vanguard to ease even more difficult Soviet integration into the world economy: raising standards, expanding trade.
It is hard to conceive yet the kind of Soviet-U.S. reconciliation that would enable Moscow to see a disintegrating Warsaw Pact and a sturdy, if transformed, NATO as favorable developments. But mentalities are changing. Already Moscow has said it is not threatened by attack from the West. The changes have been one-sided because one side needed much more change. That will be true throughout the coming decade.

HEADLINE: Florio Picks 2 Commissioners

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Governor-elect James J. Florio today named the people he wants to head the Labor and Commerce Departments when his administration begins on Jan. 16.
Mr. Florio named George R. Zoffinger of Byram, executive vice president of the First Fidelity Bank, as Commerce Commissioner and Raymond L. Bramucci of Bergenfield, director of Senator Bill Bradley's office in New Jersey, as Labor Commissioner. 
Mr. Florio said the two would work closely on activities like consolidating the 63 government-supported job-training programs. ''Never in my 25 years in public life has there been a time when it is easier to bring business and labor together to focus on common needs,'' Mr. Florio said at a news conference in the State Senate Chamber.
He said the interests of labor in providing jobs for workers and those of business in finding qualified employees will give the commissioners, who are also friends, common ground. ''I've talked to businessmen in recent days who say they can't find people to preserve even their present level of economic activity,'' Mr. Florio said.
Mr. Zoffinger, 41 years old, has been in charge of the London office of First Fidelity since January and has broad experience in international trade, which, Mr. Florio said, was important to his selection. Mr. Zoffinger is a member of the board of the New Jersey World Trade Council and the Governor's Commission on International Trade and is a director of the New Jersey District Export Council.
Mr. Bramucci, 54, has directed Mr. Bradley's New Jersey office since 1979. Before that he was an official of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union for 19 years, including seven years as assistant general manager of the New Jersey region.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
The Challenge of Teaching History As the Cold War Recedes in Europe

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

 BODY:
Many times this fall, Baiba Schletty was ready to throw away the lesson plan and make her high school history students look far beyond the orchards and fields that are the economic foundation of rural Berryville, Va.
She wanted the classes to know what it meant that Communism was crumbling in Eastern Europe. But first she had to explain a couple of things, like ''cold war'' and ''Berlin Wall.''
Ms. Schletty, like many teachers around the country, wants to link the history that Eastern Europeans are living to the history that American students are learning. Charged with illuminating the American political experience, teachers of history and social studies are eager to have their students watch Eastern European nations redefining their own political identities. 
But the realities of lesson planning, state-mandated curriculum requirements and student indifference often leave limited opportunity for impromptu lessons in current events.
''There's a lot of pressure to get through the curriculum,'' said Louise Brantley, a social studies teacher at Sprague High School in Salem, Ore. ''If I'm teaching a course in ancient civilizations, that doesn't give me a lot of opening to discuss Eastern Europe. And if I don't bring in ideas in context, they're not going to understand them at all.''
''But,'' she added, ''if I can't relate ideas from the past to their own situation, then I'm not teaching them very much.''
 
Problem With Immediacy
Part of the challenge, teachers say, is the speed and sweep of events. And some believe that the generally nonviolent character of the Eastern European revolution reduces its immediacy for a generation reared on television fare like ''Miami Vice.''
''This is revolutionary, but it doesn't have a sharp focus, like the events in Tiananmen Square,'' said Saul Bruckner, principal of Edward R. Murrow High School in Brooklyn. ''This isn't something that can be personalized the way you could personalize the death of a John Kennedy or the explosion of a space shuttle. It's too wide a picture; it's continuing over too long a period of time.''
Some teachers who grew up in the early decades of the cold war, during the Berlin blockade, the Cuban missile crisis and the omnipresent fear of nuclear annihilation, are philosophical about the new generation's indifference to the snipping of Europe's barbed wire or to youths dancing on a distant wall.
''I think this is such a major change in the world; I believe that this is the end of the cold war,'' said Ms. Schletty, a native of Latvia who always includes that Baltic republic in map tests of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. ''But it is hard for students. The basic concept that is hard for them is that different societies live differently.''
 
U.S. Frame of Reference
Bonny Cochran, who teaches history at Bethesda-Chevy Chase High School in the Maryland suburbs of Washington, observed, ''The kids think the whole world should be evolving into a two-party system because that's what we have.''
Mr. Bruckner, in Brooklyn, said that many of his students remain indifferent even though ''they're living the history,'' studying next to new students from immigrant Soviet Jewish families.
Yet things are comparatively easy for teachers like William J. Stark, head of the social studies department at the Bronx High School of Science, an academically elite school where students are eager to explore new frontiers, especially when events have outraced their textbooks.
East-West comparisons have long been part of courses in American government. Beginning about 30 years ago, most high school textbooks and course materials framed discussions of the Soviet Union in terms of ideological enmity and a Communist quest for world domination. While the basic reference point of ideological rivalry remains in most texts, the distinctions are drawn far less sharply.
Prodded by fast-moving events, many junior high schools and high schools that offer current events courses and some teachers in advanced comparative government courses have found themselves making the daily newspaper their text.
 
Lessons in Anti-Communism
A few states still mandate lessons in anti-Communism. Florida, for instance, requires that each world history course - usually taught to sophomores - includes 30 hours of instruction in ''Americanism versus Communism.''
But, said Kathleen McCarron, a world history teacher in Lincoln High School in Tallahassee, the required 30 hours of ideological instruction can be woven into different course units. ''During the events in Eastern Europe, we were talking about the Delian League, the alliance of Greek city-states, which had each member contributing money and troops,'' Ms. McCarron said. ''We made the comparisons to NATO and the Warsaw Pact.''
While teachers agree that it may be asking a lot to expect teen-agers to grasp the magnitude of the changes in Eastern Europe, they disagree about whether the students can be made to see beyond the vistas of their neighborhoods - the apartment houses in Brooklyn or the apple orchards in Berryville.
Mr. Bruckner believes that students basically do not care - and that they are not at fault. ''The fact that we have a global village makes it difficult for kids to identify with people,'' he said. ''The spelling is so different. The names are difficult. It is more difficult to teach kids than a few years ago. Then the world, for them, was the West. Now the world is so different.''
 
Challenge for Teachers Seen
But Bob Mathis, who teaches at the Bethesda-Chevy Chase High school, thinks there are few indifferent students - just inept teachers. ''I start with the premise that they know very little,'' he said. ''We start with, 'Who's Harry Truman?' But it doesn't take long to get them up to speed.''
In an affluent St. Louis suburb last month, seventh graders at Chesterfield's Central Junior High School were assigned an essay: ''If you lived in East Berlin, would you want to leave or to stay and rebuild?'' As the papers came in, the teacher, Sue Brannon, read, over and over, the words, ''I'd want more freedom.''
The lesson stayed with the students. On the day the Berlin Wall ceased to be a barrier, 12-year-old Jill Flotkin was watching the news, and ran to call her parents to the television when she saw the scenes from the Brandenburg Gate.
The changes register in another way. In Billie Day's sophomore class on Global Perspectives at Banneker High School in Washington, students huddle in groups each Monday, preparing reports on the current events discussed on the news-discussion programs they watched over the weekend.
When asked whether the United States has any national enemies, they looked at each other, puzzled, for a long half-minute before one or two hands were tentatively raised. ''Our worst enemy is ourselves, instead of a foreign country,'' responded Rebeccah Bennett, 14. ''Especially since we're seeing a lot of reforms in Eastern Europe. Since Gorbachev got in, he's gotten rid of so much that was wrong. If we were going to have a war, who would it be with?''

GRAPHIC: Billie Day is among the many teachers who are trying to supplement state-mandated curriculums with discussion of politics and current events. At Banneker High School in Washington, she talked with Gail Alleyne, left, and Reagan Rucker about developments in Eastern Europe (The New York Times/Andrea Mohin)

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
A Show in Minneapolis Offers History Behind Designs

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS

 BODY:
One of the most ambitious exhibitions in recent months is ''The American Craftsman and the European Tradition'' at the Minneapolis Institute of Arts.
Although ostensibly a display of American and European furniture, silver, glass and ceramics from 1620 to 1820, it is much more. Differences between one chest of drawers and another are not demonstrated simply to document shifts in taste over two centuries, but to support the broader theme that is the real purpose of this exhibition.
Organized by Francis J. Puig, a former curator at the museum, and by Michael Conforti, its chief curator, ''American Craftsman'' aims to show that contrary to what many scholars and other experts in the decorative arts have long maintained, American design did not develop independently from Europe but evolved very much out of European sources. 
Whether it was a chest from New Mexico that owed its patterning to Spanish precedents or a commode from the upper Mississippi River Valley that copied French models, American decorative arts depended on styles exported to the colonies by European artisans and their followers.
Which styles were preferred by the colonists, whether they were up to the minute with the latest fashions in London or whether they reflected the tastes of a previous generation, are among the questions the exhibition sets out to address. And the answers, in turn, provide fodder for bigger topics.
Similarities between American and British glassware, for example, become part of a discussion about the political and economic forces brought to bear on the colonists by the Townshend Acts of 1767, under which the British imposed a heavy tax on the importation of such materials as glass, lead and paint. American glass manufacturing thrived as a result of those taxes, with manufacturers like H. W. Stiegel in Pennsylvania campaigning to ''Buy American'' and producing sugar bowls, goblets and other objects in English styles to accommodate the tastes of buyers who would not pay increased taxes for imports.
In the case of cabinetry from Connecticut, research on the economics of that state is used to demonstrate that the rise of a nouveau riche population, which profited from the sale of agricultural and other goods to the Revolutionary Armies, explains a surge in the production of elaborate desks and chairs and other furniture.
''The American Craftsman,'' in other words, concerns itself as much with American social history as with the history of decorative arts. It includes more than 100 objects drawn from public and private collections across the country and in Europe. The works have been divided into 11 sections. There are sections not only on the decorative arts in New Mexico and the Mississippi River Valley but also on silver from Boston, furniture from Philadelphia, Baltimore and Connecticut and porcelain and glassware from Pennsylvania.
Everywhere, American works have been juxtaposed with related objects from France, Spain, Germany, England or the Netherlands, and, because so much of the furniture is unsigned, every effort has been made to identify specific artisans and workshops. Altogether, a great deal of ground is covered by ''American Craftsman,'' and the opinions and research of more than a dozen scholars can be found in the catalogue.
There are, it must be said, parts of the exhibition that suffer from a kind of pedantry characteristic of such social-history shows. A good proportion of the exhibition depends on arguments made in the catalogue that are otherwise impossible to derive from simply looking at the objects. Unusually lengthy wall labels, including an introduction and conclusion, serve at once as an aid and a burden for the viewer.
Still, there are a good number of objects that can be appreciated entirely on their own. It would be difficult to find a more fantastical piece of 18th-century sculpture than the Masonic master's chair from Williamsburg, Va., with its symbol-laden backrest made of masons' tools and decorated with a crescent moon and gilded sun.
From New Mexico there is a rough-hewn chest on four legs, adorned with geometric patterns, that has a monumentality all out of proportion to its modest size. For boldness of design, there is nothing quite like the serpentine chest on cabinet from Baltimore, which mixes diamonds and ovals to create an extraordinary abstract facade. And for sheer elegance of execution, there are few objects to equal a high chest of drawers from Philadelphia topped with an elaborately carved bust of a woman, at one time thought to be Mme. Pompadour.
Scholars will obviously have much to ponder and debate in ''American Craftsman.'' But even those who may not know what distinguishes an armoire from a commode will find something to mull over here.
''The American Craftsman and the European Tradition'' remains at the Minneapolis Institute of Arts through December, and can be seen at the Carnegie Institute in Pittsburgh from April 14 to June 10. The show is supported by the National Endowment for the Humanities.

HEADLINE: Review/Film;
Surveying What's Left When G.M. Leaves Town

 BODY:
''Roger and Me'' was shown as part of the recent New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 27, 1989. The film opens today at Cinema Third Avenue, at 60th Street.
 
America has an irrepressible new humorist in the tradition of Mark Twain and Artemus Ward. He is Michael Moore, the writer, producer and director of the rude and rollicking new documentary feature ''Roger and Me.''
Mr. Moore's frontier is his hometown, Flint, Mich., population 150,000, the birthplace of General Motors. As a result of the closing of various G.M. plants and the elimination of 40,000 jobs, Flint has become one of the more embarrassing eyesores in the landscape of what is supposed to be a booming American economy.
All sorts of attempts have been made to save Flint. ''Just when things were beginning to look bleak,'' Mr. Moore recalls on the soundtrack, ''Ronald Reagan arrived in Flint and took 12 workers out for a pizza.'' Somebody walked off with the pizzeria's cash register, though it's unclear whether the two events were connected.
When Money magazine named Flint ''the worst place to live in America,'' ABC planned to devote an entire ''Nightline'' show to the subject. The program was canceled at the last minute. The television power truck had been stolen.
Depressing figures and nutty anecdotes bubble out of ''Roger and Me'' nonstop, leaving the frequently appalled audience roaring with laughter, the kind of response that Twain would cherish.
The film takes its title from Mr. Moore's attempts to reach Roger B. Smith, the G.M. chairman. Mr. Moore's plan is to take Mr. Smith on a tour of Flint and to persuade him of G.M.'s responsibility in attending to the problems of the unemployed. A modest goal, it seems, though Mr. Moore knows as well as anybody that it's not a goal that stands any chance of being achieved. It is, however, a wonderful premise for an angry, biased, witty movie.
The portly, beady-eyed Mr. Moore, as sharp and sophisticated a documentary film maker as has come on the scene in years, manifests a down-home wonder at the world's idiocies. With a toothpick stuck in the corner of his mouth, wearing a down jacket, jeans and the sort of cap that should have the name of a feedlot on it, he stalks the G.M. chairman in the assorted sanctuaries of the seriously rich and powerful.
To save their city after the G.M. pullout, the Flint city fathers approve a series of schemes that sound as if they'd come out of the head of Evelyn Waugh, reborn as a Flint booster. They spend $13 million to build a Hyatt Regency Hotel and $100 million or so more for a theme park called AutoWorld, both of which quickly go broke. They attempt to boost morale by bringing in Pat Boone and Anita Bryant to perform for the tired masses. The Rev. Robert Schuller, the television evangelist, is paid a reported $20,000 to tell his audience, ''You can turn your hurt into a halo.''
Mr. Moore is clearly someone who believes that poverty and corporate neglect are sins, and he doesn't pull his punches. He doesn't appeal to easy sentiment. He demolishes the television personality Bob Eubanks, of ''The Newlywed Game,'' just by letting him talk on and on.
Mr. Moore makes no attempt to be fair. Playing fair is for college football. In social criticism, anything goes, as it goes triumphantly in ''Roger and Me.''

GRAPHIC: Michael Moore, whose film, ''Roger and Me,'' opens today at Cinema Third Avenue.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
History and Memories of the Fight for Civil Rights

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

Freedom Bound
A History of America's Civil Rights Movement
By Robert Weisbrot
350 pages. Illustrated. W. W. Norton. $21.95.
 
Voices of Freedom
By Henry Hampton and Steve Fayer with Sarah Flynn
692 pages. Illustrated. Bantam Books. $25.95.
Several strong impressions emerge from a reading of ''Freedom Bound,'' an authoritative and clearly written history of the modern civil rights movement by Prof. Robert Weisbrot of Colby College. These impressions are confirmed by hundreds of interviews that appear in another work on the same theme, ''Voices of Freedom,'' an oral history assembled by Henry Hampton and Steve Fayer, the producer and the writer of the public broadcasting series ''Eyes on the Prize.'' The evidence in both valuable books leaves one with these conclusions:
First, only a rainbow alliance of white liberals and black advocates enabled the movement to flourish and caused civil rights legislation to pass; second, even those Presidents who professed sympathy with the plight of minorities did not take action unless it was politically prudent to do so; third, equality under the law, standing alone, does not necessarily lead to equality of opportunity in modern American society. 
Professor Weisbrot makes this telling point: ''A basic assumption of liberalism in the 1960's was that equal protection of constitutional rights would afford all Americans, regardless of color, an equal chance to amass wealth, influence and stature. Yet civil rights laws alone could not overcome the effects of past discrimination and lingering prejudice, nor did these laws substantially alter the economic system that had long permitted vast disparities of wealth and privilege, to the disadvantage of most blacks.''
The continuing demand for economic equality did not persuade a sufficient number of liberal reformers in public office to press ahead with the same zeal that they had done for civil rights, according to the case histories in ''Freedom Bound.'' These reformers maintained that the social order was already basically sound and that merit, rather than race or class, determined a person's chances in life. However, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and other black leaders sought to stretch the liberal vision beyond endorsement of limited welfare programs to an insistence on freedom from poverty as a basic civil right.
The outspoken interviews in ''Voices of Freedom'' cover events that already begin to fade into history: the Montgomery bus boycott; student sit-ins in Nashville; James Meredith's entry into the University of Mississippi; the March on Washington; the Mississippi freedom summer; bombings of black churches; Dr. King's controversial pairing of civil rights with his stand against the Vietnam War; Attica and prisoners' rights; busing in Boston, and affirmative action in Atlanta.
The tales of individual sacrifice in ''Freedom Bound'' and ''Voices of Freedom'' recall how the civil rights movement led to limited progress. It is doubtful if many of the current officials, including the one black justice on the United States Supreme Court, Thurgood Marshall, would have achieved their high elective and appointive positions had not some brave souls once moved defiantly from the back of the bus, sat down at segregated lunch counters, or been killed by racists in Mississippi. Later, blacks and whites assembled by the hundreds of thousands in peaceful demonstrations in Washington, awakening the Federal Government to recognize civil rights.
In this respect, ''Freedom Bound'' notes, the civil rights achievements of the 1960's were in retreat during the 1980's. The Kennedy and Johnson wars against poverty turned into mere skirmishes. Even hard-won civil rights laws were placed in jeopardy during President Reagan's tenure, of which Professor Weisbrot writes:
''The Justice Department filed suit against busing and affirmative action programs as unsound paths to the goal of racial equality. More discreetly the Administration scrutinized and rejected virtually all other paths as well. Jimmy Carter had proposed regulations to implement the neglected open-housing law of 1968; Reagan withdrew the guidelines. His first Attorney General, William French Smith, sought to dilute the Voting Rights Act by requiring proof of intent to discriminate beyond clear circumstantial evidence of black exclusion.'' While Congress protected civil rights laws, ''Reagan effectively pared the agencies responsible for enforcement.''
Where does the civil rights movement now stand? On the political level, there are great changes. A number of black officials sit in city halls, statehouses and in Congress; a black, Jesse Jackson, became the first serious Presidential candidate. Dr. King's birthday, Jan. 15, is a national holiday - a symbol of recognition for the minister who led the civil rights struggle in the front lines, where he was beaten and jailed, reached the mountaintop of inspiring oratory, and was finally assassinated.
Where is the movement going? In ''Voices of Freedom,'' Marian Wright Edelman, the respected civil rights lawyer who founded the Children's Defense Fund, sees a ray of hope:
''One has to remember the seasons, that in the barest points of winter, one really does have to remember that leaves and buds are beginning to blossom now in a new recognition by the country that it is in deep trouble. That the messages of Martin 20 years ago are the messages that we have still got to answer today. But I think, paradoxically, the Reagan years, which have been very hard years, with assaults on the national role on protecting the poor and minority groups, have set the stage for the 1990's, because this country will have to confront the issues of investing in its children and families if it is going to preserve the future.''

GRAPHIC: Robert Weisbrot

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Big Slide in Housing Prices Is Latest Worry on Wall St.

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Once again, the ''wealth effect'' is bothering Wall Street. This time, the worriers may be on to something.
The wealth effect refers to the way consumers step up purchases if they feel richer, and cut back if they feel poorer. Two years ago, it was widely bandied about as a reason for a recession, as investors scaled back purchases in the aftermath of the October 1987 stock market crash. 
That recession never happened. Stocks, however much attention they get, are not a major asset for most consumers, and the crash that devastated Wall Street went all but unnoticed on Main Street.
But the family home is the biggest asset for the vast majority of Americans. Now, with the latest round of bank write-offs providing evidence that the real estate market is weakening, talk of the wealth effect is back. Confronted by signs that the house may not be worth what they paid for it a couple of years ago, Americans may pull back.
Those fears contributed to the sharp market decline on Monday, when the Dow Jones industrial average fell 42 points, or 1.5 percent, and to the continued selloff early yesterday, before prices of large stocks rebounded to close with narrow losses. But prices of many smaller stocks continued to slide, and the Nasdaq composite fell 1.68, to 434.35, its lowest level since May 11.
Even before the Bank of New England's write-offs and quest for a buyer set off the new fears, there were signs of trouble. ''It's not just New England,'' said Charles Clough, chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch. ''We see signs of credit distress in the Southeastern area, up to the Mid-Atlantic and now into the upper Midwest. We've seen a sharp falloff in loan growth in those areas, which is usually a leading indicator of problems.''
Just how much impact the wealth effect can have is a subject of some controversy, but even those who think most highly of it contend that consumer incomes play a bigger role than asset values in determining spending patterns.
Those incomes have held up well this year, but there are a few disturbing signs. New claims for unemployment insurance rose sharply in the latest week reported, and yesterday the Commerce Department said real incomes for Americans fell seven-tenths of 1 percent in November. Both data series are volatile, but the new figures do not increase confidence in the state of the economy.
Even without the fear of consumers pulling back, there was growing concern on Wall Street of a profitless prosperity, in which the economy avoids recession but companies find it difficult to make money. That seems to be happening in the retail field, where consumers have been quite willing to buy at department stores, but earnings have vanished.
Last week's Government report on November retail sales showed they were up a quite respectable eight-tenths of 1 percent. One of the biggest gains was in apparel sales, up a strong 2.4 percent. Apparel is the big seller at department stores, and that kind of performance would, in other years, have investors celebrating.
So why aren't they? ''I think retail sales are being stimulated dramatically by markdowns,'' said Stefan Abrams, the chief investment strategist at Kidder, Peabody. ''Those, of course, are horrendous for profits.''
The consensus view on Wall Street now is that corporate profits will be down in 1990. The disputes concern the size of the fall, just how long the downturn will last and, most important, whether interest rates will fall sharply. Mr. Abrams and Mr. Clough both said rates will fall rapidly as lending remains slow, and said that could offset the impact of lower earnings.
That effect, however, could be slow in coming. For now, recession fears are on the rise on Wall Street. Unless and until they subside, share prices could be under continued pressure.
 
Mixed Signals on Xtra
When a news service runs an inaccurate report, is it permissible for someone who knows it is inaccurate to trade in the stock?
That is the question the Xtra Corporation is raising about the trading of Robert Gintel, a money manager and broker, who is waging a bitter proxy fight in opposition to management of Xtra, a trucking company.
The events in question took place on Friday, Aug. 11, when Mr. Gintel, the chairman of Gintel & Company of Greenwich, Conn., told the Dow Jones Professional Investor Report that he had handled a block of 534,600 Xtra shares - more than 8 percent of the company - sold that morning at $30.25 a share. The news service quoted him as saying there was just one buyer and it was someone who already owned at least 5 percent.
Mr. Gintel subsequently informed the Dow that the report was in error, because there were two buyers, with him being the other one. That correction moved on the Professional Investor Report at 3:11 P.M., but did not make it to the more widely available Dow Jones news service until after the close of trading.
With visions of takeovers dancing, the price of Xtra stock rose to a high of $34, and that afternoon Mr. Gintel, acting as manager of two mutual funds, sold 170,000 shares. It seems clear that at least half of those trades were made before the corrected report was printed.
The timing of those sales was good. The share price fell back to $32.875 the following Monday, in part on reaction to the revised report on the buyers. Xtra has been weak since, closing at $25.625 yesterday, down 37.5 cents.
In a suit filed in Federal court in Boston late Monday, Xtra said the trading, which it called stock manipulation, was illegal because the undistributed correction was material information. Mr. Gintel's lawyer, Dennis Block of Weil Gotshal & Manges, called the Xtra allegations ''untrue and scurrilous,'' but declined to comment further.

HEADLINE: Mosbacher Backs Soviet Fiber-Optic Cable

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Demonstrating a new American flexibility regarding high-technology exports to the Eastern bloc, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said today that a deal in which an American company would help lay a fiber-optic communications cable across the Soviet Union could go ahead if certain conditions were met.
Mr. Mosbacher, whose department shares jurisdiction with the Pentagon in approving export licenses, said that if the project involved the latest, most sophisticated technology, ''it's a little premature,'' but if the technology was older - he cited 5 to 10 years - the deal might be approved.
The Soviet customers would be getting ''not a backward system, just not as much of a future system,'' he said at a breakfast with reporters.
American commercial interests will also benefit if the proposed fiber-optic link is established, but because it could be used for military communications as well, the United States is wary about allowing too modern a system to be installed. 
The remarks represent the first public discussion by an Administration official of an ambitious proposal that U S West Inc. has tentatively worked out with the Soviet Union and seven other international telephone companies that have headquarters overseas. The companies would lay fiber-optic links to carry international calls and computer data between Europe and Japan.
The proposal is seen as a test of the extent - if any - to which the United States and its allies in Cocom, the 17-nation export review agency, will relax controls over high-tech exports in the wake of the changes in Eastern Europe. Because of its applicability to military purposes, fiber-optic technology is now embargoed by Cocom.
Mr. Mosbacher's remarks were consistent with those of other Administration officials, who in light of new political relationships have called for re-examination of the 40-year embargo on exports of high technology to the East.
 
'Take a New Look'
Lawrence S. Eagleburger, Deputy Secretary of State, said on Nov. 30, ''We and our Cocom partners want to signal our clear willingness to respond constructively to the democratization under way in Eastern Europe.'' And on Saturday President Bush said, ''It's timely to take a new look at some of the commercial constraints.''
Mr. Mosbacher said that Poland and Hungary, which have moved toward democracy, would be early beneficiaries of the more relaxed policies.
Cocom, the Paris-based Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, consists of NATO members plus Australia and Japan.
Because the United States has traditionally been the most cautious member of the organization, the position eventually taken by the Bush Administration will largely influence the final Cocom decision.
Richard J. Callahan, executive vice president at U S West, the Denver-based former Bell company, declined to comment on Mr. Mosbacher's remarks. He said the company had yet to work out its final proposals for the export review process.
 
'Encouraging' Statement
But Joseph T. Tragert, an economist at PlanEcon Research Associates, which studies Soviet and East European economic developments, found the Mosbacher statement ''very encouraging.''
''He's laying the groundwork for doing these things high tech-wise,'' Mr. Tragert said, ''while still not hurting our security interests.''
U S West, which has been negotiating with the Soviet Union since late 1988, expects to submit its formal application next month.
Sharp debate between the Commerce Department and the Pentagon could still lie ahead. Frank J. Gaffney Jr., a former Pentagon official who is now director of the Center for Security Policy, a Washington research institute, said installation of such a network would enhance the strategic command, control and communications capabilities of the Soviet military.
He also said such a network would make it more difficult for American intelligence to monitor Soviet communications, which it does to assess leadership intentions, status of military forces and any preparations for conflict.
 
Carrying More Information
Optical fibers are hair-thin strands of glass that carry conversations and computer data on beams of laser light. Because the laser beams can be focused so narrowly, the glass fibers can carry far more information than conventional copper wires.
One of the issues is the electronic equipment that goes with the fiber cable, which determines the speed of transmission. U S West is expected to propose 565 megabits - that 565 million bits of information could be processed each second.
That transmission speed, technology experts here said, is two generations behind the latest technology, which allows 1.7 gigabits, or 1.7 billion bits, of information to be processed each second.
U S West is also seeking Cocom approval to construct a cellular telephone system in Hungary. One of the main issues is the kind of switches that would be part of the system.
Hungary wants the latest digital switches, in which computers locate and use the open circuits in a telephone line, instead of older electrical-mechanical or analog switches.
Mr. Mosbacher said he would oppose the digital switches because ''they are really like supercomputers.''
