HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Up By 0.4%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
The Consumer Price Index rose by four-tenths of 1 percent in November, as food and shelter grew more costly while energy prices edged down, the Labor Department said today.
The increase, which was a bit more than expected, was believed to have been of some concern to those participating in an important Federal Reserve strategy meeting today.
With the economy generally seen as sluggish, the Fed has allowed interest rates to decline slightly, but an inflation signal viewed as too strong could give the Fed pause in easing further. The dominant view among economists, however, was that the rise in inflation last month was not high enough to prevent the Fed from easing credit some more in coming days or weeks. 
 
Pressure on Credit Markets
Still, the Fed, whose Open Market Committee completed two days of meetings today, did not enter the credit markets, disappointing those who had hoped for an immediate move toward lower interest rates. As a result, traders said, the markets for Government securities, particularly short-term instruments, were under pressure. [Page D16.] Major parts of the economy, including automotive and other manufacturing sectors, are in the doldrums, economists noted. The housing market is also in a downturn, with the Government reporting today that housing starts dropped by 4.7 percent last month. [Page D8.] And last Friday's Government report on prices received by producers showed small declines at both the finished goods and intermediate goods levels, indicating that down the road consumer prices should follow suit.
 
Hints by Administration
''Inflation remains under control,'' Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said today, with recent results holding ''some promise'' of lower interest rates. The Bush Administration has throughout the year been dropping hints that it would like to see the Fed become somewhat more accommodative in supplying the banking system with credit.
After the White House comment, the stock market, which had been off significantly in the first few hours of trading, bounced back on what traders said was new hope for lower interest rates. [Page D10.] Nevertheless, today's report on prices was at least mildly troubling, with service prices rising six-tenths of 1 percent and energy unlikely to act as a brake on prices in coming months. The late-autumn weather has been exceptionally cold in various parts of the country.
Robert G. Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, called today's report ''a little dose of reality for those who thought inflation was being rapidly curtailed.'' Although commodity price inflation has dwindled to a rate of only nine-tenths of 1 percent in the six months ended in November, from 7.6 percent for the six months ended in May, overall inflation in services during these periods has eased only to a 4.8 percent rate, from 5.1 percent.
Services account for about 55 percent of the consumer price gauge -they are not directly included at all in the producer price indexes - while commodities account for only 45 percent.
Mr. Dederick suggested that the Fed might be disinclined to ease credit immediately after today's report, even if the Federal Open Market Committee had decided at the nonpublic session, one of eight conducted each year, that the economy needed additional stimulus to avoid slipping into a recession.
On Wednesday the Commerce Department will make its second revision of the third quarter's gross national product number and will also revise its initial quarterly figure on corporate profits, which it published last month.
 
Climb in Health Costs
One of the biggest inflationary forces is medical care, which is highly labor intensive. Health costs, which account for 6 percent of the price index, climbed by eight-tenths of 1 percent in November, to bring the increase over the latest 12 months to 8.5 percent. This compared with 4.7 percent for overall consumer inflation in the same period. Hospital and related services were up by 1 percent in November.
Food and beverages, constituting 18 percent of the index, rose by six-tenths of 1 percent last month - as much as September and October combined - as the meat, poultry, fish and egg component turned and dairy products climbed sharply for the third straight month. Fresh vegetables also rose sharply.
A rise of five-tenths of 1 percent in housing - 42 percent of the index -resulted mainly from steep increases in the prices of electricity and natural gas; fuel oil rose at a slower pace than in October.
 
Transportation Rise Slows
In transportation, 17 percent of the index, inflation slowed to two-tenths of 1 percent from seven-tenths, mainly because gasoline prices dropped by 2.1 percent. New cars rose by eight-tenths of 1 percent, but analysts predicted that cars would resume their May-through-September declines because of poor recent sales.
Prices of used cars rose last month by six-tenths of 1 percent, the first increase since February, while finance and insurance costs each jumped by 1 percent.
Clothing prices were little changed last month after posting big increases in September and October, with the introduction of new fall and winter merchandise. Dry cleaning and other apparel services rose sharply. Apparel has the same price index weight as medical care, 6 percent.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Foreign Investors: Fifth Column?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
THE Japanese are coming! The Japanese are coming! warn assorted Congressional Democrats, union leaders and business interests who watch in horror as foreigners - specifically the Japanese - swallow up everything from computer chip makers to the best beaches in Hawaii.
And while the overall impact is still small -Japanese companies own only about 1 percent of the American manufacturing base - they are beginning to make big waves. One domestic industry, automobiles, has been transformed in a mere half-decade by an influx of Japanese manufacturers and Japanese manufacturing techniques. Others may follow: In 1987 and 1988 alone, the assets of Japanese-controlled concerns in this country increased by $100 billion. 
What critics have not offered, however, is a careful analysis of why anyone should care whether the stockholders of the Fortune 500 carry Japanese passports rather than American, or prefer sushi to sirloin. Nor are they are likely to find much comfort from the bluntly titled ''Foreign Direct Investment in the United States'' (Institute for International Economics, $11.95), the first cool-eyed assessment of the question.
For while the authors, Edward Graham of Duke University and Paul Krugman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, are not entirely sanguine about the growing role of foreign investment, they find no evidence that it is harming American interests. What is more, they argue that Washington regulators already have sufficient power to cope with any plausible threat.
The standard explanation for the recent sharp increase in foreign direct investment is the trade deficit: Americans bought all those Toyotas; foreigners used the proceeds to buy factories in Kentucky and condos in Trump Tower.
Net foreign investment is indeed the mirror image of the American current account deficit. But much of that investment has been indirect, with foreigners parking their unspent dollars in Treasury securities, bank C.D.'s and the stock market. And as Mr. Graham and Mr. Krugman point out, surges in direct investment since the mid-1970's do not correlate with increases in the trade deficit.
Direct investment flows actually fell from 1982 to 1985, years in which the trade deficit went through the roof. And while the trade deficit has stabilized since 1986, direct investment has tripled. A better explanation, the authors suggest, turns on the fact that foreign companies now depend less on cheap labor to hold down costs, and more on technological or managerial efficiency.
Foreign companies could, and often do, exploit these newly gained efficiencies by exporting products to the United States. But trade competitiveness is vulnerable to shifts in exchange rates. And cost advantages can be nullified by protectionist restrictions. So now that Japanese manufacturers do not need bowl-of-rice-a-day labor to undercut rivals, they have every reason to compete directly with facilities in the United States.
It is hard, on first glance, to see how Americans could lose in the process. American consumers get competitively priced products, while American workers get to keep their jobs. And as a bonus, the efficient techniques the foreigners bring with them are likely to trickle down: The lessons from Honda's Ohio plant, one presumes, have not been entirely lost on General Motors.
But some critics charge that foreigners treat their American plants as colonial outposts. The best jobs, research and development facilities and the most sophisticated manufacturing processes stay home.
In fact, say Mr. Graham and Mr. Krugman, foreign companies operating in the United States do not save ''high value'' or ''high compensation'' activities for their domestic plants. Nor do they spend less for research in the United States than their American competitors. The only sticky issue is national defense: America might conceivably become dependent on foreign-owned technology, which could be withheld when it was needed.
But even here, the authors argue, broad restrictions on foreign ownership are hard to justify. As defense technology grows more complicated and the world economy more integrated, some degree of dependence on foreign companies is almost inevitable. The key is to identify truly critical technologies and do what is necessary to insure American access.
In some cases, that might mean mandatory licensing of technology to American companies. More likely, it could mean mandatory production in the United States. Ironically, foreign direct ownership may be part of the solution, rather than part of the problem.

HEADLINE: Comptroller Asserts Banks Face Growing Realty Woes

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Robert L. Clarke, the Comptroller of the Currency, said yesterday that bank problems with bad real estate loans were growing but were not yet serious enough to cause losses of the magnitude that led to the collapse of most large Texas banks a few years ago.
Mr. Clarke, the primary regulator of national banks, said at a breakfast meeting with reporters, ''I don't see where we are looking at a systemic problem.''
Although weakness in many real estate markets, particularly in the Northeast, has caused prices of most bank stocks to fall sharply, Mr. Clarke said that not all banks were exposed to great losses from real estate lending. Even among banks facing the greatest losses, he said, ''at this time'' he does not expect a flurry of failures. 
In New England, where declining prices for real estate and slow sales of recently completed projects have caused large losses at many banks, Mr. Clarke said the problem was not so serious as in Texas.
Both Texas and New England have suffered from overbuilding, he said, but Texas was hit by the additional shock of a heavy loss of jobs in the energy industry. That sent tremors through other sectors of the Texas economy, making the decline in real estate markets even more severe.
In New England, Mr. Clarke said, there has been no comparable shock.
 
More Data Collected
As teams of bank examiners visit banks with the largest portfolios of troubled real estate loans, the Comptroller's office is collecting more data than ever before about market conditions. It will use those figures to estimate which banks are most vulnerable to loss and how severe their problems might be.
By using new information about real estate prices, as well as the latest appraisals, Mr. Clarke said bank examiners could be more persuasive when they tell bankers to become more realistic and recognize that the quality of their real estate loans has declined.

HEADLINE: Bankers Trust's Profit Lower After Bad Loans

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Bankers Trust Company, which had escaped the trend among other banks of higher lending losses this year, announced yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings would be cut by $90 million after taxes, because of losses on two large loans.
The bank declined to comment on the borrowers or the size of its loans, except to say that the larger loan was made to a domestic commodity merchant and the smaller loan was for the restructuring of a British company. During the first nine months of the year, Bankers Trust's delinquent loans declined by $17 million. 
 
Dividend Is Raised
To salve the wounds of investors, and ''demonstrate its confidence in the earning power of the corporation'' Bankers Trust also announced a 12 percent increase in its quarterly common stock dividend to 58.25 cents a share from 52 cents, payable Jan. 25, 1990, to shareholders of record Jan. 4. The banking company raised its common stock dividend by 12 percent a year ago.
Market sources said the smaller loan was to Magnet P.L.C., which Bankers Trust was advising in a leveraged buyout worth about $1 billion. Besides advising Magnet, Bankers Trust led a group of banks that had trouble finding buyers for the $790 million of bank loans that were part of the financing. Besides holding a part of the bank loans estimated at $130 million by The American Banker, a trade publication, sources said Bankers Trust also held subordinated debt in Magnet and stock in the new company.
The Magnet financing ran into trouble this summer when rising interest rates in Britain hurt the housing market and cut sales of Magnet's lumber products and construction supplies. In August, Bankers Trust said it stopped trying to sell portions of Magent's bank loans to other banks.
Analysts were puzzled by the large loss to a commodity merchant, because such loans are typically secured by either raw material or financial instruments whose values are closely monitored. They said the losses suggested either a weakness in lending controls at the bank, or fraud, or both.
''The loss in a loan for a leveraged buy-out raises again the issue of how much risk there is in those type loans,'' said Lawrence W. Cohn, an analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert, ''I expect that the loss will be an isolated incident and the quality of their portfolio will hold up,'' he said, though the burden of proof is now on the bank.
Mr. Cohn estimated that before yesterday's announcement, Bankers Trust would have earned $155 million to $160 million after taxes in the fourth quarter. The bank said earnings for the fourth quarter, would be reduced by $150 million before tax and $90 million after tax.
The announcement of the lending losses came after the close of stock market trading. Shares of Bankers Trust fell 37.5 cents, to 40.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Construction of Housing Fell 4.7% in November

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Housing starts dropped by 4.7 percent in November, pulled down by a big drop in multifamily construction.
Some analysts attributed the fall to high apartment vacancy rates, while others said the savings and loan bailout law was restricting loan money available even as many failed savings institutions were going out of business.
The Commerce Department said today that new houses and apartments were built at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.36 million units in November, down from 1.43 million in October. 
 
Building Permits Decline
Total housing starts for the first 11 months of the year were down 6.5 percent from the comparable period of 1988. Applications for building permits, a barometer of future housing activity, edged down by 1.7 percent in November, to an annual rate of 1.33 million, after rising by 2.8 percent in October.
Housing starts had jumped 12.9 percent in October, the sharpest increase since December 1986, after falling by 4.9 percent in September. But the October surge was the result of a 37.9 percent gain in multifamily starts, a rate that analysts agreed was unrealistic. Multifamily starts, which include apartments and condominiums, fell back by 14.4 percent, to 346,000 units, in November.
''The multifamily starts really were unsustainable in view of the high vacancy rates'' brought about by the high level of building in the early 1980's, said David Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association.
 
New Regulations Cited
John A. Tuccillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors, suggested that another reason for the decline ''may be the result of the new capital regulations for savings and loans, which make it more difficult for developers to get loans from thrifts for multifamily projects.''
The bailout law passed by Congress last summer requires savings and loan institutions to keep more of their own funds in reserve as a buffer between losses and Federal deposit insurance.
David Seiders, chief economist of the National Association of Home Builders, also pointed to the large number of failures among savings and loan associations, which have historically provided much of the housing construction funds. ''The industry is shrinking and shrinking fast,'' he said. ''Builders are having difficulty getting money. Credit lines are being cut back.''
 
Rise in Overall Trend
Single-family starts edged down by nine-tenths of 1 percent in November, to 1.02 million units, a decline that analysts consider of little significance because of the margin of error in the statistics. These starts had posted a 5.5 percent gain in October.
Richard Peach, deputy chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association, said the overall trend of single-family starts from April through September has been rising, largely because of lower mortgage rates.
The South had the steepest decline last month, down 11.3 percent, to 495,000 units, after rising 14.8 percent in October. Starts in the West also fell, down by 5.3 percent, to 375,000 units. Starts increased by 3.7 percent, to 305,000 units, in the Midwest and rose by 3.3 percent, to 295,000 units, in the Northeast.

HEADLINE: Stocks Decline Broadley; Dow Loses 1.92

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Stock prices declined broadly yesterday, as investors' worrries about the economy and the real estate market contributed to violent swings in the market.
While the Dow Jones industrial average lost only 1.92 points, to close at 2,695.61, the number of stocks declining on the New York Stock Exchange as a whole outnumbered those advancing by more than 2 to 1, with 1,021 stocks down and 513 up. Volume on the Big Board was a moderate 186.1 million shares, up slightly from 184.8 million on Tuesday.
In the first few hours of trading the Dow declined by nearly 30 points, but it bounced back soon after the White House said the consumer price data released by the Labor Department showed that inflation might be under control, raising hope of lower interest rates. The figures showed consumer prices had increased four-tenths of 1 percent in November from October, or at an annual rate of 4.9 percent. Another Government report showed a 4.7 percent decline in housing starts for the month. 
''The problem with real estate and the banks continued into today's market,'' said Thomas R. Walsh, head of equity trading at the Nikko Securities Company. ''You still have the core of the problems that you've had for a long time. I haven't seen much of a buy side for some time.''
Still, a few issues in the banking and mortgage sectors that suffered significant declines on Monday bounced back yesterday. Federal National Mortgage, known as Fannie Mae, rose 1 3/8, to 32 1/2; Bank of New England gained 1/2, to 8.
Some bank stocks remained weak. Chemical Bank was down 3/8, to 28 7/8; and J.P. Morgan slipped 3/8, to 40 1/4.
 
Move by Citicorp
Citicorp, the parent company of Citibank, moved up 1/8, to 27, after the bank said it was acquiring the merchant credit card processing business of the FCC National Bank. The First Chicago Corporation, parent of FCC, fell 1 1/4, to 34 3/8.
Shares of the Campbell Soup Company were up 4 3/4, to 54 1/2, on renewed takeover speculation because of the dissolution of a Dorrance family voting trust holding 25.6 percent of the company.
Shares of large computer companies gained yesterday. I.B.M. was up 1 1/8, to 94 3/4; Compaq Computer was up 2 1/8, to 80; Digital Equipment advanced 2 1/8, to 84 3/8; Apple Computer moved up 1/4, to 35; Hewlett-Packard advanced 1, to 45 1/2.
Philip Morris, the most actively traded issue on the Big Board, lost 1 1/8. Nearly three million shares changed hands after the company's Kraft General Foods subsidiary said Hershey Foods had agreed to purchase parts of its Ronzoni Foods unit. Hershey moved up 7/8, to 35 1/2. USX moved up 3/4, to 34 7/8, after an announcement by the Federal Trade Commission that it had given the investor Carl C. Icahn permission to buy additional shares of the steel and energy company.
Disney fell 2 5/8, to 123 3/8, as investors took profits from the stock's recent run-ups.
L.A. Gear, a maker of athletic wear, jumped 2 3/8, to 27 5/8, after a favorable analyst's report on the company was released.
Transportation stocks were slightly softer yesterday, with the Dow transportation average losing 1.61 points to finish at 1139.22. UAL, the parent of United Airlines, was the main bright spot. It advanced 4 1/2, to 158 1/2, on continued takeover speculation. AMR, the parent of American Airlines, moved up 2 3/4, to 60.
Broader market indexes showed a general weakening of equity prices. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 1.23, to 342.46, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index lost 0.77 to end the day at 189.40.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index lost 2.91 to end at 367.95.
On the Nasdaq exchange stocks were also weaker.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Little Changed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in light trading yesterday. Dealers sold some securities when it became apparent that the Federal Reserve Board was not prepared to ease credit conditions immediately.
The Fed, whose Open Market Committee completed two days of meetings yesterday, refrained from conducting open-market operations.
As a consequence of the Fed's inaction, ''the front end of the market is under a great deal of pressure,'' one trader said, referring to short-term securities. ''We are torn between people's perceptions that the economy is slipping into recession and a Fed which seems to disagree with that analysis.'' 
Economists at MMS International, an economic information and consulting firm, said in its daily commentary that ''the lack of Fed intervention severely reduces the chances of a pre-1990 easing, according to our forecasts.''
 
Adverse Impact on 2-Year Notes
The lack of a signal from the Fed that it wanted interest rates to decline had an adverse impact on the Treasury's auction of $10 billion worth of two-year notes.
The notes, which late Monday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.64 percent, were sold yesterday at an average yield of 7.71 percent. Nevertheless, the rate on the issue was down from the 7.78 percent average yield at the last two-year note sale on Nov. 28.
''There is no question we would have seen more participation by retail customers if the Fed had signaled that rates were coming lower,'' said Peter Bass, a managing director at S. G. Warburg Securities Inc. ''And the fact that the Fed has not eased casts some doubt on who will be bidding on the four-year notes on Wednesday.''
The $8 billion worth of four-year notes to be sold today were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 7.68 percent.
 
Banking Company Bonds Tumble
In other developments, fears about troubled real estate loans pounded prices of banking company bonds again yesterday.
''The market for bank paper is in complete disarray,'' one corporate bond trader said. ''Any bank, and especially any regional bank, is just getting destroyed. I have never seen anything like it.''
Banks with well-advertised real estate problems, like the Bank of New England, suffered the most. Late yesterday, for example, a Bank of New England 9 7/8 percent issue due in 1999 traded as low as 66, to yield 17.18 percent.
''Over the last two days, Bank of New England paper has traded down about 22 points,'' the trader said.
New Jersey's Midlantic Banks Inc., recently downgraded by major ratings agencies because of its troubled real estate portfolio, also suffered.
Yesterday Midlantic's 9.20 percent bonds of 1999 traded at a price to yield 11 percent, dealers said. As recently as a week ago, the bonds were offered at a price to yield 9.50 percent.
 
Consumer Price Report Ignored
In the Government markets, however, monitoring the Fed was the key element of yesterday's session, traders said. A report that consumer prices rose by four-tenths of a percentage point last month, slightly higher than anticipated, was largely ignored. So too was a report that housing starts in November fell by 4.7 percent.
As a consequence, prices were little changed in the secondary market for Treasury issues. By late in the day, the 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 103 10/32, unchanged on the day, to yield 7.83 percent. Among note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 3/4, up 1/32, to yield 7.76 percent. And the 8 percent seven-year notes were offered at 101 5/32, down 1/32, to yield 7.77 percent.
Treasury bill rates inched higher as the possibility of a quick easing in monetary policy by the Fed receded.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.64 percent, up four basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates moved up by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 6.45 percent.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, the State of Illinois sold $110 million worth of tax revenue bonds at competitive bid.
A bid from a group led by the investment banking subsidiary of Citicorp won the issue, which consists of serial and term bonds.
The serial bonds carry maturities from 1990 to 2009, and were reoffered to investors with coupons from 5.80 percent in 1990 to 6.90 percent in 2009.
The term bonds, which mature in 2019, carry a coupon of 7 percent.
The issue is rated Aa by Moody's Investors Service and AAA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary market for municipal bonds, dealers said that prices of most issues rose by an eighth to a quarter of a point in quiet trading.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Generally Higher But Is Down Against Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished slightly higher against most primary currencies yesterday but slipped against the Japanese yen in quiet trading.
Gold prices were narrowly mixed. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery edged up 10 cents an ounce, to $411.90. 
Currency analysts said trading had slowed in recent days as the holidays approached and as traders tried to protect whatever gains they might have made for the year.
''We are in a holiday trading period, and a lot of bank traders are not as active as they had been,'' said James Merrill, the senior international economist for McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei, a financial services company.
He said the currency markets appeared to be largely unaffected by new Government reports of a decline in housing starts and a slightly larger-than-expected rise in consumer prices last month.
The dollar traders were also wary about making big commitments until they got some indication from a meeting of Federal Reserve Board's Federal Open Market Committee on what course it has charted for monetary policy over the coming weeks.
If the Fed moves to lower interest rates, the dollar could be hurt since falling interest rates cut the returns that foreign investors receive on dollar-denominated investments.
The dollar's decline against the yen yesterday was attributed to speculation that the Bank of Japan may soon raise its key lending rate. Japanese officials denied rumors of an imminent rate increase, but speculation persisted that a rise would eventually be necessary to shore up the yen.
In late New York trading, the dollar had slipped to 143.65 yen, from 143.73 yen late on Monday. The pound weakened, falling to $1.6010 from $1.60685.
Other late-dollar rates in New York, compared with those late on Monday, included: 1.7365 West German marks, up from 1.7210; 1.5565 Swiss francs, up from 1.5410; 5.9275 French francs, up from 5.8800; 1,289.25 Italian lire, up from 1,285.00, and 1.16085 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16075.

HEADLINE: Disclosing Financial Data, Reader's Digest to Go Public

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
In moves that will give its shareholders greater liquidity and help it avoid potential tax problems, the Reader's Digest Association is going public.
The company, which announced the plan in May, said yesterday in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it would sell 25 million shares, or 10 percent of its nonvoting stock, at $18 to $22 each. That would raise at least $450 million.
The prospectus said that the company, based in Pleasantville, N.Y., would not receive any proceeds from the stock sale and that all proceeds would go to shareholders. Using those figures, the nonvoting shares alone could be worth $2.5 billion and the company about $3 billion. 
No voting stock in Reader's Digest is being sold.
 
Stock Held by Trust
The voting stock had been held by a trust of which the DeWitt Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund and the Lila Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund were the primary beneficiaries. The trust has been dissolved, and the voting stock is controlled by the funds.
The funds were established by the Wallaces, who founded the company in 1922. Various charitable institutions benefit from the trust, including the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Lincoln Center and Colonial Williamsburg in Virginia.
The nonvoting stock is held by the funds and the charitable organzations.
Reader's Digest reiterated yesterday that the sale would assure the publication's independence by keeping close control of its voting stock.
 
Holdings Must Be Lowered
Tax laws require that the funds reduce their voting stock holdings to 50 percent by the year 2000, and the company said in its prospectus that it planned to begin doing so. It said it would alter its employee profit-sharing plan to permit annual contributions to the plan of previously unissued voting stock. By the year 2000, the plan will have acquired up to 20 percent of the voting stock.
There was no indication of what would be done with the other 30 percent to comply with tax laws.
The prospectus gave some insight into the economics of one of the country's most private publishing companies. The data reflected the profitability of the company, which includes the magazine, special-interest publications and a book and home-video operation. The combined operations had sales of $1.83 billion in its 1989 fiscal year, which ended on June 30, and net income of $151 million. The previous year, its sales reached $1.7 billion and net income totaled $142 million.
Net income for the company in fiscal 1989 was about 8.3 percent of its sales, and its operating income was 11.3 percent of its sales.
A longtime magazine executive, John Mack Carter, who heads new magazine development for Hearst Magazines, noted that the figures represented about the industry average.
 
Profit Contributions
The prospectus also breaks down the various operation's contributions to profits. Book and home entertainment products constitute the largest component. In fiscal 1989, it had an operating profit of $192 million, on sales of $1.09 billion. Reader's Digest magazine had an operating profit of $61.6 million, on sales of $589.4 million.
At the magazine and the book divisions, operating profits fell in fiscal 1989. Regarding the magazine, the company said the decline was partly because of postal-rate increases, while it said books published by its book division had not been as popular with readers.
After the offering, the company said 119.1 million shares would be outstanding, of which 20 million would be voting and the remaining 99.1 million would be nonvoting common stock.
In the public offering, which will be managed by Lazard Freres & Company and Goldman, Sachs & Company, 21 million shares will be sold in the United States and 4 million abroad.
 
Fifteen Languages
Reader's Digest is published in 15 languages and has a monthly circulation of 29 million. The company also publishes The Family Handyman, Travel Holiday and New Choices for the Best Years, which is aimed at readers over 50 years old.
The prospectus also showed that the largest selling shareholder would be the DeWitt Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund, which owned 17.7 million shares and planned to sell 5.9 million shares. The second-largst seller is the Lila Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund, which owns 11.4 million shares and plans to sell 4.6 million.
The fund for the Metropolitan Museum of Art owns 11.7 million shares and will sell 2.5 million shares, while the fund for the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center will sell 860,000 shares and the Fund for Lincoln Center will sell 2.3 million shares.

HEADLINE: Herbert Blaize, 71, Grenada Chief Who Won Vote After the Invasion

BYLINE: By GLENN FOWLER

 BODY:
Prime Minister Herbert A. Blaize of Grenada, a longtime political figure in that Caribbean island nation who regained power after United States armed forces invaded to oust a leftist Government there in 1983, died yesterday morning at his official residence. He was 71 years old.
Mr. Blaize, who had suffered from cancer of the prostate for several years, died as he was preparing to leave for a hospital in St. George's, the nation's capital. In recent weeks Mr. Blaize was forced by deteriorating health to cancel most public appearances. On Dec. 5, he attempted to deliver a speech at a political luncheon but was unable to raise his voice and gave up after less than two minutes. 
A staunch admirer of Ronald Reagan, Mr. Blaize led a centrist coalition that won power in an election in 1984 and sought to bring stability and economic progress to Grenada after several years of turbulence that culminated in the killing of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop, a Marxist, in a military coup shortly before the American invasion.
Mr. Blaize was appointed Grenada's Chief Minister in 1960 by British authorities when the country, which now has a population of 85,000, was moving toward independence. He was defeated in a 1961 election by a right-wing rival, Sir Eric Gairy, but returned to office 18 months later when Sir Eric was forced to resign.
 
English Teacher in Aruba
Turned out of office again in 1967, Mr. Blaize remained in the opposition through the granting of complete independence in 1974. He put together the winning coalition in 1984 after the United States, with the cooperation of other Caribbean governments, forcefully intervened.
Born on Carriacou, a small island 30 miles northeast of St. George's, Mr. Blaize spent seven years as a clerk in the colonial civil service after graduating from secondary school. For several years, he worked for an American oil company on the island of Aruba as an English teacher but returned to Carriacou when he was disabled by a severe arthritic condition of the spine.
For a time, Mr. Blaize operated a shop selling soft drinks and beer. In 1964, he took a correspondence course in law that qualified him, after 10 years of study, to practice as a solicitor in Commonwealth countries.
Political foes routinely questioned his physical ability to carry on the duties of office. ''I'm not fooling myself that it's going to be easy,'' he said on the eve of the 1984 election that made him once again Prime Minister. ''It's definitely not going to be a tea party.''
Survivors include his wife, the former Venetia Davidson; a sister, Muriel Noel of Carriacou; three daughters, Norma Blaize, who is Consul-General of Grenada in New York; Val Jerome of Grenada and Marion Fleary, and three sons, Mario, Marvin and Chris Blaize of Brooklyn.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
GORBACHEV WINS VOTE ON ECONOMY

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 19

 BODY:
The Gorbachev leadership won legislative approval of its revamped economic program today, easily rebuffing a no-confidence vote from a thin weak line of opponents who warned that it amounted to a retreat from the promised reforms of perestroika.
The program, which was upheld by a vote of 1,532 to 419, endorses a slower pace than originally promised for backing away from the centrally controlled state economy. It would delay price reforms and other painful market innovations in an effort to increase supplies in the shops for long-suffering Soviet consumers. 
With the new Congress of People's Deputies subject to the one-party dominance of the Communist political machine, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was never in danger of losing the vote on his program, which offered a series of immediate economic shifts and free-market promises extending six years into the future.
 
Opposition Considered Surprising
The only surprising element in the debate was that the informal opposition group was emboldened to invoke a Western parliamentary practice and propose a vote of no confidence.
However, the members wered reluctant to do any such thing, and their timidity became clear in a 1,685-to-199 vote expressing confidence. Nonetheless, the opposition was unstinting in inviting the members to claim more of an active role for the new and uncertain national legislature.
Critics proposed amending the economic program, but the majority defeated this move, too, by an 8-to-1 margin.
Deputy Prime Minister Leonid I. Abalkin, a major economic adviser to President Gorbachev, accused the critics of trying to further destabilize the country during the current economic crisis period and termed the vote of confidence a victory of ''reason over emotions.'' Mr. Abalkin recently outlined economic proposals including firmer deadlines for approaching a market economy than those offered in the revised Gorbachev program that was voted on today.
 
Government's Reticence
At the heart of the Government's hesitancy is anxiety and uncertainty about how to make the promised move toward a free-market economy, given its threats of surging inflation and further popular unrest.
The traumatic shift requires letting currency and food prices float at the mercies of competitive forces, with the Government no longer controlling them.
At the recent summit talks with President Bush in Malta, Mr. Bush promised to help Mr. Gorbachev in his hopes of entering the world trade market. The revamped economic plan, announced after the summit talks, was questioned by officials of the Bush Administration, who said that procrastination in market reform could undercut Mr. Bush's pledges.
In scaling back the timetable, Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov told the congress that ''if, contrary to objective reason, we should try to introduce full-fledged market relations by 1991, it would bring us to serious socio-economic upheaval, a new stage of galloping inflation, falling production, mass unemployment and aggravation of social tensions.'' Betrayal of Perestroika? Critics denounced the latest plan as a betrayal by Mr. Gorbachev of his promise of economic restructuring by resorting to more of the old five-year planning techniques that made the central economic plan a recipe for failure in the world marketplace.
The latest plan would shift investments from industrial change that Government planners consider the key to change and put those resources into an attempt to stir more and better consumer products from Soviet factories.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Congress, Not Bush, Ponders Peace Issue

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Congress is out of session, but Representative Lee H. Hamilton, chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, would not wait until the lawmakers reconvene in January. Today he held his second hearing in two weeks on ''Economic Adjustment After the Cold War.''
Two Senate committees, Budget and Armed Services, have also already held hearings on what has come to be called the ''peace dividend'' - the money that will become available as military spending is reduced because of improved relations with the Soviet Union. And about 10 other committees are lining up witnesses for hearings on the subject early in the new year.
In addition, the issue is likely to be a main topic when the American Economic Association meets in Atlanta next week. 
But, as best as can be learned, no one in the White House or elsewhere in the Bush Administration has been assigned to focus on the issue. No team of specialists has been formed to study how to use the money. No interagency working group has been established. No senior official has asked his professional staff for advice.
Many of the scores of economists in the Treasury and Commerce departments, in the Office of Management and Budget and on the staff of the President's Council of Economic Advisers have their own views, and they will discuss them if they are promised anonymity. But since they do not know what the Administration's policy is or is likely to be, they will not talk for the record.
''We are much too preoccupied with the immediate year to think about five or 10 years out,'' said one such official who has been working night and day on the budget proposals President Bush will send Congress on Jan. 22.
Some of the economists think it is useless to begin planning now for money that will not be on the books for many years. ''I have seen so many stupid results of long-term planning that I have no confidence in it,'' said one official, recalling the predictions of the 1970's that crude oil prices in the 80's would be $60 a barrel - three times what they are now.
But most Government economists believe the Administration will be negligent if it does not begin making plans.
''We know we're going to be wrong,'' said one economist in a senior position. ''We know unknowns will occur. Nonetheless, if you don't think through what the possibilities are, you're liable to have such a narrow focus that you're unable to respond to the possibilities when some of them turn out to be true.''
The top policy makers say the pace of change in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe has been so rapid that they cannot be fairly criticized for not having drawn a blueprint for how to use the peace dividend. Who knows, they ask, whether tensions have been reduced permanently? Who knows by how much military spending can be cut? Who knows when it can be done?
In any event, they say, the $5 billion or $10 billion or even $20 billion that might become available in the next year or two can be used for nothing but reducing the budget deficit. After all, next year alone, $40 billion has to be found to bring the deficit down to the $64 billion target of the budget-balancing law for the fiscal year 1991, which begins Oct. 1.
That kind of thinking seems shortsighted to Representative Hamilton.
''It seems clear that we will soon be faced with major choices about how to employ the peace dividend,'' Mr. Hamilton, an Indiana Democrat, said at the outset of the hearing today. ''Should it be used for deficit reduction, tax cuts, new spending programs or some combination of those purposes? Is this an appropriate occasion for a major reordering of priorities? Will the size of the budgetary savings make a difference in performance of the economy on a national or regional level, and should government policies be modified accordingly?''
Experts disagree on the answers to those questions; Mr. Hamilton says he wants to hear as many as possible before he makes up his own mind.
Indeed, it is the lawmakers who will eventually force the Administration to take a stand. ''Sooner or later, probably in the next month or two, we're going to be called to testify,'' a senior Administration official said. ''We're going to have to have some answers prepared. Before that, we'll sit down and really talk about it.''

HEADLINE: Fighting in Panama: The Implications;
War: Bush's Presidential Rite of Passage

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
For George Bush, the United States invasion of Panama early this morning constituted a Presidential initiation rite as well as an attempt to achieve specific goals.
For better or for worse, most American leaders since World War II have felt a need to demonstrate their willingness to shed blood to protect or advance what they construe as the national interest. John F. Kennedy in the Cuban missile crisis, Lyndon B. Johnson and Richard M. Nixon in South Vietnam, Gerald R. Ford in the Mayaguez affair, Ronald Reagan in Grenada and Lebanon, and now Mr. Bush in Panama - all of them acted in the belief that the American political culture required them to show the world promptly that they carried big sticks.
Jimmy Carter did not do it until he sought unsuccessfully to rescue American hostages in Iran late in his term, and politicians of both parties still believe that it cost him dear.
For President Bush - a man widely criticized as recently as a month ago for his purported timidity, a man assailed on Capitol Hill and elsewhere for failing to fully support an attempted coup against General Noriega only in October, a man still portrayed in the Doonesbury comic strip as the invisible President - showing his steel had a particular significance. 
 
Achievement and Annoyance
Whatever the other results of this roll of the dice in Panama, it has shown him as a man capable of bold action, especially coming, as it did, on the heels of his Malta summit talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his surprise initiative toward China.
In a narrower sense, Mr. Bush sought to remove a burr from under his saddle in the person of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, and he appears to have done that, at least in part.
Even though the Panamanian leader was not immediately captured, kept control of his radio station, could remain at large for months and may have left behind mini-Noriegas with disruptive capacities of their own, he appears to have little capacity now to exercise real power.
''We have cut off the head of that government,'' said Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. ''Yesterday's 'maximum leader' is today's hunted fugitive,'' said Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. Most experts agreed with their assessments.
Mr. Bush also sought, in Lyndon Johnson's words, to ''protect my people'' - the 35,000 Americans living in Panama, toward whose safety and well-being General Noriega seemed to have grown indifferent. That he also achieved, although some American hostages were apparently taken. But these things have their costs. Last spring, Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., General Powell's predecessor, told a Congressional committee that using military force in a place like Panama could be ''a messy, messy business.'' In the fall, Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney said that direct military intervention would seriously damage United States relations with the other countries of Latin America. Both proved right.
And only last night, Mr. Nixon told a group of senators on Capitol Hill that General Noriega was the sort of man who should be left to fall of his own weight.
 
The Risks Bush Took
Mr. Bush thought otherwise, and he risked many things in acting as he did: the prospect of an American military involvement that may well last for days and weeks, rather than hours, and might end up looking more like Vietnam than like Grenada; the possibility of a long and decidedly unheroic slog through the jungles and mountains of the isthmus in search of General Noriega, if he has indeed taken to the bush -an elephant tracking a gnat; the certainty of a hostile reaction in many Latin American capitals, and the chance that the Soviet Union would take serious umbrage at the American strike, despite the operation's confident code name, ''Operation Just Cause.''
The President issued his orders in the knowledge that he might be confronted, just before Christmas, with the awful spectacle of American soldiers in grim gray body bags being brought home for burial.
Most important of all, perhaps, he knowingly ran the risk that democracy, so often a failure in Panama, would again refuse to take root there, leaving the United States where it has been in the past, looking like an imperialist adjudicator between rivals for power.
''The big question,'' said Ambler Moss, a former United States Ambassador to Panama, now at the University of Miami, ''is whether the people we are backing can start looking and acting like a government, which is the only way this operation will gain any legitimacy and credibility. It's ominous that after 18 hours, they still hadn't raised their heads or even made a broadcast.''
 
The Anti-American Strain
Perhaps because of popular fears that General Noriega might somehow come back, perhaps because of deep-seated distrust of the Colossus of the North as the United States is called in Latin America, there was little early show of support for American intervention in the streets of Panama City or elsewhere.
Guillermo Endara, whom the United States considers the winner of May's Panamanian presidential elections, which General Noriega nullified, was sworn in at midnight Tuesday night as president - but in secret, on an American base, months after the voting.
Secretary Baker argued that the United States incursion had been made to ''assist a democratically elected government,'' and Mr. Bush said that he had acted to restore democracy. But as Robert J. Kurz of the Brookings Institution pointed out, there has not been a democratic government in Panama and Mr. Endara had not functioned for a single hour as the country's head of state.
Indeed, his mandate stems largely from the conclusion of international observers that Mr. Endara would have won, had the ballot results not been tampered with. That verdict was not accepted by the Organization of American States, which permitted a Noriega delegate to continue as Panama's representative pending fresh elections, and the moral claim of the Endara ''government'' has weakened as the months passed.
 
Mexico's Polite Outrage
The Latin American reaction, even from those nations that have led the way in branding General Noriega an outlaw, was furious. Mexico, for example, said that ''fighting international crimes is no excuse for intervention in a sovereign nation.'' Memories of gunboat diplomacy - a phrase used often today in world capitals - run deep.
But United States relations with Latin America have been unusually good in recent years, which may count for something, and recent history suggests that there are ways to heal wounds relatively quickly. One might be a major economic assistance program for Panama in concert with leading Latin nations.
Mr. Moss recalled that American intervention in the Dominican Republic in 1965, during the Johnson Administration, had been ''clumsy at first, like this one.'' But the appointment of Ellsworth Bunker, a highly skilled diplomatic operative, as ambassador, and the injection of large amounts of American money rapodly improved relations between the two governments.
Soviet spokesmen, official and unofficial, were almost as condemnatory as some Latin Americans, and spokesmen in Washington were obviously uncomfortable in trying to explain why the United States praised Moscow for its new policy of nonintervention and then intervened itself.
Georgi A. Arbatov, one of the top Kremlin experts on the United States, struck a nerve when he said that the American action would strengthen ''the Soviet military-industrial complex'' in its contention that Soviet disarmament and reform were serious mistakes in the face of American bellicosity.
 
When All Else Fails
Even if that is correct, the failure of past American policies, in which Mr. Bush had a major hand, had left him with very few alternatives. Negotiations, sanctions, elections, international mediation, veiled military threats, spontaneous coups and an unending flow of superheated proclamations from Washington had all failed to remove or isolate General Noriega.
''The difficulty of dislodging him was grossly underestimated by the officials in charge of formulating the anti-Noriega policy,'' writes Linda Robinson, a senior editor of Foreign Affairs, in the quarterly's winter issue. ''The basic problem is that there is a substantial gap between the ends the United States has defined in Panama and the means it has so far been willing to employ there.''
Unprepared to scale down the objective - getting rid of General Noriega - Mr. Bush finally decided to scale up the means he would authorize.

LENGTH: 795 words

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
U.S. Ambassador No Longer Keeps His Poles Apart

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW

 BODY:
It was George Bush's first visit to Poland, and when talk over dinner turned to Solidarity, the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, picked at his food and said the banned union no longer existed. It was just a bunch of people that John Davis was always having to dinner.
The time was 1987, Solidarity was still largely underground and the Communist leaders around General Jaruzelski did not dream of letting the outlawed union help drag Poland out of a deep crisis of the economy and the spirit.
Two years later, when Mr. Bush returned as President, Solidarity was restored and its candidates had just swept Poland's freest elections in over four decades. Had he waited a few weeks, he would have seen John Davis's dinner guests forming their own Government, the first in Eastern Europe since World War II not dominated by Communists. 
After reaching the sooty splendor of Warsaw in early 1983, the seasoned, pipe-smoking American diplomat continued practicing the fine art of not mixing his Poles. But last July, at a reception during President Bush's visit, Communists mingled with Solidarity people, former prisoners clinked glasses with their jailers.
 
Smiles and Nods
The result is that Ambassador John R. Davis Jr. now commands attention and respect in Poland. It is no small success. In a recent moment of euphoria, the wife of a Solidarity Government minister not only described him as a brilliant diplomat but numbered him among those she said had worked Poland's remarkable transformation: Lech Walesa, General Jaruzelski, the Pope and John Davis.
Not flamboyant, but a communicator by smiles and nods who asks more questions than he gives answers, Mr. Davis has gained unusual access to all sides in the Polish conflict. The relationship with Solidarity is so relaxed that his wife, Helen, has begun teaching English to Solidarity's freshmen legislators.
The warmth was not always evenly spread. When Poland refused in 1983 to accept a new American Ambassador, President Reagan sent Mr. Davis as charge d'affaires. Mr. Davis, a diplomat with experience in Italy and Australia in addition to two previous tours in Poland, was then director of the State Department's Eastern European office.
Many Poles knew Mr. Davis from the earlier tours in Warsaw, where he and Mrs. Davis, an engaging and energetic woman, and their three children had acquired fluent Polish and made many friends.
 
Outsider's Eye
Government bureaucrats were ordered not to see him, and those who did required permits. But when the Davises invited 100 people to a reception at the residence, a red-brick building on the edge of Warsaw, 140 showed up. On the Fourth of July, Government people had orders to leave a traditional feast when a senior Foreign Ministry official did. Few, however, knew the man. So they stayed on, enjoying the food, drinks and conviviality.
Poles say they appreciate the Ambassador's uncanny feel for their nation.
Janusz Onyszkiewicz, Solidarity's national spokesman, said, ''He somehow managed to reconcile two things that sometimes appear irreconcilable: to keep the eye of the outside observer but also to think the way Poles think.''
Mr. Onyszkiewicz's wife, Johanna, added, ''He has an instinctive grasp, and, of course, politics in Poland is mostly intuitive.''
During the drawn-out Senate confirmation hearings that led to his appointment as Ambassador in 1988, when Warsaw and Washington restored full diplomatic relations, there was talk that Mr. Davis had pressed Lech Walesa into saying American sanctions had served their purpose and should be lifted. Mr. Walesa's assurances ultimately helped prompt the Reagan Administration to dismantle the last of the curbs that had been imposed to protest the imposition of martial law in December 1981.
 
Conduit to All Sides
In the end, Mr. Davis was confirmed, and Solidarity leaders still call the charge absurd.
''John communicates with smiles and a puff of the pipe,'' Mr. Onyszkiewicz said. ''He never told us what to do, but he asked very intelligent questions. Sometimes he asked the questions that showed our tremendous weaknesses. But he always knew his role as someone who was not trying to influence us.''
In time, Ambassador Davis became a conduit to all sides in the conflict - a special circumstance in a country where politics was played out above and below ground with few interconnecting links.
These days, much of his time is spent playing host to American visitors who flock to Warsaw to witness the remarkable transformations. He likes to tell businessmen that those who get in first get the best pickings.
At 62, Ambassador Davis is not thinking of stopping soon, and few Poles wish him to. When it is over, Helen Davis hopes he will write a memoir.

HEADLINE: Fighting in Panama: The President;
A Transcript of Bush's Address on the Decision to Use Force in Panama

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of the address by President Bush from the White House at 7 A.M. today, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:
Fellow citizens, last night I ordered U.S. military forces to Panama.
No President takes such action lightly. This morning, I want to tell you what I did and why I did it.
For nearly two years, the United States, nations of Latin America and the Caribbean have worked together to resolve the crisis in Panama. The goals of the United States have been to safeguard the lives of Americans, to defend democracy in Panama, to combat drug trafficking and to protect the integrity of the Panama Canal Treaty. Many attempts have been made to resolve this crisis through diplomacy and negotiations. All were rejected by the dictator of Panama, Gen. Manuel Noriega, an indicted drug trafficker. Last Friday, Noriega declared his military dictatorship to be in a state of war with the United States and publicly threatened the lives of Americans in Panama. The very next day forces under his command shot and killed an unarmed American serviceman, wounded another, arrested and brutally beat a third American serviceman and then brutally interrogated his wife, threatening her with sexual abuse. That was enough. 
General Noriega's reckless threats and attacks upon Americans in Panama created an eminent danger to the 35,000 American citizens in Panama. As President, I have no higher obligation than to safeguard the lives of American citizens. And that is why I directed our armed force to protect the lives of American citizens in Panama, and to bring General Noriega to justice in the United States. I contacted the bipartisan leadership of Congress last night and informed them of this decision, and after taking this action, I also talked with leaders in Latin America, the Caribbean, and those of other U.S. allies.
 
Lifting of U.S. Sanctions
At this moment, U.S. forces, including forces deployed from the United States last night, are engaged in action in Panama. The United States intends to withdraw the forces newly deployed to Panama as quickly as possible. All forces have conducted themselves courageously and selflessly, and as Commander in Chief, I salute everyone of them and thank them on behalf of our country.
Tragically, some Americans have lost their lives in defense of their fellow citizens, in defense of democracy, and my heart goes out to their families. We also regret and mourn the loss of innocent Panamanians.
The brave Panamanians elected by the people of Panama in the elections last May, President Guillermo Endara and Vice Presidents Calderon and Ford have assumed the rightful leadership of their country. You remember those horrible pictures of newly-elected Vice President Ford covered head to toe with blood, beaten mercilessly by so-called dignity battalions. Well, the United States today recognizes the democratically elected Government of President Endara. I will send our Ambassador back to Panama immediately. Key military objectives have been achieved. Most organized resistance has been eliminated. But the operation is not over yet. General Noriega is in hiding. And nevertheless, yesterday, a dictator ruled Panama, and today, constitutionally-elected govern - elected leaders govern.
I have today directed the Secretary of the Treasury and the Secretary of State to lift the economic sanctions with respect to the democratically elected Government of Panama, and in cooperation with that Government, to take steps to effect an orderly unblocking of Panamanian Government assets in the United States.
 
Reasons for Military Action
I am fully committed to implement the Panama Canal Treaties and turn over the Canal to Panama in the year 2000. The actions we have taken and the cooperation of a new democratic Government in Panama will permit us to honor these commitments. As soon as the new Government recommends a qualified candidate, Panamanian, to be administrator of the canal, as called for in the treaties, I will submit this nominee to the Senate for expedited consideration.
I am committed to strengthening our relationship with the democratic nations in this hemisphere. I will continue to seek solutions to the problems of this region through dialogue and multilateral diplomacy.
I took this action only after reaching the conclusion that every other avenue was closed and the lives of American citizens were in grave danger.
I hope that the people of Panama will put this dark chapter of dictatorship behind them and move forward together as citizens of a democratic Panama with this Government that they themselves have elected.
The United States is eager to work with the Panamanian people in partnership and friendship to rebuild their economy. The Panamanian people want democracy, peace, and the chance for a better life in dignity and freedom. The people of the United States seek only to support them in pursuit of these noble goals.
Thank you very much.

GRAPHIC: Photo of President Bush monitoring events in Panama from the White House with John H. Sununu, right, White House chief of staff, and Brent Scowcroft, national security adviser. (White House photograph via Reuters)

PUB-DATE: December 21, 1989

SECTION: Section A; Page 22, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1003 words

HEADLINE: Fighting in Panama: A New Government;
The 3 Panamanians Who'll Lead Where Noriega Held Sway

 BODY:

Guillermo Endara
Guillermo Endara, a 54-year-old lawyer who was sworn in yesterday as the new President of Panama, was virtually unknown in Panamanian politics until last year, when he emerged as the compromise candidate of a three-party anti-Noriega group called the Civilian Democratic Opposition Alliance.
Like other members of the opposition, Mr. Endara, representing the Authentic Liberal Party, was resolutely anti-Noriega. But he was equally opposed to American military action.
''We are not in accord with military intervention by any country,'' Mr. Endara said last spring, soon after General Noriega nullified the results of the presidential election. ''It will cause more problems than it solves.'' Mr. Endara, a widower known for his amiable manner and ample girth, is believed by many to have defeated the pro-Noriega candidate, Carlos Duque, by a margin of 3 to 1. 
Three days after the May 7 election, Mr. Endara and his two vice-presidential running mates were beaten by paramilitary thugs as they led an opposition motorcade through Panama City. Mr. Endara was hospitalized for a week with head injuries.
Over the summer, with public opposition to General Noriega at a low ebb, Mr. Endara sought to step up the economic pressure by urging Panamanians to delay paying taxes and utility bills, and to boycott the state-controlled lottery and casinos.
Discouraged by the response, Mr. Endara began a two-week hunger strike on Sept. 20, announcing that it was in protest of the National Assembly's appointment of Franciso A. Rodriguez as president. Lying on a hospital bed in the window of a downtown office building, Mr. Endara is believed to have shed at least 30 of his 265 pounds - and stirred many jokes in the process.
Two weeks later, on Oct. 5, hours after the second abortive military coup against General Noriega in two years, armed men ransacked opposition-party headquarters and Mr. Endara fled into hiding, where he remained until yesterday's strike.
 
Ricardo Arias Calderon
For months, Ricardo Arias Calderon, 56, a philosophy professor who became leader of Panama's Christian Democratic Party, was considered Mr. Endara's strongest rival for the opposition nomination for the presidency. But Mr. Arias Calderon, whose sometimes austere personality has been overshadowed by Mr. Endara's warmth, settled for a spot as candidate for first vice president.
But as Panama's political crisis worsened, it was almost invariably Mr. Arias Calderon who stepped forward to articulate the views of the opposition.
He seemed especially presidential in March 1988, when the Government allowed him to return from a brief period of exile and he gave a moving speech to supporters at the airport. ''We have but one objective,'' he said. ''To get rid of Noriega and build reconciliation and democracy in Panama.''
Like his running mates, Mr. Arias Calderon is no stranger to physical violence at the hands of the Panamanian military. In June 1987, as General Noriega found himself faced with a rising wave of street demonstrations and general strikes, Mr. Arias Calderon and his wife were clubbed by the riot police during a demonstration.
Last May 10, he was wounded when paramilitary men attacked the same opposition motorcade in which Mr. Endara was hurt. And in early October, shortly before the unsuccessful military coup, Mr. Arias Calderon and eight companions were detained for 20 hours and questioned about their role in the opposition campaign to convince Panamanians to deprive the Government of tax revenues.
Despite his appreciation for American support against General Noriega, Mr. Arias Calderon made it clear over the years that he had few illusions about the relationship of the United States and the General. ''The chief interest of the Americans here is the security of the Panama Canal,'' he said in June 1986. ''In all these years, they have known exactly what Noriega was doing. But now they are against him because they feel he is a source of instability rather than stability.''
 
Guillermo Ford
Although Guillermo Ford was the junior vice-presidential candidate in May's presidential elections, for a time he eclipsed his two running mates as the country's most recognizable anti-Noriega leader.
For many Panamanians, the 53-year-old Mr. Ford's slashing stump style and brusque manner seemed to project a machismo that contrasted favorably with the cautious approach of other opposition figures, whose defiance of the Noriega regime seemed limited to waving white handkerchiefs, honking corn horns and banging pots.
Yet he made it clear that he had no plans to help lead the opposition into a suicidal charge. ''We're not going to ask our people to confront these monsters,'' Mr. Ford said on May 13, three days after he and his associates were beaten during an opposition motorcade. ''We're not going to take them to the butcher shop.''
For Americans, Mr. Ford's prominence was assured by his command of idiomatic English, his nickname of Billy, and especially by stirring pictures of him taken on May 10. He was shown clad in a shirt soaked with his slain bodyguard's blood, being pummeled by a club-swinging vigilate thug.
At the time of his nomination by the Nationalist Liberal Republican Party, known by its Spanish acronym of Molirena, Mr. Ford, a businessman, was a self-described political novice. But he was so successful at forging a following that many suspected that the motorcade attack might well have been an murder attempt aimed principally at him. Mr. Ford was in the United States at the time of the failed october coup. A day later, he discussed it with President Bush.
''I looked Bush straight in the eye and he told me he'd do whatever it takes to get Noriega out, that nothing has been ruled out,'' Mr. Ford said. ''He said he would not allow a dictator like Noriega to make a fool of the United States and the rest of the world.'' At the time, Mr. Ford said, Mr. Bush did not offer any hint of what he might have in mind.

HEADLINE: Fighting in Panama: The U.S. and Noriega

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
For more than two and a half years General Manuel Antonio Noriega enraged, embarrassed and eluded the grasp of two successive Administrations.
The Panamanian military leader was accused of shredding the results of an election last May, making millions through drug deals and money laundering, spying against the United States and slaying his political enemies. President Bush has portrayed him as the bad guy in a pulp crime novel, a Latin American ''narcoterrorist'' corrupting the youth of America.
The general, with his intense nationalism and anti-Americanism, his ambition and shrewdness, came to represent all that the United States found offensive in a leader. He resisted pleas that he relinquish power, rejected promises of safe haven in a third country, spurned threats of United States military intervention, survived intense economic pressure and diplomatic censure and defied indictments on drug-trafficking charges in American courts. In short, General Noriega dared to challenge the image of the United States as a world power. 
 
The End of a Battle
Today's invasion effectively ends a battle between President Bush and General Noriega that dates from last year's American Presidential race. As part of a campaign of psychological warfare against Mr. Bush, General Noriega spread the word that he had ''something on Bush'' that would prevent the United States from moving against Panama.
Mr. Bush also was plagued by speculation that the Reagan Administration knew about General Noriega's involvement in drug trafficking and money laundering for several years and did nothing to stop it. When an embarrassing photo of a 1983 meeting between Mr. Bush and General Noriega in Panama City surfaced last year, Panamanian opposition leaders said that the meeting was to discuss money laundering of drug profits through Panama while Bush aides called it a routine stopover to discuss drug interdiction efforts.
General Noriega was believed to have been on the payroll of the Central Intelligence Agency, and critics of Mr. Bush argued that the President, who was Director of Central Intelligence in 1976, had material that should have prompted him to play a more active role in limiting this country's dealings with the general.
Mr. Bush responded that seven administrations had dealt with General Noriega, an assertion that was confirmed by Government officials at the time. Government officials said that in 1976, when Mr. Bush headed the C.I.A., and General Noriega was Panama's intelligence chief, their paths crossed for the first of several times.
Trained by the United States at the School of the Americas and the head of military intelligence for more than a decade, General Noriega simultaneously cultivated relationships of expediency with the Drug Enforcement Administration and the Colombian drug cartel leaders, with Israel and Libya and Nicaragua. He manipulated his way to the head of the Panama Defense Forces in 1983, becoming the de facto leader of the strategically located country of 2.2 million people.
Successive Administrations were willing to ignore General Noriega's excesses, largely because of his cooperation on matters of intelligence and drug trafficking. In 1985, when Dr. Hugo Spadafora was slain in Panama after he publicly accused General Noriega of drug-trafficking, United States policy remained unchanged, despite reports by American intelligence that connected Dr. Spadafora's death to Panama's Defense Forces.
 
Officer Charges Fraud
The current crisis dates from the summer of 1987, when Col. Roberto Diaz Herrera, the military's second in command, gave details of fraud in the 1984 presidential election and accused General Noriega of drug trafficking. After violent street demonstrations, General Noriega declared a state of emergency, and the United States hinted that Panama would be better off without its leader, a campaign that intensified after he was indicted by two Florida Federal grand juries on drug-trafficking charges.
Relations between the two nations deteriorated further when General Noriega voided the results of the presidential election last May and then sent paramilitary forces into the streets of Panama City, where they beat up opposition candidates.
Another crucial point came last October when a group of Panamanian military officers tried to oust General Noriega. A key element in the coup's failure was a counterattack by a unit loyal to General Noriega, a unit that might have been blocked by a show of force at a bridge across the Panama Canal.
American units were in the area of the bridge and could have secured it. Mr. Bush was harshly criticized for his decision not to do so. The coup leader, Maj. Moises Giroldi Vega, and some of his men were killed. Others were arrested, and the rest fled to the United States.
 
The Final Straw
Last week, in what turned out to be a final blow to Panama-United States relations, General Noriega had himself named head of state and declared his country in a ''''state of war'' against the United States. A day later, an American marine officer died at the hands of the General's Defense Forces. Mr. Bush lost his patience and decided to take military action that in a way reflected General Noriega's own political philosophy, expressed in his 1975 manual on psychological warfare: use ''astuteness before threats or violence,'' but be prepared to ''exterminate'' enemies in a ''cold and calculating way.''
