HEADLINE: In Depressed Farm Belt, Cultivating Self-Reliance

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ROBBINS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GREEN CITY, Mo., Dec. 14

 BODY:
Three years after the agricultural economy began slowly and unevenly to struggle out of its deepest recession in half a century, rural America is still freckled with small towns and small farms that the recovery left behind, places like the Green Hills region of northern Missouri.
But the Green Hills had one advantage over most places. It had Jack McCall, a sort of missionary of rural development, who came to the region about 16 years ago with a message that has proved an inspiration.
And now the University of Missouri is ''packaging'' Mr. McCall, so to speak. Last year it published his 43-page ''Small Town Survival Manual,'' and it is now distributing his message around the world. 
 
Allies and Disciples
The book, Mr. McCall says, is a distillation of the education he has gained as a University of Missouri Extension Service specialist, dealing with the towns and people of the Green Hills who helped him fight back against hard times. He has allies like Ellen Dolan and Joy Jackson and disciples like Linda Robinson, Jeannine (Aunt Nene) Williams, Doris and Louis Ayers and the Rev. James Rardin.
Mr. Rardin, a Methodist minister, said:
''Jack said you've got to stop sitting around hoping that some big industry is going to come along and save you. He said you've got to look to your own resources. Well, the resource we had was people.''
Here in the Green Hills, as elsewhere in rural America, many of those people also had ideas for making money not through large-scale agriculture but through small enterprises, many of them making use of farm products, others making use of the farm people's spare time.
 
From Energy and Curiosity
In Mr. Rardin's case, in Green City, a town with a population of about 700, the enterprise also stemmed from the minister's energy and curiosity. In October 1987, he recalls, he began calling companies ''to find out what we could do for them.''
Soon, he says, he had made several deals and was hiring workers from neighboring farms for the new business, ASI, for American Syscomptel Inc. A local variety-store proprietor, Doris Ayers, sold out her inventory, and she and her husband, Louis, invested in ASI and offered their building as an assembly shop.
The new company employs 25 to 45 people, depending on the amount of orders at hand. She now manages the business, whose clients include small telephone companies commissioning the assembling of products ranging from telephone cords and computer cables.
At the nearby village of Trenton, a county seat with a population of 6,800, Ellen Dolan and Joy Jackson are allies, if not exactly disciples, of Mr. McCall.
 
Bringing the Proceeds Back
The company they run aims to help add value to farm products, to sell them around the world and to bring the proceeds back to the farm communities and small towns where most of their clients are based - operations, for example, like the family concern of Alewel's Country Meats of Warrensburg, Mo.
This company, called Amtex, for American Trade Exchange, was formed in 1986, the depth of the farm recession, by Mrs. Dolan, her husband, Gary, and several other farmers and executives.
Experienced guidance was hard to find. ''After all,'' Mrs. Dolan said, ''there aren't many international trading companies in rural America.''
But one of the first responses made the business seem disarmingly simple. Mrs. Dolan wrote to Sam Walton, the founder of Wal-Mart, and asked for a chance to show their offerings. The letter brought an invitation to the company's headquarters in Bentonville, Ark.
Still, it took 18 months to get an order, for oat bran. It was the business's first sale, and the commission carried the owners through many dry months.
 
Local Markets Are Not Enough
They decline to say exactly how much that sale amounted to or how much they have sold since. They will say they represent the products of 50 clients, including specialists in smoked meats, ginseng producers, hatcheries and wineries. They have exhibited their wares at trade shows from Boston to Seattle and have lined up buyers as far away as Singapore and Tokyo.
One of the people helped by both Amtex and Mr. McCall is Jeannine Williams of Aunt Nene's Specialty Foods in nearby Lucerne. She and her husband, Bud, lost their farm, she said, after ''everything that could happen did happen, from hail to floods and drought.''
Mrs. Williams says Mr. McCall was a motivating force. ''He said, 'Look to your own assets and add value,' '' she recalled. ''I decided, 'I'm going to sell some of this stuff I've been giving away.' ''
She got out some old family recipes, had some fancy labels made and began producing jars of pickles and jellies. She now employs five women to help with preserving and pickling, although the rest is largely a family operation.
 
A Staff of 14 Busy Hands
On a hill on the other side of Lucerne is a farmhouse where another McCall disciple, Linda Robinson, is making a still more ambitious effort. What started as a crafts sideline that her husband, David, said, ''put the food on the table'' is now a booming business. At a shop in her basement - ''The Paintin' Place'' - she employs seven women.
She also employs 24 contractors who have cottage industries of their own supplying a business she calls Forever Friends with such things as molded porcelain heads for clown dolls and carved and painted wall decorations.
''I always remembered what Jack McCall said at that meeting in Unionville,'' she said. ''I remember him saying, 'Above everything else, you've got to have quality.' ''

HEADLINE: Presque Isle Journal;
Changes On Horizon In Fields Of Potatoes

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRESQUE ISLE, Me., Dec. 14

 BODY:
Since World War II, the three-week school vacation known as the potato harvest recess has been a fixture of autumn in northern Maine.
But last month, citing the increasing mechanization of farms and a resulting decline in the number of children working during the harvest, school officials voted to eliminate the recess beginning in 1991.
Farmers are furious. They say the loss of student workers will ripple through the economy, causing farmers to earn less money because they will plant fewer acres if they cannot depend on help at harvest time. Some go so far as to predict that farmers will go out of business or decide to retire. 
''They've been making us get down on our hands and knees and beg for the recess for the last five years,'' said Scott Smith, who with his brother runs his family's potato farm in Mapleton, just outside Presque Isle. ''But I look at it and I say we're supporting these schools quite heavily, and they're not willing to help us.''
Here in Aroostook County, where the wide rolling fields are covered now with several feet of snow, growing potatoes is big business, bringing in $110 million to 650 farms this year. Potatoes are Maine's biggest cash crop, the Maine Department of Agriculture says. And although the number of acres planted, 80,000 in 1989, has dropped every year since a high of 200,000 in World War II, Maine remains the fifth-largest potato-growing state in the nation, after Idaho, Washington, Wisconsin and Oregon.
Farmers here have come to rely on student help to make sure they get their crop harvested in a short period, a matter of a few weeks from mid-September to early October, between the time the potatoes are big enough to pick and the time the ground freezes. (Schools in northeastern Idaho schedule a recess for the same reason, said John Rooney, the executive director of the Potato Growers of Idaho.) But officials in School Administrative District 1, which covers Presque Isle and four surrounding towns, said that each year the number of students involved in the harvest had decreased. Last fall, about a third of the 700 high school students worked picking, hauling or storing potatoes.
''It used to be the majority, but now we're dealing with the minority,'' said Linda Pelletier, a school board member. ''You see kids hanging around downtown on the streets, in vehicles. They don't have anything to do, and you have to keep teen-agers busy.''
The district had already eliminated the recess for the elementary and middle schools because of a change in Federal law that prohibits anyone younger than 16 from working on a mechanical harvester. Few farmers here, where most farms cover 500 or more acres, pick their crop by hand, Mr. Smith said.
But, he added, farmers still need high school-age workers to work on the harvesters, sorting rocks from potatoes. They work 12 hours a day, seven days a week and are paid $5 to $5.25 an hour. Last fall, five of the 13 people Mr. Smith hired for the harvest were students.
Mr. Smith said finding adult workers is made even more difficult by the shrinking labor pool in Aroostook County, whose population is shrinking as young people move away in search of work.
''We can increase wages all we want to,'' he said, ''but if the workers aren't there, they aren't there.''
Each year, Mr. Smith said, he contacts the local unemployment office but has never had an applicant.
Teachers supported the elimination of the recess, saying it interrupted the school year almost as soon as it began, forcing them to repeat lessons that students have forgotten during the break.
But farmers say teachers have overlooked the benefit to students, who learn the value of hard work.
''That's the problem with most of the youth in the country,'' said Keith Doyen, who hired 13 students last fall to harvest his 900 acres. ''They never learned the value of a dollar and what it takes to earn a living.''
The farmers have formed a committee to encourage the board to reinstate the recess. Mrs. Pelletier said the board wants to help the farmers and might make exceptions for students on a case-by-case basis. But she is not holding out much hope that the board will reverse its decision.
''The whole point is, times have changed,'' she said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Suicide to Donate Heart to Brother Is in Vain

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TAMARAC, Fla., Dec. 20

 BODY:
A man who said in a note that he wanted to donate his heart in an effort to save a brother with heart disease committed suicide outside a hospital Monday night. But the body was found too late, and his heart could not be used for a transplant.
The man, Gerald Olson, drove his van to University Community Hospital in Tamarac on Monday night and parked outside the emergency room, the authorities said Tuesday. Then he put a gun in his mouth and pulled the trigger. 
Ten minutes passed before a nurse on her way home noticed Mr. Olson slumped over the steering wheel. An emergency medical crew administered heart massage, but he died less than an hour later.
The police found suicide notes in the van in which Mr. Olson, who was 46 years old, complained of ''too many downs and no ups for me on this roller-coaster ride of life.'' He wrote that he wanted his heart donated to his 56-year-old brother, Bob, who has been on a waiting list for a heart transplant for nearly three years.
 
'He Thought of Me'
From his home in Belvedere, Ill., Bob Olson, who has cardiomyopathy, which causes an enlarged heart, said: ''It made me feel like someone special. He thought of me in his last thoughts. He wanted somebody benefiting from his death.''
Bob Olson and other relatives said that they realized Jerry Olson did not succeed in life as he might have wished, but added that they had no idea he might be suicidal.
''I think he probably was capable of doing anything he wanted to do,'' Roland Olson, 58, who lives in Rockford, Ill., said of his younger brother. ''If he'd only gone and done it.''
Jerry Olson worked in lounges and sold bar supplies. He was unemployed in recent months. Eight years ago he moved to Tamarac, a South Florida community about 10 miles northwest of Fort Lauderdale, to help a sister after her husband died of a heart attack, Roland Olson said.
 
A Letter to His Daughter
But three weeks ago she asked her brother to move out, said Steve Wiley, a detective in the sheriff's office here.
''She thought it was time for him to stand on his own two feet,'' the detective said, adding that Mr. Olson then lived in his van.
On Sunday he recorded a tape. Mr. Olson, an Elvis Presley fan who named his daughter Lisa Marie, the same as the singer's daughter, sang ''I'll Be Home for Christmas,'' and asked that the song be played at his funeral.
In a letter to his daughter Mr. Olson wrote: ''I'm tired of everyone saying how much talent I've got. Uncle Bob's got everything to live for. And if they find out he can use it and Uncle Bob wants it, I'm going to be his donor, Lisa. I figure I could do more good for him than myself.''

HEADLINE: Wheelchair Lifts Increase Bus Ridership

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Wayne J. Smith, executive director of the United Bus Owners of America, tries to paint a picture of a troubled private transit industry that would be devastated if the Americans with disabilities bill, now in the House of Representatives, requires wheelchair lifts on private buses (''Bye, Bye, Bus Industry,'' Op.-Ed, Nov. 30).
Experience speaks otherwise. Denver's Regional Transportation District operates 17 over-the-road coaches between Denver and Boulder, Colo. All those buses are equipped with wheelchair lifts, John Davis, coordinator of the district maintenance reporting systems, told The Disability Rag in November. The lifts cost the district $4,000 to buy and $6,000 to install - far less than the ''$15,000 to $50,000'' that Mr. Smith says lifts cost. According to Mr. Davis, they cost less than $60 a year to maintain. 
But United Bus Owners is opposed to lifts ''even if they were free,'' its spokesman told us.
The private bus industry simply doesn't want to put lifts on buses. It wishes to discriminate and to rationalize it by framing the issue only as alleged economic hardship.
It does not want the public to consider the devastating economic hardship member bus companies inflict on thousands of low-income American wheelchair users who cannot afford private autos but who desire to travel without the assault to their dignity of being unceremoniously carried aboard like a sack of potatoes -a far less dignified treatment even than that once afforded Rosa Parks, with a seat in the back.
It United Bus Owners of America believes that loss of ridership is forcing smaller bus companies out of business, it should consider this: Denver's Regional Transportation District attributes an additional 42,087 boardings in 1988 to the lifts on buses.
Lifts are a one-time cost. Discriminatory denial of dignified access, though, is a psychic cost exacted daily against wheelchair users.
It's time the transit industry stopped fighting the extension of dignity and civil rights to disabled Americans.
 
(Rev) WADE BLANK
MARY JOHNSON
Denver, Dec. 1, 1989
 The writers are, respectively, a leader of American Disabled for Accessible Public Transportation and editor of The Disability Rag.

HEADLINE: FOR NEW POLICE COMMISSIONER, TOWERING CHALLANGES;
Stranger to New York, Brown Says First Act Will Be to 'Reach Out'

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Police Chief Lee P. Brown, who will take over as New York City's Police Commissioner next month, describes himself as a stranger to New York and says he will not make any major changes in the current system until he learns his way around.
In an interview in his office, surrounded by pictures of the Houston skyline, the chief said he has only visited the city ''a few times, for meetings.''
He said he was not bringing any ''preconceived notions'' to New York, and he asked that the city's officers treat him as he is treating them - with an open mind.
 
'I Am a Natural at This'
It is natural for officers to complain about Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins's choice of an outsider, he said, adding: ''Once I get there I intend to reach out to them. Once I get to meet the people, they'll understand I am a natural at this.'' 
He noted that officers in Houston had a similar negative reaction when he was appointed to the chief's job here almost eight years ago. There is still hostility from the rank and file - ''I Love New York'' signs sprouted in many police offices when his move to New York was announced - and he says that frustrates him. But the issues that divide him and his officers, he said ''are really not issues I can control.'' The main complaint of the city's police unions here is the low pay, which he said is mostly a result of the economic downturn in Houston earlier in the decade.
''I agree with them,'' he said. ''I've been the drum major trying to get more police officers for this city and more pay for the ones we do have. But the money has just not been there.''
He said he had no specific plans for the New York department, but would not just recreate his Houston-based programs. ''I'm not going to try to transfer Houston to New York,'' he said, ''New York's completely different.''
The first thing he will do, he said, is thoroughly evaluate the department. He conducted such a review when he came to Houston and issued a report listing the strengths and weaknesses of the force. Partly as a result of his years in academia and management, he said ''I believe in careful analysis and study before making any major decisions.''
Whatever his findings, he said, one of his priorities is certain to be the city's drug problem. ''I consider narcotics as being the No. 1 problem confronting America,'' he said ''and that is true of New York as well.''
 
Input From the Community
He also said he would try to involve citizens in police work in New York. In Houston, the police are encouraged to identify and solve problems and solicit help from the community, he said, rather than simply respond to emergency calls.
For example, he cited an apartment complex here that was overrun by drug dealers. Residents told an officer that most of the drug sales were made at a pay telephone in the complex, and the officer arranged for the telephone company to change the phone line so that outgoing calls could be made but incoming calls could not be received.
The approach has drawn praise from community groups here, which credit Chief Brown with improving relations between citizens and police.
He said he realized that these programs were a drain on resources, but that such work was worth the sacrifice. ''If you solve the problems for good, you don't have to keep returning to them day after day,'' he said.
 
Criticism From Officers
Chief Brown said he expects to show the same loyalty to Mr. Dinkins as he did to Mayor Kathryn J. Whitmire of Houston. Chief Brown received criticism from police officers for not battling publicly with the Mayor over officer salaries.
''The mayor is the chief executive officer of the city,'' he said. ''We may disagree many times, about many things, but it serves no purpose for me to be out raising questions in public.''
He is not certain whether his program of establishing dozens of police substations around the city would work in New York. The stations were introduced in Houston because the city is spread over 550 square miles, and this plan helped keep small neighborhoods in touch with the police.
For the same reason he is unsure whether he can import the Houston program of single-officer patrol cars. Without that rule, he said, there would not be enough cars to cover all of Houston. New York is more compact, he said, and he would evaluate the advisability of one-man cars.
 
Final Word on Discipline
Though he has opposed the creation of a civilian review board to investigate police misconduct in Houston, he said he supported Mr. Dinkins plan for such a board in New York because it would give the Commissioner the final word on officer discipline.
He said the job of president of the International Association of Chiefs of Police, which he assumes in October of 1990, would not interfere with his duties as chief. His critics in New York have said that the travel required by the job would keep him away from his office for 100 days a year.
''I wouldn't go away for 100 days no matter where I was,'' he said, noting that the group holds quarterly meetings and that, as president, he could arrange for many to be held in New York.
''I certainly understand that New York is a demanding city,'' he said, ''and it demands a lot from its chief.''

HEADLINE: New Jersey Gives Up Park Land in Swap With Developer

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

DATELINE: MOUNT OLIVE, N.J., Dec. 20

 BODY:
A deal in which state officials pushed through the sale of state park land to a developer to keep a large corporation from leaving New Jersey has raised questions about the state's guardianship of public property.
On one side is a group of officials, including managers of the state parks, that endorses the deal, in which a 58-acre section of Allamuchy Mountain State Park is being exchanged for nearby land owned by the developer here in the Morris County hills 44 miles west of New York City.
They say the deal has enormous economic importance for the state, because it will prevent the BASF Corporation, the West German chemical manufacturer and conglomerate, from moving its North American headquarters out of New Jersey. On the other side are conservationists, local officials and a legislator who fear New Jersey was taken for a ride, swapping a block of highly desirable land for scattered parcels of wetlands that the developers were unlikely to build on anyway.
At the heart of the complicated transaction is concern that public land is not safe from development as suburban sprawl spreads across the state. The land being sold was bought under the Green Acres program, to preserve open space. 
''What's at stake is the future of public lands,'' the chairman of the Northwest Jersey group of the Sierra Club, Leonard Frank of Hackettstown, said. ''The question that has to be asked is this: Is it appropriate to give away state land for purposes other than what the land was purchased for in the first place?''
The tale begins early last year, when the state's economic engine was beginning to run out of gas. One of the few big businesses still planning to expand was the BASF Corporation, which was renting offices in Parsippany-Troy Hills for its North American headquarters.
BASF has 2,500 employees in 13 locations in New Jersey alone, and it is growing. It wanted to pull together some administrative operations and build a 600,000-square-foot headquarters. Last year the company decided that it would buy 150 acres. Northern New Jersey was preferred. But BASF hired a relocation consultant, and 40 East Coast sites were considered. One prime candidate was the International Trade Center on Interstate 80 here. The center, a 670-acre project begun in the early 80's, contains the New Jersey Foreign Trade Zone, where parts for Seiko watches and BMW automobiles, among other products, are warehoused without customs duty until they are sold.
The center, a joint project by the Rockefeller Group Inc. of New York and a local developer, Leslie Smith, includes 300 acres in its master plan for offices and a hotel.
But the largest piece of developable land not intersected by roads was 100 acres, not the 150 required by BASF. Next to the center, however, is the tip of Allamuchy Mountain State Park, 8,000 acres of woods and hills bought with Green Acres bond money in the 60's. By April 1988 BASF began direct negotiations with the International Trade Center and the state. The director of the State Economic Development Division, Ben A. Ferrara, said the executives wanted assurances that the proposal to take land from the park had the support of the state's highest authority.
On a rainy Wednesday in May, the executives met with Mr. Ferrara and Gov. Thomas H. Kean at Drumthwacket, the 19th-century governor's mansion in Princeton. At the meeting, Mr. Ferrara recounted, Mr. Kean said New Jersey wanted to keep BASF and would do all it could.
Mr. Ferrara said the executives went to West Germany to present the expansion plan to their superiors. From then on, with the Governor's backing, Mr. Ferrara's staff ''put on the full court press,'' he said.
 
Access for Anglers
Officials at the International Trade Center said BASF engineers identified 58.363 acres that the company wanted. The land has a moderate slope, and the appraiser considered 85 percent of suitable for building. Conservationists say it contains trails and is a breeding habitat for the golden winged warbler.
Mr. Smith said parks officials from the Environmental Protection Department, in turn, looked over maps of the trade center's land and identified five irregular parcels along the Musconetcong River totaling 67.5 acres that could provide riverfront access to anglers and hikers.
Materials were prepared for the final arbiter of state land deals, a legislative-executive branch hybrid called the State House Commission.
The State House Commission has seven members, the Governor, the State Treasurer, Budgeting and Accounting Director and four legislators, two from each party. Established in 1931 to take custody of the State House and other government buildings in Trenton, it now also reviews the sale or lease of any state lands, including open space bought through the Green Acres bond program.
 
Normal Process Avoided
Most of the commission's quarterly meetings occur without controversy, often taken up with no more than the disposal of bits and pieces of land left over from highway construction. But there are several indications that in the commission's latest session, on Sept. 19, normal procedures were ignored for the sake of expediently handling what was presented as an urgent need: confirmation of the Allamuchy land swap.
Usually, agendas and supporting documents go out to members two weeks before a meeting. But on the morning of Sept. 19, there were several late additions, including the Allamuchy transaction. The lone notice of the meeting was posted on Sept. 19 on a board at the State House and distributed to reporters with offices there. There was no requirement that the notice be published.
Regulations require that public hearings be held at least 30 days before the commission can consider the sale of public land bought by a municipality with Green Acres bond money. There is no such requirement, however, for the sale of Green Acres land owned by the state.
 
Reaction by Karcher
Commission members also said official appraisals accompanied most proposals, but not this one.
''For the eight years I have been on the commission, this was the first time to my recollection that I was asked to make a decision without an appraisal in front of me,'' said Assemblyman Alan J. Karcher, Democrat of Sayreville.
Mr. Karcher also said he was surprised to find the deal presented with a strong letter of endorsement from the Environmental Protection Commissioner, Christopher J. Daggett, who noted the importance of keeping BASF's jobs.
''It was gently suggested that if we did not act right away, we would be put in the position of being scapegoats'' if BASF moved out of state, Mr. Karcher said.
Now that he has had an opportunity to review the appraisals, Mr. Karcher said, he thinks the Sept. 19 vote should be overturned by Governor-elect James J. Florio after he takes office next month. ''I suggest that the minutes of this meeting be rejected and this transaction be looked at from scratch,'' Mr. Karcher said.
 
List of Criticisms
The assistant commissioner for natural and historic resources in the Environmental Protection Department, Helen C. Fenske, said the economic and environmental benefits of the swap outweigh any negatives. But critics, including Mr. Karcher, called it a bad deal for the state.
They make several arguments. One is that the value of the trade center's land may have been overstated. The 67 acres are appraised at $4.1 million, or an average of more than $60,000 an acre, because it has preliminary approvals for two office buildings. But one building site is sloped and largely by wetlands. N.J. Transit uses the second site, across the Musconetcong, near Stanhope, for a park-and-ride lot. Opponents say that with current wetlands regulations and an overbuilt office market, it seems unlikely either spot would be built on.
The state-owned land may have been undervalued. The 58 acres were appraised at $782,500, or $13,500 an acre for a large almost entirely developable plot with frontage on Interstate 80. The appraisers reasoned that the land was zoned for single-family houses on two-acre lots and that rezoning to Trade Zone status was speculative. Critics, however, said such a change was the very reason for the swap.
 
Commissioner Under Fire
The deal calls for a $300,000 payment to the state to buy land elsewhere. The developer is also paying $4.7 million to the Waterloo Village Foundation, which has a long-term lease on part of the park, including the 58 acres being sold. Critics say all money from the transaction should go to the State Treasury to buy park land.
There may be other problems. To sell state land, at least five commission members have to vote for that. On Sept. 19, five members were present, and one was was State Senator John H. Dorsey, Republican of Mountain Lakes. Besides sitting in the Legislature, he is Township Attorney in Mount Olive, the site of the proposed BASF project.
To some, Mr. Dorsey's vote is a conflict of interest. ''The decision is contaminated because of Dorsey,'' said Gordon A. MacInnes, Jr., former assemblyman and member of the State House Commission. Mr. MacInnes is chairman of the Morris County Democratic Committee.
Mr. Dorsey said he had not violated the Legislature's Code of Ethics, which prohibits lawmakers from voting on issues in which they have a financial interest. ''This is striking out at straws,'' he said.
 
BASF Plea for Secrecy
Critics are upset because the public did not know about the deal until after the commission had voted. Mr. Smith, the developer, said BASF required the swap to be kept secret until approved, because it did not want to upset its employees. Mr. Smith said that the transaction met all regulations and that the opposition was the work of a landowner involved in a separate lawsuit against him.
''To try to nail us now is terribly unfair,'' Mr. Smith said. ''We have not done a thing wrong.''
The dispute involves more than local people. The Sierra Club has given $1,500 to explore filing a suit challenging the deal. The New Jersey Audubon Society is also opposing the exchange. ''The public is being shortchanged,'' said William R. Neil, assistant director of conservation for the society. He said the rules of the State House Commission should be changed to prevent ''de facto public exclusion.'' He also said the state ought to rethink the policy of selling park land for any purpose.
''If we can't respond to this alarm in the night,'' he said, ''if we can't point out how poorly the State House Commission has protected the public interest, then we're opening a barn door for future abuse.''

HEADLINE: Pact to End Soybean Subsidies

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
The United States has won a 20-year fight with the European Community over European soybean subsidies, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said today. American farmers have complained that the subsidies cost them hundreds of millions of dollars a year in lost exports.
Under the settlement, the European Community has agreed to pass legislation before the end of next year that would eliminate the subsidies. The agreement removes an immediate threat of American retaliation. Had there been no settlement, the Bush Administration faced a Jan. 31 statutory deadline for reprisal. 
The European Community has accepted the findings of a panel of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the 97-nation organization that decides trade disputes.
 
Unfair Edge for Europe
The panel, finding in favor of the United States, said the subsidies violate an international trade commitment of the community and give unfair advantage to European farmers.
Soybeans and other oil seeds, together with cereals, are the leading American farm exports.
Mrs. Hills, just back from meetings with community officials in Brussels, said she feels ''comfortable'' that the 12-nation bloc will bring its practices into compliance with the GATT finding.
In Brussels Tuesday, the community's Council of Ministers, the organization's highest decision-making body, said it would make the needed adjustments in European regulations covering soybeans and other oil seeds during 1990, a time span that Mrs. Hills said was acceptable.
''We will monitor their progress closely,'' Mrs. Hills said at a press briefing here.
Kenneth L. Bader, chief executive of the American Soybean Association, which represents 400,000 soybean farmers, said from the group's St. Louis headquarters that he was ''elated that the community has accepted the panel findings.'' But he added that the United States must now make sure the promises are kept.
 
Dispute Dates to Late 60's
The Jan. 31 deadline for retaliation was linked to tough trade legislation written by Congress last year that more aggressively asserts American trading rights.
The dispute dates to the late 1960's, when the economic bloc began subsidizing producers of oil seeds - soybeans, rape seeds and sunflower seeds - to help them compete against lower-cost products from the United States.
The initial subsidies were small, but they increased to the point where last year in Italy and France they were more than twice the $6-a-bushel American price for soybeans.
United States officials have said that the American trade losses have been substantial. In 1983, this country sold $3.5 billion worth of oil seeds to the community. By 1988, exports had fallen to $1.5 billion.
Mr. Bader said American farmers would seek to recapture the lost European market, but noted that there was now increased competition from Brazil and other countries in Latin America.
The panel found, as the United States had argued, that the subsidies ''nullified and impaired'' a zero tariff on soybeans that the United States had won from the community in the Dillon Round of worldwide tariff reductions in 1962.
 
Advantages and Concessions
The zero duty was made permanent as part of the balance of advantages and concessions made in that negotiation.
Because complex, politically sensitive community regulations will have to be reworked, the panel counseled the United States to be patient in allowing time for the necessary changes.
Meanwhile, the community's own budget problems, not unlike those in Washington, have made the bloc more willing to curb its costly subsidies, which according to American figures total more than $120 billion annually.
Sensitivity to budget costs also figured in a European Community decision to end programs of Government subsidies for the steel industry. The community joined countries accounting for two-thirds of American steel imports that have signed an agreement with the United States to end trade-distorting steel subsidies.
Although GATT cannot compel countries to accept its rulings, the community decision to accept the panel report was in step with the United States, Japan and other countries, which in recent months have also acted to conform with the Geneva-based international body.
Under the GATT-sponsored Uruguay Round of trade-liberalization negotiations, which are due to wind up next December, leading trading nations want to increase the standing of GATT as the arbiter of a more binding set of international trade rules.
In GATT cases involving customs fees, waste-cleanup payments and infringements of patents, copyrights and trademarks, the Bush Administration has already sought to comply with GATT panel rulings.
 
Time Needed to Change Laws
But, as in the soybean case, time is necessary to change the legislation.
The United States earlier this year brought its Superfund law into compliance with GATT after a 1986 finding that a difference in the fee the United States charges domestic and foreign oil companies to clean up waste under the law discriminates against the foreigner. Congress did away with the difference.
In cases involving Customs fees and infringement of patents, copyrights and trademarks, Mrs. Hills said today that the Administration will also ask Congress for changes next year to conform with panel decisions that went against the United States.
She also said that if a GATT ruling expected shortly on American sugar quotas was negative, ''I will have to look at the whole sugar program.'' She added, ''I don't know how it will come out.''
The United States earlier this year lost a case brought by Australia in which GATT found fault with the way the United States protects sugar farmers. The second case, brought by the community, attacks the statutory basis of the program.

HEADLINE: In Upward Revision, G.N.P. Growth Rate for the Third Quarter Is Put at 3%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
The nation's economy grew at a faster rate in the third quarter than previously estimated, but economists and analysts continue to say it is slowing dramatically.
The Commerce Department said today that the gross national product, the broadest measure of economic health, grew at an annual rate of 3 percent in the July-September period, up from a 2.5 percent rate reported in October and the subsequent revision to 2.7 percent last month.
The latest revision resulted in large part from new data that showed exports rose 3.9 percent, rather than the 1.6 percent reported earlier. At the same time, imports rose 7.4 percent, down from the 9.5 percent first reported. 
 
Borrowed Strength
But analysts said the economy in the third quarter borrowed its strength from the current quarter. Many of them anticipate a growth rate of less than 1 percent for the current quarter and a possible end to the unprecedented seven years of peacetime expansion.
The Bush Administration forecast a 2.7 percent growth rate for all of 1989; the fourth-quarter G.N.P. will have to advance 1.6 percent to meet that goal. The G.N.P. grew by 3.7 percent in the first quarter and 2.5 percent in the second.
''The bottom line is that we borrowed from the future to produce 3 percent growth and that source of strength is gone now,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist for the Boston Company.
Mr. Sinai and others said much of the third-quarter growth resulted from robust sales of automobiles and light trucks stimulated by buyer incentives.
 
Bringing Back Rebates
The incentives were dropped with the introduction of higher-priced 1990 models in October, and sales immediately slumped. Only this month have auto makers begun to restore rebates and offer cut-rate financing in an effort to bolster sales.
The sluggish fourth-quarter growth is a result of Federal Reserve efforts to contain inflation by keeping a tight rein on credit. With signs that inflation had started to moderate, the central bank has eased some short-term interest rates since June, but many analysts have suggested that the Fed will have to ease credit further to stimulate the economy.
The Fed's policy-making arm, the Federal Open Market Committee, met Monday and Tuesday. As usual, the committee gave no indication of any decisions, though the Fed added money to the banking system late on Tuesday in a signal that it might lower interest rates.
As a result, the key Federal funds rate, the interest banks charge each other for overnight loans, dropped to 8 7/16 percent today from about 8 1/2 percent late Tuesday. Analysts said they expected a target of 8 1/4 percent for the rate, the first drop since late November.
The G.N.P. report contained some favorable inflation news. A price index tied to the G.N.P. rose at an annual rate of 2.9 percent, unchanged from earlier estimates but down from the 5 percent jump in the April-June quarter.
 
Profit Data Revised
In a companion report, the Commerce Department said after-tax profits of corporations fell 5.4 percent rather than the 7.2 percent decline reported in November.
Housing construction, hurt by high mortgage interest rates during much of the year, fell 9.2 percent in the third quarter, a revision from the 8.4 percent decline reported earlier.
Government purchases were down 2.4 percent, three-tenths of a percentage point below the November estimate.
The various changes left the G.N.P. expanding in the third quarter at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.16 trillion.

HEADLINE: Natural Gas Sales Set At Denver Amoco Sites

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Amoco Inc., the nation's fourth-largest oil company, said today that it would begin selling compressed natural gas at four gasoline service stations in the Denver area early next year.
That would be the first time a primary gasoline marketer has moved to test public demand for the cleaner-burning fuel in the United States. Compressed natural gas is increasingly popular among motorists in New Zealand, Italy and the Netherlands. 
''The question is how the U.S. consumer will take to it, and now we'll see,'' Amoco's chief economist, Theodore R. Eck, said in a telephone interview from the company's headquarters in Chicago. ''I don't think there is any question that it will succeed over the long term.''
 
Others Following Suit
Many oil companies are privately exploring steps similar to those Amoco announced in Denver to market natural gas to motorists. Their most likely initial customers are operators of trucks and fleet vehicles that travel more than 150 miles a week in urban areas, where public pressure to reduce air pollution is growing.
In many areas, passenger cars can be converted to burn natural gas, while not losing the capability for burning gasoline, for about $1,500. In Vancouver, British Columbia, natural gas has been available to car operators since the early 1980's. About half of the 8,000 vehicles powered by natural gas there are privately owned cars. The rest are fleet vehicles, taxis and delivery trucks.
Over all, Canada has 20,000 natural-gas-powered vehicles, and the United States has 30,000, according to the American Gas Association, a trade group based in Washington. New Zealand has 125,000 natural-gas vehicles, and the Soviet Union 200,000.
Natural-gas fuel produces half as many carbon monoxide emissions as unleaded gasolines. Many analysts believe it will become the nation's alternative fuel of choice, over methanol and ethanol, in the 1990's as Federal and local governments tighten air pollution standards. 357 Miles vs. 227 Miles Compressed natural gas costs less than gasoline and burns more efficiently in an automobile engine. A passenger car can travel 227 miles on $10 worth of gasoline, and 357 miles on $10 worth of compressed natural gas, the gas association said.
In Amoco's Denver project, the Public Service Company of Colorado will spend $75,000 to $250,000 at each of the four Amoco service stations to install compressor stations. The Amoco Production Company, one of the nation's largest natural-gas producers, will deliver gas from its fields in the nearby Rocky Mountains through Public Service's pipelines.
The retail price for the compressed natural gas has not been set, but it will be competitive with gasoline prices, which range from 90 cents to $1.05 a gallon in Denver, said Robert D. McKeehan, Amoco's marketing general manager. Colorado has 700 natural-gas-powered vehicles, including 250 owned by Public Service of Colorado.
Asked how many passenger cars Amoco expects to attract to its new natural-gas pumps, Mr. McKeehan said: ''We don't have any idea. That's one of the reasons why we are starting the test.''

HEADLINE: Dow Drops 7.68 Points, To 2,687.93

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Stock prices were mixed yesterday, amid worries about the economic outlook and the events in Panama. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 7.68 points to end at 2,687.93.
Trading was volatile. Volume totaled 176.5 million shares, compared with 186.1 million shares on Wednesday. Declining issues barely led advancing ones, 759 to 749. 
The economic picture remained gloomy for the fourth quarter and into next year. The Commerce Department said yesterday that the gross national product grew at a revised annual rate of 3 percent, after adjusting for inflation, in the third quarter, up from a previous estimate of 2.7 percent.
 
Buying Is Slowed
''In addition to all the year-end crosscurrents, you have the Panama situation, which might not stop selling, but it slows buying until things become clearer,'' said Robert B. Ridder, the chief technical analyst at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company in New York.
He added that a fair amount of confusion existed, as all these changes combined at the end of the year, and some economists sensed that the Federal Reserve had eased the Federal funds rate. The rate is what banks charge each other on overnight loans.
Byron R. Wein, the chief portfolio strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company, also in New York, said: ''Portfolio managers are concerned that they're seeing their absolute performance melt away at year-end. This has been a big year for a lot of stocks, and any ripple of discontent causes exaggerated downside movement, as we saw in Disney today.''
Walt Disney fell sharply, losing 11 3/8, to 112, and was the third-most-active stock on the Big Board, with nearly 2.5 million shares trading. In the morning, two unfavorable analysts' reports were released, and Goldman, Sachs dropped Disney from its recommended list.
 
Oil Stocks Rise
The stocks of the nation's largest oil companies rose on news of the Panamanian invasion. Exxon advanced 3/8, to 50 5/8; ARCO moved up 7/8, to 110 7/8, and Mobil climbed 1 3/4, to 62 3/8.
Technology issues weakened, reversing some gains they made in the last two sessions. I.B.M. was down 1/8, at 94 5/8, and Digital lost 7/8, to 83 1/2. Honeywell rose 2 1/4, to 82 3/4, after the company said it had sold 7.5 percent of its Japanese partnership for $126 million.
Among the actively traded blue-chip issues, Philip Morris slid 1/4, to 40 1/8, and McDonald's dropped 5/8, to 32 7/8. The company, based in Oak Brook, Ill., said on Tuesday that its president and chief executive, Michael R. Quinlan, had been promoted to chairman, effective March 31.
A. G. Edwards Inc., with 5.7 million shares, was the most heavily traded issue on the Big Board. It rose 1/4, to 22 1/8, after the financial services company, based in St. Louis, announced higher quarterly earnings.
 
Insurance Sector Up
Insurance company stocks regained some of the ground lost on Monday. The American International Group was up 2 3/4, to 100 1/2, while Chubb rose 1 1/4, to 90 1/4.
Bank stocks also made some gains. Citicorp moved up 1, to 28; Wells Fargo advanced 1 3/4, to 70 3/8, and Chase Manhattan Bank finished up 1 3/8, to 33 1/2.
Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, continued to regain some of what it had lost, also on Monday, advancing 1 7/8, to 34 3/8.
Alexander's Inc. moved up 2 5/8, to 53, in heavy trading after the New York-based retailer said it had retained Morgan Stanley to consider a possible sale.
Stride Rite fell 3 3/4, to 23 1/2, after the shoe manufacturer said it was expecting its fourth-quarter earnings to be flat.
 
Transport Average Off
The Dow transportation average lost 2.48, to 1,136.74, as airline stocks sank on concerns that the Panama invasion would push oil prices higher, the traders said. UAL, the parent of United Airlines, slid 1 1/2, to 157; AMR, which owns American Airlines, dropped 1 1/4, to 58 3/4, and USAir dropped 1/8, to 31 5/8.
Broader market indexes registered slight gains, with the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rising 0.38 point, to 342.84, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index increasing 0.14 to end at 189.54.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index gained a slight 0.23, to 368.18.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 2.59, to 436.94, with MCI Communications, which lost 1 1/4, to 39 3/4, leading the most active issues in over-the-counter trading.

HEADLINE: Taiwan Monetary Policy

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Taiwan will temporarily relax its tight monetary policy to help local companies pay out billions of local dollars in salaries and bonuses before the Lunar New Year on Jan. 27. Bankers said the measure would also keep interest rates and the United States-Taiwan dollar exchange rate stable. They said the easing will start in mid-January, lasting about a month. Taiwanese companies traditionally give a New Year's bonus worth three to six months' salary.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Light Trading After the Fed Adds Reserves

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished lower against most foreign currencies, except for the yen and the Canadian dollar, in light trading yesterday.
Gold prices edged higher in New York after falling in Europe and Asia. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery rose $1.70 an ounce, to $413.60. 
Dealers in Europe said the dollar rose early in the trading day in reaction to news of the United States military action in Panama. But the currency reversed course midway through the New York trading day when the Federal Reserve Board took steps to inject reserves into the financial system.
The Fed's move was viewed as a sign that it might be encouraging lower interest rates. Falling interest rates reduce demand for dollars because the decline cuts the yields available to foreign investors on their dollar-denominated investments.
Richard Levine, the vice president for foreign exchange and precious metals at Elders Futures Inc. in New York, said trading was relatively light all day. ''You could tell there was no real conviction,'' he said.
Mr. Levine said the market viewed the American military action as ''a sign of strength'' but recognized the move was a ''limited regional action'' that was not likely to have global ramifications.
The subsequent decline in the dollar came on low volume, he said, because traders remember that they misinterpreted a similar move by the central bank a few weeks ago as an sign that it was easing credit policy.
He also noted that as the end of the year approached, banks that otherwise would be active in the currency markets were not trading. ''Most of the major banks have squared their books for the year,'' he said.
In New York, the dollar edged up to 143.93 yen, from 143.65 yen late on Tuesday. The pound rose to $1.6060, from $1.6010 late on Tuesday.
Other late-dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late on Tuesday, included: 1.7320 West German marks, down from 1.7365; 5.9125 French francs, down from 5.9275; 1.5555 Swiss francs, down from 1.5565; 1,288.50 Italian lire, down from 1,289.25, and 1.16095 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16085.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fed Said to Signal Lower Rates

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve Board yesterday came through with a long-awaited signal that analysts said clearly showed the central bank wanted short-term interest rates to decline, but prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed on the development.
Yesterday, the Fed added reserves to the banking system when the overnight Federal funds rate was trading at 8 7/16 percent. The Fed's move came after several days when it refrained from conducting any open-market operations, and by late yesterday the funds rate was trading at 8 1/4 percent.
''The Fed had not supplied reserves over the past several days when the funds rate was at 8.50 percent,'' said Darwin L. Beck, a money market economist at the First Boston Corporation. ''I am sure they knew that the market would be looking for a sign, and if they didn't want to indicate they were easing policy, they could have stayed out of the market. I am pretty convinced they are saying they want the funds rate to go down to 8.25 percent.'' 
 
Gramley Prediction
Lyle Gramley, chief economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association in Washington and a former Fed governor, predicted in an interview late Tuesday with a reporter from the Market News Service that the Fed would move the next day to ease policy.
''It was a pure guess,'' Mr. Gramley said yesterday, even though his remarks caused dealers to buy Treasury securities late Tuesday.
''My reasoning is based on the fact that the indicators coming in suggest that weakness in the durable goods sector is increasing,'' Mr. Gramley said. ''Also, I can't find any evidence that the monetary easing we have had to date is having beneficial results. Additional easing moves will be coming along in the not-too-distant future. And the next cut in the funds rate will carry with it a reduction in the discount rate.''
The discount rate currently stands at 7 percent.
 
Reaction Surprises Analysts
The market's tepid reaction to the Fed's step surprised some analysts. But others pointed out that since the move has been widely anticipated since before Thanksgiving, there was little reason for prices to move sharply higher.
Indeed, the day before Thanksgiving many dealers and analysts thought that a move by the Fed represented the start of an easing in policy, and a rally ensued. Early the following week, the Fed sent a blunt message that its steps had been misinterpreted. That bout of miscommunication has forced traders and analysts to await an unequivocal signal from the Fed. That clear message was sent, and received, yesterday.
''After the Thanksgiving debacle, the Fed had to send a clear signal,'' said Stuart G. Hoffman, a senior vice president and chief economist at the Pittsburgh National Bank. ''The market's mild reaction shows it was expecting this move. If the Fed had decided to stay out of the market again, the reaction would have been strongly negative.''
The move to an easier credit policy by the Fed is almost certain to prompt speculation about when commercial banks will lower the prime lending rate, currently at 10 1/2 percent. Indeed, a number of analysts said the Fed might hope such a step would take place in reasonably short order.
 
Eurodollar Rates Cited
But a number of bankers said a cut in the prime might be delayed because other key financing costs, like three-month Eurodollar deposits, remained stubbornly high despite recent declines in the overnight funds market. Late yesterday, three-month Eurodollar deposits were offered at 8.50 percent.
''I am sure the Fed would welcome a cut in the prime,'' said one banker, who asked not to be identified. ''But nobody will move fast to lower the prime rate. Three-month Eurodollar deposits would have to get to 8.25 percent before they do that.''
Reaction to the Fed's step was more pronounced among shorter-term Treasury securities than long-term notes and bonds. And participants said the easing move had a mildly positive impact on an auction of $8 billion of new four-year Treasury notes.
At the auction, the Treasury sold the notes at an average yield of 7.65 percent, the lowest yield on such an issue in just under three years, and well below the 8.35 percent yield on four-year notes sold at the last auction on Sept. 27. 6-Month Bill at 7.37% In the secondary market for Treasury securities, three-month Treasury bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 7.54 percent, down 10 basis points, or hundredths of a point. And six-month bill rates fell by nine basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.37 percent.
Meanwhile, bond prices dipped slightly. By late in the day, the 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 103 1/4, down 3/32, to yield 7.84 percent. And the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 25/32, up 2/32 to yield 7.76 percent.
In other developments, worries about troubled real estate loans continued to hound bonds issued by Northeastern banks in the investment-grade corporate bond market.
Once again, prices of Bank of New England, Midlantic and Shawmut Bank bonds came under heavy pressure, dealers said.
Bank of New England, whose problems appear most severe, was badly hit again. The bank's 9 7/8 percent bonds of 1999 fell another three points yesterday, to a price to yield 18.50 percent.
''We have seen a little bit of buying among the better money center names as well as the better regional banks,'' one corporate trader said. ''But there is further deterioration in paper issued by institutions in the Northeast.''
Away from the financial sector, dealers said that prices of most investment-grade corporate bonds moved higher by about an eighth of a point.
 
Hospital Corp. Bonds Fall
Participants in the high-yield ''junk bond'' market were jolted when the Hospital Corporation of America announced that a planned divestiture of its psychiatric care units would not take place. The announcement caused prices of the company's 15 3/4 percent zero-coupon bonds due in 2003 to fall by about five points.
The news had little effect outside of the health care industry, and market participants said that prices of most issues were down by an eighth of a point to a quarter of a point. Trading remains extremely light, the participants said.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, dealers said that prices of most actively traded issues rose by an eighth of a point to a quarter of a point in slow trading.

HEADLINE: Japanese Discount Rate Expected to Be Raised

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Despite a series of denials by Government officials and reports of disputes within the Government, speculation is mounting here that a rise in Japan's key discount rate is imminent.
''I have no doubts,'' said a senior official at the Industrial Bank of Japan, a leading Japanese bank. ''They are very concerned about the exchange rate. It's only a question of whether it is a half-point or three-quarters of a point.'' 
Japan's central bank, the Bank of Japan, has increased the discount rate twice this year already in what has been a largely fruitless effort to curb signs of inflation and to stem the dollar's rise against the yen.
 
Eager to Keep Yen Strong
The Japanese have been eager to keep the yen strong and the dollar weak in an effort to reduce Japan's yawning trade deficit with the United States. A weak dollar makes it cheaper for Japanese to import American goods and tends to reduce Japanese exports.
But the dollar has risen to a range of about 143 to 145 yen, well above what had been believed to be the Bank of Japan's preferred level of less than 142 yen. In addition, a severe labor shortage threatens to push wages higher, the money supply has been growing at a rate of nearly 10 percent a year, and consumer prices have risen this year at a rate of about 3 percent, still low but significantly above last year's level.
The discount rate, which banks pay on certain short-term loans from the central bank, was raised to 3.75 percent this fall and now it is expected to be increased to 4.25 percent to 4.50 percent.
 
Disagreement Over Increase
Earlier this week Japanese newspapers quoted unidentified Bank of Japan officials as saying that the rise would be announced later this week. Those reports were followed by comments from Finance Ministry officials saying that there was no need for such a rise and that none had been agreed upon.
Several bankers confirmed this dispute and said that it reflected concerns at the Finance Ministry about a rate increase before an election, expected in February.

HEADLINE: Fighting in Panama;
Panama's Troubled Past

 BODY:

JANUARY 1964. Riots break out in the Canal zone, which the United States has controlled since 1903. Panama temporarily breaks dipolmatic relations with Washington to express discontent over American control of the canal. Relations resume in April, when the two coutries agree to renegotiate their treaty relationship. 
 
OCT. 11, 1968. President Arnulfo Arias Madrid is overthrown by officers of the National Guard, who establish a junta. Power is held by Col. Omar Torrijos Herrera.
 
OCT. 1, 1979. The United States flag is lowered within the Canal Zone and adminsitrative authority for canal is transferred to a binational commission.
 
JULY 31, 1981. General Torrijos dies in airplane crash.
 August 1983. Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega takes over as commander of the armed forces. The next year, General Noreiga obtains the resignation of President Nicolas Ardito-Barletta and replaces him with the Vice President, Eric Arturo Del Valle.
 
JUNE 6, 1987. Col. Roberto Diaz Herrera, second in command of the army accuses General Noriega of electoral fraud and a political killing. The accusations set off the first anti-Noriega protests.
 
FEB. 4, 1988. Federal grand juries in Miami and in Tampa hand up drug and racketeering indictiments against General Noriega.
 
FEB. 25, 1988. President Delvalle dismised General Noriega, but is instead ousted himself by the National Assembly. Manuel Solis Palma, a Noriega ally, is appointed acting President. United States continues to recognize President Delvalle.
 
MARCH 3, 1988. United States courts block withdrawal of Panama funds from American banks. Eight days later, President Reagan imposes economic sanctions.
 
MARCH 16, 1988. General Noriega puts down a coup attempt led by the police chief. Continuing street protests bring the capital to a halt.
 
APRIL 8, 1988. President Reagan freezes over $56 million in Panamian assets in American banks and prohibits American companies and the the Government from making payments to Panama.
 
MAY 7, 1988. National elections are held. Exit polls give the opposition a large lead, but offical results give General Noriega's candidate a 2-to-1 lead. Violence breaks out. General Noriega anulls election. President Bush declares it fraudulent.
 
MAY 11. President Bush orders 2,000 additional American troops to Panama, bringing the total United States military presence to 12,000.
 
OCT. 3. Coup effort against General Noriega fails.
 
DEC. 15. Panama's National Assembly declares ''state of war'' between United States and Panama.
 
DEC. 16. Panamanian soldiers kill a United States marine lieutenant.
 
DEC. 18. A United States Army officer wounds a Panamanian police corporal, who he thought was about to draw a weapon.
 
DEC. 20. President Bush orders United States troops into combat in Panama in an attempt to seize General Noriega.

PUB-DATE: December 22, 1989
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1335 words

HEADLINE: Spurt in Travel Abroad Cuts Japan's Large Trade Surplus 

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 21 

 BODY:
After fruitless years of struggling with Japan to negotiate down its yawning trade surpluses, foreign governments are getting help from an unlikely source: 10 million Japanese with a passion for overseas travel.
With all those yen and dollars being spent offshore as Japanese ''import'' hotel lodging, restaurant meals and myriad other travel services, Japan's financial surpluses are shrinking quickly, even while many thorny trade issues remain unresolved.
 ''To our surprise, travel services have become Japan's second-largest 'import,' after oil,'' said Koji Watanabe, the deputy minister for foreign affairs and a top official representing Japan in current trade negotiations with the United States. Travel, Mr. Watanabe added, represents ''one of the most promising areas for Japan to increase its imports.''

A Large Travel Deficit
 In the first nine months of this year, Japan ran a $14.5 billion travel deficit, meaning that is how much more Japanese travelers spent overseas than foreign travelers spent in Japan. With a year-end surge beginning - travel agents estimate that a half-million Japanese will go abroad for the holidays - the Government expects the deficit to top $20 billion for the year. That would more than double the $8.7 billion travel deficit in 1987 and would represent a fivefold increase from the $3.7 billion gap in 1985. 
 The total of 10 million overseas travelers includes both tourists and people on business trips and is nearly double the level of three years ago. Some experts maintain that the figures would be much higher were it not for serious bottlenecks at Japan's undersized, overburdened international airports, which can make overseas travel an ordeal.
 ''Not only are people spending these huge amounts on travel, but they all bring back lots of omiyage,'' said Susumo Saito, chief economist here for a unit of Credit Suisse, using the Japanese word for gifts. ''The cumulative amounts have been getting very big,'' Mr. Saito said.
 The typical Japanese tourist will go abroad for six to seven days, spending $1,750 on travel and an additional $1,000 or so on goods, according to the Japan Travel Bureau, the nation's largest travel agent.
 The favorite destinations are in the Pacific Rim. More than a million Japanese visited Hawaii last year, and a similar number also traveled to South Korea and to Hong Kong.
 Japan's travel deficit with the United States alone represented more than a third of its worldwide travel gap in 1988. This year, a growing number of young Japanese are booking trips to New York and San Francisco, Japanese travel agents say.
 Just why the Government and economists are taking notice is clear from the impact the travel boom is having on Japan's current account, the broadest measure of a nation's trade performance with the rest of the world, including trade in both goods and services.
 In the first 10 months of this year, Japan's current-account surplus shrank in dollar terms by 23.5 percent, to $48.6 billion, from the period a year earlier. Government economists now predict that for the full year the current-account surplus could be less than $60 billion, well under the $71 billion forecast earlier and down sharply from the peak of $87 billion in 1987.

Would Slow Rise in Wealth
 To be sure, there are many frictions between the United States and Japan that a reduction in the current-account surplus would not solve. These include American assertions that Japanese markets remain closed to items like semiconductors, wood products, supercomputers and satellites. But a sustained decline in the current-account surplus would slow Japan's extraordinary accumulation of wealth in recent years.
 In the arithmetic of trade figures, the travel deficit is part of the ledger dealing with ''invisible trade,'' which includes services, fees, royalties and investment income. The other part of the ledger concerns merchandise, or ''visible,'' trade. Most of the negotiations between the United States and Japan have been over the merchandise trade balance.
 A declining Japanese current-account surplus could have a significant impact on Japan's purchasing power abroad, reducing its investment in the United States on everything from real estate to Treasury bonds and hampering the competitiveness of Japanese banks overseas.
 ''This is why you hear the Japanese Government talking a lot more about the current account than the visible trade balance, where there hasn't been as much progress,'' said Kenneth S. Courtis, senior economist here for Deutsche Bank. ''And the travel deficit is behind it.''
 Some economists agree with Mr. Watanabe that the travel boom could do more to shrink Japan's capital surpluses than all the measures being planned for increasing the country's imports and opening its markets to foreign goods.

'An Enormous New Market'
 ''What people are starting to realize is that this is not just a change for Japanese consumers, but is changing consumption around the world because of how much Japanese tourists are spending overseas,'' Mr. Courtis said. ''You have some 10 million high spenders going abroad each year. It's an enormous new market that is going to continue to grow.''
 On the front lines of this new army of travelers, life can be hectic. Takeshi Saito, manager of the overseas sales department for the bustling Shinjuku office of the Japan Travel Bureau, said his office's sales had more than doubled this year from 1988.
 As young people nearby studied pamphlets for package trips to Australia, Hawaii and Europe, Mr. Saito noted that he had increased his staff by 30 percent to keep up with the demand. He pointed out that domestic travel has also boomed.

A Different Tourist Now
 Along with the boom is a change in the tourist, reflecting Japan's growing self-confidence. The days of Japanese travel groups moving through museums, hotels, restaurants and stores in lockstep, wearing the same tour hats, carrying the official tour bags and following a flag-waving tour leader also seem to be ending.
 ''No more hats, no more bags,'' Mr. Saito said. ''Things have changed 100 percent. Especially the younger people. They want more free time when they get someplace.''
 Many Japanese who make up the country's roving army of frequent fliers had to be forced as recently as two years ago to take Saturdays off and use their vacation time.
 The Japanese Government lent its rhetorical support to the new spirit. Three years ago it declared its ''10 million plan,'' an effort to cajole that many Japanese to travel abroad. But the Government took almost no practical steps to raise interest in travel. Nonetheless, and to everyone's surprise, the goal has been met two years earlier than hoped.
 Japan enforced rigorous travel restrictions in the postwar years to keep the nation's precious capital resources at home and to help rebuild the economy.

'Saved All the Time'
 ''People were used to being conservative and saved all the time because the Government told them it was necessary,'' said Manabu Kanematsu, president of the Japan Association of Travel Agents, a trade group. ''But when they heard the Government, even the prime minister, encouraging them to use their savings and to travel, people really became more positive, more relaxed.''
 Mr. Kanematsu also said that overseas travel has become a way for Japanese, whose living standard at home has been stunted by dauntingly high costs for housing and luxury goods, to begin to feel the wealth they had been reading about.
 ''People who live in the smallest houses here want the biggest hotel rooms when they travel overseas,'' Mr. Kanematsu said. The Japanese travel boom appears to have a great deal of room for growth. Compared with people in many other industrialized countries, Japanese are still homebodies. Britain, for example, with less than half the population of Japan, has three times as many overseas travelers.
 ''They're way behind other countries,'' Mr. Courtis said. ''I think we can still expect a lot of catching up.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Giving High Priority to Building a New Embassy in Moscow

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
The State Department, citing ''changing conditions'' in the Soviet Union, is giving high priority to constructing a new United States Embassy in Moscow to replace the one to be razed after years of indecision.
The job could cost up to $500 million. Nicholas Salgo, a former United States Ambassador to Hungary, was assigned on Wednesday to hold formal negotiations with the Kremlin. While the talks are in process, Moscow will continue to be shut out of its new embassy in the Mount Alto section of Washington and relegated to an older mansion near the White House. 
Ever since United States intelligence 10 years ago detected what was said to be a network of sophisticated listening devices in the Moscow embassy, American officials have pondered what to do with the $95 million building.
 
Congressmen Notified
Finally, on Wednesday, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d notified key members of Congress that the embassy will be torn down and a new one constructed in its place.
Mr. Baker, who sent Mr. Salgo and Ivan Selin, the Under Secretary of State for management, to Moscow on an inspection trip in April, passed up the option of saving millions of dollars by demolishing only floors believed to be infested with listening devices, and salvaging others.
He also rejected the option of constructing an annex for top-secret business. That plan would have involved at least two problems: finding the space and creating an assumption that whoever entered the annex was involved in sensitive operations.
''The decision was taken after a careful review of the alternatives for dealing with the bugged new building,'' the State Department said in a news release Wednesday night.
 
'The Realistic Alternatives'
''The review showed that, among the realistic alternatives, the tear-down/ rebuild option offered the optimum combination of security, space, cost and time required for rebuilding,'' the statement added.
The embassy was built under a 1972 agreement made by the Nixon administration that allowed the Soviets to prefabricate the concrete slabs for the building. American officials did not insist on a right of inspection.
The agreement also provided for a new Soviet embassy in the Mount Alto section of Washington, one of the highest points in the city. The embassy was built, but the Soviets were kept from occupying it while a decision on the Moscow embassy was pending. Critics of the arrangement said Americans gave away valuable real estate that also put the Soviets in a good spot to monitor communications through listening devices.
 
Progress in Preliminary Talks
The State Department news release said there was progress in preliminary talks with Soviet officials and added, ''We look forward to working with the Congress and getting on with the project.''
The statement said, ''The changing conditions in the Soviet Union have made resolution of this issue very high among our foreign policy priorities.''
In April, Mr. Salgo and Mr. Selin reported to Secretary Baker that building an annex would be cheaper than the estimated $500 million cost of building a new embassy. Former President Reagan last year advocated razing the building, saying the United States had ''no choice.'' But he left the decision to President Bush.
The State Department said it would ask Congress in the next budget for $270 million for initial building costs. It also said the United States would press claims against the Soviets to recover damages for implanting eavesdropping devices in the building and for shoddy workmanship.
 
Offer by Trade Group
A trade group headed by Dwayne O. Andreas, chairman of the Archer Daniels Midland Company, has offered to buy the building for use as business offices.
Mr. Andreas is co-chairman of the U.S.-U.S.S.R. Trade and Economic Council, which promotes trade between the two nations. He made the offer on behalf of a consortium of United States companies, which would use the building as a Moscow headquarters.
Mr. Baker's decision was first disclosed by the office of Representative Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine.

HEADLINE: Fighting in Panama: Beijing;
China Calls U.S. Strike in Panama A Violation of International Law

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Dec. 21

 BODY:
Saying it is ''shocked,'' China today condemned the American military strike in Panama as a violation of international law and demanded the immediate withdrawal of American forces.
The statement, issued by the Chinese Foreign Ministry late this morning, came nearly a day after a similar condemnation of the American action by the Soviet Union. China has no diplomatic relations with Panama, which has an embassy in Taiwan, but some low-level Panamanian delegations have visited, Western diplomats said.
The Foreign Ministry statement called the American action ''a military invasion'' and said it ''constitutes an infringement against a sovereign state of the third world and violates the norms of international law and the aims and purposes of the United Nations Charter. 
''We were shocked and condemn this act,'' the statement said. China, the ministry said, ''firmly opposes any country's interference in the internal affairs of another country under any pretext and in any form, particularly by the use of military force.''
 
'Shock and Strong Condemnation'
The statement concluded: ''The independence and sovereignty of Panama should be respected, and the United States should immediately stop the military invasion of Panama so as to prevent a deterioration of the situation.''
At the United Nations in New York, the New China News Agency reported, the Chinese Ambassador, Li Luye, told the Security Council last night of his ''utmost shock and strong condemnation'' of the American military attempt to topple the Panamanian leader Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Mr. Li said that the American action ''can only aggravate the tension in the region and have a serious negative impact on peace and stability in the world,'' and he urged Washington to withdraw its troops immediately.
Since the crushing of pro-democracy demonstrations here in June, China has frequently attacked the United States for interference in Chinese internal affairs. The United States imposed economic sanctions in the wake of the June crackdown, but sent secret missions headed by Brent Scowcroft, the White House national security adviser, and Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger, in July and again earlier this month, to seek improved relations.
 
It's 'Their Internal Affair'
At a Foreign Ministry press briefing this afternoon, a spokesman, Jin Guihua, would not say anything more about Panama.
Asked to comment on Rumania's reported crackdown last weekend on demonstrators, he said only that China would not interfere in the internal affairs of any other country. ''We've always held that what is happening in some East European countries is their internal affair,'' Mr. Jin said. ''We believe that Rumania can properly deal with its own affairs.''
Mr. Jin also welcomed President Bush's decision to ease economic sanctions on China by allowing the Export-Import Bank to extend credit to American companies doing business in China and by authorizing the export of three communications satellites to be launched on Chinese rockets.
Mr. Jin called the decisions ''positive steps helpful to the normalization of relations between China and the United States.''
 
Japan Backs President
TOKYO, Dec. 21 (Special to The New York Times) - In a guarded statement of support for President Bush's actions in Panama, Japan today said it ''regretted'' that circumstances had brought the American intervention but that it understood the reasons why the United States felt it had to act.
Japan's comments were issued this evening by the Foreign Ministry after long deliberations within the Government, where officials said they were stunned by the American action.
The private expressions of many officials in informal conversations hinted at more criticism of the United States than was reflected in the official Government statement.
The Panama action received extensive news coverage, with much attention on the adverse effect on Japanase oil imports from the closing of the Panama Canal.
In an editorial headline ''Bush Blunders in Panama,'' the Asahi newspaper asserted that the action would inevitably be viewed by the world ''as a blatant invasion of Panama's independence and sovereignty.''
